inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: C. annua is capable of self pollination, although seed set is at least twice as high when cross pollination occurs (Boaz et al. 1990 in Cooke 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Carrichtera annua is capable of producing 3,000-30,000m� seeds annually (Cooke 2003), the plant is able to grow to 60 cm in height (Weber 2003) and a diameter of up to 30 cm (Halevy 1989). Therefore, C. annua has the capability of producing above 2000 propagules annually.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: In drought periods seeds of Carrichtera annua can remain on the parent plant for more than one year (Gutterman and Shem-Tov 1997). It is unclear to what extent C. annua forms a long lasting seed bank, but it is suggested to be very limited and barely sufficient to sustain one recruitment event and that seeds have very short persistence when buried (Meissner and Facelli 1999).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: C. annua is a winter growing annual plant, following plant senescence the dead plant remains upright over the summer months (Cooke 2003). The mature plant produces viable propagules for only one year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Flowering may begin as early as 40 days after seed germination (Cooke 2003). The first seeds mature about two months after germination (Halevy 1989).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Dominant mechanism is by rain, although may also spreads through vehicle and stock movements due to its ability to adhere to a substrate (Cook 2003).
Small proportions of ingested seeds can also survive herbivory of native animals and stock, dispersal vectors may include vertebrate herbivores including goats, macropods, emus, sheep, cattle and rabbits (Cooke 2003).
The seed of C. annua contains a mucilaginous layer which aids its floating capabilities so that seeds can be carried in runoff water along runnels in the desert (Gutterman and Shem-Tov 1997).
C. annua seeds are described as a possible food source for emus and ingested seed can survive herbivory, therefore dispersal by birds and highly mobile animals may occur.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: When it rains, seeds can be flicked up to 25 cm from the parent plant (Loria and Noy-Mier 1979/80). Although, this is insignificant to account for rate at which C. annua spread in Australia. C. annua has the ability to spread through vehicle and stock movements including railways, demonstrating the ability to be transported long distances, presumably by seed (Cooke 2003). C. annua seeds are also described as a possible food source for emus and when ingested, seed can survive herbivory (Cook 2003). Spennemann and Allen (2000) describe that emus are able to disperse seeds greater than 50 km. It is very likely that at least one propagule will disperse greater than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: C. annua can form dense stands, to 60 cm in height (Cooke 2003: Weber 2003). C. annua would not restrict human access, minimal impact.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments:
Orchard (1946) describes Carrichtera annua as an ‘evil smelling weed’ due to its pungent, penetrating odour.
This may cause minor effects to aesthetics and tourism value.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: C. annua is not reported having any toxic qualities or spines. Not described in the literature reviewed, to cause injury to humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Unknown: No reviewed documentation suggests that C. annua causes damage to indigenous, european heritage sites or infrastructure.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: C. annua occurs in less dry habitats in desert situations (Loria and Noy-Meir 1979/80) where water runoff may occur, and is a tap-rooted, erect winter annual herb (Cooke 2003: Weber, 2003). The species does not occur within watercourses, little impact on surface or subsurface water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: No reviewed documentation suggests that C. annua impacts on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
C. annua can form dense stands and has a deep taproot (Weber 2003) which may reduce soil erosion, although because C. annua can form dense stands and displace native plants (Cooke 2003) may increase the probability of soil erosion slightly.
The annual species may leave bare patches that are exposed to soil erosion. Moderate probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: C. annua forms dense stands displacing both native plants and other weed species and can comprise up to an estimated 95% of total herbaceous biomass (Cooke 2003). Direct replacement of biomass by invader.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
C. annua is a winter growing annual plant, following plant senescence, the dead plant remains upright over the summer months (Cooke 2003). Gat-Tilman (1995) describes C. annua as a ‘dry plant’ during the summer months.
This suggests the plant may increase the risk of fire intensity. Minor change.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Semi-arid woodland (V); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
C. annua can form dense stands becoming the dominant herbaceous plant. Across its range, C. annua displaces both native plants and other weed species and comprises up to an estimated 95% of total herbaceous biomass.
C. annua could be considered as forming a monoculture in the Flinders Rangers National Park within a specific layer (Cooke 2003), although in other areas such as Willandra C. annua occurs with perennial competitors.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Semi-arid woodland (D); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
C. annua can form dense stands becoming the dominant herbaceous plant. Across its range, C. annua displaces both native plants and other weed species and comprises up to an estimated 95% of total herbaceous biomass.
C. annua could be considered as forming a monoculture in the Flinders Rangers National Park within a specific layer (Cooke 2003), although in other areas such as Willandra C. annua occurs with perennial competitors.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Shrubby Woodland (E); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Greater Grampians; CLIMATE potential=VH.
C. annua can form dense stands becoming the dominant herbaceous plant. Across its range, C. annua displaces both native plants and other weed species and comprises up to an estimated 95% of total herbaceous biomass.
C. annua could be considered as forming a monoculture in the Flinders Rangers National Park within a specific layer (Cooke 2003), although in other areas such as Willandra C. annua occurs with perennial competitors.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Across its range, C. annua displaces both native plants and other weed species and comprises up to an estimated 95% of total herbaceous biomass. C. annua could be considered as forming a monoculture in the Flinders Rangers National Park (Cooke 2003) within the ground cover layer.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Described by Cooke (2003), C. annua may form part of a succession of weed species, which appears to have succeeded hops (Rumex vesicarius) in the Flinders Rangers, which is now rare. This species is in the same genus as Glistening dock (Rumex crystallinus s.s.) a species classed as vulnerable in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: No reviewed documentation directly suggests that C. annua causes a threat to fauna species, although the ability of C. annua to form dense stands becoming the dominant herbaceous plant (Cooke 2003) may suggest a reduction in the available habitat for certain fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The pod seed bank of C. annua forms a potential food source for vertebrate herbivores including goats, macropods, emus, sheep, cattle and rabbits. Ant species in semi-arid areas dominated by C. annua also use the seed of the species as an alternative food source (Cooke 2003 pg. 71).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No literature suggests that C. annua is injurious to fauna although the species is described by Orchard (1946) as being unpalatable to fauna because of its hairiness and pungent, penetrating odour.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: C. annua provides a potential food source for vertebrate herbivores, including rabbits (Cooke 2003).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: C. annua can form dense stands, to 60 cm in height (Cooke 2003: Weber 2003) which may suggest that the species has the capacity to harbour pest species, especially considering C. annua provides a potential food source for vertebrate herbivores including rabbits (Cooke 2003).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: C. annua is described as a major pastoral weed (Keighery 1991 in Cooke 2003 pg7) due to its ability to replace native vegetation following overgrazing. Orchard (1946) also describes that C. annua might choke out cereal crops entirely, if left uncontrolled.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Reduced quality of meat and milk from animals feeding on C. annua has been recorded due to the strong odours of C. annua being transferred to the produce (Orchard 1946). Seeds of C. annua were also recognised as an impurity in wheat in Australia (Cooke 2003).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: C. annua is unpalatable to sheep and cattle; it reduces the carrying capacity and so value of infested property (Cooke 2003). C. annua might choke out cereal crops entirely, if left uncontrolled. (Orchard 1946), causing a decrease in land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: C. annua is unpalatable to sheep and cattle therefore reduces the carrying capacity (Cooke 2003), C. annua may also choke out cereal crops entirely, if left uncontrolled (Orchard 1946) this may cause a downgrading of the priority land use, to one with less agricultural return.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Unknown: No reviewed literature suggests C. annua increases the cost of production.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Unknown: No reviewed documentation suggests that C. annua acts as an alternative host or vector for disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination for this species occurs in Autumn (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: The species often occurs on disturbed sites and is reported to be intolerant of shade (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001; PFAF 2007; Restrepo & Vitousek 2001).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: The species invades habitats which are considered highly disturbed such as roadsides and overgrazed native pasture (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Grass; the species is a C4 perennial bunchgrass (Marks & Strain 1989).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: The species has been found to have significant inhibitory effect on the growth of seedlings of a number of species (Rice 1972).  Reported to have some allelopathic properties (Rice 1984).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: The species is reported to have little fodder value and that the dried biomass can present as a fire hazard in late summer, which would indicate that largely the species isn’t consumed (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). The species is considered unpalatable and of low forage value (Griffin, Watson & Strachan 1988).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Reported to have a slow growth rate through winter, plants are then able to grow to 1 m high during spring and summer (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). The species is therefore considered to have a growth rate equal to that of other grass species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Reported to occur in ephemeral wetlands (Kirkman & Sharitz 1994). Therefore the species has some tolerance to waterlogging.  The species can persist through fire events (D’Antonio, Tunison & Loh 2000).  Tolerant of drought (Marks & Strain 1989).  Tolerant of heavy metals (Gibson & Risser 1982).  Tolerant of frost, Reported to be hardy to zone 6 (-20�C) (PFAF 2007).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The species reproduces sexually producing seed (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Unknown.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: The species is reported to persist in almost pure stands for many years (Rice 1972).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: The species is able to reproduce in its first year (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The species seeds are reported to be dispersed externally on animals and with human aided dispersal (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: This species is spreading into Eastern Victoria through the movement of hay and livestock from NSW, which enables the species to be spread more than 1 km (Sexton 2003).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
An annual, the plant can be propagated by seed sown in spring or autumn (PFAF 2003). Optimum temperature for germination is constant 20 or 25�C (Anderson 1968). Lisci et al. (1994) note that M. annua flowers all year round in southern and central Italy, hence pollination and seed production would occur throughout the year. They do not report on seed dormancy. As a weed in sugar beet crops Jursik et al. (2004) noted there were several waves of emergence, influenced by weather conditions. Seedling emergence began at the end of April and progressively increased to a maximum in June (northern hemisphere summer). Germination had mostly ceased by November.  Magyar and Hunyadi (2000) record temperature as the main factor regulating germination of M. annua. Magyar (2003) states, “It can be observed that the germination of annual mercury seeds has a seasonal pattern under
natural field conditions.” Natural seasonal disturbance.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Common habitats are gardens, arable land, vineyards; rubbish tips; on soils rich in nutrients, in light and moderately warm situations up to montane level. In California it is noted as a weed of agriculture in disturbed habitats (CALFLORA 2007). In Hungary, where the weed has significantly extended it area of infestation, it is mostly known in cropping situations (maize and winter wheat, sugar beet and carrot) and ruderal areas (Magyar 2003). Requires open space or bare ground to establish

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In some areas of Europe (Hungary, Czech Republic) it is more common in arable land used for annual cropping activities (Magyar 2003). Infestations most commonly occur in highly disturbed environments. See above.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual herb, 10–40 cm high. ‘Other’ life form.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Magyar (2003) found allelopathic potential against three species; amaranth, white mustard and wheat. In wheat, only the early growth of seedlings was affected; germination was not inhibited. Magyar’s conclusion was that, “The proven allelopathic potential of annual mercury as a part of the interference can contribute to its further expansion on arable lands.”

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: The plant is consumed by grazing animals, but the plants are known for, “high seed production and longevity.”  Reproduction may be inhibited by herbivory, but extensive seed bank would ensure weed persists. Yampolsky (1930) found that heavily pruned plants of M. annua recovered and subsequently produced flowers and seed.  (Note: some of the male-only plants produced a few female and hermaphrodite flowers after pruning.)

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Magyar & Hunyadi (2000) state, “The high relative growth rate values during early development indicate the strong competitive nature of this weed,” but this is contradicted by Magyar (2003) and Jursik et al. (2004) who suggest it is less competitive particularly in relation to other species of primary weed infestations. Growth rate likely to be less than other species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: The plant is, “frost resistant but drought tender,” (Bodkin 1990). An annual, the plant would not tolerate fire. No data on response to water logging. Resistant to one stressor, susceptible to at least two.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
An annual; dioecious (male and female flowers borne on separate plants). M. annua is known to produce both functional males and hermaphrodites under some conditions. Under experimental conditions, Yampolsky (1930) found the same male-only plant can produce female and hermaphrodite flowers during recovery from deliberate damage (pruning). Pannel et al. (2003) demonstrate also that under the influence of ecological interactions populations of M. annua can be dioecious, androdioecious (males and hermaphrodites) and functional
hermaphroditism. It has been suggested that species of Mecurialis are out-crossers.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Jursik et al. (2004) found that M. annua produces up to 20,000 seeds m-2 in sugar beet stands. Propagules likely to exceed 2,000 per plant per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: The plant has, “a long primary seed dormancy, …and longevity in soil,” (Kohout & Hamouz 2000) Specific values of percentage viability and longevity not available. Assume at least 25% of seed survives 5 to 10 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual species.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: An annual, the plant reaches maturity and produces viable propagules in under one year.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
Annual herb 10 – 40 cm high. In Western Australia, it is recorded to reach a height of 60 cm (Hussey et al. 1997).
Negligible impact on human access

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: An introduced species to North America, it is known in San Francisco in open, disturbed areas, fields and roadsides. Where it occurs north east of Melbourne (Victoria), it is most commonly associated with a creek corridor in a nature reserve, but is also known to be present in local gardens. Infestations likely to be undetectable to the average visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Vallverdu et al. (1997) demonstrated a high level (46.4%) of sensitisation to pollen of M. annua in subjects with a known sensitivity to other pollens. Lisci et al. (1994) records that M. annua is a wind-pollinated plant and produces pollen throughout the year in central and southern Italy. Rossof (2002) reinforces the allergenicity of this plant in Italy where, he states, its aeroallergens have caused rhinitis, bronchial asthma, and/or hypersensitivity pneumonitis in humans. “Use of it colors urine red.” Neat huh! Potential to cause allergic reaction or increase the duration of suffering for those susceptible to pollen allergies.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Low growing annual herb. Dense patches may create a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Although it is found near to streams and drains in Victoria, it is a terrestrial species. No impact on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: See comment above. No data is available to indicate the water stress-tolerance of this plant. Assume it unlikely to establish in standing water.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A soft annual herb more commonly found in disturbed or ruderal situations. Its presence is unlikely to affect soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In natural ecosystems it is commonly found in disturbed sites or waste places (CALFLORA 2007; Magyar 2003).  Biomass may increase slightly, but likely little to no effect.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Small, fleshy annual herb. Even dense patches are unlikely to add significantly to fuel load. Little to no affect on fire intensity or frequency.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC=Valley Grassy Forest (V); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH. Occurs along creek / drain line north east of Melbourne where it is displacing other herbaceous annuals and, as a prolific seeding annual, spreading quickly in the absence of control. It is difficult to comment on the level of displacement (minor or major) this species may impose on the lower stratum. Somewhere in the middle?

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Coastal Headland Scrub (D); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH. A soft, annual herb. Impact similar to 10. above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Riparian scrum (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Wilsons Promontory; CLIMATE potential=VH. A soft, annual herb. Impact similar to 10. above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Known in peppermint woodland at Hamelin Bay, Western Australia (about 35 km south of Margaret River), but no detail on effect of its presence on other vegetation. Where it occurs near Melbourne, Victoria, it is associated with a creek corridor / drain in a nature reserve (Baber; Lorimer, pers. comms) where it is displacing other more desirable annual herbs. Minor impact on lower stratum.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Not documented.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Displacement of beneficial plants by M. annua may lead to a reduction in available fodder for non-threatened species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Provides no documented benefit. It is recorded as poisonous to domesticated animals (sheep, cattle and horses (Rossof, 2002)). See comments below.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Welchman et al. (1995) and Deprez et al. (1996) report the poisoning of lambs and cattle respectively. 11 lambs died, but the life outcome of the cattle is not described. In the case of lamb poisoning, the authors noted that annual mercury was the predominant vegetation. Rossof (2002) indicates that annual mercury is lethal to all domestic animals (sheep, cattle, horses). Though animals may avoid eating the plant, the potential exists to fatally harm fauna at certain times of the year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Probably unlikely; see comments in 16 above. Pest herbivores may find consuming this plant to be fatal.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Images of infestations in California (CalPhotos) show the plant would not provide harbour for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Although reported as toxic to domesticated animals no data exists on effects on yield regarding stock. Magyar (2003) has undertaken the most comprehensive study of this plant to date, though with a focus on agricultural ecosystems, notably annual crops such as maize and winter wheat. He found that the average cover in maize varied from 1.16% to 2.28%. How it affected production and yield is not discussed. The major concern was the emergence of the weed before the cultivated crop. Given this early competition for plant resources, it could result in a reduction in crop yield of more than 5%, but less than 20%.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: There are no data available to suggest the quality of agricultural produce is affected. The few studies on animals consuming the plant (Rossof 2002; Welchman et al. 1995; Deprez et al.1996) suggest that mortality is the most likely outcome rather than a reduction in vigour. It is not recorded as a seed contaminant. No impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The continuous spread of this weed in north-western Hungary (Magyar 2003) in annual crops indicates it has been a difficult weed to control or possibly just ignored as another weedy crop competitor. Magyar (2003) demonstrates effective control of annual mercury with herbicides. Normal farm / crop management practices would likely control the weed, though possibly adding to the cost of production. Unlikely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See comment in 21 above regarding cropping situations. As the weed is most closely associated with high disturbance regimes, well maintained, good quality perennial pasture is likely to suppress the growth of annual mercury. Unlikely to lead to change in land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not demonstrated to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not documented.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination is combination of light and temperature and although usually germinates in spring, can germinate at other times of year if conditions are suitable (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001, DNRM 2005).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Prefers dry, sunny grassy plains, along riverbanks, roadsides, disturbed soils, vacant lots and ruderal sites (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Limited growth in shade.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: "Primarily a plant of disturbed open areas" occurs as weed of cultivated lands, stubble fields, old pastures, wastelands" (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual herb (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001) – life form –other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Annual ragweed ‘produces allelopathic responses in several other weed and crop species .. strongly inhibit germination of onion, oats, Lolium spp. (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Cattle eat annual ragweed in early stages. A variegated leaf beetle and stem-galling moth are used in biological control in Queensland with the moth ‘reducing ragweed populations and seed production in warmer areas’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Serious competitor with cereal crops and vegetables in early growth stage but poor competitor in well managed pastures and legume crops. Growth rate rapid depending on environment (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Most often occurs in wasteland areas so score as Medium High.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Due to the locations it can be found, it appears to have saline tolerance. Susceptible to frost and fire.  Drought tolerant. Can be found in flood plains but no mention of ability to withstand waterlogging (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Wind pollinated. A ‘self-compatible species’ (Bassett & Crompton 1975 (cited in Genton, Shykoff & Giraud). Cross and self-pollination but cannot vegetatively reproduce (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Annual ragweed produces an average of 3000 seeds per year (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Annual ragweed seeds can be viable for more than 40 years (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual plant (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Reaches maturity in 4-5 months (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Clings to sheep, furred animals, bags, clothing, water, contaminated gravel and soil (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Spreads ‘readily over long distances’. Hull provides buoyancy (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). 

Seems likely that some of the propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: S. cinerea spreads by seed to riparian as well as other moist to wet habitats, and this is of special concern.” (Cremer, 1999). “S. nigra has the potential to behave in the same invasive manner as S. cinerea in wetlands” (Ladson et al, 1989). These species do not need uncommon natural events for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Willows are described as heliophyllic (intolerant of shade) (Haines, 2004) and most species …must not be over-humg by larger plants or trees (Newsholme, 1992).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: S. nigra generally invade as seedlings (Carr, 1996) and so are “virtually restricted to bare sediment that is wet for weeks or months following seed shed [and] seedlings need much light” (Cremer, 1999). This is a major disturbance with little or no competition from other plant species.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Semi-aquatic- All willows are described as growing on the banks of water courses or in moist locations. S. nigra grow in “streams in pastoral country…opening in pine and eucalypt forest” (Cremer, 1999) and offstream wetlands (Ladson et al, 1997).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Of the naturalised willows in Australia, allelopathic compounds have been demonstrated in S. rubra (Bokarev, Kefeli & Kapeljusnikova, 1966), S. babylonica (Koul et al, 1991), S. fragilis (Davison, 1965), S. viminalis (Bowen & Hoad, 1968), S. alba (Banzhaf et al, 1983) and S. purpurea (Gilliver, 1947). For other willow species, their “dense shade and mat-forming willow roots suppress and kill indigenous understorey” (Purtle et al, 2001b), suggesting that there might be an allelopathic basis for this lack of understorey beneath willow infestations, however no specific reference to these species was found.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No information

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Salix are fast growing trees or shrubs, rarely prostrate” (Spencer, 1997). Where growth rates are described, tree and shrub forms of Salix are recorded as vigorous or fast growing, e.g. S. alba (Spencer, 1997), S. glaucophylloides (Newsholme, 1992), S. nigra (Cremer, 1995), S. purpurea (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988) and S. x rubens (Meikle).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
FIRE “If a tree is completely girdled by fire at ground level it may die without coppicing… however young trees tend to sprout from the buried portion of their stem” (Cremer, 1999), indicating some fire tolerance in tree and shrub willows in general.

FROST All tree and shrub species (except S. humboldtiana) in this study are recorded as tolerating USDA hardiness zones of between 1 and 6 (average minimum temperatures between –46oC and –17oC) (Bailey & Bailey, 1976, Griffiths, 1992). S. humboldtiana is susceptible to frost (Newsholme, 1992).

DROUGHT All willows are described as growing on the banks or in the riverbeds of water courses or in moist locations (Carr, 1996; Carr et. al, 1992; Cody, 1996; Davis, 1982; Howard, 1988; Ladson, et al, 1997; Maloney et al, 1999; Munz, 1963; Voss, 1972; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988) suggesting a low drought tolerance; and only few species (S. cinerea and S. exigua) can also establish on drier soil (but are not necessarily drought tolerant), with S. purpurea alone tolerating extremely dry, sandy soils (Newsholme, 1992).

WATERLOGGING Those species able to grow in riverbeds must have high tolerance of waterlogging (S. exigua, Cody, 1996; S. fragilis, Maloney et al, 1999; S. alba, S. x rubens, and S. viminalis; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988) and also S. cinerea (Cremer, 1999).

SALINITY S. alba is “the most tolerant of all willows to brackish water” (Zallar). S. cinerea “tolerates salt-laden air” (Newsholme, 1992), S. fragilis, S. matsudana & S. seringeana tolerate high levels of salinity (Crouch & Honeyman, 1986). S. nigra has moderately high tolerance of salt (Swift, 1997) and S. purpurea shows “considerable tolerance for salt water” (Newsholme, 1992). S. alba are highly tolerant of waterlogging, salinity and frost, have some tolerance of fire, but not of drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: S. nigra Seeds and possible vegetatively…brittle twigs (Spencer, 1997). Abundantly recruiting by seed…probably also reproducing vegetatively (Carr, 1996). Capable of reproduction vegetatively and also by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “A large crown would produce over 500,000 seeds (Cremer, 1999). Seeds numerous, very small, each with a tuft of long hairs (Tutin, 1993).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Willow seed is very short-lived” with longer-lived species recorded at surviving 8-10 weeks (Cremer, 1999).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Following reproductive maturity “flowering tends to be ample and to occur every year” (Cremer, 1999). S. cinerea “stands are mostly monoculture excluding 97% of sunlight and most other species” (Cremer, 1999). The oldest stem S. exigua in this study was 31 years (Ottenbreit & Staniforth, 1992). An old S. fragilis tree was observed to 130 years (Meikle, 1984).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
“Flowering and the production of viable seed may begin two to three years after germination, provided the plant is at least 1 m tall if it is a shrub willow, or 2 m tall if it is a tree willow…In some taxa (e.g. S. alba) flowering tends to begin at larger sizes” (Cremer, 1999), which is probably still within 5 years.

For plants that have reproduced vegetatively, this may be reduced, as in S. nigra, observed flowering on cuttings produced from < 1 year old growth (Crouch & Honeyman, 1986).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Vegetative propagules and seed spread by water. “Seed is easily carried by wind” (Cremer, 1999).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Seed is easily carried by wind for more than 1 km and some travels for up to 50 km or even 100 km (Cremer, 1999) for species that commonly reproduce by seed, such as S. nigra (ARMCANZ, 2001).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination is reported to occur in Autumn, especially after fire or another disturbance. The seeds are not dependent on fire for germination however (Blood 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Tolerant of partial shade, invades forest (Blood 2001).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Highly invasive in heathland (Muyt 2001).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: In the Fabaceae family and can fix nitrogen (Blood 2001). Therefore a legume.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No allelopathic properties are reported for this species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Tolerant of grazing, used as a fodder source (Blood 2001).
Resprouts after being cut at the base (Blood 2001).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Very fast growing (Blood 2001).
Can grow rapidly to 1.5 m in a year (Eliovson 1960).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of frost, to temperatures of -4�C (Blood 2001).
Tolerant of fire; fire stimulates germination and mature plants can reprout (Blood 2001).
Tolerant of dry conditions (Blood 2001). No reported tolerance of drought however.
Tolerant of waterlogging; occurs in swamps (Blood 2001).
Tolerant of salt laden winds (Muyt 2001).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by seed (Blood 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Can produce thousands of seeds annually (Muyt 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds remain viable for at least 8 years (Muyt 2001).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Can live for 15 years (Muyt 2001). Being able to start flowering in its second year as reported by Blood (2001) would give a potential reproductive period of more than 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Can start flowering after 1 year (Eliovson 1960).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Dispersed by water and possibly by birds (Blood 2001).
Human aided dispersal includes accidentally through machinery and contaminated soil and deliberately; still occasionally available in trade (Blood 2001; Muyt 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Dispersal by water and possibly by birds would enable propagules to move more than 1 km.
Dispersal of more than 1 km along a roadside most probably through contaminated machinery has been observed (Mitchard pers comm. 2007).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A small tree growing to 4 m, reported to occur in riparian areas and able to forms dense thickets (Weber 2003). As the plant can grow to 1.5 m in one year and has a lasting seed bank, the species may need to be controlled to maintain access which would require significant works (Eliovson 1960; Muyt 2001).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments:
An ornamental tree species which can form dense thickets the species may have some effect on aesthetics (Weber 2003). 
Unknown if the species potential to restrict access has had any impact on recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: There is no reported evidence of this.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: An ornamental tree species which can form dense thickets the species may have some effect on aesthetics (Weber 2003).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species is reported to occur in swamps and riparian vegetation (Hussey et al 1997; Muyt 2001). There is no evidence reported of the species impacting water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species is reported to occur in swamps and riparian vegetation (Hussey et al 1997; Muyt 2001). There is no evidence reported of the species impacting water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The species root system is described as being woody and branching but mostly shallow (Muyt 2001). Having a shallow root system would limit the species ability to prevent large scale erosion occurring.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Described as a fast growing species which can crowd out other shrub species and shade out species of lower strata (Muyt 2001). Invasion by this species is overall likely to cause direct replacement.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
Blood (2001) reports that fire stimulates mass germination of this fast growing species, this could increase fire frequency.
The flammability of this species is not reported and therefore its affect on fire intensity can’t be speculated.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Wet Heathland (V); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Greater Grampians; VH CLIMATE potential.
P. pinnata is a small tree species, which can form dense thickets, shading out species of the lower strata, crowd out shrub species and impede the regeneration of overstorey species (Muyt 2001; Weber 2003). It can also fix nitrogen which can change the soil fertility and affect indigenous species persistence in the long term (Muyt 2001). Therefore the species is capable of causing major displacement within layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Damp Heathland (D); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
P. pinnata is a small tree species, which can form dense thickets, shading out species of the lower strata, crowd out shrub species and impede the regeneration of overstorey species (Muyt 2001; Weber 2003). It can also fix nitrogen which can change the soil fertility and affect indigenous species persistence in the long term (Muyt 2001). Therefore the species is capable of causing major displacement within layers.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Heathland (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
P. pinnata is a small tree species, which can form dense thickets, shading out species of the lower strata, crowd out shrub species and impede the regeneration of overstorey species (Muyt 2001; Weber 2003). It can also fix nitrogen which can change the soil fertility and affect indigenous species persistence in the long term (Muyt 2001). Therefore the species is capable of causing major displacement within layers.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: P. pinnata is a small tree species, which can form dense thickets, shading out species of the lower strata, crowd out shrub species and impede the regeneration of overstorey species (Muyt 2001; Weber 2003). It can also fix nitrogen which can change the soil fertility and affect indigenous species persistence in the long term (Muyt 2001). Therefore the species has potential to have a major impact on the middle to lower strata through direct competition and a minor impact through impeding regeneration and alteration of soil chemistry.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Listed as threatening competitor to Villarsia calthifolia a rare species in Western Australia (Gilfillan & Barrett 2004). There is no data reported however of this species impacting a species threatened in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Is managed as a threat to the Southern Emu-wren Stipiturus malachurus (Maguire & Mulder 2004).

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Observed as a food source of the New Holland Honeyeater Phylidonyris novaehollandiae (Lepschi 1997). Is reported to be used by the Southern Emu-wren Stipiturus malachurus (Maguire 2005).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this occurring.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Introduced as a nectar source for bees (Blood 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Reported to forms thickets (Weber 2003). There is potential therefore for the species to harbour species such as rabbits and foxes. There is no evidence of this occurring however.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Reported to be becoming a problem in forestry (Blood 2001). The species impact is unknown however.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Reported to be becoming a problem in forestry (Blood 2001). The species impact is unknown however.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Reported to be becoming a problem in forestry (Blood 2001). The species impact is unknown however.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Reported to be becoming a problem in forestry (Blood 2001). The species impact is unknown however.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Reported to be becoming a problem in forestry (Blood 2001). The species impact is unknown however.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Phakopsora pachyrhizae has been identified on the plant and other Phakopsora species are reported to infect a range of legume species (Mennicken & Oberwinkler 2004). Therefore this species my be an alternate host for rusts that effect legume crops, at this stage however there is no direct evidence.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germinates in autumn (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Requires natural seasonal conditions.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Prefers dryplains of temperate regions and is a weed of wastelands (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Limited growth in shade.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in ‘run-down pastures, orchards, roadsides, wastelands and other disturbed areas’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Established in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial herbaceous plants (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Life form – other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: A. confertiflora not documented to have allelopathic properties (Parsons & Cuthbertson).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: A. confertiflora not known to be eaten by animals and insects

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Seedlings grow at moderate rate during winter with growth rate increasing in spring (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). No indication that plant growth rate would equal competitive species of same life form. Therefore score as medium.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘When dry periods occur in summer, aerial growth dies back and redevelops from the perennial roots in autumn’ Drought tolerant. Can be found in flood plains but no mention of ability to withstand waterlogging (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Due to locations found, assume weed has some tolerance to salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually and vegetatively (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “All types (of ragweed) are prolific seeders … average about 3,000 seeds per year’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Annual ragweed propagule longevity is up to 40 years (Schmoll, Reigner & Harrison 2004). In contrast, giant ragweed is only viable for 6 weeks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). No information on A. confertiflora. Due to variation within genus, scored as medium.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Not specified. Form large colonies and plants known to live up to 10 years (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).  Therefore score as medium high.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: A. confertiflora reaches maturity in approximately 9 months (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Known to be dispersed by clinging to sheep, furred animals, bags, clothing, water, contaminated gravel and soil (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Spreads ‘readily over long distances’. Hull provides buoyancy (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Assume likely that some of the propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grows from 75 to 200 cm. The burrs associated with burr ragweed and dermatogenic properties have the potential to impede individual access (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Most species are ‘so ordinary in appearance that they are rarely noticed despite their abundance’. All species are noted for their allergens and are a major contributor to hay fever in US, with some places advertising as ‘ragweed free’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Potential to have major impact on tourism in autumn months when pollen counts is high.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: ‘Most important hay-fever producing plant in North America’. Also associated with asthma and dermatogenic properties. Burr ragweed ‘burrs’ cause discomfort throughout the year with three species having a high pollen count from late summer through to autumn being a major component in hayfever and asthma (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Not known to cause structural damage. Little or negligible effect on aesthetics.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In dry periods over summer and in autumn, aerial growth dies back. Plants have ‘creeping runner-like roots’ and form large colonies (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Unlikely that the species would contribute to large-scale soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Plant grows up to 200 cm and forms large colonies. Often occurs in wasteland where little vegetation exists (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Likely that biomass would slightly increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Herbaceous plant (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001) so assume that it would have small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains Grassy Woodland (E), CMA=Wimmera, Bioreg.=Wimmera, CLIMATE=VH. 
Weed doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Very little displacement of any indigenous species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Hills Herb-rich Woodland (D), CMA=NorthCentral, Bioreg=Goldfields, CLIMATE=VH. 
Weed doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Very little displacement of any indigenous species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Coastal Tussock Grassland (LC), CMA=West Gippsland, Bioreg.=Gippsland Plain, CLIMATE=L. 
Weed doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata
are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Very little displacement of any indigenous species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Weed doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Usually only affecting one of the strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information available.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Tends to grow in ruderal sites so assume that there is no reduction in habitat/food/shelter for non threatened fauna spp. (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No documented evidence that A. confertiflora benefits fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Hooked spines and burrs attach to sheep and furred animals but no documented impact on health or well being of animals (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No documented evidence that A. confertiflora is a food source to pests (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: No documented evidence that A. confertiflora provides harbour for pest spp.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: ‘Is an extremely competitive plant, readily suppressing pasture species…also a problem in orchards, competing for nutrients’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Minor impact on quantity of produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Burr ragweed contaminates wool with hooked spines (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Likely that would have greater than 5% impact on quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No information on whether or not the weed affects land value. Numerous studies on effect of annual ragweed and giant ragweed on cropping systems but no references made to burr ragweed and land values. Score medium.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed can be controlled by herbicides in pasture (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Assume little or no change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: ‘..a problem in orchards, competing for nutrients, interfering with the harvest, and both pollen and burrs cause discomfort to pickers’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Hooked spines difficult to remove from wool so added costs in acid carbonate used for removal (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Increase in time, labour and cost.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes in mostly ‘open’ situations e.g. pasture, fields.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in vigorously growing crops (e.g. cotton) and pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Annual herb.

Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Minor allelopathic effects on itself and tomato plants have been shown.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: The plant’s prickly nature deters grazing animals.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Is a strong competitor in cotton crops in parts of the United States”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to water logging (occurs on shores), drought (occurs in arid areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproducing by seed.

Has capacity for both self and cross pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Established based on pictures and descriptions.

 20 berries per plant x 85 seeds per berry = 1,700 seeds per plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual  < one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Containment of cereal grain: burr also sticks to wool and bags, and can float on water.  Can also be blown about.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Above mechanisms would transport burrs between at least 20-200 m or even > 200 m. burr also stated to float ‘some’ distance on water.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect annual herb, commonly 20 to 30 cm high.” Information on population density not available, and it is not recorded as being aggressive or invasive in natural ecosystems. From images available, which demonstrate the plant’s growth habit, it would be a minor nuisance to humans. Its spiny nature would ensure walkers avoid contact with the plant.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The spiny stems and fruit of the plant would make its presence felt. Recreational uses may be affected because infested areas cannot be used.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: It grows through winter and survives well into summer before dying. Dead material continues to present a hazard because of spines. “Buffalo burr is poisonous and, overseas, there have been fatalities in children after eating the fruit.” (One source has described the plant thus: “Nasty, nasty, nasty. This plant is not one to be handled or even stepped on. The spines are very dense, stiff, and sharp. The plant is just brutal.”)

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Limited spread of plant. Likely to present a moderate negative visual effect. No effect on structure.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In the western United States it commonly occurs on disturbed sites and sandy soils. Its presence would not increase soil erosion. In Victoria, S. rostratum is more commonly a problem in the wheat-growing areas.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Its growth habit and common habitat (waste areas, overgrazed pastures and roadsides) suggest that biomass would not be greatly affected. Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: The dead plant presents a small amount of dry matter, and “mature plants break off at ground level and are blown about as ‘tumble weeds’.” Not likely to change the fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Wimmera; Very high CLIMATE match. 
Mainly a weed of cropping. “…it is generally confined to the wheatbelt. It is somewhat weedy on neglected sites and pastures.” In natural ecosystem minor displace species within a strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Heathy Woodland (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; High potential CLIMATE match only; little displacement of any indigenous species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; Very high CLIMATE match. 
Mainly a weed of cropping. “…it is generally confined to the wheatbelt. It is somewhat weedy on neglected sites and pastures.” In natural ecosystem minor displace species within a strata.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Its effect on other species is not recorded. As a low growing annual it may not have a serious impact on structure. In its native region (midwest USA) it is regarded as highly aggressive and invasive, but beyond this range it seems less so. Possibly a minor effect on the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments:
Direct threat to native orchid Pterostylis truncata (brittle greenhood) in the You Yang ranges.

Threatens ANZECC rated rare or threatened native plant species

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Not known to invade natural ecosystems. However, its spiny nature and toxic fruit may have a minor impact on non-threatened fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The plant causes physical injury to stock, particularly around the mouth and nose, and these areas become infected.” Potential to harm fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: None documented.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A low growing annual. It would not provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Where it occurs in pastures it may reduce available fodder as the plant’s prickly nature deters animals from grazing.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: S. rostratum became a problem in wheat growing areas in Victoria. Its seeds contaminate cereal crops. “Changed farming methods have reduced its significance… it is no longer considered an important weed.” The burrs stick to wool, and contribute to vegetable fault in a wool clip.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Occurs in overgrazed pasture and cropping situations. Cultivation prior to flowering effectively controls the weed, and it is not known as an aggressive weed in Victoria. Likely to have little affect on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Occurs in overgrazed pasture and cropping situations. Cultivation prior to flowering effectively controls the weed, and it is not known as an aggressive weed in Victoria. Population density not known. Change in land use unlikely.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “The weed acts a host for nematodes which affect tomatoes and tobacco in North America.” Potential problem for Victorian agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: No information found.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Found under slight shade” (Dassanayake & Fosberg, 1980)

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In its native range, “found under slight shade, in bushy thickets, along edges of jungles or in dense mossy forests” (Dassanayake & Fosberg 1980). “Serious creekline weed…Found in creeks in the Perth area”  (Hussey et. al, 1997). Beyond its native range it establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Semiscandent [scrambling] shrub (Dassanayake & Fosberg, 1980).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No information found.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Strongly growing (Dassanayake & Fosberg, 1980). Very vigorous to 3 m (anon., 2005).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Keep soil moist especially when young…Sandy to clay loam as long as drainage adequate…Avoid areas with heavy or frequent frosts” (anon., 2005). Moderate frost tolerance, intolerant of drought and waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Seeds… Stems sprawl and root where they touch the ground” (Hussey et. al, 1997).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Heavy fruiting (anon., 2005). Not enough data.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: No information found.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: No information found.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Healthy plants produce fruit after 18 months” (anon., 2005).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “New plants are spread from seeds carried by birds and foxes” (Hussey et. al, 1997).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As the seeds are carried by birds and foxes (Hussey et. al, 1997) it is likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Germination is reported to occur largely in spring and autumn if there is sufficient moisture (Blood 2001).
Therefore the species is capable of germinating under natural seasonal conditions.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Capable of establishing under low light conditions within existing vegetation (Blood 2001).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: While the species is reported to prefer disturbed soil, it is capable of establishing within vegetation and is invasive in heathland (Blood 2001; Muyt 2001)

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Geophyte; has lignotuber, from which it can regrow (Blood 2001).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: The plants leaves and fruits contain emodin at levels of 0.04% � 0.05% d. wt, and 0.0017% � 0.0006% d. wt, respectively. At levels of 10-100 mg l-1 emodin can inhibit root and shoot growth of sunflower and corn (Izhaki 2002). Weber (2003) reports the levels of shade the species creates is thought to be the main agent in suppressing other species, however no studies on this species allelopathic ability have been reported. It is unknown to what level of impact any allelopathic properties Rhamnus alaternus might exhibit will have on other species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
The species’ leaves are reported to contain emodin which has been hypothesised as a deterrent against phytophagous insects (Izhaki 2002).
The species is palatable to sheep and goats (Le Hou�rou 1980).
A large amount of material is reported dumped due to the species fast growing nature and ability to sucker (Blood 2001).
Therefore the species is considered capable of recovering from moderate grazing. However Aronne & Wilcock (1995) report that the fruit is formed on the one year old branches. Browsing may therefore have some impact on sexual reproduction but it would probably not eliminate it all together.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Fast growing once established (Blood 2001).
R.alaternus was shown to have an average relative growth rate after the first 6 months of growth in comparison with 9 other woody species native to the Mediterranean and almost double the average of the evergreen species (Ruiz-Robelto & Villar 2005).
Therefore it is presumed to have equal growth to other competitive shrub species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Frost; tolerant -15�C (Blood 2001).
Tolerates drought (Blood 2001).
Tolerates salt spray (Blood 2001).
Can survive intense fire (Blood 2001).
Tolerance to waterlogging is not reported, however the species preference for drier habitats may indicate a susceptibility (Polunin & Smythies 1973).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Can reproduce sexually producing seed and vegetatively through root suckers (Weber 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Each fruit has between two and five seeds and while reportedly very variable fruit production per plant has been estimated at approximately 11,000 (Bas, G�mez & Pons 2005).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Reported to be very long lived (Blood 2001). Therefore presumed to have a reproductive period greater than 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
The fruits have been reported to be eaten by starlings and blackbirds in New Zealand (Cole & Albrecht 1999 Produces fruits dispersed by birds, and possibly foxes and possums (Muyt 2001).
Is also dispersed by ants in Europe (Aronne & Wilcock 1994; G�mez, Pons & Bas 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
The fruits have been reported to be eaten by starlings (Sturnus vulgaris) in New Zealand (Cole & Albrecht 1999).
The starling has been reported to have a seed dispersal range of 40 km (Spennemann & Allen 2000).
The fruits of the species have been reported to contain emodin, which has been reported to potentially do two things, deter a bird from consuming too much and therefore reducing the possibility of seeds being excreted beneath the parent plant and shorten the bird’s digestion increasing the seeds viability but reducing the distance of dispersal (Izhaki 2002).
The dispersal range of the species may therefore be less than the 40 km but still likely more than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A. longifolia produces dense thickets to 8 m (Weber 2003) which may impede individual access and cause difficulty for vehicle access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: A. longifolia is an upright spreading bushy shrubs to small trees; 1 - 8 m, which may produce dense thickets. Also produces bright yellow flowers to 5 cm in length (Weber 2003). May cause minor effect to aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Reported by PIER (2007), as not being toxic to humans and not to cause allergies. No other reviewed documentation suggests the plant is injurious to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: No reviewed documentation suggests the plant causes damage to indigenous, european heritage sites or infrastructure. Little or negligible effect on aesthetics or structure of site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments:
Unknown: No reviewed documentation suggests that A. longifolia impacts upon water flows within watercourses
or waterbodies.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Unknown: No reviewed documentation suggests that A. longifolia impacts on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A. longifolia was introduced into South Africa as a dune binder and stabiliser to reduce erosion (Hagemann and Rose 1988: Pieterse and Cairns 1988). May decrease the probability of soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Dense stands will shade out many ground-flora species, crowd out shrubs and severely impede overstorey regeneration (Muyt 2001). The plant produces large amounts of litter increasing nitrogen and phosphorus content in the soil (Weber 2003). This may mean A. longifolia directly replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Dense stands of A. longifolia can burn at high intensities (Pieterse and Cairns 1988). Mass germination of seeds occurs when stimulated by fire, so fire increased frequency would benefit the species (Pieterse and Cairns 1986). A. longifolia may cause moderate change to the intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Coastal Headland Scrub (V); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Where invasive, dense thickets may reduce native plant species richness (Weber 2003). A. longifolia encroaches into coastal interiors replacing indigenous flora and valuable natural grassland (Hagemann and Rose 1988). Dense stands will shade out many ground-flora species, crowd out shrubs and severely impede overstorey regeneration (Muyt 2001). A. longifolia is described as forming dense monocultures (Pieterse and Cairns 1988).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Coastal Dune Scrub/Coastal Dune Grassland Mosaic (D); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Where invasive, dense thickets may reduce native plant species richness (Weber 2003). A. longifolia encroaches into coastal interiors replacing indigenous flora and valuable natural grassland (Hagemann and Rose 1988). Dense stands will shade out many ground-flora species, crowd out shrubs and severely impede overstorey regeneration (Muyt 2001). A. longifolia is described as forming dense monocultures (Pieterse and Cairns 1988).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Dunefield Heathland (LC); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Where invasive, dense thickets may reduce native plant species richness (Weber 2003). A. longifolia encroaches into coastal interiors replacing indigenous flora and valuable natural grassland (Hagemann and Rose 1988). Dense stands will shade out many ground-flora species, crowd out shrubs and severely impede overstorey regeneration (Muyt 2001). A. longifolia is described as forming dense monocultures (Pieterse and Cairns 1988).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Dense stands will shade out many ground-flora species, crowd out shrubs and severely impede overstorey regeneration (Muyt 2001). A. longifolia has encroached into the coastal interior replacing indigenous flora and valuable natural grassland (Hagemann and Rose 1988). Plant communities in dunes, naturally characterised by open structure and low cover can be transformed into Acacia woodlands, with arboreal structure, higher cover and low species number, decreasing species richness (Marchante et al. 2003). Pieterse and Cairns (1988) describe A. longifolia forming dense monocultures.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Dense thickets may reduce native plant species richness (Weber 2003). A. longifolia may replace indigenous flora and valuable natural grassland (Hagemann and Rose 1988). A Portuguese study found A. longifolia prevents the germination of therophytes and hemicryptophytes (Marchante et al. 2003). Although no specific information is documented on the effect of A. longifolia on VROT species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Where A. longifolia is invasive, dense thickets may reduce native invertebrate species richness (Weber 2003), reducing habitat and displacing individuals but not causing local extinction.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: May provide as a food source for native invertebrates (Muyt 2001). Although no other specific information is documented on the benefits of A. longifolia for indigenous fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Everist (1981) recorded stock poisoning by A. longifolia believing the toxic substance to be cyanides in the leaves. Although, no specific information was found to document that A. longifolia is injurious to indigenous fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No specific information was found to document that A. longifolia provides a food source to assist in success of pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Everist (1981) recorded stock poisoning by A. longifolia believing the toxic substance to be cyanides in the leaves.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not described as a weed of agriculture. No literature suggests that A. longifolia impacts on the quality of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not described as a weed of agriculture. No literature suggests that A. longifolia affects land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not described as a weed of agriculture. No literature suggests that A. longifolia causes a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not described as a weed of agriculture. No literature suggests that the presence A. longifolia increases the cost of production.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: A fungal disease of A. longifolia has been documented in South Africa. The disease starts as a leaf spot on small seedlings and proceeds to a lethal infection. The cause of the disease of A. longifolia was noted as Clindrocladium scoparium which is known as a widespread pathogen (Hagemann and Rose 1988) in agricultural systems including conifer and hardwood seedling (Forest Pests 2006). A. longifolia may provide host to a minor disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
