inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate at most times of the year.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Mostly occurs in ‘open’ habitats in Australia.

However, occurs with willow riparian vegetation and sycamore woodland in Dan Diego But. Subsp. Of J. acutus.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems e.g. riparian vegetation and wetland areas.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Semi aquatic.  Occurs in swamps, creeks and wetlands.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not readily eaten by grazing animals.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Once established completely covers an area and eliminates all other vegetation.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of water logging (occurs along waterways), salinity (occurs in saline wetlands), drought? (Survives in desert environments).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seeds and from rhizomes.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Seeds numerous in each capsule.

 200 seed capsules x 20 seeds per capsule = 4,000 seeds per plant.  (Refer to pic. P & C 1992 p. 82).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Plants are long lived.

Do not flower until at least two years old, so would produce seeds at least 3-10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants do not flower until at least two years old.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds – contaminant of agricultural produce, machinery, vehicles, water, mud etc.  Also dispersed by rhizomes.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As riparian sp. many seeds would be dispersed by water movements, which is likely to be 20-200 m.  Plus seed adhering to animals would also be dispersed 20-200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Once firmly established, it completely covers an area and eliminates almost all other vegetation. The area also becomes impenetrable to stock and humans because of the sharp spines.”

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “The occurrence of spiny rush along waterways can be quite important in keeping animals from water.” Similar impact in recreational areas. Potential to lead to major impact on recreation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Both stems and leaves terminate in a sharp spine. Most stems and leaves are present all year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Presence of the weed would create a negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: “When growing in drains and watercourses, spiny rush restricts the flow of water which can result in serious flooding.”

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Not known to affect water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “In Australia it is commonly found as a weed of coastal flats, mine dumps and disturbed saline areas. When growing in drains and watercourses, spiny rush restricts the flow of water which can result in serious flooding.” Potential to cause serious flooding may lead to high probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “In Australia it is commonly found as a weed of coastal flats, mine dumps and disturbed saline areas.” Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Not known as a fire hazard

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Swamp scrub (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Warnambool Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“…commonly found as a weed of coastal flats, mine dumps and disturbed saline areas. Eliminate almost all other vegetation.” Major displacement of grasses/ground covers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Plains sedgy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Coastal dune scrub (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “In Australia it is commonly found as a weed of coastal flats, mine dumps and disturbed saline areas. Once firmly established, it completely covers an area and eliminates almost all other vegetation.” Major effect on ground flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “In Australia it is commonly found as a weed of coastal flats, mine dumps and disturbed saline areas.” Limited impact on fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Spiny rush is not readily eaten by grazing animals.” No benefits

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to cause injury to fauna, however, spiny nature of plant may have potential to inflict injury should an animal attempt to browse on it. Grazing animals are not known to eat this plant; potentially minor impact.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “It also provides an effective harbour for vermin, particularly rabbits, because dogs will not work in clumps of the weed and burrows cannot be ripped.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: No data available on agricultural impact. More commonly found in non-agricultural situations such as coastal flats, mine dumps and disturbed saline areas.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: As in 19 above.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: As in 19 above.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: As in 19 above.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: As in 19 above.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: No data available.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Sown in Summer. Storage improves germination as there is “some dormancy” post-harvest and seed ripens unevenly (Speedy 2004). Dormancy was overcome experimentally by manipulating light or temperature and by soil burial in combination with optimal germination temperatures, between 20oC and 30oC (Ishimine 1987).
Requires natural seasonal disturbance.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Prefers full sunlight. Does not grow well in shade” (Speedy 2004), however, studies have found that shade enhances the growth of this weed (Ishimine et al. 1985). Likely to be able to establish under moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Weed of disturbed areas (PIER 2007). Found on a grassy track, amongst other grasses (Moore & Edgar 2007).
Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial grass (Clayton et al. 2007) with leaves to 60 cm and flowers to 180 cm (Walsh & Entwisle 1994) with short rhizomes 1-1.5 cm diameter (Moore & Edgar 2007).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Exudates significantly reduced the growth of other plants (Ishimine et al. 1987).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: A study of rice stink bug found that the flowers of this species was preferred, over 11 other grass species, and one sedge (Naresh & Smith 1983). “Killed by heavy grazing [however] not as palatable as other species, quickly becoming coarse and thus avoided by stock” (Speedy 2004). Mature grass not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Spreads fairly quickly under…moist soil conditions” and has very vigorous seedlings. Competes successfully with weeds (Speedy 2004). Up to 60 days from germination, Paspalum was shorter than sugarcane, but after 120 days it had grown taller than the crop (Ishimine 1987), however examination of the data suggests that when measurements began, the cane was 50 cm tall whilst the weed had just germinated. Able to out compete similar life forms.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Grows from 0-1,000 m in summer-dominant high rainfall regions of 1,000-1,500 mm and can withstand fire, severe drought and a wide range of soils, including very wet land, but does not survive winter in Washington State USA.
Tolerance to salinity not recorded (Speedy 2004). Wetland plants (Beadle et al. 2004). Highly tolerant of drought and waterlogging, some tolerance to fire, not highly tolerant of frost.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Sexual (Speedy 2004). Not known if self or cross-fertile.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Heavy seed production” (Speedy 2004). Produces more viable seed than P. dilatatum (Schrauf et al. 2003). P. dilatatum can produce more than 25,000 seeds annually (Muyt 2001). More than 25, 000 seeds produced per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds survived at least 9 months under various experimental conditions (Ishimine 1987). Unknown beyond this.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Abundant seed set in the second or third year of sowing (Rosengurtt 1948). Plants survived a four year study (Schrauf et al. 2003). Mature plant produces viable propagules for at least 3 years, but unlikely to be more than 10 years, as this is a grass.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Abundant seed set in the second or third year of sowing (Rosengurtt 1948). 1-2 years to reach sexual maturity.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seed is fluffy and smaller than P. dilatatum (Speedy 2004). For P. dilatatum, seed is spread by animals, water, vehicles, machinery, on clothing and footwear (Muyt 2001). This is likely to be true for P. urvillei also.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Likely to have been introduced to Victoria with stock or grain from interstate (Walsh & Entwisle 1994). Proven ability to disperse greater than one kilometre.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy - occurs orchards, vineyards, oak woodlands.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades crops & pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual/biennial erect herbs - ‘Other’.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Allelopathic compounds restrict growth of other species & also decrease germination of its own seeds.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not readily eaten by stock except when it is very young, due to the presence of spines.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Competes with pastures and crops.  Yellow star thistle germinates & grows more rapidly than many of its competitors under a variety of conditions (Larson et al 1997).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought (occurs in semi-arid rangeland), fire (although not continued burns), some salinity and frost.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed → not sure if cross &/or self pollination

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: More than 10,000 seeds have been recorded on some plants but the average is much less

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Most seeds germinate the following year, but some seeds can last 10 years or more in the soil.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms monocultures (dense infestations) →see pic P&C (1992) p.203.  Densities of 5-7 m plants/ha  have been recorded.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds – wind, water, contaminant of agricultural produce including commercial seed, vehicles, machinery, wool & fodder.  Also by birds (Woo et al 1992).  However, is not the primary dispersal mechanism.  Seeds not ingested by birds, but rather attach to bird feathers (Callihan et al 1993).  In addition, dispersal by birds not noted in Australia by P&C (1992). CONTRADICTS During seed dispersal, birds feed heavily on yellow star thistle achenes… Birds have been implicated in both long & short distance dispersal of weed seeds. (See Roche 1992 p.64)

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Plumed seeds can disperse 1.5 m by wind and many seeds disperse over longer distance in fur, feathers or human activity.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Plants typically germinate in fall [autumn] after first rains” (Healy, Enloe & DiTomaso, 2005).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Most species grow in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1993). Onopordum in general grow along roadsides and in fields (Healy, Enloe & DiTomaso, 2005).  Requires open space.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Most species grow in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1993). Onopordum in general grow along roadsides and in fields (Healy, Enloe & DiTomaso, 2005).  Establishes in highly disturbed ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Biennial (Tutin, 1993).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: For all Onopordum, stems spinose-winged, or absent…involucral bracts spine-tipped (Tutin, 1993). Spines on the inflorescence (and probably the stems) would deter herbivory by vertebrates.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: No information found.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Grows in deep dry soils in Spain and Portugal (Rivas-Martinez et al, 2002). No further information found
about stress tolerances.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Onopordum reproduce only by seeds (Healy et al, 2005). No further information found.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Average of 218 capitula per plant (Briese et al, 1995).No further information found.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: No information found.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Flowering stems develop during the second spring/summer season” (Healy, Enloe & DiTomaso, 2005) on this biennial plant (Tutin, 1993), so that they produce seed for only one year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Biennial (Tutin, 1993). “Flowering stems develop during the second spring/summer season” (Healy, Enloe & DiTomaso, 2005), within two years of germinating.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: No information found.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: No information found.

social_access.comments: No information about the morphology of this plant was found.

social_tourism.comments: No information about the morphology of this plant was found.

social_injurious.comments: For all Onopordum, stems spinose-winged, or absent…involucral bracts spine-tipped (Tutin, 1980). Spines on the infloresence (and probably the stems) may cause some damage at most times of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: No information about the morphology of this plant was found.

env_flow.comments: Most species grow in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1980). Terrestrial species.

env_water.comments: Most species grow in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1980). Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Biennial species (Tutin, 1980) that may leave large bare patches after it dies off, however the extent of infestations is unknown.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Seeds germinate early in the wet season, following the first significant storms’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Requires seasonal rainfall for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘Moderately intolerant of shade, growing in both full sunlight and under light forest canopies’ (Francis 2002). Can establish under a moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘Most often found on roadsides, bluffs and bars above streams, overgrazed range, disturbed areas, and farmsteads’ (Francis 2002). ‘Grows well in tropical savanna country and along riverbanks’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Although common in highly disturbed natural ecosystems, can establish in relatively intact natural ecosystems also.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial shrub (Francis 2002) – other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘Spiny and generally ignored by cattle ’ (Francis 2002). ‘Unpalatable to stock’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Favoured by heavy grazing as not eaten by animals / insects.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Dense stands eliminate most other ground vegetation. ..the species doesn’t compete well in dense stands of tall grass. ‘ Seedlings of porcupine flower grow slowly at first’ (Francis 2002). Insufficient information. Score as medium.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Grows on sandy soils. Susceptible to frost (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Insufficient information to determine if tolerant of drought, waterlogging and / or fire. Score as medium.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: ‘Reproduces by seed.’ ‘Many plants that are closely related to baleria are capable of vegetative reproduction .. baleria can probably also reproduce vegetatively’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Each seed capsule contains two fairly large flat seeds’.’. one plant producing up to hundreds of seeds in a season’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Forty-four percent of the seeds sown on commercial potting mix germinated between 13 and 77 days following sowing ..not known how long the seeds remain viable in the soil after being dropped but it is likely to be at least several years’ (Francis 2002).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘In Puerto Rico, these shrubs live about 4 years’. ‘Can probably live for about ten years in good conditions’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Not definitively known how old seedlings are before they first flower’. ‘In Katherine plants do not flower until they are at least half a metre tall and their estimated age is one year’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: '.. animal vectors for seed dispersal are lacking’ (Francis 2002). ‘Infestations can move relatively quickly downhill, where seed transport may be aided by water’. ‘.. infestations in Australia have been traced back to escapees from gardens .. from garden waste that was dumped in bushland or transported on heavy machinery’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Natural regeneration generally occurs within 1 or 2 m of the parent plant (Francis 2002). However, attached to machinery or spread along roadways, highly likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grows up to 1.5 m. May grow as a single plant or in large, tangled thickets. ‘Thickets can impede the movement of stock, restrict access to waterways’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘The prickly nature and dense thickets of the bush makes it impossible for wildlife, stock or humans to get through to waterways’ (CPC 2002). Weed would have a high nuisance value.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Can ‘reduce the aesthetic values of natural bushland’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Potential to have a minor effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant has 5- to 20 mm long spines (Francis 2002). Spines are present at certain times of years.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Can ‘reduce the aesthetic values of natural bushland’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Possible that the weed would have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Although defoliates annually during the dry season, it has a tap and lateral root system, branching in all directions which would help ‘protect the soil against erosion’ (Francis 2002). Unlikely to contribute to large-scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Dense stands eliminate most other ground vegetation’ (Francis 2002). Likely that biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Weed dies off during the dry season and grows up to 1.5 m. Can grow in grassland. Possible that the weed’s dry matter would have a minor effect on the frequency or intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: The potential distribution of Barleria prionitis excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: The potential distribution of Barleria prionitis excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: The potential distribution of Barleria prionitis excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘Dense stands eliminate most other ground vegetation’ (Francis 2002). The weed would have a major effect on less than 60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The potential for Barleria prionitis to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations. No impact on threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: ‘The prickly nature and dense thickets of the bush makes it impossible for wildlife, stock or humans to get through to waterways’ (CPC 2002). Weed may have a minor effect on fauna spp.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: ‘Furnishes cover for wildlife’ (Francis 2002). May provide some assistance in shelter to desirable species

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: ‘Spiny and generally ignored by cattle’ (Francis 2002). Spines are present at certain times of the year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not a known food source for pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: ‘Can provide refuge for feral animals’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). May provide harbour for minor pest spp.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: ‘Thickets can impede the movement of stock, restrict access to waterways’. ‘Infestations reduce the productivity of pastoral country’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). May have a minor impact on carrying capacity of land.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Primarily a weed of natural ecosystems. Unlikely to effect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Primarily a weed of natural ecosystems. Unlikely to cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy – occurs in “wooded” habitats and canopy microclimates.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in vigorously growing crops, e.g. summer crops, early winter crops.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of water logging (occurs in riverbeds and banks), drought  (occurs in Central Australia, California).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Assumed similar to D. stramonium, as has similar fruit and habit.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: See D. stramonium.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: See D. stramonium.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Erect annual or sometimes perennial herb, commonly 30 to 60 cm high. Unlikely to affect human access to recreational areas.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations would have a minor effect on aesthetics. However, as the leaves produce an unpleasant odour when crushed and the fruit is armed with spines, some recreational activities may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “All parts of the plant, particularly the seeds, are poisonous.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches likely to create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Roots comprise a stout, branched, peg-like taproot with extensive stringy laterals extending horizontally or curving downwards to more than 1 m; adventitious roots often formed at the stem base. D. inoxia can behave as a perennial, developing a substantial root system.” Unlikely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Thornapples now occur…in Victoria in the irrigated cropping areas close to Melbourne, at Orbost, along the Murray River, and I the tobacco crops of the north east.” In these situations the weed would replace biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “The plants die in the cooler autumn weather, but dead plants bearing capsules may remain standing through winter into spring.” Potential for a minor change in the frequency of fire risk within dense patches.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Riparian woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Compete strongly with summer species for moisture and nutrient. Not known as a serious weed of natural ecosystems. Major displacement of annual grasses/ground covers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Murray Goulburn; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not occur in any low value EVC in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dense infestations occur in pastures and on river flats, producing a complete ground cover.” Likely to have a major impact on plants in the lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Dense infestations occur in pastures and on river flats, producing a complete ground cover.” Likely to reduce available fodder for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “All parts of the plant, particularly the seeds, are poisonous.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Thornapples…are of most importance in Queensland and northern New South Wales where they compete with many crops. Mung beans and soybeans are seriously affected and yield losses of up to 90% have been recorded.” Serious impact on quantity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Thornapple seeds are difficult to separate from seeds of grain sorghum…and contaminated samples are downgraded or rejected.” Produce rejected for sale.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Primarily a weed of cropping, control can be achieved by repeated cultivations. Thornapple plants produce a large amount of seed and seeds remain viable for more than 30 years, therefore, control is a long-term exercise. With the serious impact this plant can have on agricultural production and the time to control or eradicate it, land values may be greatly affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Normal farm practices in cropping situations may be sufficient to control the plant, and a change in land use does not appear necessary. Grazing land may be temporarily unavailable while control efforts are undertaken.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “The plants being large and coarse also interfere with harvesting equipment.” Greater time and labour required to conduct harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “They [Datura spp.] act as alternative hosts of insect pests and diseases of solanaceous crops such as tomatoes, tobacco, and potatoes but the significance of this is not known in Australia.” Potential impact?

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An aquatic species, it does not restrict human access on land.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “When densely established, water hyacinth makes swimming and pleasure boating impossible.” Major impact on recreation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No toxic properties, however, infestations provide ideal breeding sites for mosquitoes and other animal vectors. “Decaying plants make water putrid and unfit for drinking by humans or animals.” Potentially harmful associations.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “Floating rafts can be up to 1 metre deep and, in Florida, have become so large that wooden railway bridges are pushed over.” Potential threat to European cultural structures.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: “Water hyacinth chokes waterways reducing flow.” Minor impact on surface flow due to free-floating aquatics.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: “Dense growth removes considerable oxygen from water which, affecting the health of fish.” Moderate effect on O2 level.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Aquatic species.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Biomass significantly increased.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Aquatic species

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
“Dense mats exclude other aquatic plants.” 
“In its native range, E. crassipes may be part of a mixed community of floating and emergent plants or grow as a monoculture.”

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Dense mats…destroy habitat for native invertebrates, fish and birds.” Habitat changed dramatically.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Dense mats…destroy habitat for native invertebrates, fish and birds.” Habitat changed dramatically.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: No known benefits.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Losses are staggering, for example, in the Indian State of West Bengal, it causes an annual loss of paddy rice valued at 110 million rupees.” Serious potential to affect irrigated crops in Victoria.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Aquatic species.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: In areas using irrigation, land values may be seriously affected. (See Q19 above.)

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: If water is not available for irrigation, infestations may lead to land being unusable for some agricultural activities. (See Q19 above.)

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Does not affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “…water hyacinth has been reported to be an alternative host for the Asian corn borer, Ostrinia furnacalis Guenee and the rice root nematode, Hirschmanniella oryzae (van Breda de Haan) Luc and Goody.”

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A much branched, spiny herb with stems 30 to 60 cm long and well developed spines (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). Can occur in coastal sand dunes. May impede individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Ornamental foliage (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). Can smother ground cover and occur in some recreational areas. Plant may have minor effect on aesthetics and inhibit some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Plant has ‘well developed spines 5 to 10 mm long’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). Spines at most times of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Ornamental foliage and can smother ground cover (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). May have moderate visual effect if occurs at cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Thick mat of tuberous roots. Plant doesn’t die back and leave bare soil exposed. (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002).  May help to bind soil. Low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Smothers ground cover and can prevent regeneration of canopy species’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002), but also produces a large mass of underground tubers (Vivian-Smith et al. 2006). The large underground biomass is likely to increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: The mass of underground organs completely suppresses other species (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002), however flammability of this plant is unknown. Insufficient evidence to determine whether plant may alter fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Valley Grassy Forest (BCS =V); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Greater Grampians; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘The mass of underground organs, together with the numerous seedlings produced, completely suppresses other species’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). Major displacement of some dominant spp. within the lower strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Semi-arid woodland (BCS =D); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘The mass of underground organs, together with the numerous seedlings produced, completely suppresses other species’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). Major displacement of some dominant spp. within the lower strata.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowan Sands Mallee (BCS =LC); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
‘The mass of underground organs, together with the numerous seedlings produced, completely suppresses other species’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). Major displacement of some dominant spp. within the lower strata.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘The mass of underground organs, together with the numerous seedlings produced, completely suppresses other species’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). The area beneath mature asparagus fern can be devoid of other species (Breaden et al. 2006). Major effect on lower strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is a risk to threatened species in NSW (Downey 2006) but not documented to have an additional effect on threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: ‘The mass of underground organs, together with the numerous seedlings produced, completely suppresses other species’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). Effect on animals not documented although possible that the species may reduce habitat and food supply of non-threatened fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Berries are eaten by native birds (Breaden et al. 2006).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Weed produces spines (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2002). May be injurious to fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Species not documented as a food source to pest species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Species not documented as a food source to pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not documented as a weed of agriculture in references that would be expected to report this, vis: Parsons & Cuthbertson (2001) or the ‘Asparagus weeds best practise manual’ (DWLBC 2006).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not documented as a weed of agriculture in references that would be expected to report this, vis: Parsons & Cuthbertson (2001) or the ‘Asparagus weeds best practise manual’ (DWLBC 2006).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not documented as a weed of agriculture in references that would be expected to report this, vis: Parsons & Cuthbertson (2001) or the ‘Asparagus weeds best practise manual’ (DWLBC 2006).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not documented as a weed of agriculture in references that would be expected to report this, vis: Parsons & Cuthbertson (2001) or the ‘Asparagus weeds best practise manual’ (DWLBC 2006).

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not documented as a weed of agriculture in references that would be expected to report this, vis: Parsons & Cuthbertson (2001) or the ‘Asparagus weeds best practise manual’ (DWLBC 2006).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for disease of agriculture. Not documented in references that would be expected to report this, vis: Parsons & Cuthbertson (2002) or the ‘Asparagus weeds best practise manual’ (DWLBC 2006).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
“Several germination’s occur after late spring and summer rains or after irrigation”.

“In Australia, some seeds germinate out of season”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Bathurst burr grows best in open, unshaded areas”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades minor disturbed ecosystems, (e.g. lowland grassland and grassy woodland and rock outcrop vegetation).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect annual herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “In some areas stock seem to relish Bathurst burr seedlings…more mature Bathurst burr plants are not palatable to stock”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“Competes strongly with many summer crops”.

“Capable of forming extensive dominant stands under suitable conditions”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “It grows in drier conditions than Noogoora burr, but succumbs to water logging”.  Tolerates drought and frost (occurring in areas of Australia that experience both).  However assumed to tolerate some water logging as occurs in seasonal fresh water wetlands. (Carr et al 1992).  Also likely to tolerate some salinity as the closely related Noogoora burr is moderate to quite high.  (H & L 1995 p. 262).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
“Reproducing by seed”.

Male and female flowers on same plant.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
“Two seeds are produced in each burr”.

If 100 burrs per plant = 200 seeds per plant.  “About 150 burrs are produced per plant”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Some seed remains dormant in the soil for at least three years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Refer to ‘dispersal’ in P & C (1992 p. 319 & 320).

 animals, clothing and contaminated seeds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Well adapted for dispersal because the hooked spines on the burrs cling firmly to the wool or fur of animals…”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Erect annual herb usually to about 1 metre high. Thick burr patches in pastures eliminate almost all other species, and may be so dense (up to 30 plants per square metre) that sheep are denied access to watering points.” Similarly, because of the prickly nature of the plant, patches would restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “In Victoria …it exists on flood-prone areas along the [Murray River] and its tributaries. Xanthium spp. is spread widely along waterways.” Dense patches would affect some recreational activities such as boating or fishing in these situations.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The fruit is a “woody ellipsoid burr 1.2 to 2.5 cm long.” “The seed and seedlings are poisonous to animals…both species cause contact dermatitis in humans and the pollen may cause hay fever.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual impact and seriously affect the aesthetics of an area.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A competitive annual, “thick burr patches in pastures eliminate almost all other species.” Potential to leave areas of soil exposed to erosion. “In Australia, it thrives on the banks of rivers and creeks.” In these situations there may be off-site implications associated with soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “…these plants [are] strong competitors in both pasture and summer crops.” Direct replacement of biomass by invader.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Plants die in autumn, but remain standing. Dense patches may increase the intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Creekline grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential
It occurs along flood-prone areas of the Murray River and its tributaries. “Thick burr patches in pasture eliminate almost all other species.” Prefers unshaded situations. Major impact on grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; L CLIMATE potential
Prefers unshaded situations. Likely CLIMATE potential and forest situation would limit impact.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Noogoora burr can form very dense stands which are completely dominant and cover entire paddocks. Some forms prefer open communities and die out if shaded or crowded.” Major impact on lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In natural environments it is most likely to establish dense infestations in disturbed areas. It also tends to colonise in medium to large populations. In those situations, the presence of the weed would have a significant impact on the habitat of non-threatened fauna. Spiny nature of plant would deter grazing.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Small birds feed on the seeds.” Bird species not mentioned. Limited food source.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The plant has spines for most of the year. Potential for injury.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests. “The seeds and seedlings of both species are poisonous.”

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “These plants [are] strong competitors both in pasture and summer crops such as maize, cotton and soybeans.” Its presence in pasture seriously reduces carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Burrs contaminate wool reducing its value. “In 1978–79, between 7% and 8% of the wool sold in eastern Australia was contaminated with Noogoora burr.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The plant can be effectively controlled, but management programs can extend for more than six years to ensure the seed bank is exhausted. The cost of implementing such a program, plus the potential loss of income from reduced yields and quality, would likely have a negative impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: With an appropriate control program, land use would not need to change significantly. “Neither species is particularly important to cattle producers.” If the weed is left untreated, changing from sheep to cattle may be required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: The burrs “…damage carding machines.” The cost of processing contaminated wool increases. “…travelling stock must be inspected and any burrs removed.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “In North America, Noogoora burr is a host of two Sclerotinia pathogens which cause important diseases in soybeans. It is not known if it plays a similar role in Australia.” Potential host a threat to agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: In the field, seeds germinate in autumn and spring (HDRA 2006). Requires natural seasonal disturbances for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Described growing in shaded situations (Dore & McNeil 1980) and as invading forest (Carr et al 1992). Could establish under a moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: It is described as being one of worst pasture weeds of the high rainfall zone of Victoria dominating in lightly grazed pastures (Hill et al 1996), suggesting it can establish with minimum disturbance such as in well established pasture. Also described as invading grassland (Edgar & Connor 2000), grassy woodland, sclerophyll forest/woodland, heathland & heathy woodland, riparian and alpine & subalpine vegetation (Carr et al 1992). Establishes in relatively intact natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Life form: Grass (Batson 1998).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No evidence was found to suggest the presence of allelopathy within the species, or genus.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Under severe grazing, common bent will soon appear in grassland and within 5 years it can make up a significant proportion of the sward (Spedding 1966). Adapts to heavy grazing by growing close to ground level. Bent grass grows slowly over winter/ early spring producing little feed for stock, but in late spring/early summer bent grass produces excess feed of poor quality which is not utilised by stock (Batson 1998b). Appears to be only preferred and grazed for part of the year.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: A. castellana grows more vigorously by rhizomes than A. capillaris (Batson 1998) and is more competitive and chokes out ryegrass and clover (Batson 1998b). Grows slowly over cooler periods but in late spring and early summer produces excess feed (Batson 1998b). Although slow growing in Winter, the literature suggests overall growth would equal competitive species of the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Described as surviving waterlogged soils better than ryegrass and clover (Batson 1998b), dominating seasonally flooded grasslands (Sanchez & Peco 2004) and occurring in seasonal wetlands (Carr et al 1992). Hardy to European winters (Jones & Charles 1984) and occurs on subantarctic Islands (Clayton et al 2007). Not tolerant of salinity (Marcum 2004). Exhibits some tolerance to burning (HDRA 2006) probably due to rhizome system.  Likely to have some drought tolerance occurring in semi-arid grasslands (Vaquero et al 2003).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually by seed (Hill et al 1996) and vegetatively via rhizomes (Batson 1998).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Observed producing up to 298,000 seeds/m2 (Alexander 1995 in Batson 1999). It is likely that an individual plant would produce greater than 2,000 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Thompson et al. (1993) suggest that based on seed character, common bent seed is likely to persist for longer than 5 years. Seed buried at 13 cm depth retained 28 % viability after 4 years (Lewis 1973 in HDRA 2006)’.  Greater than 25% of seed may survive beyond 5 years

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: A perennial grass (Edgar & Forde 1991), therefore having the potential to produce propagules for several (3+) years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: As a grass (Batson 1998), time to reproductive maturity is presumed to be less than 2 years.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Spread by wind and attachment to animals (Carr et al 1992). Some seeds also likely to be accidentally ingested and dispersed internally by grazers (Janzen 1984).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Attachment and internal dispersal can spread seeds considerable distance (Janzen 1984), with free ranging introduced and native grazers able to disperse seeds greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Perennial grass of height 20-80 cm (Tutin et al 1980). There is no information to suggest that A. castellana would restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: There is no information to indicate it would reduce tourism, and as a grass species (Edgar & Forde 1991) it is not likely to be obvious as a weed to the ‘average’ visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Nothing was found in the literature to indicate that A. castellana possesses any injurious properties.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Perennial grass of height 20-80 cm (Tutin et al 1980). No information found to suggest it would cause damage to cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: As a terrestrial species it is unlikely to impact on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: As a terrestrial species it is unlikely to impact on water flow.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: It produces rhizomes (Batson 1998) so may decrease the probability of erosion in some situations.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: When displacing native vegetation (DECC 2004), there is potential for direct replacement of biomass, as it would most likely replace other grass species.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Produces thick dry mats of coarse grass that are very sensitive to fire (Bernaldez 1991). Potential to increase fire frequency in some of the less fire prone ecosystems it invades, with a likely varying level of impact.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains Grassland (BCS= E); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Described as a ‘very serious threat’ to several vegetation formations in Victoria (Carr et al 1992), and as displacing native vegetation (DECC 2004). Thick dry mats suppress annual herbs in pasture (Bernaldez 1991) and a similar affect is likely in natural systems, as it is documented dominating large areas of permanent grassland (Hubbard 1968). Potential for major displacement of some dominant species within the ground layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Grassy Dry Forest (BCS= D); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Central Victorian Uplands; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Described as a ‘very serious threat’ to several vegetation formations in Victoria (Carr et al 1992) and as displacing native vegetation (DECC 2004). Thick dry mats suppress annual herbs in pasture (Bernaldez 1991) and a similar affect is likely in natural systems, as it is documented dominating large areas of permanent grassland (Hubbard 1968). Potential for major displacement of some dominant species within the ground layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC= Coastal Tussock Grassland (BCS= LC); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH. Described as a ‘very serious threat’ to several vegetation formations in Victoria (Carr et al 1992) and as displacing native vegetation (DECC 2004). Thick dry mats suppress annual herbs in pasture (Bernaldez 1991) and a similar affect is likely in natural systems, as it is documented dominating large areas of permanent grassland (Hubbard 1968). Potential for major displacement of some dominant species within the ground layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Displaces native vegetation (DECC 2004). Thick dry mats suppress annual herbs in pasture (Bernaldez 1991) and a similar affect is likely in natural systems, as it is documented dominating large areas of permanent grassland (Hubbard 1968). Potential for major effect on <60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Described as a ‘very serious threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria’ (Carr et al 1992) and as displacing native vegetation (DECC 2004). Its affect specific to threatened flora was not described.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Described as a ‘very serious threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria’ (Carr et al 1992) and as displacing native vegetation (DECC 2004). Its affect on native flora is likely to lead to reduced habitat availability, however the possible impact on native fauna was not documented.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Though described as having relatively low agricultural value (Hubbard 1968) and only nutritious to stock for part of the year (Hill et al 1996) it is likely to provide some food source to native grazing animals such as macropods.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No information to suggest it would be injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Grazed by rabbits (Gillham 1955 in HDRA 2006). Supplies food to one serious pest.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not described providing harbour to pests, and unlikely to being a relatively low growing grass (Tutin et al 1980).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: ‘…bent grass has become one of the worst pasture weeds of the high rainfall zone of Victoria. It was estimated to dominate over 1 million hectares (Siefert 1971) and, after rapid spread recently the authors consider that it now restricts production on a further 1 million hectares (Hill et al. 1996)’. ‘It is not unusual for a perennial ryegrass and phalaris pasture dominated by bent grass to have its capacity to produce meat, milk or wool reduced by one third (Lamp et al …). Potential to decrease yield by >20%

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No information found to suggest it would impact on the quality of agricultural yield.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Described as one of the worst pasture weeds of the high rainfall zone of Victoria (Hill et al 1996), it could affect the land value of grazing properties due to its capacity to restrict production, however, no specific reference was found in the literature.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: As a serious pasture weed (Hill et al 1996), and with significant effort and outlay required to renovate infested pastures (Batson 1998b), some pastures would be utilised less than others and there is potential for a downgrade of their priority land use to occur to one with less agricultural return.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: It is recommended that heavily infested pasture >40%), undergo full renovation consisting of cutting, spraying, cultivating, re-sowing and fertilising (Batson 1998b), resulting in considerable time and cost outlay. In addition because stocking capacity is significantly reduced (Hill et al 1996), increased time allocation for stock movement would also be required. Potential for major increase in production costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not found, described as a host of agricultural disease or vector.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate throughout the year if moisture is adequate.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy, occurs in forests (e.g. coniferous overstorey).  Uses its viney stems to move into sunlight (FEIS).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in minor disturbed natural ecosystems, e.g. riparian vegetation, shrubland, grassland.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A prostrate trailing and twining perennial herb.  Creeper.  Also geophytic.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Strongly Allelopathic to such plants as Prince-of-Wales feather, Amaranthus sp.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Has little fodder value out of its native range.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Strong competitor with cereal crops, orchards, and vineyards – may even kill such vegetation.  One of the 10 worst weeds in the world.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to moisture stress, water logging, however, stated as being ‘quickly killed by water logging’ (Agriculture Protection Board 1993).  Occurs in riparian areas, wet meadow margins, etc.), frost (although foliage may die, rhizomes resprout), fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed and from roots.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Up to 500 seeds are produced per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: 80% seeds remain dormant in soil for at least 20 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms heavy infestations (monocultures).  See pics, P & C (1992) p. 398.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants may not flower in the first year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Contaminated fodder, machinery, grain, animals including birds, animal manure, cultivation equipment.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Migratory birds have been implicated in long distance dispersal.  “Seeds fall near the parent plant but can be transported by water or birds.  Seeds remain viable in the stomachs of migrating Kildeer for up to 144 hours, and can pass through animals with little or no damage.  Quail may retain the seed for 24 hours, ducks 5, and geese 19, lesser yellowlegs 6 hours.  (Lyons 1998).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A prostrate trailing and twining perennial herb. Would present minimal impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: A strong competitor it can dominate in open areas. However, its prostrate form would not seriously affect recreation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No toxic principles or harmful physical properties.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The plant has a vigorous root system that, “…also allows shoots to push through asphalt paths.” This vigour could also have some impact on the structure of cultural sites or features.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. Does not survive in waterlogged situations.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Perennial with tap root to three metres deep and numerous horizontal roots between 0.6 to 2 metres deep. Would not increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Occurring predominantly in agricultural situations where it, “…eliminates more valuable pasture species and smothers cereal crops.” Invader directly replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aerial growth dies off in autumn. In cropping situation, dry matter left with remnant material from harvest. Likely to have little effect on changing fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
The plant has a dominant growth habit in pasture and cultivated areas. While not a significant weed of natural ecosystems, where it does occur, it is likely to dominate the ground flora in low quality, open grassland areas. It does not grow well under the shade of other plants. Major effect on ground-flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Herb-rich heathy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
The plant has a dominant growth habit in pasture and cultivated areas. It does not grow well under the shade of other plants. Minor effect on ground flora/forbs in this EVC.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
The plant has a dominant growth habit in pasture and cultivated areas. It does not grow well under the shade of other plants. Minor effect on ground flora/forbs in this EVC.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: The plant has a dominant growth habit in pasture and cultivated areas. While not a significant weed of natural ecosystems, where it does occur, it is likely to dominate the ground flora in low quality, open grassland areas. It does not grow well under the shade of other plants. Likely to affect 20–60% of the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “It occurs on roadsides, railway lines, and neglected areas in both urban and rural areas.” Its effect on the habitat of native fauna would be minimal.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The plant is eaten by stock and may provide some food source to native herbivores. However, it is regarded as having little fodder value.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “It may be toxic or emetic and is suspected of causing photosensitisation in susceptible animals and of poisoning pigs after eating the roots.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Birds are a known vector for seed, however, bird species are not recorded. Assume potential for pest species to forage

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The aerial parts of the plant die back in autumn leaving little cover for harbor. May provide limited harbor for mice or other small rodents during growth and flowering stages.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “It is a strong competitor with cereal crops in North America where crop reductions of 30% to 40% are not uncommon. In some years Kansas wheat and Canadian grain sorghum are reduced by 80%.”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Seeds contaminate grain for sowing, particularly wheat.” Plants can produce up to 500 seeds. Likely to have at least a minor impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The plant seriously affects yield and it requires a concerted control program for several years to eradicate it. This would have a negative influence on price, depending upon type of agricultural activity.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “In California…some areas had been abandoned because of the weed.”

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “The long stems twine through the maturing crop, which makes harvesting difficult or impossible.” Significant potential for increase harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “It is an alternative host for a number of viruses… and hosts several arthropods and nematodes of agricultural importance.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds mostly germinate in spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in orchards, forest plantations and bushland where it would be shaded by overstorey species.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Weed of bushland.  “Blackberry rarely invades virgin bushland but establishes most readily on disturbed sites”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Scrambling shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not readily consumed by sheep and cattle but is consumed by goats.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Few other plants can compete and blackberry completely dominates the vegetation of an area in a very short time”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to water logging, frost (occurs above snow line).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by seed root suckers and layering.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: > 2,000 seeds/plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms self-sustaining dense monocultures.  (See picture P & C 1992 p. 579).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: 2+ years.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Birds, foxes, creeks and rivers.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “In one study an average of 570 seeds were recovered from fox droppings and 2,460 from EMU droppings”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Blackberry forms dense, impenetrable thickets…often along watercourses.” Presents a major impediment to both human and vehicular traffic.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “It is the bane of bushwalkers and fishing enthusiasts.” Its dense form can seriously affect recreational pursuits.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Canes, which can grow up to seven metres in lengths, are covered in large, sharp prickles. Dead canes remain attached to the crown indefinitely. This presents a constant hazard to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Although forming dense thickets, the root system is not extensive or highly vigorous. The plant is unlikely to cause structural damage to cultural features or structures, but would have a moderate visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant was initially recommended for soil stabilisation on riverbanks, but, “lack of other vegetation can eventually destabilised an area.” Potential for high probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Many plants become deciduous during the cooler months and, as a dominant species, it would potentially decrease biomass. “As much as 70% of the mass of the clump may consist of dead canes.”

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “As much as 70% of the mass of the clump may consist of dead canes…and large clumps are a considerable fire hazard.”

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
“…blackberry completely dominates the vegetation of an area in a very short time. Regeneration of native plants is seriously impeded.” Monoculture.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential
“…blackberry completely dominates the vegetation of an area in a very short time. Regeneration of native plants is seriously impeded.” Monoculture within mid stratum

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (LC); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential
“…blackberry completely dominates the vegetation of an area in a very short time. Regeneration of native plants is seriously impeded.” Monoculture within mid stratum.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “…it covers large areas with a dense canopy excluding light from the soil surface. Few other plants can compete and blackberry completely dominates the vegetation of an area in a very short time. Regeneration of native plants is seriously impeded.” Monoculture, or close enough!

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Threatens ANZECC rated rare or threatened native plant species

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Because of its spreading habit, dominant nature, and spiny canes, it reduces the habitat for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The native birds crimson rosella (Platycercus elegans), and the red browed finch (Neochima temporalis), and emus (Dromaius novaehollandiae) feed on the berries.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Thorns are a problem for grazing animals.” A similar situation would exist for native fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The berries are a food source for foxes and the introduced starling (Sturnus vulgaris L.) and blackbird (Turdus merula L.).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: It provides harbor for rabbits, foxes and snakes.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “In agricultural production the main industries affected are grazing and forestry.” Production of timber in forest plantations is reduced…natural regeneration of hardwood plantations can be prevented or reduced. Heavy infestations in pastures reduce carrying capacity because of access limitations and reduced availability of fodder.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No recorded level of impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Its ability to significantly reduce available pasture, and the high cost and time taken to control the plant suggest that land prices would be affected by more than 10%. “Some property values have been substantially decreased, due to heavy infestations of blackberry across the property.”

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: While heavy infestations limit carrying capacity, grazing of canes and stem damage through stock movement reduces tip-rooting and thus slow the spread of the plant. Paddocks can still be used, but with limited return. Neglected farming areas can be totally over-run with blackberry, effectively rendering the land useless.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: The plant is recorded as occurring in orchards, however, no evidence exists of the impact on harvest costs. Not a significant weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect perennial herb to 20 to 90 cm high. A common plant of meadows in its native range, it has little impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The plant is not likely to affect recreational activities. Its presence may a have a minor effect on the aesthetics of an area.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: It does not have any spines or burrs, nor is the plant toxic. The roots and seeds have been used ancient European medicines.
