social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: C. nigra has been shown to be aggressive and invasive in pastures and meadows. Its presence would create a moderate visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant is aggressive and competes well against grasses, and the aerial parts of the plant die off in autumn. It has the potential to leave areas of bare soil, possibly resulting in erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Replaces grass species. Little or no change in biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Competes well against grasses. Similar fire potential as displaced vegetation. Little change to frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
It is an aggressive and invasive species in pastures and meadows in the U.S. Potential to seriously affect grasses and ground covers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Similar impact as in 10(a) above. More commonly occurs in open areas (roadsides, pasture, waste places). Therefore, population density may be restricted by overstorey cover.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Similar impact as in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: It invades overgrazed or underdeveloped pastures, and there is evidence that the plants produce allelopathic compounds reducing germination and early seedling development of some other species. It may have a major negative impact on the lower stratum. In the U.S., it is aggressive and invasive in pastures and meadows.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Not known as a serious weed of natural ecosystems in Victoria (it is not recorded in Carr et al (1992)). Its presence in pastures reduces carrying capacity. Assume its presence would also reduce available food for non-threatened fauna

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No known toxic principles.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source for pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A perennial herb with erect stems and narrow leaves; the aerial parts die back leaving little vegetative cover. Unlikely to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Its presence in pasture reduces the carrying capacity. Considered to be allelopathic. Competes well against grasses.

Considered a serious crop weed, but impact in cropping situations not known. In the U.S., it is known as aggressive, invasive species, particularly in pastures and meadows.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No known impact on quality of harvest/produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “It was first recorded in Victoria in 1910 and now occurs in limited infestations.” Likely to be little or no change in land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The recommended method of control is to use herbicides; cultivation is not effective. Land used for grazing purposes may be restricted while control activities undertaken. Temporary loss of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence of increasing harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Taylor (1997) showed highest seed germination at 15oC and no germination occurring at 25oC, which corresponds to temperatures in the field when rainfall is at its highest, indicating a requirement of natural seasonal disturbances for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can grow in part shade (Blood 2001) and known to invade several forest communities (Carr et al 1992). Could establish under moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Germination is reported to occur in Autumn, especially after fire or another disturbance. The seeds are not dependent on fire for germination however (Blood 2001).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Twining climber or dense scrambling shrub (Muyt 2001).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Nothing grows under canopies and this is likely due to allelopathy (R. Adair pers.com.).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Although it is documented not to mature in regularly grazed pasture (White 2007), Taylor (1997) found that in natural ecosystems herbivore damage of plants was extremely low.
Consumed but not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Although seedlings are described as initially slow growing as an extensive root system forms (Blood 2001) it is otherwise documented as growing rapidly (Blood 2001, Strickland 1990) especially after fire (R. Adair pers. comm., Muyt 2001). Overall available information suggests at least a moderately rapid growth rate.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought, frost to -5oC (Blood 2001) and in WA (B. heterophylla) inhabits saline soils and occurs around inland salt lakes (Cayzer et al 2004). Although most established plants are killed by hot fire, low intensity fires enhance invasion (Taylor 1997) and fire triggers germination and rapid growth (White 2007, Muyt 2001).  Highly tolerant of at least two stresses. Tolerance to water logging not found documented.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduction is by seed and regeneration from root segments (Blood 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Fruits contain up to 80 seeds (Taylor 1997). Images indicate that a single plant could produce above 2000 propagules.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Seeds are reported to remain viable for at least 5 years although this requires confirmation (Hill 1997)’.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Has the ability to convert large areas to a near monoculture (Hill 1997) with large colonies many metres across being formed purely by vegetative means (Blood 2001). Potential to form self-sustaining monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Rapid growth following fire initiates flowering and fruiting within 12-24 months (White 2007). Produces propagules between 1-2 years after germination.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Spread by birds, animals including foxes and dumped garden waste (Blood 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Its spread by birds and foxes (Blood 2001) is likely to disperse some seeds greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: ‘Blue-bell creeper scrambles to head height on middle storey plants forming an almost impenetrable barrier that is difficult to treat or transverse with equipment (Hill 1997)’. High nuisance value, people access with difficulty.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: ‘Blue-bell creeper scrambles to head height on middle storey plants forming an almost impenetrable barrier that is difficult to treat or transverse with equipment (Hill 1997)’. There is a possibility of it having a minor affect on recreational use if it grew across walking paths. It is also described as forming large colonies (Blood 2001), that could impact on the aesthetics of an area.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: ‘It contains toxins, which can cause skin irritation and nausea, so it is important that gloves are worn when handling’. Mildly toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Though not specifically documented, as a climbing species that can reach up to 4 metres in height (DNRE 2002), there is potential for it to have a moderate visual affect on the aesthetics of a cultural site or infrastructure.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: As a terrestrial species it is unlikely to impact on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: As a terrestrial species it is unlikely to impact on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘It affects sites on slopes and with loss of biodiversity as a result of invasion this could lead to increased erosion risks e.g. at Arthur’s seat (R. Adair pers. com.)’. Its ability to smother and eliminate other vegetation (Muyt 2001, DNRE 1997) particularly those with extensive root systems, could lead to an increase in soil erosion, especially as it often inhabits coastal areas (Muyt 2001). It has the potential to impact on erosion but the extent of its impact is unclear.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Appears to increase biomass in communities due to development of heavily tangled shrub layer (R. Adair pers. com.).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: ‘Likely to increase fire risk due to increase in fine fuel loads (R. Adair pers. com.)’. This species invades many diverse ecosystems with varying fire regimes. An increase in fine fuel loads could cause a moderate change to both fire frequency and intensity. For example in a ‘shrubby wet forest’ habitat (White 2007), it could moderately increase fire frequency but decrease fire intensity.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Large colonies many metres across can be formed (Blood 2001) and isolated plants can develop into aggressive invading fronts that smother all vegetation in their path, forming virtual monocultures (Taylor 1997, Hill 1997).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Large colonies many metres across can be formed (Blood 2001) and isolated plants can develop into aggressive invading fronts that smother all vegetation in their path, forming virtual monocultures (Taylor 1997, Hill 1997).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Large colonies many metres across can be formed (Blood 2001) and isolated plants can develop into aggressive invading fronts that smother all vegetation in their path, forming virtual monocultures (Taylor 1997, Hill 1997).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
Large colonies many metres across can be formed (Blood 2001) and isolated plants can develop into aggressive invading fronts that smother all vegetation in their path, forming virtual monocultures (Taylor 1997, Hill 1997).
Can impact on all strata including tree stratum due to lower availability of niches for seedling establishment (R. Adair pers.com.).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: White (1997) identified 45 flora taxa that are threatened by habitat alteration as a result of invasion through direct competition for regeneration sites, light, water and space. However, no description of its specific impact on individual threatened flora species was documented.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: White (1997) identifies that habitat alteration as a result of invasion threatens fauna, through structural degradation, changed fire regimes, trophic disintegration, and loss of prey or food plants. Reduction in habitat and food source would likely lead to a reduction in the number of individuals in a population.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: ‘A range of fauna including frugivorous birds, mammals and possibly reptiles (Bachmann and Johnson in prep) disperse seeds (White 2007)’. Likely to provide some assistance as a food source to desirable fauna species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No reference was found in the literature to suggest that this species possesses any properties injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Foxes are described as a seed disperser (Blood 2001, White 2007). Provides food to one serious pest species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The nature of its habit suggests it is unlikely to provide harbour for serious pests like rabbits or foxes, and no information was found documented to indicate that it provides harbour for any minor pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: B. heterophylla is not described as a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: B. heterophylla is not described as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: B. heterophylla is not described as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: B. heterophylla is not described as a weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: B. heterophylla is not described as a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: B. heterophylla is not described as a weed of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: No information in the literature outlines the germination requirements for this grass.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Phalaris spp. grasses are able to establish on a wide range of soil types including soils in low rainfall areas and poorly drained soils subject to occasional inundation (Anderton et al, 1999). P. coerulescens is commonly noted in the literature to establish in moist well drained soils (Colegate et al, 1999) and living in slightly wet soils (Herbario Virtual). In Victoria, it is associated with native and exotic grasses on disused pasture (Walsh and Entwisle 1994). For successful establishment the species seems to primarily require moist soils but may have the capacity to establish in drier areas. The ability to grow in disused pasture suggests that it can establish under moderate cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
When the species was first found and identified in Australia it was associated with native and exotic grasses on disused pastures (Walsh and Entwisle, 1994). In its native, Mediterranean Europe, it is usually found along rivers, lakes and streams or in damp depressions (McLaren and Turner, 1999; Colegate et al, 1999). It has also been found to establish in waste areas, path and road sides, disturbed zones, edges of cultivated fields, cultivated ground/fields, along field boarders and mainly on clay soils with periodic inundation (Baldini, 1995; Herbario
Virtual; Tutin et al, 1980). It is noted as a minor component of pastures in several areas of Victoria and is reported to be present in NSW and NT (Blackstock). The species is able to establish in relatively disturbed areas and has been more commonly attributed to establishing in pasture, not cultivated fields in Australia.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: It is a hemicryptophyte grass belonging to the family Poaeace/Gramineae (Baldini, 1995; GRIN, Herbario virtual). The adult plants grow to heights of 30-150 cm tall (Davis, 1985; McLaren and Turner, 1999).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: After all the literature reviewed there was no reference to any allelopathy properties relating to the species.  However little information exists on this species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Grazed by horses, sheep and cattle (Colegate et al, 1999). Arevalo et al (2007) conducted a study in pastures in its native Tenerife under a goat grazing management system found that P. coerulescens was the dominant species. It is noted as a minor component of pastures in several areas of Victoria and is reported to be present in NSW and NT (Blackstock). It is a pasture grass that is able to persist within moderate grazing systems.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: The plant undergoes rapid germination with vigorous seed growth and high production in its seedling year (Anderton et al, 1999, Colegate et al, 1999). It has been noted to be similar to the growth rate of native and exotic grasses on disused pastures (Walsh and Entwisle 1994). It is a rapid growing, competitive species with other perennial grasses.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: The plant establishes in slightly wet soils near waterways (Under Control, 1999; Baldini, 1995, McLaren and Turner, 1999). Furthermore the genus is likened to establish in areas that receive regular inundation (Anderton et al, 1999). Therefore the species may have a degree of tolerance to waterlogging. No information on other tolerances was found.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The grass reproduces by seed. Seeds are 2-4 mm long and 0.7-1.4 mm wide (McLaren and Turner, 1999; Undercontrol, 1999). Plants are bisexual and flowers from September to December. The Phalaris genera has been described as being bisexual with bisexual spikelet with hermaphrodite florets with the spikelets of sexually distinct forms on the same plant (rarely), or all alike in sexuality (Watson and Dallwitz, 1985). The species is sexual with either cross and/or self pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: 6-8 fertile spikelets falling from panicle when mature (Davis, 1985) fruit is dry seed-like fruit (grain). However it is difficult to determine from the available literature on the species biology on how many propagules the grass produces.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: No information was found in the literature.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: After all of the literature reviewed no information on the reproductive period of the grass was found.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: After all of the literature reviewed no information time to reproductive maturity of the grass was found.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Escape from cultivation in the Armidale area (Harden, 1993). Possible introduction into Victoria as an accidental contaminant of stock fodder (McLaren and Turner, 1999). Suggesting that it is likely that the seed has been dispersed by humans possibly unintentionally such as, through the transport of hay containing seeds from one property to another (Bladstock). Also dispersal through vehicles may also be implicated. Other dispersal mechanisms of the species have not been discussed in the literature reviewed.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: No information in the literature that explains seed dispersal of this species.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: The grass grows in tufts or clumps with tubers at base of stem generally above ground (Herbarium usu). The adult plant grows to heights of 30-150 cm tall (Davis, 1985; McLaren and Turner, 1999). The plant may not prevent human access but may be of a low nuisance value.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The adult plant grows to heights of 30-150 cm tall (Davis, 1985; McLaren and Turner, 1999). Therefore infestations of the species may have minor effects to aesthetics and most recreational activities will not be inhibited. The plants toxicity to horses (Bourke et al, 2003) may reduce horse related recreation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Of the literature consulted (Harden, G. 1993; McLaren, and Turner, 1999; Muyt A., 2001) none mentioned the grass being injurious to humans. Not known to be injurious to people, no prickles, spines or toxins present.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The adult plant grows to heights of 30-150 cm tall (Davis, 1985; McLaren and Turner, 1999) suggesting that height of the plant is likely to have a moderate visual effect in densely infested areas. However no reported effect or damage to cultural sites was found.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Despite the grass being often found near streams and lakes the species is terrestrial (Colgate et al, 1999) and is not known to invade the waterbody or streambed.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Despite the grass being often found near streams and lakes the species is terrestrial (Colgate et al, 1999) and is not known to invade or have any effect on the waterbody or streambed. No measurable effect on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
The grass grows in tufts or clumps (Herbarium usu). The adult plants grow to heights of 30-150 cm tall (Davis, 1985; McLaren and Turner, 1999). It is a species that commonly invades already disturbed eroded areas such as disturbed pastures edges of cultivated fields and roadsides (Baldini, 1995; Herbario Virtual; Tutin et al, 1980).
Existing with other native and exotic grasses (Walsh and Entwisle 1994). It has the potential to dominate grasslands and pastures as experienced in Mediterranean grasslands (Troumbis et al, 2000). Therefore it is likely that the species can replace and displace exiting species of a similar life form and in the highly disturbed areas it colonises may contribute to soil stability.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Other Phalaris species (such as P. acquatica and P. paradoxa) are known to increase the biomass and fuel load of introduced areas. On the basis that P. coerulescens is closely related with both particularly P. paradoxa (Bourke et al, 2003; Davis, 1985; Richardson et al, 2006) it may have the capacity to displace other species and dominate infested areas, in turn increasing fuel load and biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Other Phalaris species are known to have a higher fuel load than the original native grasses (CFA, 2004). Phalaris species have a fuel load of 27.5 tonnes/hectare compared to 2.9 t/h for kangaroo grass (CFA, 2004). On this basis, dense stands of P.coerulescens increase biomass and fuel hazard and are likely to have a minor affect more so on fire intensity than frequency.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains Grassy Woodland (E); CMA=Port Phillip and Westernport; Bioregion= Victorian Volcanic Plains; VH Climate potential.  
Reported to grow in association with native and exotic grasses (Walsh and Entwisle 1994) some displacement and possible dominance due to it being a persistence and productive grass species (Anderton et al, 1999). It has the potential to dominate grasslands and pastures as experienced in Mediterranean grasslands (Troumbis et al, 2000).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC= Grassy Dry Forest (D); CMA= Port Phillip and Westernport; Bioregion= Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH = Climate potential. Reported to grow in association with native and exotic grasses (Walsh and Entwisle 1994) some displacement and possible dominance due to it being a persistence and productive grass species (Anderton et al, 1999). It has the potential to dominate grasslands and pastures as experienced in Mediterranean grasslands (Troumbis et al, 2000).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Forest (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioregion= Glenelg Plain; MED Climate potential.
Reported to grow in association with native and exotic grasses (Walsh and Entwisle 1994) in moist well drained soils (Colegate et al, 1999). Some displacement and possible dominance due to it being a persistence and productive grass species (Anderton et al, 1999). It has the potential to dominate grasslands and pastures as experienced in Mediterranean grasslands (Troumbis et al, 2000).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Growing up to 150 cm affecting mainly the lower stratum and may have a minimal affect on the lower end of the mid stratum. Reported to be a competitive species therefore associated with other grass species (Under Control, 1999). The species has been found to be a persistence and productive grass species (Anderton et al, 1999). It has the potential to dominate grasslands and pastures as experienced in Mediterranean grasslands (Troumbis et al, 2000), suggesting that it can become a dominant species of the lower strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The impact on threatened flora is indeterminable

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Strong circumstantial evidence suggests that P.coerulescens is fatal to horses (Bourke et al, 2003). Sheep, goat and cattle seem to be unaffected by the species (Bourke et al, 2003). It can provide an alternate food source for livestock similar to other cultivated Phalaris species (Watson et al, 2000). It contains six alkaloids that may make it unpalatable to natives. No reports of toxicity to natives. The species can have a minor impact on structure and habitat and availability of food resources.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: May provide an alternate, reliable food source for livestock or native animals. Particularly because it can tolerate herb pressure (Colegate et al, 1999). Areas of high infestations in combination with other grass species may provide cover for native animals (e.g. bandicoots).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Contains toxic alkaloids poisonous to horses (Bourke et al, 2003). Alkaloids may render it unpalatable to native fauna. Found to have little or no effect on cattle and sheep but found that horses are most susceptible to poisoning once plant has been ingested due to the presence in P.coerulescens of methylated tryptamine and related beta- carboline alkaloids (Bourke et al, 2003). At the moment strong circumstantial evidence suggests that these deaths are associated with P. coerulescens. Toxicity to horses may suggest that it can have the same effect on native fauna however no reported effects on native fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Can be a food source to goats. In its native range Arevalo et al (2007) studied P.coerulescens dominated pastures under a goat grazing system.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Growing to heights of up to 150 cm (Davis, 1985; McLaren and Turner, 1999) large, dense infestations may provide temporary harbour to major pest specie such as rabbits. However nothing has been documented in the literature.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: P. coerulescens in its native range it is a known weed of cultivated fields (Baldini, 1995). The closely related P. paradoxa is a serious weed of cereal crops (Bourke et al, 2003). According to Global Compendium of Weeds it is considered an agricultural weed. In Portugal P. coerulescens amongst other Phalaris species infest a wide variety of crops but principally cereals and uncropped land (Costa, 1981). However in Australia it has not yet been documented as a weed of cultivated fields. Due to the similarities P.coerulescens shares with P. paradoxa (Bourke et al, 2003; Davis, 1985) it is possible that P. coerulescens can potentially invade cultivated fields (pers comm. David McLaren) however the impact is not yet known.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: A known weed of cultivated pastures. However there is no information in the literature that indicates how this species impacts on the quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: A known weed of cultivated pastures (Baldini, 1995) however there is no information in the literature describing how this species could affect land values.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Due to toxicity to horses (Bourke et al, 2003) can change grazing system of pastures and subsequently land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Currently not a documented weed of cultivated pastures in Australia. There is no evidence that suggests that this species currently requires a control regime outside normal weed management

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Benigno and Brook (1972) reported P. coerulescens as a host for the Cocksfoot Mottle Virus. They are viruses transmitted by beetles prevalent in the Gramineae. Its closely related species P. paradoxa is susceptible to a number of viruses including barley stripe mosaic hordeivirus, maize dwarf mosaic potyvirus, and sugarcane mosaic potyvirus (Brunt et al, 1996). Diseases identified and prevalent in Phalaris species, that may affect P. coerulescens, include Ergot and Stem rust, Grass downy mildew fungus, wheat eye spot fungus, powdery mildew and a new disease identified in Victoria, Stagonospora foliicola (Watson and Bourke, 2000).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germinates in autumn and flowers in spring-summer (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Requires natural seasonal conditions.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: No information available regarding C. creticum although C. officinale (the most closely related species which is also biennial herb found in same habitats) is shade tolerant and can occur in areas of thick litter accumulation (USFS 2003). As C. creticum can also occur in open woodlands, assume it too can establish under a moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades grasslands. Most commonly grows on disturbed sites such as roadsides, sand dunes or open woodlands, where it establishes and spreads quickly’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Although prefers disturbed sites, can establish in minor disturbed natural ecosystem.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A biennial herb (USFS 2003) – life form – other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘ leaves contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids that kill cattle and horses. ‘.. insects tend to avoid the plant because of the alkaloids in its leaves’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Favoured by heavy grazing as not eaten by animals

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Invades grasslands and suppresses native grasses’. ‘Seedlings are fast growing’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Assume that plant will equal competitive species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘Fire probably top-kills hounds tongue plants’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). C. officinale, a closely related species, does not tolerate waterlogging and is frost susceptible (USFS 2003).  Insufficient information available on C. creticum. Score as medium

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: ‘Spreads by seeds’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Does not vegetatively reproduce. No evidence in literature to suggest if self or cross-pollinates.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘ .. mature plants each producing several hundred [seeds]’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Likely that plant produces between 50 to 1,000 propagules per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Plant dies after flowering, but seeds may stay attached until the following spring, delaying germination for a year’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Viability is two to three years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘Lifecycle that is completed in two years or seasons, with the second season usually devoted to flowering and fruiting’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Lifecycle that is completed in two years or seasons, with the second season usually devoted to flowering and fruiting’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘In North America cattle and wildlife are important dispersers of the closely related C. officinale .. likely also to be the case in Australia’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Seeds may be transported by animals or people into disturbed areas where they find suitable conditions for germination.’

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Spread long distances attached to people or animals’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: ‘Although flowers have hooks, the plants only grow up to 600 mm high’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Weed would have a minimal or negligible impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Grows up to 600 mm high and typically occurs on roadsides, pastures, grasslands. Plant also has hooks (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Visitor may be aware of weed but not bothered or activity not inhibited.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: ‘Flowers are covered in hooks’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). These hooks can attach to people at certain times of year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Not likely to cause damage to cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Plant has long taproot. Although the plant dies off after flowering and may leave some of the ground exposed, (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003) low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘It invades grasslands and suppresses native grasses’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Grows up to 600 mm high so likely that biomass will increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Plants die off after flowering. Invades grasslands and suppresses native grasses. Weed may have small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC= Damp sands herb rich woodland (V); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Lowland; CLIMATE potential=VH. ‘Invades grasslands and suppresses native grasses’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Minor displacement of some dominant species within the groundcover layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Valley grassy forest (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Upland; CLIMATE potential=VH.
‘Invades grasslands and suppresses native grasses’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within the groundcover layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC= Coastal Banksia Woodland (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Lowland; CLIMATE potential=VH. ‘Invades grasslands and suppresses native grasses’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Minor displacement of some dominant species within the groundcover layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘Invades grasslands and suppresses native grasses’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). When occurring in open areas where only one stratum present likely to have a minor effect on greater than 60% of the layers (MH). In open woodlands, likely to have a minor effect on 20-60% of the floral strata (ML). Therefore score as medium.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Weed is mostly a pasture weed so greatest impact on domesticated animals (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Horses may be especially affected when restricted to small, infested area without other desirable forage’ (Graham & Johnson 2003). Weed may have a minor effect on fauna spp.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Weed not documented to provide benefit to indigenous fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Leaves are toxic to livestock. ‘Plant has burrs that attach to cattle, causing irritation’. ‘Leaves contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids that kill cattle and horses’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known to be a food source to pests

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbour for pest spp.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: ‘Grazing and dairy farms throughout [humid temperate and subhumid zones of Australia] would potentially be affected by a loss of pasture and stock’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Potential to have a major impact on quantity of produce (5-20%).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: C. officinale (a closely related species) also has prickly seeds which ‘ are very hard to remove after they cling to animals, thus lowering the wool value of sheep’. If the leaves of C. creticum are contained in hay or chopped forage, then possible that the cattle and horses will die if they eat it. Leaves have a serious toxicity effect (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Likely to have a major impact on quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No evidence to suggest the weed will affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not known to cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence to suggest the weed will increase the cost of harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for disease.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at any time of year but mostly in autumn”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in forested areas (e.g. wet sclerophyll forests), where it would receive shading from overstorey Eucalypts.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Boneseed, however is a weed because of its ability to establish in areas of native vegetation, whether disturbed or not.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A perennial shrub

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “There is recent evidence that boneseed exercises an allelopathic effect on some native species.  Leaf litter and fruit leaches inhibit the germ and growth of some species”.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
“Seedlings of boneseed are eaten by rabbits”.

“Boneseed does not persist when grazed or trampled by stock nor when cultivated”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “There is dense growth of seedling after fire which swamps out other species”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of frost (occurs in South Tasmania): drought (occurs in Mallee).

“It is not restricted by climate, tolerates saline conditions”.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
“Reproducing by seed”.

“Also reproduces by stem layering and some plants will re sprout after fires or *

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Seed production is prolific and up to 50,000 seeds per plant per year have been recorded”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seed of ssp: Monilifera is longer lived and retains a high viability for 4-5 years at least”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Plants live for 10-20 years”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants are at least 18 months and sometimes 3 years old before flowering”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Birds have been a major agent of spread because they readily eat the fleshy fruit and either pass or regurgitate the seed in a viable condition”.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Birds and other agents could disperse seeds > 1 km

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
Shrub 1 to 3 metres high and wide. It is highly invasive in many ecosystems including coastal dunes, and can dominate vegetation. 

“Dense stands can restrict recreational activities.”

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dominant presence of weed and difficulty in accessing recreational facilities would have a major impact on tourism.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No prickles, spines or burrs. The fruit is edible.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: It is a shallow rooted plant with no distinct taproot. Infestations would seriously affect the aesthetics of a cultural site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. It does not tolerate waterlogged soils.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Originally planted to stabilise disturbed sandy soils (due to sandmining). Dense, broad evergreen cover protects soil from wind erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: It dominates native species such as Acacia longifolia (>2 m height), Correa alba  (1.5 m height) , Leucopogon parviflorus  (2 m height), potentially increasing biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No data available that suggests infestations change the fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
“Dense stands [of C. monilifera] eliminate most indigenous ground-flora and prevent virtually all overstorey regeneration.” Displaces species across all strata with major impact on ground-flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Valley grassy forest (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential
“…its ability to establish in areas of native vegetation ranging from mallee scrub to wet sclerophyll forests.”

“Dense stands [of C. monilifera] eliminate most indigenous ground-flora and prevent virtually all overstorey regeneration.” Displaces species across all strata with major impact on ground-flora.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Lowlands; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dense stands [of C. monilifera] eliminate most indigenous ground-flora and prevent virtually all overstorey regeneration.” In some areas of the NSW coast it now forms almost pure stands.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments:
Direct threat to native orchid Pterostylis truncata (brittle greenhood) in the You Yang ranges.
Threatens ANZECC rated rare or threatened native plant species

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Dense stands destroy or drastically alter the habitat of native birds and animals. In NSW it has replaced plant species known to be important food sources for migratory birds.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: May provide alternative food source.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No evidence of the plant parts being toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Rabbits and foxes are both known to eat the fruit.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A dense, perennial and dominating shrub that is a source of food for both rabbits and foxes. It can provide harbor throughout the year.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: It does not affect agriculture detrimentally and is rarely found in pastures. It does not persist when grazed and trampled by stock nor when cultivated.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Mass germination occurs in spring (Blood 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish in partially shaded habitats (M�drzycki 2007).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Can invade riparian vegetation (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; Tree (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Leaves contain inhibitory compounds (Rice 1984). The impact these compounds have on other plants is not reported.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
In a study in the US after four years exposed to browsing pressure of 67 White tailed deer per km2 all box elder saplings were eliminated (Rossell, Gorsira & Patch 2005). Densities of 67 White tailed deer per km2 are high as Kilpatrick, Spohr & Lima (2001) report that densities of 20 deer/ km2 to be moderate and at a more moderate grazing pressure it is presumed some will be able to reach maturity as the species is able to grow to 4.6 m in its first four to five years (Dineva 2005).
When leaves are damaged they release volatile compounds which may act as a deterrent to insects (Ping, Shen & Jin 2001).
In the species native range it is generally avoided by foraging insectivorous birds (Gabbe et al 2002). This would indicate that the tree doesn’t support much insect life and therefore as a mature tree not effected by grazing.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Fast growing (Blood 2001).
Fast growing, gap colonising tree (O’Hanlon-Manner & Kotanen 2006).
Fast growing tree (M�llerov� 2005).
Very fast growing in its first 20 years of life, able to grow to 4.6 m in four to five years (Dineva 2005).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of flooding (Weber 2003). Saplings can be killed is inundated for more than 85 days during the growing season, mature trees however can survive being inundated for the entire growing season (Friedman & Auble 1999).
Tolerant of frost (Blood 2001).
Will re-shoot after fire (Blood 2001). Saplings that are only a few years old will not survive fire (Sachse 1992).
Sensitive to water stress, females more than males (Ward et al 2002). Tolerant to some  extent of drought (Weber 2003). Drought resistant (M�drzycki & Pabjanek 2001). Susceptible to caviation under drought conditions (Tissier et al 2004). Growth is reportedly poor on saline soils (Dineva 2005).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Plants of the species produce separate female and male flowers, which are usually on separate plants and through sexual reproduction seeds are produced (Blood 2001). The different sex flowers are said to be usually on different plants, usually would indicate, not always, therefore the species is capable of self and cross pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Female trees can produces up to 30,000 seeds (M�drzycki & Pabjanek 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Germinating power of seed is reported to reduce quickly (M�llerov� 2005). This is presumably less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Can live for 60 years (Kort & Michiels 1997).
Can form monocultures (Sachse 1992).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
First fruits after 10 years (M�llerov� 2005).
Maturity reported in five years (Sachse 1992).
While there is dispute to when the species can reproduce the minimum is still five years or more.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seed is dispersed by wind and water. Plants are also still available in trade (Blood 2001).
Seeds can be transported by vehicles along roads (Von Der Lippe & Kowarik 2007).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Wind dispersed seeds may be carried more than 50 m, and seed can survive at least six weeks in water (M�drzycki 2007).
With water as a dispersal agent, seeds are capable of being dispersed distances greater than 1 km (Vogt, Rasran & Jensen 2004).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: This fast growing tree germinates on mass and can form dense thickets in riparian areas (Blood 2001).  Therefore the species has the potential to be a major impediment in access to waterways and as a tree require significant works to remove.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Unknown.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: People can have hypersensitivity to the species pollen (Shah & Lin 2004).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Has extensive root system which can invade piping in the search for water (Blood 2001). This could be damaging to infrastructure.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Saplings can establish in the stream bed, they are however killed if inundated for more than 85 days during the growing season or if broken under the stress of the water (Friedman & Auble 1999).  Unknown to what extent this would impact on actual water flows.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species is a deciduous tree that is reported to occur in riparian habitats (Blood 2001). As a deciduous species alteration of seasonal light levels and changes to nutrient cycling could impact water quality, the impact this species has on water quality has not been reported however.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Has an extensive root system (Blood 2001). Therefore there is a low probability of large scale soil movement occurring in association with this species.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In open environments which are the species preferred habitat, establishment of the species especially in a thicket would increase biomass. In more heavily shaded environments where the species is more stunted its invasion is likely to cause a direct replacement of biomass (M�drzycki 2007).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown impact on fire regime, considering the species preference for wetter environments it is unlikely to be significant.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Floodplain Riparian Woodland (E); CMA= Corangamite ; Bioreg= Otway Plain ; VH CLIMATE potential.
Able to form thickets excluding all other species except winter growing bulb species (Blood 2001). Exclusion of all other species indicates a monoculture at least within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Sedgy Riparian Woodland (D); CMA= Corangamite ; Bioreg= Otway Plain ; VH CLIMATE potential.
Able to form thickets excluding all other species except winter growing bulb species (Blood 2001). Exclusion of all other species indicates a monoculture at least within a layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Riparian Scrub (LC); CMA= West Gippsland ; Bioreg= Wilsons Promontory; VH CLIMATE potential.
Able to form thickets excluding all other species except winter growing bulb species (Blood 2001). Exclusion of all other species indicates a monoculture at least within a layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Able to form thickets excluding all other species except winter growing bulb species (Blood 2001). Therefore the species is capable of major displacement.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown; there is no evidence of this reported.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Significant alteration of habitat in terms of flora composition could have a significant impact on food supply for fauna species. The degree to which this species would impact on Australian fauna has not been quantified however.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments:
Even in the species native range, it is generally avoided by foraging insectivorous birds (Gabbe et al 2002).
As a moderate sized tree it may provide some shelter for species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence reported to support this.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Browsed by deer species (Rossell, Gorsira & Patch 2005).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense thickets of the species have been described as places of informal intimate social life (M�drzycki 2007).  This dense vegetation cover could provide shelter for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not reported as a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not reported as a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not reported as a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not reported as a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not reported as a significant weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: The species is effected by die back caused by Fusarium solani and cankers caused by Eutypella parasitica and Inonotus rickii (Annesi, Coppola & Motta 2003; Demirci & Maden 2006; Ogris, Jurc & Jurc 2006). Fusarium solani can also damage soybeans (Roy et al 1989). Inonotus rickii is a wood decaying fungus of hardwoods and could have implications for forestry (Barnard 1993).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Broom rape seeds are triggered to germinate by the presence of roots of certain plants.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Small plant, which can establish under broad-leaved crops and amongst pasture paddocks therefore under moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Can establish in vigorously growing crops (e.g. hemp, tobacco, and tomato).  AS WELL AS in established pastures (especially clover).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Parasite.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Plant may be consumed by herbivores, but would recover quickly, as most of its life cycle is completed underground.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Other Orobanche species are common weeds, e.g. Orobanche minor.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerates drought (occurs in Iran, Iraq: sandy soils), and frost (occurs in Nepal and at high elevations).  Also, presumably tolerates fire, as occurs beneath soil surface.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Sexual (seeds) and vegetative (suckers).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: A single capsule can contain 600-800 seeds with a plant producing up to 500,000 seeds.  (20,000).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds remain viable for 10-20 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Perennial species assumed to produce viable propagules for > 10 years, as long as host plants are available.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ~61 days (diagram of life cycle in reference) – 45 days.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seeds  0.3 mm, also described as ‘dust-sized’.

Easily carried as dust on subterranean clover seed.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As seeds dust-sized very likely to disperse > 1 km.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Requires direct sunlight to grow’ (ISSG 2005). ‘Factors believed to be important in affecting germination are red light, temperature and high carbon dioxide levels (Sanders 1976 cited in Mackey & Swarbrick 1998). Score as medium as insufficient evidence to determine specific germination requirements.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘Grows well in eutrophic conditions with low pH but conditions above pH 8 tend to defoliate the stems’ (ISSG 2005). Requires direct sunlight to grow. Requires more specific conditions to establish.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘.. grows in the mud of stagnant to slow flowing water, including streams, and smaller rivers, and also ponds, lakes, reservoirs, sloughs, ditches, and canals’ (ISSG 2005). Can establish in relatively intact natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Fully submerged aquatic plant (ISSG 2005).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: ‘Extracts of cabomba have allelopathic effects at medium and high concentrations’ (Mackey & Swarbrick 1998). Allelopathic properties seriously affecting some plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘In its native habitat, C. caroliniana is eaten by waterfowl and some fish’ (ISSG 2005). Consumed but capable of reproduction.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Is a ‘fast-growing’ plant. Stated to be extremely competitive but can be out competed by such weeds as Egeria densa (Mackey & Swarbrick 1998). Moderately rapid growth that will equal competitive species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘Can survive temperatures of less than 0 degrees (ISSG 2005). Stated to be a threat to freshwater plants and habitats only (Mackey & Swarbrick 1998). Aquatic plant – not drought tolerant. Tolerant to at least 2 and susceptible to at least 2.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Grows and sprouts mainly from fragmentation. Can reproduce by seed but seeds have not been recorded from Australian plants (Mackey & Swarbrick 1998).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Seeds have not been recorded from Australian plants (Mackey & Swarbrick 1998). Mainly vegetatively reproduces. Score medium.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘In Louisiana seed is produced but viability is low and only about 25% of seeds germinate naturally’. Seeds can remain viable for more than two years (Mackey & Swarbrick 1998).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘Can form dense stands’ (ISSG 2005).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Reaches maturity and produces viable propagules in under one year (Mackey and Swarbrick 1998).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: �rgaard (1991 cited in Mackey & Swarbrick 1998), suggested that like most water plants, seed dispersal is due to birds. Also spread through motorboats.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: �rgaard (1991 cited in Mackey & Swarbrick 1998), suggested that like most water plants, seed dispersal  is due to birds. Also water dispersed. Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Aquatic species (Panetta, et al 1998). Access to recreational areas not affected.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: As a potentially invasive aquatic weed, water-based recreations may be seriously affected. “…water skiers or swimmers could easily become entangled by the weed’s long thick stems and drown” (Panetta, et al 1998).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No known toxic principles.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Cabomba could grow in irrigation channels, “…where it could impede water flow, cause overflows and blockages” (Panetta, et al 1998). Serious impact on flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: “Oxygen depletion can occur when massive dieback and consequent decomposition occurs. In Queensland, cabomba infestations may deleteriously affect water quality through increasing water colour” (Panetta, et al 1998). High effect on dissolved O2 levels.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Cabomba is found in ponds, ditches, small shallow lakes and slow flowing streams. If present in water storages, heavy infestations, because of the large volume of plant material, could cause water loss from overflow or seepage” (Panetta, et al 1998). Although water flow may not be significant, overflows may create some minor soil erosion,..

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Cabomba is capable of rapid spread once it has been introduced in to a suitable water body. It was first reported from Lake MacDonald in April 1992, and by 1995 had invaded almost the whole of the lake’s extensive littoral zone” (Panetta, et al 1998). As an aquatic species, the significant increase in biomass is a negative attribute.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
Basin=Snowy River- Brodribb River (ISC=excellent); CMA=East Gippsland; CLIMATE=VH. 
“It is extremely persistent and can establish a monoculture by excluding native plant species” (ARMCANZ 2000). Monoculture  within a specific layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)i.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)ii.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “It is extremely persistent and can establish a monoculture by excluding native plant species” (ARMCANZ 2000).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Its ability to replace native aquatic plants, with the likely displacement of native fish and invertebrate populations, together with the ability to infest large areas of water, suggest that native aquatic life would be considerably endangered” (Panetta, et al 1998). Reduction in habitat leading to reduced populations.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “In regions where it is invasive, it is not clear whether native fish and invertebrates utilize it readily as a habitat” (Panetta, et al 1998). Assume limited or no benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be injurious.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Aquatic species (P & C 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Aquatic species (P & C 2001).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: No evidence. Not known as a weed of agriculture. It can occur in irrigation systems and demonstrate allelopathy on seed germination in wheat and lettuce (P & C 2001). Potential to affect irrigated crops. Impact unknown.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate at any time of the year.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in open areas.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Establishes in pastures.

Listed as a ‘problematic weed of agricultural situations’.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Large shrub.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Seldom grazed by stock because of the sharp spines.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Early root growth is rapid ensuring young plants are competitive.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of drought and frost (refer to Australian Distribution).

Some water logging (occurs in creek beds and along streams and rivers).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Fruit production has ranged between 0 & 535.  Seeds numerous. ˜ 500 fruit x 10 seeds per fruit = 5,000 seeds.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Large shrub.

Produces dense thickets.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants do not flower until at least 2 years old.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The fruit is commonly eaten by birds and foxes and the seeds are viable when excreted.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Above animals could disperse seeds > 1 km as quite mobile.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
“A dense spiny shrub to five metres high and wide. Extremely sharp spines prevent any movement through dense stands.”
In one reported infestation some roads were practically impassable. The spines are strong enough to puncture pneumatic tyres. Serious impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations likely to have a major impact on recreation. The plant is known to invade roadsides, sand dunes, and waterways. It tolerates salt spray, which indicates its potential to affect recreation in beachside and other coastal areas.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The stems and tips of branches are equipped with sharp rigid spines to 2 – 15 cm long, which are present all year. The fruit is believed to be toxic to humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The root system comprises an extensive deep, branched taproot. However, there is no evidence to suggest the root system is vigorous enough to cause structural damage. With growth to 5 metres high and 3 metres wide, the presence of the plant would seriously affect the aesthetics of an area. But more likely visual effect rather than structural – if boxthorns in middens – would have rabbits.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “An erect shrub to 5 m high and 3 m across. African boxthorn makes an effective hedge plant, producing a dense thicket.” Not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: African boxthorn grows to a great size when left unchecked. Originally planted as a hedging plant, the area it invades suggests the plant’s presence would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “African boxthorn makes an effective hedge plant, producing a dense thicket.” With the increase in biomass there is a likelihood of a moderate increase in the frequency and intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential
“…shades and crowds out other vegetation preventing any regeneration occurring. It is an extremely tough species adapted to a wide range of conditions.” Can grow to 5 m high. Major displacement of dominant species within different layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (LC); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “…shades and crowds out other vegetation preventing any regeneration occurring. Commonly a harbor for rabbits so there is little other vegetation.” Major impact on the floral strata and minor effects on layers.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Dense thickets may deny animals access to watering points. Interferes with sea lion breeding.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: African boxthorn commonly provides habitat and food for smaller native animals.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The spines damage stock, therefore, potential to injure fauna species  Although spines – not much impact, fauna can move through plant easily and use it for cover/harbor.  Storm petrels get caught up on them at Sth channel fort at some times of year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Birds and foxes commonly eat seeds. Bird species not documented; assume equal potential for introduced and native species. Fruits heavily over autumn-winter, some ripe fruit may be present at other times of the year. The fruit is a breeding place for fruit fly, dried fruit beetles, tomato fly and the common housefly.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “Thickets commonly harbor rabbits.” Rabbits frequently burrow under clumps.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Large clumps obviously eliminate considerable areas of pasture and can also impede stock movement.” Animals seldom graze the plant because of the sharp spines. The reduction in available pasture would have major impact on yield. Not known as a problem in cropping situations.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Dense infestations minimise available pasture. Applying herbicides and excavating plants is the best method of control. Cost of control would affect land values in grazing areas.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Left unchecked, African boxthorn can grow to a great size. Dense infestations minimise available pasture. Without implementing a management plan, the land would become useless for agricultural activity.  Could not think of examples where boxthorn changed landuse – can be controlled after a long period of time (i.e. thick dense thickets easily with bulldozer

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect cropping situations.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Flowering occurs in December/January.

New shoots produced in late winter and early spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy – occurs in forests/woodlands.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems e.g. woodlands, forests, grasslands, natural communities.  “It was not found in undisturbed areas”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Geophyte.  Buds on root produce new shoots in winter/spring.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Produces allelopathic compounds, having an inhibitory effect on the growth of other plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Stock avoid grazing in and around dense patches.  “Unpalatable to livestock and wildlife”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Growth is prolific”.  It is strongly competitive in pastures and crops.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to drought (occurs in desert shrub), frost (occurs in alpine areas), fire, water logging (occurs in wet areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed and from extensive creeping rhizome.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Between 5-6,000 seeds per plant under favourable conditions.  (According to European studies).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Small % remain viable in the soil for at least 21 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “The deep roots grow horizontally and send up shoots along their length, forming dense colonies”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Some plants flower in their first year but this is not common.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wind, water, machinery, equipment.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Studies show wind disperses seeds only tens of metres.  “Seeds travelling in irrigation canals and rivers causes new infestations far from the seed source.  The parachuting effect of the pappus allows wind to carry Canada Thistle seed several hundred yards before settling”. (FEIS).  “Canada thistle produces an abundance of bristly-plumed seeds which are easily dispersed by the wind”.  (Thunhurst & Swearingen 1999).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate after late spring and summer rains’.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in open areas (i.e. crops and pasture).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Invades pastures and crops (e.g. vineyards, irrigated cotton).

“Only in recent years has it invaded horticultural and agricultural crops and pastures”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Annual herb.

Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “There is evidence that Caltrop has an Allelopathic effect on some plants” (e.g. grass seedlings).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
