inv_herb_pressure.comments: “They do not normally graze Caltrop when other feed is available but, in some cases there is no alternative”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Competes with pastures and a variety of crops throughout Australia.  (e.g. cereals, cotton, vines and peanuts).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Its extensive root system allows it to survive droughts.

Its extensive distribution in Australia would allow it to tolerate some frost and likely other conditions.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Fruit are thus formed continually throughout the summer and autumn and according to Indian studies up to 1,000 fruit can be produced on each plant”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Buried seed remains viable for several years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual herb.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “The first flowers may be formed when plants are only three weeks old and the first fruit at five or six weeks”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Animals, vehicle tyres, shoes and almost any object which is placed on it.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Animals, vehicles could easily disperse seeds numerous km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A prostrate summer-growing annual herb.” Even in dense infestations, its presence does not hinder human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Its presence is likely to affect recreational activities. The fruit is a woody burr with sharp rigid spines to about 6 mm long. It splits into five segments each with two spines. The spines on the fruit and segments can easily penetrate human flesh causing discomfort. Infestations may limit recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The fruit and resultant segments present rigid spines to about 6 mm long. Fruit are formed continuously through the summer and autumn. In India, plants have produced up to 1,000 fruit.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: In dense infestations in NSW the plant is known to provide cover of up to 45 cm deep for several months of the year. Also, in shaded areas or when competing with taller plants the stems will grow erect. The physical structure of site is not affected, but dense infestations would seriously affect the aesthetics of an area.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “It occurs mostly on dry sandy soils where there is little competition.” Its presence may help to reduce soil erosion marginally during its growth and flowering period.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Grows best in disturbed areas with minimal vegetation. Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: A summer annual it adds little if any fuel load. Dry matter would present little or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential
“…caltrop is most frequently found in the north of the State…where it occurs in railway yards, nature strips, parks and waste areas in almost every town.” “Prefers dry sandy soils where there is little competition.” Allelopathic. Major displacement of grasses or ground covers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: It is not likely to occur in medium value EVCs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: It is not likely to occur in low value EVCs

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Grows best in disturbed areas with minimal other vegetation. It is reported to have allelopathic properties which inhibit the growth of grass seedlings, and its extensive root system can compete effectively for moisture and nutrients. In dense infestations it can dominate the ground flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The areas where T. terrestris inhabit (railway yards, nature strips and waste areas) would not be a significant food source for grazing fauna. Its presence may have a minor effect in reducing food source.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Spines on the fruit damage the feet of animals.” When eaten, the fruit can damage the mouth and possibly the lining of the stomach and intestines. It is toxic to sheep and may present similar properties to native fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A prostrate annual herb with spiny fruit, it is unlikely to provide habitat for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: A significant pest in crops, it is able to extract soil moisture from great depth. This allows it to offer severe competition under very dry conditions. In pasture situations, in the absence of other suitable fodder, animals will graze new growth of T. terrestris, which may cause stock losses. The level of impact is not documented but losses in New South Wales and Western Australia have been reported.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: It contaminates harvested product, particularly in the dried fruit industry, and is a vegetable fault in wool. However, presence of the seed does not affect wool processing.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The weed causes some agricultural loss, but it can be readily controlled with suitable mechanical and chemical controls. Its presence may affect land value somewhat.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The potential threat to grazing animals presented by the weed may dictate a temporary change to land use. In NSW grows exceptionally well on farms with a system of winter cereal crops and sheep grazing. A period of continuous cropping may be required until the weed is controlled.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Seeds and seed segments are a nuisance causing painful injury to fruit pickers and shearers. Continuous interruption (to remove the offending spine) may increase the time to harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Growth (vegetative) starts with development of node buds on old stems in early spring”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Establishes readily wherever there is an adequate water supply…it has a low light requirement”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Established in rice crops and inundated pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Aquatic (emergent or free flowing) as well as terrestrial.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“Strong competition in rice fields and pastures prone to water logging, often crowding out desirable species”.

“Alternanthera philoxeroides competes successfully with other plants with the exception of water hyacinth.  (Spenser & Coulson 1976); (Coulson 1977); (Julien & Broadbent 1980 p. 154).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of frosts, water logging and salinity.  “It requires a warm growing season but will tolerate cold winters including severe frosts which may kill emergent stem material.  (Coulson 1977)”.  (Julien & Broadbent 1980 p. 152).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproduction in the field is entirely vegetative”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Reproduction in the field is entirely vegetative”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Produces thick mats.  (See picture P & C 1992 p. 157).
  
“Floating mats of alligator weed are generally monocultures”.  (Julien & Broadbent 1980 p. 152).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Nodes on old stems in early spring  stems and flowers in mid summer  - flowering until March.  

Some seeds produced but rarely ever viable in Australia.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Water currents and cultivation.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Prostrate, semi-prostrate or ascending plant in both terrestrial and aquatic situations. Restricts access on land and can seriously affect access to waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “In water dense mats…extend for 15 m or more.” Major impact on water-based recreation and creates a dangerous hazard for swimming.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Not toxic through physical contact. The plant has been cultivated and consumed in Australia in the mistaken belief it is the culinary herb A. sessilis, known commonly as Mukunu-wenna. The plant does contain calcium oxalate crystals.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: An “aggressive, invasive species.” In terrestrial situations it develops extensive root systems and is very persistent. Infestation could seriously affect historic or cultural feature. In attempting to eradicate the weed extensive excavation may need to be undertaken.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: “The prolific growth restricts flow, increases sedimentation, aggravates flooding and acts as a barrier.”

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments:
“…the thick mats…restrict light penetration…and create anaerobic conditions.”
“The mats restrict light, thereby reducing primary productivity and anoxic conditions may result.”

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Terrestrial plants have thickened, dense roots to depths of 0.5 m. Soil erosion not increased as a result of infestation.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In aquatic situations biomass is increased significantly. Little effect in terrestrial situations

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: In both aquatic and terrestrial situations the plant does not die back leaving dry matter to support fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains Grassy Wetland (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg:= Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Although not known as an invasive weed in Victorian natural ecosystems, it has the potential to invade riparian vegetation, freshwater wetland (seasonal and permanent). “It has a low light requirement.” 
In aquatic situations it has the capacity to form monocultures, but less so on land.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Sedgy riparian woodland (D); CMA= Port Phillip; Bioreg:= Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Similarly invasive as above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Wet forest (LC); CMA= Port Phillip; Bioreg:= Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
As in 10(a).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Floating mats of A. philoxeroides are generally monocultures but other species occur close to the bank. In wet terrestrial situations, it may occur as the only emergent species but is more often associated with clover, grasses or common rush.”

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Due to its invasive habit in waterways and its potential to create anoxic conditions, it is likely to reduce the habitat and threaten aquatic fauna. “…affects fish and other organism habitat.”

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Alligator weed provides no benefits to Australia.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No evidence of harm to fauna although, “In New Zealand and Australia alligator weed causes photosensitisation of skin in light pigmented cattle resulting in cancerous lesions.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not evident, but some herbivorous insects do feed on plant.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: May provide harbour for minor pest species (birds).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: It is a strong competitor in rice fields and pastures prone to waterlogging. “Alligator weed has eliminated small crops and turf farming from parts of the Lower Hunter (NSW).”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “If present, land and associated production can be quarantined and sales restricted due to W1 weed status.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: As above.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: In terrestrial situations it is difficult to eradicate. The plant is resistant to herbicide treatment and mechanical removal is difficult due to the depth of the root system. Excavation of up to 2 m is recommended. Significant change to use is dictated. See also comment in Q21 above.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Occurrence of the weed in water supplies for irrigation and the need to control it can increase production costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “Provides habitat for disease vectors such as mosquitoes.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “In the field Amsinckia germinates with the autumn rains (April onwards), and by winter the seed produced in the preceding spring is highly germinable.” Requires autumn temperature and rainfall to germinate.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Connor (1965) found that, given suitable moisture, seed germination was consistently high under both light and dark conditions (66% and 62% germination respectively). Seed can thus germinate whether buried or exposed.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
While it does occur in lowland grassland & grassy woodland population densities are small.

Predominantly, it is a weed of highly disturbed areas such as cereal crops, lucerne, degraded pastures and roadsides.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual herb. Others category.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: While one sp. of Amsinckia is toxic particularly to cattle, it is nonetheless grazed. Germination and seed production are staggered through the life cycle of the plant. “Four separate germinations have been noted during this period [autumn].” Seed production is high. This indicates that, while the plant may be eaten, its staggered seed production ensures that plants will continue to flower and to persist through subsequent years.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Early germination and rapid growth give yellow burrweed seedlings a competitive advantage over other species.” Rapid growth rate exceeds that of species of similar life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Plants die with the onset of summer temperatures in late spring or early summer.” Not drought tolerant. Resistance to other stresses not documented. Consider a tender herb.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: An annual herb. Reproduces sexually. “The species of Amsinckia… belong to the section* Muricatae. Self-pollination is a common feature of reproduction within the Muricatae. Combined with cross-compatibility, this places the group in a very aggressive position.” Self and cross-pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Amsinckia spp. are prolific seeders producing up to 1600 seeds per plant.” Produces more than 1,000 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “The longevity of seed is not known but, stored indoors, they live for more than 2 years but probably not as long as this in the field.” Seeds survive less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual herb. Produces propagules for only one year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Seeds germinate… in autumn. The seedling develops into a rosette from which a flowering stem is produced in mid-winter. Growth is still rapid and flowering commences in August, continuing for about 2 months.” Less than 12 months to produce propagules.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “The bristly calyx facilitates dispersal on wool, fur and hair of animals including foxes. Human activities are most important, resulting in spread through the movement of contaminated harvesting equipment, hay balers and seed graders, and the dispersal of contaminated seed, fodder and stock.” Propagules spread by attaching to animals and through normal harvesting activities.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As human activities are most important in spreading the seed, it is likely that contaminated produce or machinery will disperse propagules more than 1 kilometre. (see comment above).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Amsinckia is an erect annual herb that grows to a height of 70 cm. While infestations can be of the order of 90 plants per square metre, it is not likely to impede human traffic.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Its presence is clearly noticeable during flowering. The plant would have a major effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No recorded affect on humans, but the stiff hairs or bristles on the leaves and stems may cause some discomfort for a person on foot.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Presence of the plant is quite noticeable during flowering. It would have a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial spp.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Predominantly a weed of crops. Not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Competes with crops; replaces existing biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No known to affect fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
It occurs on a wide range of soils, particularly dry, sandy soils, in moderately warm, unshaded situations. Annual; competes with annual grasses/forbs. Occurs rarely in small populations.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Broombush mallee (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Northern Inland Slopes; VH CLIMATE potential
As above

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Sand heathland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plains; VH CLIMATE potential
As above

hab_structure.question: 13. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Not known as a problem in environmental situations. It occurs in lowland grassland and grassy woodland vegetation, but its distribution is rare and it occurs in small populations. Minor effect on > 20% of the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 16. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: No recorded effects on habitat or food source of non-threatened fauna. Predominantly a weed of cropping; few if any fauna co-existing in situation.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 17. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Birds are known to eat the seed.” But bird spp. not specified (native or introduced). “Bristles on the leaves and stems make the plant unattractive to stock and it is generally unpalatable.” Annual spp. dying back in summer; no harbor. Very limited benefit, if at all.

fauna_injurious.question: 18. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not evident, though “…one spp. causes liver disease which killed 2000 cattle in the United States, but deaths have not be recorded in Australia.” Generally unpalatable; limited potential to injure to fauna.

pest_food.question: 19. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Birds are known to eat the seed.” Not known if native or introduced species. Not known to provide a significant source of food.

pest_harbor.question: 20. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: An erect, annual herb that dies back in late spring or early summer. Not likely to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 21. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Very competitive in cereal crops. Recorded instance of 48% reduction in wheat yield in NSW.

ag_quality.question: 22. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: It is claimed Amsinckia seed imparts a peculiar taint to flour and fragments of the black seedcoat discolour flour. The “bristly calyx becomes an impurity in wool.”

ag_land_value.question: 23. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Considering its potential impact on both yield and quality, the presence of this weed would reduce land value. It can be controlled with appropriate mechanical and chemical treatments.

ag_land_use.question: 24. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See above. No chemicals are registered for use against Amsinckia in broad-leaved cereal crops. Therefore, farmers wishing to cultivate broad-leaved winter crops in lieu of winter cereals may have to temporarily change land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 25. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “Human activities are most important [in dispersal] resulting in spread [of seed] through the movement of contaminated harvesting equipment, hay balers and seed graders.” Farm machinery used on affected properties must be thoroughly cleaned to eliminate the presence and subsequent dispersal of the seed. This could increase harvesting costs.

ag_disease.question: 26. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds and bulbs germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in woodlands and ‘shady places’.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed ecosystems (e.g. riparian, wetlands & woodlands), and pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Bulbous perennial herb.

Geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Consumed – response unknown.  However, probably recovers quickly as it is noted as being z’ a very persistent weed which may take some time and intensive effort to completely eradicate”. (NCC).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Does not compete strongly with crops and improved pastures.

Can completely smother and replace native ground cover vegetation.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of water logging (occurs on poorly drained soils along watercourses).  Also, assumed tolerant of frosts (occurs on slopes of Great Dividing Range and the Dandenong Ranges).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seeds and bulbs.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Probably < 50 seeds produced by each small bulb.
(See picture Hyde-Wyatt & Morris 1980 and O’Neill 1962).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Provides a complete ground cover in some areas.
 - forms monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Year one  - Seeds germinate.		
Year two   - Bulbs germinate.		
Year three   - Seeds produced by bulbs.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Agricultural produce, animals, machinery, vehicles, garden refuse and contaminated soil.  Also insects and water.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Although invading a significant number of environmental vegetation formations, A. triquetrum, as a low growing perennial herb (to 50 cm high), is would have minimal impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: It is a persistent species capable of totally dominating ground flora. During leaf growth and flowering stage its presence is quite obvious resulting in a major negative impact on aesthetics. “The leaves and stems have a strong garlic-like aroma when crushed.” Some recreational activities may be affected as a result.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No known toxicity or harmful physical properties (burrs, spines, etc.). It has been used as a culinary herb.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The obvious presence of the plant would produce a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial sp.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Colonies dense, out-competes other herbaceous plants leaving bare ground in summer dormancy period, thereby increasing likelihood of erosion.”

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Dense stands will smother and crowd out any competing ground-flora while seriously impeding over-storey regeneration.” It is only active from mid-winter to early summer, thus leaving infested areas bare of vegetation for about six months of the year. Biomass would be decreased.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Prefers moist environments. Dried plant material provides little fuel. Low probability of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands–Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential.  “…tenacious, persistent species capable of totally dominating the ground-flora wherever conditions are suitable.”
Major displacement of dominant sp. within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Herb-rich foothill forest (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
 “…tenacious, persistent species capable of totally dominating the ground-flora wherever conditions are suitable.”
Major displacement of dominant sp. within a layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“…tenacious, persistent species capable of totally dominating the ground-flora wherever conditions are suitable.”
Major displacement of dominant sp. within a layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dense stands will smother and crowd out any competing ground-flora while seriously impeding over-storey regeneration.” Major effect on ground flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Its presence is widespread, in medium to large populations, and it invades a large number of vegetative forms. It is thus likely to have a major negative effect on the habitat of non-threatened fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Attachments on seeds [are] attractive to ants, which are important vectors.” Literature does not clarify native or introduces spp.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No toxic properties. Both humans and animals have eaten the plant.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Attachments on seeds [are] attractive to ants, which are important vectors.” Literature does not clarify native or introduced spp. Assume potential for both.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: As a bulbous herb, the plant only has foliage for six months. It would not provide any suitable, permanent harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: A. triquetrum, “does not compete in strongly in crops and improved pastures.” Little affect agricultural yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: The plant, “imparts a strong onion flavour and an unpleasant odour to dairy products and meat, making them unfit for sale.” Contaminates product making it unfit for sale.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Due to its significant impact on agricultural quality, the presence of A. triquetrum in paddocks would have a negative impact on land prices. However, the plant can be controlled with appropriate farm practices.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The plant can be controlled with straightforward cultivation techniques and the use of incrop herbicide sprays. Access by grazing animals would be restricted until weed was eliminated.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: A known vector is contaminated mud on farm machinery and vehicles. Strict hygiene practices must be observed to prevent further spread. Potential to increase harvest costs through cleaning vehicles and machinery.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Established in mostly ‘open’ habitats, e.g. pasture and open vegetation formatios.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems, e.g. coastal vegetation; grassland/grassy woodland and rock outcrop vegetation.  

Appears in some National Park’s (P & C 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect spreading shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Foliage is not eaten by stock because of its prickly nature”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Can form dense patches which crowd out other vegetation.

“Competes strongly with native species and poorer pastures”. (P & C 1992).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought (occurs in central WA), some salinity (occurs in coastal areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Fruit a berry: numerous seeds in each fruit  berries per plant x 50 seeds per berry = 1,500 seeds per plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Can form “dense patches which crowd out other vegetation”  monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants generally not flowering until at least 2 years old”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Fruit eventually drops off bush and is blown or dragged away.
 - spread by gravity.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: S. linnaeanum grows well in sandy coastal areas where it strongly competes with native species. If left to develop it can, “…result in dense patches which crowd out other vegetation [and] restrict stock movement.” Because of its prickly nature it may potentially restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: In Victoria, its distribution is limited, but it occurs in medium to large populations. Because of its prickly nature, its presence may affect some recreational activities, particularly bushwalking or hiking.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: An erect perennial shrub, the plant has numerous prickles on the stem, leaves and fruit. The fruit is poisonous.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches may create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial sp.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A perennial, spreading shrub with a stout taproot. Plants are partially deciduous in winter. Not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: It competes strongly with native plants and crowds out other vegetation. Direct replacement of biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Predominantly evergreen (plants are partially deciduous), it does not significantly increase fuel load. It therefore presents little change to the fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Coastal dune scrub (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Warnambool Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
Occurs in medium to large populations and, “…competes strongly with native species.” Major displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Coastal dune scrub (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Occurs in medium to large populations and, “…competes strongly with native species.” Impact as above..

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Plains; VH CLIMATE potential
“Grows well…[in]…coastal areas.” Prefers open areas. Possible minor impact in woodland areas.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dense patches can crowd out other vegetation.” It also, “…competes strongly with native species.” It would have a major impact on the floral strata in coastal vegetation and grasslands.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Medium to large populations, though limited in distribution. Competes with beneficial plants so is likely to reduce food source for non-threatened fauna. Spiny nature of plant discourages grazing.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits for fauna. “Neither the fruit nor seeds are eaten by birds or animals.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Prickles present throughout the year. Fruit is poisonous.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Neither the fruit nor seeds are eaten by birds or animals.”

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The plant does provide harbor for rabbits. As a perennial, it possibly provides for permanent harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Although the fruit is poisonous, animals avoid grazing the plant because of its prickly nature. Infestations crowd out other vegetation and restricts stock movement; reduces carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Seeds do not present as impurities in seed or cereal crops. No burrs to affect wool.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: It is more a problem in unimproved pastures. Would have minimal impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: It is more a problem in unimproved pastures. Seedlings are easily killed by frequent cultivation as part of crop sowing or pasture improvement.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence of increased harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Water is sufficient to break seed dormancy’ (Dlugosch 2004). Opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘It seems to invade only disturbed or dry sites that have sufficient light’ (PIER 2005). Requires more specific requirements to establish.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In Hawaii found ‘along roads, in yards, gulches, and pastures’ (Starr et al 2003). On Canary Islands it is found in dry scrub and laurel forests (Dlugosch 2004). Also found in coastal sage scrub and in grassland habitats (PIER 2005). Can establish in minor disturbed natural ecosystem.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Shrub (Randall 2002). Life form – other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: In Maui numerous insects were observed to be associated with H. canariense however ‘none of these insects were doing much damage to the plants’ (Starr et al 2003). Consumed but recovers quickly.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Given favourable conditions, it may grow to over 1 m in its first year’ (Dlugosch 2004). In California it does out compete dominant native shrubs (Randall 2002). Rapid growth rate that will exceed most other species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Found in xerophytic scrub (PIER 2005). Somewhat tolerant to drought. In its native range in Canary Islands, not subjected to frost. Occurs in places with salinity (Hansford & Laconis 2004). No evidence to suggest that plant is tolerant of fire or waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by both seeds and rhizomes (Hansford & Laconis 2004). Both vegetative and sexual reproduction.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Seeds are numerous (Randall 2002). Each fruit ‘releases hundreds of tiny seeds’ (Dlugosch 2004).  Produces greater than 2,000 seeds per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘.. seed germination rate is approximately 50%’ (Dlugosch 2004). Longevity not documented but no evidence to suggest seed survival is greater than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘Left undisturbed it is very likely to develop dense monoculture infestations’ (Randall 2002).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Flowers and fruits may be produced in the first year of growth’ (Dlugosch 2004).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘[H. canariense] light seeds are probably wind dispersed’. Plants are found along roads, which may be an indication that it is spread by light vehicular traffic. (Starr et al 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Local spread in California ranges from 45 to 90 metres a year, which is considerable distance for a perennial shrub with no outside assistance or any known dispersal mechanisms ’ (Randall 2002). Very  few to none will disperse to 1 km, most 20-200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Many-branched shrub which can grow from one to 5 metres tall (Randall 2002). Species can be used in borders. Plant is likely to impede individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Has ‘numerous bright yellow flowers and an attractive shrubby habit (Randall 2002). Most noticeable during its flowering period (spring ) (Starr et al 2003). Weed would have minor effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Weed not documented to be injurious in any way.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Has ‘numerous bright yellow flowers and an attractive shrubby habit (Randall 2002). Most noticeable during its flowering period (spring ) (Starr et al 2003). Weed would have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Shrub is dense and multi-stemmed. Although foliage drops, unlikely that soil would be exposed for any length of time. Low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Highly competitive plant which displaces virtually all lower storey species’ (Randall 2002). Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Multi-stemmed scrub with foliage dropping in late summer (Dlugosch 2004). ‘Dense growth in dry environments, carries few leaves’ (PIER 2005). Plant would have minor effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains Grassy Woodland (E.); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Major displacement of some dominant species within the lower storey.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Grassy Woodland (D); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highland Southern Fall; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Major displacement of some dominant species within the lower storey.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Granitic Hills Woodland (LC); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Northern Inland Slopes; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Major displacement of some dominant species within the lower storey.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘Highly competitive plant which displaces virtually all lower storey species’ (Randall 2002). Major effect on less than 60% of floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Plant not documented to have an effect on non-threatened fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Plant not known to provide benefits to indigenous fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Plant doesn’t have burrs or spines (PIER 2005) and not known to be toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Weed not documented as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Weed not known to provide harbour for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture (Randall 2002).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping (Randall 2002).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Weed not documented to affect land value. Can be controlled by herbicides (PIER 2005).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not documented to cause a change in priority of land use. Can be controlled by herbicides (PIER 2005).

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture (Randall 2002).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not documented as a host or vector for disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in Spring” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 2001)

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: 6 hours of light or less cause seeds to germinate (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). “A large amount of stubble can…[shade] arrowhead seeds, slowing germination” (RIRDC, 2000). Require light to germinate (Flower et al, 1999). Less than 10% of seed germinated without light, compared to up to 50-65% with light (Flower et al, 1998). Can establish under moderate cover

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Usually found in warm-temperate shallowly flooded or marshy areas associated with rivers and streams…drainage ditches, rice fields and permanent swamps associated with irrigation drainage systems.” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). All evidence points towards highly disturbed aquatic environments, such as irrigation channels and rice fields.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: “Emergent, broad-leafed aquatic plant” (Flower et al, 1999)

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Spoonbills and carp have been observed feeding on the plant. Either or both of these animals may have been the cause of the plants disappearance on river flats along the River Murray but this is not certain (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). The weed may still persist.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Rice has been observed outgrowing S. montevidensis in California (Gibson et al, 2001) however Australian rice yields can be reduced by up to 75% (Flower et al, 1999). The ability of rice to out compete arrowhead depends on when it is sown after flooding (Flower et al, 2002). 

Equal competitiveness of same life forms.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: One study showed that draining rice bays for up to two weeks killed very young arrowhead seedlings, but didn’t kill more mature seed-grown plants (Flower et al, 1999). Survive in temporary dry ditches (Sagliocco & Bruzzese, 2005). Killed by frost and most plants killed by drought (Kaul, 1985 Angelo & Boufford (2005) record it growing in tidal mud flats of estuaries and salt marshes.  The rosette form may be able to tolerate submersion for years (MGW, nd). As a low growing aquatic species (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) will not be affected by fire. Tolerance of fire, waterlogging and salinity, but not frost or drought (severe enough to dry out damp areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed and rhizomes” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992)

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Can produce many thousands of seeds per plant (MGW, nd). 414,000 achenes per plant per year (Kaul, 1985).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “The viability of …seeds does not reduce significantly after three years in the soil, suggesting that they remain viable for many years after being deposited” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). Kaul (1985) found that scarified seed viability reduced to 50% after 7 years

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Species forms dense monocultures, as seen in photograph (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Seeds germinate in spring and plants mature during summer, producing flowers from January to March. Seeds mature in autumn” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Kaul (1985) describes S. calycina (syn. for subspecies ) as a fruit-bearing annual. “Two subspecies recorded in Australia, one perennial (ssp. Montevidensis and one annual ssp. calycina)” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). Produces propagules in under a year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Under Australian field conditions, spread of arrowhead is by seed. They move in water along channels and ditches and also in mud sticking to hooves and fur of animals…Some seeds are eaten by ducks and believed to be viable when excreted” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Under Australian field conditions, spread of arrowhead is by seed. They move in water along channels and ditches and also in mud sticking to hooves and fur of animals” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) “due to a slightly sticky surface” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft).  “The achenes produced by Altismataceous species have a pericarp that provides buoyancy…those of S. montevidensis float for a little under two weeks.” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km by sticking to animal fur, or transport by water.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An emergent aquatic perennial herb. Inhabits shallowly flooded (to 45 cm) or marshy areas associated with rivers and streams. In south eastern Australia it is commonly found in drainage ditches and permanent swamps associated with irrigation and drainage systems (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Would not impede human access to waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Although most commonly found in drainage ditches and irrigation canals, it has also been found in a number of creeks in Victoria including Nine Mile Creek, Wunghnu and Bullock Creek near the junction of the Oven and Murray Rivers. In drain and irrigation channels it can form dense infestations that block the flow of water (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Its presence may affect water-based activities such as fishing or swimming.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No prickles, spines or burrs described (Aston, 1973). Sagittaria species are eaten by ducks and sometimes humans, suggesting that they are not toxic either (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: An aquatic species (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Not likely to impact on sites of cultural significance.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: "Sagittaria forms extensive infestations in shallow waterways, seriously restricting water flow and increasing sedimentation, thus aggravating flooding." (BPRC, 2004). An emergent aquatic, firmly rooted.  “Dense infestations block channels and drainage ditches” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). “Arrowhead can severely retard and completely choke water flow in irrigation channels” (Gunasekera & Krake, 2001).  Serious impacts to both surface and subsurface water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: “Decaying plant material contributes to water pollution and sedimentation and may also increase the risk of algal bloom and microbial activity” (Sagliocco & Bruzesse, 2005). Likely to cause noticeable but minor effects on dissolved O2.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In New Zealand it, "forms extensive infestations in shallow waterways, seriously restricting water flow and increasing sedimentation, thus aggravating flooding" (BPRC, 2004). Increased chance of flooding would create the potential for large-scale soil movement with minor off-site implications.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Where it occurs in drainage channels and irrigation canals (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992) little other vegetation would normally exist. Infestations of arrowhead would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species (Flower et al, 1999). Fire not applicable in this ecosystem.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
Basin=East Gippsland- Cann River (ISC=Excellent); CMA=East Gippsland; CLIMATE=VH. 
“S. calycina [syn. S. montevidensis ssp. calycina] is very abundant in suitable years, sometimes forming vast beds” (Kaul, 1985). Can displace native water plants which occupy the same habitat (ESC, 2005). Able to form monocultures displacing all species within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)i.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)ii.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “S. calycina [syn. S. montevidensis ssp. calycina] is very abundant in suitable years, sometimes forming vast beds” (Kaul, 1985). Can displace native water plants which occupy the same habitat (ESC, 2005).  Able to form monocultures.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Has a negative impact on native species and on the integrity of natural waterways, such as the waterways of the Barmah-Millewa forest, where it has been recorded” (GMW). Large populations obstruct the movement of wildlife and fish (Sagliocco & Bruzzese, 2005). May reduce habitat and have a minor effect on native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Spoonbills have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). The plant may provide an alternate source of food.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No prickles, spines or burrs described (Aston, 1973). Spoonbills and carp have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Not harmful to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Carp (considered a serious aquatic pest) have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Carp (considered a serious aquatic pest) have been observed feeding on the plant Parson & Cuthberston (1992) and dense infestations (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) may also provide harbor for them.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Grain yields were not affected by Californian arrowhead densities up to 200 plants/m2 (Gibson et al, 2001). “Arrowhead reduced the yield of rice by up to 75% if completely unchecked” (Flower, Pratley & Slater, 1999). The ability of rice to out compete arrowhead depends on when it is sown after flooding (Flower et al, 2002). This species has the capacity to have a serious impact on rice yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Weed senesced well before rice maturity” (Gibson et al, 2001). Unlikely to impact on the quality of the produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Whilst this species can “severely retard and completely choke water flow in irrigation channels”  (Gunasekera & Krake, 2001), it is the responsibility of the water service provider to control the weed (GMW) so is unlikely to have an impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Land use may need to change from rice growing to another crop (see Q. 19), however, this is unlikely to cause a reduction in income.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: One study showed that draining rice bays for up to two weeks killed very young arrowhead seedlings, but didn’t kill more mature seed-grown plants (Flower et al, 1999). Controlling arrowhead this way may cause a minor increase to the costs of harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Harbours several important plant viruses (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds may germinate at any time of the year but most do so after autumn rain”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Requires ‘open’ areas e.g. pasture, gardens, wasteland, roadsides, vacant allotments.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed ecosystems (e.g. riparian, grassland) and well-established pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Perennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “The spiny nature of the plant deters sheep and cattle from grazing on heavy infestations but, when hungry, animals will eat the leaves”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Can choke out or dominate vegetation of an area once established.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to salinity, presumably also drought (occurs in Ciza & Kalubia, Egypt & Australia).  Water logging (occurs in irrigated and riparian areas)  ?  (Wernli & Tames 1984)

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from a perennial taproot and by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Approximately 16 inflorescence per plant x 100 florets per inflorescence x 1 seed per floret = approximately 1,600 seeds.  About 16 heads on each plant but occasionally > 50  or more inflorescence 8 less florets

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
“Individual plants may live for many years”.

Also, can form monocultures.  (See pic. P & C 1992 p. 214).  Carr et al (1992) also states that the plant forms ‘medium to large infestations’.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants may flower in the first year but generally flowering is delayed until the second summer”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Mostly seed dispersal – wind, animals, water, mud and birds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Seeds are usually blown within a few metres of the birds, plants.  Animals, particularly birds and water are however likely to spread seeds farther.  Small birds feed on seeds, perhaps dispersing seed > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Generally associated with agriculture, C. cardunculus does invade native grasslands and grassy woodlands, and riparian vegetation. Large populations can develop in disturbed areas, and with the tall growth habit (to 2 m) and spines on the leaves, the plant would present a high level of nuisance to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The obvious presence of the weed, dense growth and prickly nature would affect recreational activities, and no doubt lead to visitor complaints.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant has spines for most of the year. “The plant is reported to cause contact dermatitis in some people.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “Wherever it occurs in the world, it becomes a very visible component of the flora.” In dense infestations it would create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial sp.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Large populations eliminate most indigenous flora and, after flowering in summer, the aerial parts of the plant die off. However, the dense population would provide suitable soil stability resulting in little effect on large-scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In disturbed areas large populations can eliminate ground flora and seriously impede overstorey regeneration. Invades native grasslands and grassy woodlands, and riparian vegetation. Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Although the aerial parts of the plant die off in summer, the flowering stems remain standing for several months. These are dry and woody and may contribute to an increase in the frequency of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“…once established, it dominates the vegetation of an area. Large plants with their dense foliage shade most pasture species as well as drawing moisture and nutrients from the soil.” Serious impact on grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Herb-rich heathy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands. VH CLIMATE potential. 
“…once established, it dominates the vegetation of an area. Large plants with their dense foliage shade most pasture species as well as drawing moisture and nutrients from the soil.” Serious impact on species within the lower stratum.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“…once established, it dominates the vegetation of an area. Large plants with their dense foliage shade most pasture species as well as drawing moisture and nutrients from the soil.” Serious impact on species within the lower stratum.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In disturbed areas large populations can eliminate ground flora and seriously impede overstorey regeneration. Major effect lower storey, minor impact on mid and overstorey species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In natural environments it is most likely to establish dense infestations in disturbed areas. It also tends to colonise in medium to large populations. In those situations, the presence of the weed would have a significant impact on the habitat of non-threatened fauna. Spiny nature of plant would deter grazing.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Small birds feed on the seeds.” Bird species not mentioned. Limited food source.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The plant has spines for most of the year. Potential for injury.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Small birds feed on the seeds.” Bird species not mentioned. Limited food source. Mice are known vectors for seed dispersal.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: No evidence of plant providing harbor for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: In permanent pastures C. cardunculus can dominate the vegetation. “Its spiny nature deters sheep and cattle from grazing on heavy infestations but, when hungry, animals will eat the leaves and survive on them.” “It has low nutrient value and may cause stomach impaction and mechanical injuries.” Potential for high impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No recorded impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Heavily infested pasture requires mechanical and/or chemical control to re-establish desired pasture spp. Presence of weed would have some minor influence on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Control practices can be incorporated into existing pasture use. Change in land use would not be required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: In Western Australia, the weed has occurred in cropping situations where it, “…impedes harvesting.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in both autumn and spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes as an understorey shrub in woodland and forest areas where it would receive shading from overstorey Eucalypts.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems and healthy natural ecosystems e.g. heathland.  National Parks (e.g. Dandenong Ranges National Park).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Erect, evergreen, leguminous shrub.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Mature plants are unpalatable”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Forms dense thickets, which exclude most other vegetation.

May completely smother surrounding vegetation.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought, fire, frost (occurs in alpine areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Prolific seed producer”.  > 2,000 flowers per bush (see pic. P & C 1992) therefore > 2,000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
“Seed is long lived within the soil”.  (IFFA 1989).
20-30 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms dense thickets.  (See pic. P & C 1992 p. 479).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Produce first flowers when about two years old.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Pods bursting and ejecting seeds.  Also seed movement by vehicles, equipment, agricultural products, mud, etc.  Perhaps birds? And animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Most seeds likely ejected from seed pods on hot summer days, with seeds only being flung  2 m from the parent plant.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Evergreen plant that can dominate the shrub canopy and grow to 3 metres high and wide. It grows in a variety of natural habitats including forest margins and riparian areas. It was used as a hedge plant. In dense infestations it would present a significant barrier to both humans and vehicles.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Infestations in natural ecosystems would restrict some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The seeds are highly poisonous.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The root system is not vigorous and is unlikely to cause structural damage. “Brooms are highly invasive, commonly invading disturbed bushland margins before expanding into less disturbed areas.” The presence of G. monspessulana would be very noticeable particularly during flowering, which would seriously affect the aesthetics of a cultural site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. Although it does occur in riparian areas, there is no documented evidence of its affecting water flow.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: An evergreen plant that provides extensive vegetative cover; branched taproot with numerous shallow lateral roots. This plant would not contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Generally invades disturbed. With its growth habit biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: It is a fire hazard in forest areas where it can form “an inflammable understorey at the edge of forests where fires are most likely to start.” High potential to change the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Valley grassy forest (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“Infestations shade and crowd out smaller shrubs and ground-flora species, eventually dominating the shrub canopy and severely impeding overstorey regeneration.” Serious impact on lower and mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy Woodland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Infestations shade and crowd out smaller shrubs and ground-flora species, eventually dominating the shrub canopy and severely impeding overstorey regeneration.” Potential to serious affect lower and mid-storey species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Dense thickets exclude most other plants and thus affect the carrying capacity.” It is widespread in medium to large populations. Its capacity to invade a broad range of vegetative communities including grasslands, woodlands, heathlands, forests and riparian areas and its potential to dominate indicates the plant is likely to have a major impact on the food sources of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No recorded benefits. The plant may provide harbor for some species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Seeds are highly poisonous.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: It “affords cover for pest animals such as rabbits.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Its effect in agricultural situations is limited as it mostly occurs in poorer pastures. In these situations, however, “it forms dense thickets, which exclude most other vegetation and thus affect the carrying capacity.” It would have at least a minor impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: The plant reproduces sexually and takes about two years to reach sexual maturity. The plant would not develop in cultivated situations.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: On arable land control is easily effected by mechanical means. Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not a serious weed of agriculture. Control is easily effected by mechanical means.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds don’t need any specific treatment other than sufficient light and moisture, seedlings however are rarely seen. Vegetative reproduction also doesn’t appear to have any restrictions (Blood 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Prefers bare ground for germination, however it is not reported to require it and it is tolerant of semi shade (Blood 2001).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems: sclerophyll forest and woodland: wetlands (Carr, Yugovic and Robinson 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Vine (Carr, Yugovic and Robinson 1992).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments:
No allelopathic properties described.
However the species does contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids and can smother the plant species it grows over (Muyt 2001; Porter & Geissman 1962).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids that make it unsuitable forage for most fauna and if slashed to ground level, plants can regrow (Jessop & Toelken 1986; Porter & Geissman 1962; Weber 2003)

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Reported to be a fast growing vine (Weber 2003).
Therefore presumed to be at least competitive.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Reported in saline wetlands, therefore tolerant of salinity and waterlogging (Blood 2001).
Drought tolerant (Blood 2001).
Has supposed fire retardant properties (Blood 2001).
Frost; Unknown.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Produces seed and can also reproduce vegetatively from stem fragments (Weber 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Unknown however the similar species Delaria oderata can have an annual seed production of 40,000 (Muyt 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
Seeds are long lived (Blood 2001).
Not reported for just how long.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Can smother other species and form thickets up to 20 m in diameter (Blood 2001; Muyt 2001). While it is not stated to form a self perpetuating monoculture it is believed one of these thickets would be very close to one.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Fast growing, could produce vegetative propgules within the first season (Blood 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The fruits as small (2-2.5 mm) hairy achenes and dispersed by wind (Weber 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Wind dispersed seed can travel distances of more than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Can from thickets of more than 20 metres in diameter (Blood 2001). As it is a vine however its growth would largely be over existing vegetation and not likely to close a vehicles track, it may impede access along a walking track.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Unremarkable ornamental species could alter aesthetics (Blood 2001).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Does contain toxic compounds, however not reported as toxic to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Unremarkable ornamental species could alter aesthetics (Blood 2001).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The similar Delaria oderata can impact upon flood mitigation strategies (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments:
No reported evidence that this species impacts on water quality factors such as dissolved oxygen or temperature.
However the plant contains Pyrrolizidine alkaloids that are toxic to fish and may be released into the water (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000; Porter & Geissman 1962)

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Unknown specifically for this species, however a similar species Delaria oderata can contribute to soil erosion on hillsides (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments:
It is able to cover and smother vegetation in the lower strata (<6 m) (Newton 1996).
This would reduce the living biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Has supposed fire retardant properties (Blood 2001). Could therefore reduce the fire intensity.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Valley Grassy Forest (V); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Greater Grampians; VH CLIMATE potential.
Forming thickets of more than 20 m in diameter, it is able to cover the lower strata with copious growth and smothering and therefore displacing species (Blood 2001; Newton 1996).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Grassy Dry Forest (D); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Greater Grampians; VH CLIMATE potential.
Forming thickets of more than 20 m in diameter, it is able to cover the lower strata with copious growth and smothering and therefore displacing species (Blood 2001; Newton 1996).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Lowland Forest (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Greater Grampians; VH CLIMATE potential.
Forming thickets of more than 20 m in diameter, it is able to cover the lower strata with copious growth and smothering and therefore displacing species (Blood 2001; Newton 1996).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Forming thickets of more than 20 m in diameter, it is able to cover the lower strata with copious growth and smothering and therefore displacing species (Blood 2001; Newton 1996).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Its ability to smother native vegetation is of concern in areas where it is invading small and threatened areas of undisturbed native vegetation (Newton 1996).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Unknown to what extent this species has, it may cause significant alteration of habitat; reducing plant species richness and diversity and therefore diversity of food and shelter available.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Nothing reported. Insects may visit flowers, dense foliage may provide some shelter.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Like other Senecio species its foliage contains a Pyrrolizidine alkaloid which can be toxic if eaten (Jessop & Toelken 1986; Porter & Geissman 1962). Unknown toxicity.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Visited by bees (Butz Huryn & Moller 1995).
