pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense foliage could provide shelter.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Has been linked to stock poisoning (Jessop & Toelken 1986). There have been very few reports however.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Unknown if the Pyrrolizidine alkaloid it contains effects the quality of the output.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: There is no evidence of this.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: There is no evidence of this.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Stock may need to be managed so as to avoid exposure and it may have some impact in forestry.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: No evidence of this reported.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
“Seeds germinate in spring. Aerial growth dies in autumn and new shoots emerge from roots each spring.” “Seeds appear to need special conditions for germination, for example, in North America, seedlings are usually found only in bovine dung suggesting that scarification of the seed coat…may be necessary.”

Established plants re-shoot from roots each spring. Requires natural seasonal disturbance for germination or root development.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Seeds appear to need special conditions for germination.” It is found mostly in pastures and neglected areas and, in the northern parts of Victoria, is usually associated with irrigation. It is not documented to occur in undisturbed natural ecosystems, however, in the United States it is known to be abundant along riverbanks, canals and irrigation ditches.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Camelthorn has become a troublesome weed overseas in cereal and horticultural crops where repeated cultivation aids its spread.” Most commonly occurs in highly disturbed or neglected environments.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: “An erect perennial shrub.” A member of the Fabaceae family (legume).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Camelthorn is grazed…by cattle and sheep in the United States and Australia.” Consumed, but root system remains intact to produce new shoots.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Seeds germinate in spring and rapid root growth ensures establishment ahead of most other species.” Rapid growth rate is likely to exceed most other species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Plants are sensitive to low temperatures.” Will not withstand flooding for extended period (weeks). While there is no documented evidence of the plant’s ability to survive drought, its deep root system may ensure the plant endures through periods of drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces vegetatively and sexually.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: In the United States, “Flower production is high under hot, dry conditions (700–4,000 per plant). There are 5 to 8 seeds in the pod.” Plants could produce more than 2,000 seeds annually.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
“Seed viability in semi-arid soils may extend over a number of years.” 

“Seeds remain viable for many years.” >25% of seed survive 5–10 years. include other propagule material e.g. roots increase from ML to MH.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: A perennial shrub with an extensive and vigorous root system. “It is strongly competitive with other plants and, in the Merbein infestation, has eliminated most other vegetation.” Long-lived, by does not establish as a monoculture.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants generally do not flower until they are 1 year old.” Propagules produced after 1 year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Camelthorn is grazed…cattle and sheep in the United States and Australia.” Cultivation equipment can also spread root fragments.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Cattle and sheep graze the plant, and machinery may spread propagules. These vectors could spread the plant by more than 200 metres from infestation.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Erect perennial shrub 40 to 100 cm high with rigid, much branched stems bearing numerous sharp spines 1.0 to 2.5 cm long. The spines can puncture human skin and break off in the wound. Dense infestations would restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The size and spiny nature of the plant may reduce some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Woody stems remain after the plant dies back in autumn. Spines present for most of the year. The spines can break off in the skin.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The plant has an extensive and vigorous root system. In north-western Victoria “…shoots regularly break through a sealed bitumen road and the roots have extended the patch by a distance of about 6 metres.” It has the potential to cause serious structural damage to cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The aerial parts of the plant die back in autumn leaving the soil surface exposed in dense infestations. The extensive and deep root system (2 m deep and 8 m laterally), provide good soil stability. Potential for low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In Australia, it is found in pastures and neglected areas. Likely to replace existing biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Woody tissues persist after plant death.” Increase fuel load is likely to increase frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland; CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential
“It is found mostly in pastures and neglected areas. It is strongly competitive with other plants. In Merbein [Victoria]…it has eliminated most other vegetation.” Major displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: “It is found mostly in pastures and neglected areas.” Requires pH>6. Unlikely to occur in any medium value EVC in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: “It is found mostly in pastures and neglected areas.” Requires pH>6. Unlikely to occur in any low value EVC in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “It is strongly competitive with other plants and, in the Merbein infestation, has eliminated most other vegetation.” Is found mostly in pastures and neglected areas. Likely to have a major impact on the lower strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In Australia, cattle and sheep graze the plant. However, it is also unpalatable and injurious to some animals. A competitive plant, it may impact on the habitat of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Cattle and sheep graze the plant. It may be a limited food source for some species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: It is injurious to some animals. The spines are present for much of the year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “The plant is confined to the northern parts of Victoria usually associated with irrigation.” Rabbits are known to occur in this area and the plant may provide some limited food.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense patches may provide limited harbor for rabbits.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Overseas, it is a troublesome weed in cereal and horticultural crops where repeated cultivation aids its spread. It has an extensive root system and strongly competes with other plants. Likely to have serious impacts on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No documented impact on quality. In the United States the plant is a potential alfalfa seed contaminant.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Where it occurs in pasture situations it is unlikely to affect land value. Sheep and cattle graze the plant without apparent harm (from the spines).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: In cropping situations cultivation spreads the weed and may increase shoot density. Land use would have to change until the plant was controlled. Change from cropping to permanent pasture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds and corms germinate after autumn rains”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
“It does not establish well on shaded sites:  but establishes.

 Invades dry sclerophyll forest and woodland where some shading would occur.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in heathland and heathy woodland.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Cormour geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Stock accustomed to grazing on infested areas are seldom affected, mainly because they do not eat much of the plant”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Patches can be very dense with almost 7,000 corms per square metre recorded in some areas”.  See pic. in P & C (1992 p. 76).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Occurs in semi arid areas.  Some corms likely to survive fire.  Occurs in freshwater wetland (seasonal).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing from corms and by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Up to 150 seeds per capsule x 8 capsules per plant = 1,200 seeds.  (See description and illustration in P & C (1992 p. 75)).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seeds are not long lived in the soil and most germinate in the autumn following formation.  Corms show longer viability than seeds”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Competes with crops and pastures and a very serious threat to indigenous communities.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants are 2 or 3 years old before they flower and produce seeds”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Machinery, animals (internal and external), wind and water.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Seeds remain viable after passing through stock and spread throughout much of WA, is thought to have been in cattle droppings.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Life cycle of H. miniata is much the same as H. flaccida, though H. miniata does not produce viable seed. Reproduction is from corms only. “…corms germinate after autumn rains.”

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “It does not establish well on shaded sites,”  but as a weed of grazing it does establish in pastures.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Occurs in semi-arid and sub-humid subtropical scrublands.” Establishes in grazed pastures where there is ample light and little competition. Disturbed situation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial herb reproducing from corms. Geophyte

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “…the weed is generally avoided by grazing animals. This avoidance… encourages the weed to persist.” Consumed but not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Patches can be very dense with almost 7,000 corms per square metre recorded in some areas.” With such dense infestations, the plant would take advantage of moisture and nutrients to the detriment of other species, retarding their growth. Growth rate possibly equal to similar species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
A recommended method of control is to use fire to clear debris from the infested area. This will maximise the amount of rainfall taken up by the soil and stimulate germination.

Additionally, it is thought that burning has some direct stimulation on germination. Corms survive low intensity (grass) fires. 

In ornamental situations, it is recommended to protect bulbs from frost.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by cormils that are produced in leaf axils, and around the main corm at the base of the plant. Vegetative reproduction only.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “It is estimated that in an established patch of two-leaf cape tulip there can be up to 200,000 cormils per square metre.” Plants produce large numbers of propagules, possibly more than 2,000 per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “The cormils of two-leaf cape tulip live longer than the seed of the one-leaf species, and may remain dormant in soil for at least 8 years.” Long-lived propagules.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Plants are 2 to 3 years old before they flower and produce seeds. (Two-leaf cape tulip produces seed, but it is not viable.) Seedling plants produce cormils. “… established infestations of cape tulip consist of plants of varying maturity, from non-flowering seedlings and plants 1 or 2 years old, to flowering plants 2 or 3 years old and older.” Plants produce propagules for more than 3 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Seedling plants produce cormils. Produces viable propagules in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: As with one leaf cape tulip, “The dried plants, with seed capsules intact, break off at ground level and are blown about by wind and carried in running water.”

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “… the most important method of dispersal at present is in hay or silage cut from infested paddocks.” Distribution of propagules in such material would extend beyond one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect perennial herb with two or three annual leaves to 2 cm wide, and flowers to 60 cm high. Even in dense infestations, the plant would not inhibit human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations in open situations cover large areas and, during flowering, look attractive. The presence of the weed would be obvious during this period, but it would have little impact on recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: All parts of the plant are poisonous if ingested. “There is a known human fatality in South Africa as a result of eating corms.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Because of its ability to form dense infestations (patches of up to 7,000 corms per square metre have been recorded), the weed would present a moderate negative visual effect if occurring in cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Aerial parts of the plant are only present for five to six months each year. However, the root system while not deep is fine and fibrous. With dense infestations (up to 7,000 corms per square metre), the soil integrity would not be subjected to significant soil erosion. However, where the plant occurs in seasonal wetland situations some erosion may occur. “Cape tulip corms can be spread by floodwaters.”

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: It grows best in open situations such as grasslands (pasture), competes with and replaces desirable plants in pastures. Direct replacement of biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Although it can grow at very high densities, the change in fuel load is minimal. Not likely to alter the fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Severely impedes the growth and regeneration of indigenous ground-flora.” Major displacement of ground-flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. It competes with and replaces desirable plants in pastures, but it does not establish well on shaded sites. “Severely impedes the growth and regeneration of indigenous ground-flora.” May not establish as large a population as in plains grassland, but still has a high potential to affect ground-flora.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Not likely to occur in low value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: It competes with and replaces desirable plants in pastures, but it does not establish well on shaded sites. “Severely impedes the growth and regeneration of indigenous ground-flora.”

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Threatens ANZECC rated rare or threatened native plant species

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Displaces desirable plants reducing food availability. Reduces carrying capacity. Although it is limited in distribution in natural ecosystems, it is present in medium to large populations where it does infest.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Cockatoos eat the corms readily after cultivation, apparently without ill effects.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: All parts of the plant are toxic, whether green or dry.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not documented. Cockatoos eat the corms readily after cultivation, apparently without ill effects. Potential for similar birds to also use the corms as a source of food.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Growth habit would not provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: M. miniata occurs mostly in grazing areas and is a serious weed of pasture. It replaces desirable pasture plants thus reducing carrying capacity considerably.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: It is not a problem weed in cropping situations. Reduced pasture may impact on the live weight of stock. “The most important method of dispersal at present is in hay or silage cut from infested paddocks.” This produce may be rejected for sale. No serious changes due to this weed being seen in community – product not rejected for sale

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Cape tulips can be difficult and expensive to eradicate.” Control on arable land and permanent pasture can be achieved, but “cultivation must be carried out for at least 4 years to exhaust the supply of dormant corms in the soil.” Considering the cost and time involved, the presence of this weed is likely to reduce the value of land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments:
“Cape tulips can be difficult and expensive to eradicate.” Chemical control may discourage farmers due to associated pasture damage. Land may have to be used for another agricultural activity (e.g. cropping or forestry).

Plant is tolerated – stock get resistant to toxic properties – unlikely to change land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No known impact on harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy → occurs under trees in scrubby paddocks & along shady creek banks.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes mostly in highly disturbed natural ecosystems e.g. roadsides, suburban allotments, paddocks, fence lines etc.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Erect shrub → ‘other’.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Cattle graze C. Parqui only after the more palatable species have been depleted.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Grows well on alluvial river flats often to the exclusion of most other vegetation.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Frost hardy, occurs in arid areas of South America, perhaps also waterlogging (occurs along creek banks & high rainfall gullies).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from creeping roots & by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: >2,000 assumed due to producing abundant berries containing seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds remain dormant in the soil for many years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Plants are ling-lived.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants are at least 2 years old before flowering.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Birds, water, pieces of root dragged by cultivation equipment.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect shrub 2 – 3 metres. It builds up large populations in moist habitats such as river flats, creekbanks and wetland edges. It has sometimes been planted as a hedge plant. High potential to block access to waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Due to its potential to build a large population in moist habitats, some associated recreational pursuits may be affected (e.g. swimming, boating, bird watching, etc).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Plant material is poisonous to animals and humans if chewed or swallowed. Some people may develop skin rashes from handling plants.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: In dense infestations it would present a moderate visual impact. Although the plant reproduces vegetatively and has an extensive root system, there is no evidence to indicate it could affect the structure of cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Although it invades creekbanks and wetland edges there is no indication it affects the flow of water.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Although it invades creekbanks and wetland edges there is no indication it affects water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: An evergreen shrub, it has an extensive though shallow root system. Unlikely to cause soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It forms extensive stands along disturbed edges and openings preventing growth and regeneration by indigenous plants.” Infestations would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: The plant does not create a fire hazard in natural ecosystems. Small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC=Alluvial terraces herb-rich woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. “The plant grows well on alluvial river flats often to the exclusion of most other vegetation.”

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: “Green cestrum builds up large populations in moist habitats such as river flats, creekbanks and wetland edges.” Unlikely to occur in any medium value EVC in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Montane damp forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; H CLIMATE potential.
“Green cestrum builds up large populations in moist habitats…on disturbed edges and openings.” CLIMATE potential distribution rating is HIGH in this EVC/CMA/bioregion; limited impact. Other EVCs less affected.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
“The plant grows well on alluvial river flats often to the exclusion of most other vegetation.” 

“It forms extensive stands along disturbed edges and openings preventing growth and regeneration by indigenous plants.”

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “The plant grows vigorously when neglected and is toxic to animals including cattle, sheep, horses, pigs and poultry.” Its ability to form dense stands, “preventing growth and regeneration by indigenous plants,” and its toxic property suggests the plant would reduce the habitat of desirable species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The dense stands may provide harbor for birds. Birds are known to eat the fruit.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Plant material is toxic.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Birds are a known vector, but it is claimed the plant is toxic to birds and bees.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense stands may provide harbour for pest birds.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “The plant prefers moist habitats such as river flats, creekbanks and wetland edges.” However, animals are attracted to the plant and will graze it. Infested areas have to be fenced off to prevent stock losses. “In Auckland, New Zealand, stock losses have occurred in spite of attempts to restrict access to the plant.”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: The plant takes several years to mature so would not become a weed of cropping. No seed contamination. Animals that eat the plant usually die; they do not end up in the food chain.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The plant grows vigorously, and it reproduces sexually and vegetatively. It is difficult to control. Where it occurs in grazing land the value of the land would be affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: In grazing situations stock losses can be minimised by fencing off infested areas. The land use would not be compromised.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seed germinates in spring after a period of cold stratification (Blood 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Seed can germinate in dense shade (Blood 2001). As the species is also reported to invade disturbed sites such as roadsides and waste areas, it is thought that the species can establish with out additional factors (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: The species can “invade relatively undisturbed vegetation” including wet sclerophyll forest and riparian vegetation (Blood 2001).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other. Tree or shrub (Blood 2001).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Reported to be unpalatable and toxic to stock species and not preferred by them (Connor 1977).
The species has very few insect pests in Britain where it was introduced in 1576 (Leather 1985).
There has been an anecdotal report that cultivated plants of this species have been completely stripped by deer (Dave’s Garden 2007).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Reported to have a moderate growth rate (PFAF 2007).
As a seedling the species’ growth rate has been found to be only marginally faster than Ilex aquifolium (Cornelissen, Carnelli & Callachan 1999). The species is therefore considered to have a growth rate equal to that of the tree/shrub species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Can be killed by fire and can resprout after fire (Blood 2001).
Susceptible to drought (Nardini, Tyree & Salleo 2001).
There is some conflicting evidence on frost tolerance; Blood (2001) reports the species to be frost tender, while PFAF (2007) report it to be hardy to zone 7.
Reported to not be tolerant of maritime exposure (PFAF 2007). This may indicate a  susceptibility to salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Primarily reproduces by seed; however it is reported to be capable of vegetative reproduction as lower branches can tip root if in contact with the soil (Blood 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Each fruit only contains one seed (Weber 2003).
Blood (2001) reports that the species produces numerous flowers, it is unknown however what a plants potential yield is.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Reported to be long-lived (Blood 2001).
Reported to be able to form pure stands (Weber 2003).
It is therefore thought likely that the species has a reproductive period greater than ten years or that is can form self-persisting monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown; being a shrub/tree it is likely to take 2-3 years to mature.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Spread internally by birds and animals (Blood 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
The fruit is eaten by blackbirds, however as their gape size is smaller than the species seed it is likely only to carry to cover and have an approximate dispersal distance of 100 m (Blood 2001; Debussche & Isenmann 1989; Spennemann & Allen 2000).
The dispersal distance for this species has not been reported, however as the plant produces medium sized fruits (10-12 mm) it may be dispersed by species such as currawongs and foxes which can disperse seeds more than 1 km (Spennemann & Allen 2000).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: The species has been used ornamentally as a hedging plant and has also been reported to be able to form large thickets in invaded areas (Blood 2001; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). Therefore this species is considered to have the potential to have high nuisance value to both people and vehicles.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Unknown.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: There is some conflicting information on the species toxicity, there are reports that the fruit is always toxic and others where it is reported to be edible when ripe, this is probably due to the difference between the wild form and the domesticated varieties (Blood 2007; �alisir & Aydin 2004; PFAF 2007). If the fruit is bitter it is toxic and if they are eaten can be fatal.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Unknown.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species can occur in riparian vegetation, there is no evidence however of it occurring in flowing water and obstructing flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species can occur in riparian vegetation, there is no evidence however of it occurring in water and affecting water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The species has a shallow root system (Aussie Gardening 2007).Therefore areas invaded by the species are viewed to have a moderate probability of large scale soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The species is reported to be able to form pure stands and generally reduce species richness (Weber 2003). It is unknown however how this affects biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (V); CMA= Corangamite ; Bioreg= Otway Plain ; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Reported to be able to form pure stands and generally reduce species richness (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is able to form monocultures within the middle strata and impact upon species in the lower strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Lowland Forest (D); CMA= Corangamite ; Bioreg= Otway Plain ; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Reported to be able to form pure stands and generally reduce species richness (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is able to form monocultures within the middle strata and impact upon species in the lower strata.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Forest (LC); CMA= Corangamite ; Bioreg= Otway Ranges; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Reported to be able to form pure stands and generally reduce species richness (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is able to form monocultures within the middle strata and impact upon species in the lower strata.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Reported to be able to form pure stands and generally reduce species richness (Weber 2003). Therefore the species impacts upon more than 60% of the floral strata, as it is able to form monocultures within the middle strata, inhibit the growth of species in the lower strata and prevent the regeneration of canopy species.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown; the species however generally reduces the species richness of the flora at invaded sites (Weber 2003).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Unknown; however the increased food the species provides through the fruit load could support increased populations of aggressive bird species such as currowongs, which could then impact on smaller species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Produces a fruit crop which may be of some assistance to bird species (Blood 2001).  Shrub species may provide some assistance in terms of shelter.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: It may be toxic to some species (Blood 2001). It in unknown if they would then consume material of the species and be caused harm.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Blackbirds are reported to eat the fruit (Blood 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Can form thickets (Weber 2003). The species could therefore provide some harbour to pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Suspected in cases of stock poisoning and if chickens eat material of the plant their eggs are reportedly inedible (Everist 1974).
Can kill stock, however this is uncommon as it is reportedly unpalatable to stock and not sort out by them (Connor 1977).
Can cause stock death, however, this occurs rarely therefore, it is considered to have only a minor impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Considered an environmental weed not an agricultural weed, it is therefore unlikely to have a significant impact.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Considered an environmental weed not an agricultural weed, it is therefore unlikely to have a significant impact.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Considered an environmental weed not an agricultural weed, it is therefore unlikely to have a significant impact.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Considered an environmental weed not an agricultural weed, it is therefore unlikely to have a significant impact.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Host of Mediterranean fruit fly (Blood 2001).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Seeds have a seasonal requirement for germination; it has been found that this species seeds germinate best during a period of fluctuating temperatures after a period of cold stratification such as early spring (Piotto & Piccini 1998).
Mass germination occurs in spring (Blood 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Seedlings prefer an area free of other vigorously growing ground flora and are unlikely to establish in dense shade (Muyt 2001). The species is however reported by Carr et al (1992) to invade grassy woodland and is therefore considered capable of establishing under a moderate canopy or litter cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
The species may have a preference for disturbed sites however it has been described as having the potential to invade riparian vegetation in the Victorian high country (Muyt 2001; Richardson, Richardson & Shepherd 2006).
Therefore the species is considered to be able to invade relatively intact ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; a deciduous tree species able to grow to 20 m (Debussche & Lepart 1992).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Although there has been no evidence for this species reported, other species in the genus have been reported to have allelopathic properties (Rice 1984).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Trees cut down by beavers have regrown from the stump (Fustec et al 2001).
The growth and form of seedlings exposed to heavy animal browsing was improved through a stumping technique (�i�ek & Tilki 2007).
The species can therefore tolerate extreme biomass reduction events and is considered therefore to be capable to withstand moderate browsing pressure.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: The species is reported to have a very high growth rate (Carus & �i�ek 2007).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Frost can damage seedlings (�i�ek & Tilki 2007). Being deciduous the species may be able to withstand below zero winter temperatures but is however considered frost tender (Blood 2001).
The species is considered one of the more drought resistant Fraxinus sp. however it is also reported to be drought tender (Blood 2001; Percival, Keary & Al-Habsi 2006).
Waterlogging; The species can tolerate periodic inundation (Muyt 2001).
The species tolerance to fire is not reported, however its ability to recover after being logged by beavers shows potential for recovery even if the above ground biomass is killed (Fustec et al 2001).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The species reproduces sexually by producing seed and vegetatively through suckering (Blood 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: The species is reported to be capable of producing thousands of seeds annually (Muyt 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown, the seeds are able to become dormant (Piotto 1997).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Can form monocultures (Muyt 2001).
The plantation rotation time for this species is reported to be 40 years (�i�ek & Tilki 2007).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown; however the species is described as very fast growing, therefore it is possibly not long,

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds are dispersed by wind and water (Debussche & Lepart 1992).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Seeds spread by water can be dispersed a number of kilometres (Debussche & Lepart 1992).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: The species is very fast growing, invades riparian vegetation and is reported to be able to form dense stands (Blood 2001; Carus & �i�ek 2007). As the species is reported by Fustec et al (2001) to be able to re-shoot from the stump when cut down, to create and maintain access to an invaded waterway, significant works may be required as the species would need to be controlled to prevent reinvasion.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Ornamental deciduous tree species would be obvious and may have some aesthetic impact.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Ornamental deciduous tree species would be obvious and may have some aesthetic impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species is reported to tolerate periodic inundation and is invading riparian vegetation (Muyt 2001, Richardson, Richardson & Shepherd 2006). The species is not reported to impact water flow however little information is available on this species impact on water in areas where it is an invading species.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Occurring in riparian vegetation the species is deciduous and in addition to this it’s litter has a fast decomposition rate (P�rez-Corona, P�rez Hern�ndez & de Castro 2006). Therefore the species may have similar impacts upon water quality as Salix species altering shading patterns and therefore temperature and changing the time, quantity and possibly the quality of litter inputs which could then impact upon dissolved oxygen. The extent this species can have on water quality has not however been reported on.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Unknown.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: There is conflicting evidence on this; the species is a fast growing tree with recorded biomass increases of 15 m3ha-1 per annum (Carus & �i�ek 2007). The species however can form monocultures shading out other tree and shrub species (Muyt 2001). Therefore the only biomass accumulation would be by this species and if the shrub layer is removed this could result in a net decrease however this is not known.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Creekline Herb-rich Woodland (V); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is reported to be able to form monocultures and prevent the regeneration of other species over time
(Muyt 2001).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Sedgy Riparian Woodland (D); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is reported to be able to form monocultures and prevent the regeneration of other species over time
(Muyt 2001).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (LC); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is reported to be able to form monocultures and prevent the regeneration of other species over time
(Muyt 2001).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
The species is reported to be able to form monocultures and prevent the regeneration of other species over time
(Muyt 2001). This would be a have a major impact on all layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The species is reported to be able to form monocultures and prevent the regeneration of other species over time (Muyt 2001). This level of change to vegetation is likely to impact upon species in terms of food sources and availability of appropriate shelter. The species impact upon native fauna however has not been reported.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Is used a nesting sites by birds in Europe (Polo & Veiga 2006; Su�rez, Balbontin & Ferrer 2000). Therefore the species may provide some support in terms of shelter.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Possible but not thought to be significant.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Is used a nesting sites by birds in Europe including starling species (Polo & Veiga 2006). Therefore the species may provide some shelter to low priority best species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
The species can be used as plantation timber (Carus & �i�ek 2007).
It is considered an environmental weed and is only recorded to significantly invade orchards that have been abandoned (Debussche, Lepart & Devieux 1999).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Considered an environmental weed.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Considered an environmental weed.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Considered an environmental weed.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Considered an environmental weed.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: There is no evidence of this.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes in ‘open spaces’ (e.g. roadsides, river flats, cultivation’s fallows).  However, stated as occurring in partial shade.  (Horticopia 1999).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in vigorously growing crops (e.g. cotton and grain).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: “Soft pumpkin – like vine spreading along the ground”,  (NSW Dept of Ag. 1962).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Have an Allelopathic effect on wheat and cotton radical elongation.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “As a rule, stock do not eat this plant”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“The extensive root system enables the plant to compete strongly with summer crops such as cotton”.  
(P & C (1992)

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of water logging? (Occurs on river flats, drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed (experiments indicate that cross-pollination is essential for fruit development).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Field grown plants produced on average of 122 pods per plant with an average of 71 seeds per pod”.  Therefore 122 x 71 = > 8,000 seeds per plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: As annual, mature plants would produce viable propagules for only one year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual herbs.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘Capsules adhere to wool, bag, clothes etc. and seed fall from capsules as the transporting agent moves from place to place”.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Above mechanisms could transport seeds > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect low growing annual herb 20 to 50 cm high. It occurs as isolated plants and small patches on roadsides, neglected areas and, occasionally, on fallows and in annual pastures, but broad-area infestations are rare.” The plant would have little or no impact on human traffic.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “It is generally found on disturbed sites on roadsides and river flats.” Its presence would create a minor negative visual impact. The slimy, sticky sap exuded by the stems, and the obnoxious odour produced by the secretions on the leaves would make it unpleasant to walk through an infestation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No toxic properties. “Entire young pods are used for pickling.” The claws of the fruit may cause injury to the bare feet of humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Low growing annual. May present a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: It commonly grows on disturbed sites and is unlikely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Small patches of isolated plants. It would replace existing biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: A low growing annual, it does not produce extensive vegetation and is unlikely to contribute to an increase in the risk of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
“It occurs as isolated plants and small patches on roadsides, neglected areas and, occasionally, on fallows and in annual pastures, but broad-area infestations are rare.” Sparse population density; minor displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to invade in low value EVCs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Marked seasonal variation in population size and density. Naturalised since 1882. Not documented as a weed of natural ecosystems.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In Australia, it occurs as isolated plants in small patches. Minimal impact on the habitat of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Seeds are eaten by cockatoos.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The fruit injures stock when caught over the mouth potentially leading to death by starvation. Also, it causes physical damage when the claws work into the animal’s body or become attached to the feet.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Seeds are eaten by cockatoos. Pest birds may also eat the seed.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A low growing annual; unlikely to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Commonly occurs as isolated plants and small patches. Is known to compete strongly with summer crops such as cotton. Minimal impact on yield. The fruit can injure stock, which may lead to death. Losses not documented.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Possible damage to sheep carcasses. Potential for major impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Occurs as isolated plants and small patches. The plant can be easily controlled by cultivation (normal farm operation). Seed viability is low. Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The plant can be easily controlled by cultivation (normal farm operation). Change in land use would not be required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: The dried fruit pods can break the combs of shearing machines.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Mainly occurs in ‘open’ habitats e.g. roadsides, river flats and cultivated fallows.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Can establish in summer crops, e.g. cotton.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect low-lying annual herbs.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Stock do not graze devil’s claw because of the offensive slimy discharge”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Completes strongly with summer crops (e.g. cotton).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought, water logging (occurs on riverflats).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed,

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Bulbous capsule contains numerous seeds.

10 flowers x 100 seeds per capsule =  1,000 seeds per plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual – only produces propagules 1 year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual – germinates in spring and flowers in summer.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “With its hooked claws, the fruit readily attaches to almost anything”, particularly sheep.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As seed ‘readily attaches to almost anything’, likely to spread > 200 m.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in spring, summer and autumn, but mostly in late spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Requires host.  Can grow in shade (Khanna et al 1976).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems (e.g. riparian), as well as vigorously growing crops.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Twinning parasitic annual herbs – climber/creeper.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Consumed by herbivores – unsure of response/palatability.
P & C (1992).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Rapid growth rate = to Orobanche aegyptiaca/ramosa.
Zerman & Saghir (1995).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought (occurs in Sonoran desert), frost (occurs in Finland).  Small seed would aid long distance dispersal.  Also presumably water logging (occurs in riparian habitats) – host tol. Of w/1.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproducing by seed.

Can also produce new individuals by asexual means.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Seed production is prolific and up to 16,000 seeds have been recorded from individual plants”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds may remain dormant in the soil for at least 5 years.  “Many (seeds) will remain dormant in the soil for years".  As long as 10 years according to Menke (1954) (cited in DAS 1976).  Stated to remain viable for > 60 years. (Province of British Columbia, Ministry of Ag. Fisheries and Food)

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual.  Monoculture not formed because requires presence of host plant.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Seeds may be set when plants are only 3 weeks old.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Farm equipment, water, animals,  (external & internal).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Can be transported “great distances”.  Such as: “Seeds of dodder pass through animals in a viable state and seedlings have been observed growing in droppings of cows, sheep, goats and kangaroos.  Seeds are also known to be spread in mud on the feet of birds”

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A twining parasitic annual herb with thread-like stems and no root system. It would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The plant produces a dense mass of stems coloured yellow, green or pink. Its presence is obvious and would have a major negative effect on the visual aesthetic of an area.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant does not present any spines or burrs. It is not known to be toxic to humans and seedlings have been observed growing in droppings of cows, sheep, goats and kangaroos.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Its presence would present a moderate visual effect. It would not have any negative impact on the structure of a site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Parasitises existing plants covering them in a dense mass of stems; unlikely to affect soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Produces dense mats covering host plants. Replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Low growing annual that does not produce significant organic material. No evidence of this plant contributing to an increase in the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Riparian woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfieds; VH CLIMATE potential.
“They…affect a wide range of broad-leaved plants…[and] grow under a wide range of environmental conditions.” “Severe yield reductions occur when crops are infested.” Major displacement of forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Hillcrest herb-rich woodland (D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfieds; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to occur in any low value EVC in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “They…affect a wide range of broad-leaved plants…[and] grow under a wide range of environmental conditions.” “It is seldom found on woody plants, grasses, cereals.” It reduces crop yields severely. Potential to affect the majority of the ground and mid strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: It affects a wide range of broad-leaved plants, but generally does not parasitise grasses. Animals will graze the plant. May have a minor impact on the habitat of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Seedlings have been found growing in kangaroo droppings. Minor food source.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Cattle and horses forced to eat the plant often develop digestive upsets.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No evidence to suggest pest animals use the plant as a source of food.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: An annual that forms a dense mass of stems, it may provide limited harbor for rabbits.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Severe yield reductions occur when crops are infested with golden dodder.”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Infested areas are often quarantined…” “Lucerne or hay containing golden dodder seeds or plant parts may not be sold or removed from the property.” Produce rejected for sale.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Severe yield reductions occur when crops are infested with golden dodder.” “Infested areas are often quarantined, causing considerable financial loss and inconvenience.” Potential negative impact on agricultural production would seriously affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “When dodder is removed from agricultural land, the area must be sown to resistant plants, such as cereals or pasture grasses, and not resown to susceptible crops for at least 5 years.”

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not viable to harvest crop. No increase in harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “Dodders transmit diseases in certain crops.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Germinates in late winter’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Requires natural seasonal temperatures for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘.. successful germination of seed and subsequent growth of the seedling to maturity is dependent on the level of sunlight penetration’ However, can tolerate partial shade (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In Brisbane, it has ‘invaded urban parks, bushland, gullies and streets’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Tree Life form – other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No evidence to suggest that plant is affected by herbivores.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Growth rate: Fast .. minimum for a fast growing medium tree’ (PIER 2005). Moderately rapid growth that will equal competitive species of same life form

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘It tolerates full sun, partial shade, drought, frost, heat, well drained to wet soils, extended flooding and air pollution. … may be tolerant of light salt spray, but not saline conditions’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Highly tolerant of frost, drought and waterlogging. Susceptible to salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by seed (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘As observed in .. K. elegans subsp. formosana, the flowers are entomophilous, bees and other small insects being the usual pollinators’ (Meyer 1976).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Fruits are up to 50 mm long and appear in large drooping clusters. The seeds are small, black and round and about 5 mm in diameter (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘.. relatively large seed based on photo, two seed per fruit and roughly 100-200 seeds per panicle’ (PIER 2005). Trees likely to produce greater than 2,000 propagules per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Not known exactly how long seeds can survive in the soil .. experiments have shown that the seeds can achieve a 90-100% success rate of germination after 10 months of moist storage .. may be viable for  some time’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Insufficient information to determine longevity  – score medium.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Insufficient information to determine length of reproductive period but would be greater than 3 years.  Score as Medium High.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Insufficient information to determine time to reach reproductive maturity. Score as Medium.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘Not known exactly how seeds are dispersed … possible that water may contribute, as supported by evidence of infestation of gullies in Brisbane….. birds may also be a factor in facilitating the spread’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Insufficient evidence – score as medium.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Insufficient information relating to dispersal. Score medium.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grows to approximately 5 meters tall (up to 18 metres under ideal conditions). Has ‘a dense rounded crown and may achieve a spread of 10-15 m when mature (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  No record of the plant forming clusters.  Would have minimal or negligible impact.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: ‘Abundant, colourful yellow flowers and pink, inflated fruit’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Grows up to 5 metres  with dense crown. May have minor effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Although species may cause ‘vomiting, abdominal pain, and in some cases diarrhoea, there is no evidence that it is consumed’ (PIER 2005).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: ‘Abundant, colourful yellow flowers and pink, inflated fruit’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Grows up to 15 metres with dense crown. Moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (PIER 2005).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Deciduous tree. Would leave some of the ground exposed for a period of time. Can occur in gullies but unlikely to contribute to large-scale soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Because of ‘its rapid growth habit and high seed viability.. may crowd out native plant populations (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Would depend on the area that the plant establishes but likely to be a direct replacement of biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Tree is of low flammability (PIER 2005). Small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Potential distribution of Koelreutaria elegans excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Potential distribution of Koelreutaria elegans excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Potential distribution of Koelreutaria elegans excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Because of ‘its rapid growth habit and high seed viability.. may crowd out native plant populations (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Would have a major effect on less than 60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Not documented as having an effect on non-threatened fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No evidence that the plant benefits fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Plant not documented to be toxic or have burrs or spines (PIER 2005).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No evidence that the plant provides a food source to pest species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: No evidence that the plant provides harbour for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not recorded as a weed of agriculture (PIER 2005).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping (PIER 2005).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No evidence that the weed would effect land value. Can be well controlled by herbicides (PIER 2005).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No evidence that the weed would cause a change in priority of land use. Can be well controlled by herbicides (PIER 2005).

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of agriculture (PIER 2005).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Although light may inhibit germination to some extent (Metcalfe 2005), H. helix is an opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘Will grow in variable light conditions but prefers shade, damp soils, and a moist, cool environment’ (ISSG 2005).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in ‘coastland, estuaries, natural forest, planted forests, riparian zones, urban areas, wetlands…  where it infests woodlands, forest edges, fields, hedgerows, coastal areas, salt marsh edges ’ (ISSG 2005).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Variable in life form – ‘it may be a perennial herbaceous vine or climber, a herb, a woody subshrub, or rarely a tree’ (Metcalfe 2005).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: ‘Known to produce chemicals that kill other plants (Allelopathy)’ (Blood 2001).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: A number of vertebrate species browse H. helix. In England, where sheep graze ivy, colonisation of grassland areas and woodland understorey may be severely restricted. A wide range of anthropods are found to feed on H. helix (Metcalfe 2005). Consumed and recovers slowly.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Fast growing (ISSG 2005). Moderately rapid growth that will equal competitive species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Low tolerance of fire when it does burn. Not tolerant of waterlogged soils. Tolerant of seasonal drought. (Metcalfe 2005). ‘Tolerates.. frost to at least -15�C. drought …salt’ (Blood 2001) Tolerant of 1 stress, susceptible to at least 2. Tolerant to at least 2, susceptible to at least 2.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Produces both vegetatively and by seeds (insect-pollinated) (ISSG 2005).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Fruits have one to a few hard, stone-like seeds (ISSG 2005) Rooting is prolific on all stems (Muyt 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Dormancy of cleaned seeds may last for up to 30 days; cleaning results in nearly 100% germination .. Seeds planted within the fruits may remain dormant for up to 57 days, associated with c. 40% seed mortality’ (Metcalfe 2005). Also produces vegetatively

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Longevity of plants in Australia is unknown but can live for 400 years in Europe (Muyt 2001).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Flowers are produced from about 10 years old (Metcalfe 2005).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Dispersed by birds, foxes and possibly water (Muyt 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Dispersed by birds, foxes and possibly water (Muyt 2001). Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Vines climb over trees and replace ground cover (Muyt 2001). Presence of weed would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: In Victoria, it has invaded dry and wet sclerophyll forests, woodlands, riparian vegetation, rocky outcrops and warm temperate rainforest (DEH 2004). May have a minor effect on aesthetics of an area.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: ‘Compounds in English ivy are somewhat toxic and include glycosides that cause vomiting, diarrhoea, nervous conditions and dermatitis in sensitive individuals’ (PCA 2005). Can result in skin rash, dermatitis in some people (Schmidt 2005). Poisoning has been reported in a child (Metcalfe 2005), although unlikely to be ingested.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Vines climb over trees and replace ground cover (Muyt 2001). Presence of weed may have moderate visual effect on cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Muyt 2001).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘Rooting is prolific on all stems and the extensive rootlets on trailing stems can dry the soil surface around them’ (Muyt 2001). Evergreen plant so highly unlikely to contribute to large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Vines climb as high as they can be supported and, with their heavy weight and vigour, smother and collapse overstorey plants’ (Muyt 2001). Over time, trees may be replaced by more open community leading to a decrease in biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: ‘Being evergreen and with a relatively high water content, ivy is slow to burn and will not readily spread fire well … has been proposed to reduce fire risk in seasonally dry areas’ (Metcalfe 2005). Plant has potential to moderately change both frequency and intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Limestone Box Forest (V), CMA= East Gippsland, Bioreg.=East Gippsland Lowlands, CLIMATE=VH. 
An ‘aggressive invader that threatens all vegetation levels of forested and open areas, growing along the ground as well as into the forest canopy’ (PCA, 2005). Displaces all species within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riparian Forest (D), CMA= East Gippsland, Bioreg.=East Gippsland Lowlands, CLIMATE=VH.
An ‘aggressive invader that threatens all vegetation levels of forested and open areas, growing along the ground as well as into the forest canopy’ (PCA, 2005). Displaces all species within a layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland Forest (LC), CMA= East Gippsland, Bioreg.=East Gippsland Lowlands, CLIMATE=VH.
An ‘aggressive invader that threatens all vegetation levels of forested and open areas, growing along the ground as well as into the forest canopy’ (PCA, 2005). Displaces all species within a layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: An ‘aggressive invader that threatens all vegetation levels of forested and open areas, growing along the ground as well as into the forest canopy’ (PCA 2005). Major effects on all layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: No documented evidence to suggest weed effects non-threatened fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Weed not known to provide benefits to indigenous fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Weed not known to be injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Seed is dispersed by birds including English house sparrows, European starlings. (PCA 2005) In England, the typical consumer is the blackbird (ISSG 2005). In Australia, seed dispersed by foxes (Muyt 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbour for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
