ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Weed not known to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed not known to cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘In tropical climates plant growth is probably continuous, especially in moist conditions or following rainfall’. ‘Forms roots when the nodes make contact with moist soil’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘Forms roots when the nodes make contact with moist soil (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Prefers full sun or part shade. Plants in deep shade do not thrive’. ‘If established underneath a hedge it often comes up through the hedge by leaning its weak stems on the shrub’s branches’ (Whistler 2000  cited in PIER 2005). Although the weed prefers sun, can establish under a moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘Most infestations .. occur on vacant residential land, along fencelines and in neglected garden beds .. present along roadsides and on crown land’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Establishes  in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A perennial creeper (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Where Asystasia gangetica is present in Malaysia it has been found that ‘strip-grazing sheep in a weed infested rubber plantation markedly reduced weed height (to 10 cm above the soil) after 3 grazing cycles.  The sheep preferentially selected Asystasia spp. before passing on to other weeds ’ (Abdullah 1985).

 ‘High stocking rates (>6 sheep/ ha) resulted in a decrease in the proportion of palatable species, namely, Asystasia gangetica.’ (Chong et al 1997). Consumed and recovers slowly.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘.. a perennial creeper that grows rapidly’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Assume that weed has moderately rapid growth rate that will equal competitive species of the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘Winter frosts kill the above-ground plant parts but plants regrow the following spring from basal shoots’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Found on coastal sandy soils’ (Whistler 2000 cited in PIER 2005). ‘It can withstand drought.’

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Produces through seed and rhizomes (PIER 2005). Produces both sexually and vegetatively.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Each seed capsule ‘contain four flattened seeds’. ‘High seed production’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). No documentation on number of capsules per plant. Score medium.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘ seeds remain dormant for some months .. if the seed coat is removed, about 75% germinate’ (Akamine 1947). Assume that seeds survive less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘ .. the plant dies back to ground level after most of the ripe capsules have released their seeds’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). No documentation on the reproductive period of the plant. Score as medium.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘ it grows rapidly following germination and throughout flowering and seed capsule production’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). PIER (2005) states that can be grown as an annual.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘The main method of dispersal over long distances is by human activities, such as mining, gardening, landscaping and roadworks. Propagules can spread by light vehicular traffic (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘The main method of dispersal over long distances is by human activities, such as mining, gardening, landscaping and roadworks' (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Without further documentation, assume few propagules will disperse greater than 1 km but many will reach 200-1,000 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: ‘A perennial creeper .. grows up to 0.5 m high alone but to 3 m high on supporting vegetation’. Due to the preferred sites the weed grows ‘on vacant residential land, along fencelines and in neglected garden beds’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003), it is likely to have only a minimal or negligible impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: ‘Infestations have now been identified at .. Anna Bay and Fern Bay [NSW]. These infestations are spread over a distance of 9 km and range in size from 2 square metres to several hectares’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Due to the smothering nature of the weed, it may have a minor effect on the aesthetics of the land.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No toxic principle or physical properties likely to cause injury.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Not documented to occur in areas of cultural significance.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘..makes a good ground cover, especially on slopes that need protection from erosion’ (Whistler 2000 (cited in PIER 2005)). Unlikely to contribute to large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Smothers other ground plants and displaces vegetation’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Likely that biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Grows well in drought areas and the plant will die off (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). However no evidence to suggest that it would change the frequency or intensity of fire. Assume small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Coastal Banksia Woodland (V); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=H.
‘Can smother all vegetation in the herbaceous layer’ (PIER 2005). Monoculture within the groundcover layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: No EVC found.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Coastal tussock grassland (LC.); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=H. 
‘Can smother all vegetation in the herbaceous layer’ (PIER 2005). Monoculture within the groundcover layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘Smothers other ground plants and displaces vegetation’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Can smother all vegetation in the herbaceous layer’ (PIER 2005). Would have a major effect on <60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The potential for Asystasia gangetica ssp. micrantha to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations. No impact on threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: As an environmental weed, ‘it smothers other ground plants and displaces vegetation, which reduces the availability of habitat for native plants and animals’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). May have a minor effect on fauna spp.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No evidence that the weed benefits indigenous fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be harmful.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbour to pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: ‘It is a major weed overseas .. it infests plantations, particularly oil-palm crops, and competes effectively for soil nutrients, reducing productivity and increasing crop management costs’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Has the potential to have a minor impact on quantity of produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No evidence that the weed impacts on agricultural quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No evidence to suggest that the weed will affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No evidence that the weed will cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: ‘It is a major weed overseas .. it infests plantations, particularly oil-palm crops, and competes effectively for soil nutrients, reducing productivity and increasing crop management costs’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Weed may lead to a minor increase in cost of harvesting.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: The weed provides host to minor disease (Asystasia gangetica mottle – potyvirus). Diagnostically susceptible host species include Chenopodium amaranticolor, Nicotiana tabacum, Phaseolus vulgaris and Sesamum indicum (VIDE 1996).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect multi-stemmed perennial herb commonly 1.5 to 2.0 metres high. It is found along waterways, drainage lines and in seasonally moist locations within grasslands and woodlands. Dense infestations may restrict access to waterways. A soft, herbaceous plant the high growth of the plant may be a nuisance to people.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations along waterways may restrict some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission documents F. vulgare as causing photosensitivity through skin contact with the plant or its juices.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Not an aggressive root system; structure not affected. Dense infestations would create have a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A perennial herb that in dense infestations eliminates most other ground flora, but retains good ground cover. It has a stout branched taproot to around 1 metre deep with many laterals. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Grows mostly in open, disturbed areas, such as roadside, railway easements, channels and drains. Minor effect on biomass. Dense infestations may increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Flower stems partly die back in winter. Images of dense infestations show increased dry matter. Possible minor increase to the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Falls; VH CLIMATE potential
“Grows best in open, unshaded situations. Once established, fennel excludes almost all other vegetation.” Major displacement of species within different strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Shrubby woodland (R); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above. Population density may be limited due to overstorey cover.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dense infestations eliminate most other ground-flora and severely impede overstorey regeneration.” Major effect on ground flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: While livestock may find the plant palatable, its widespread distribution in medium to large populations suggests that native fauna do not significantly graze on it. With its dominant nature, it is likely to reduce habitat.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No documented benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Apparently animals graze the fennel stubble without ill effects.” Not known to cause injury to native fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No evidence of the plant providing food to pest species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense infestations may provide harbor for minor pests such as rodents.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not a serious weed of pasture or cropping. “It does not establish in grazed pastures or cultivated paddocks. Herb growers note that tomatoes and beans do not grow in association with fennel, suggesting possible allelopathic effect.” Likely to have some effect in those situations.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a serious weed of pasture or cropping. “When growing on headlands of arable crops, seedlings often occur in the crops.” Minor impact on quality through seed contamination.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not a serious weed of pasture or cropping.  Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not a serious weed of pasture or cropping. Land use not affected.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No increase in harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn and spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy cover  understorey shrub in many vegetation formations.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems/healthy natural ecosystems, e.g. heathland, dry and damp sclerophyll forest and riparian vegetation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Erect evergreen leguminous shrub.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Little grazed”  consumed but not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Plants develop slowly during the first year.  They do not flower until at least two years old”. “A rapid” spreader which can crowd out pasture”.  (Dept. Crown Lands and Survey. Vic. 1982).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought, water logging? (Occurs in riparian vegetation): fire (regenerates prolifically from soil-stored seed after fire).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Bush contains > 2000 flowers (see pic. P & C 1992 p. 476 & 477). Therefore > 2000 seeds.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Forms impenetrable thickets (not really monocultures though).  

However, as it is a shrub it is likely to produce propagules for between 3-> 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants do not flower until at least two years old.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seeds are ejected some distance from pods in summer.

Seeds are spread by vehicles, could disperse > 200 m, produce, mud, etc.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Most seeds would be ejected < 20 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Evergreen plant that can dominate the shrub canopy and grow to 3 metres high and wide. It grows in a variety of natural habitats including forest margins and riparian areas. It was used as a hedge plant, and dense infestations would present a significant barrier to people.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Infestations in natural ecosystems would restrict some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The seeds are highly poisonous.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The root system is not vigorous, thus, the plant would not cause structural damage to sites. “Brooms are highly invasive, commonly invading disturbed bushland margins before expanding into less disturbed areas.” The presence of G. linifolia would be very noticeable particularly during flowering, which would present a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: An evergreen plant that provides extensive vegetative cover; branched taproot with numerous shallow lateral roots. This plant would not contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Generally invades disturbed bushland areas. With its growth habit biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: G. monspessulana is a fire hazard in forest areas where it can form “an inflammable understorey at the edge of forests where fires are most likely to start.” G. linifolia is likely to be similar. High potential to change the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
“Infestations shade and crowd out smaller shrubs and ground-flora species, eventually dominating the shrub canopy and severely impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major displacement of some species within low to mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Montane grassy woodland (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian forest (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Infestations shade and crowd out smaller shrubs and ground-flora species, eventually dominating the shrub canopy and severely impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major impact on lower and mid-storey species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Its capacity to invade a broad range of vegetative communities including grasslands, woodlands, heathlands, forests and riparian areas and its potential to dominate indicates the plant is likely to have a major impact on the food sources of native fauna. “Dense thickets exclude most other plants and thus affect the carrying capacity.” It is widespread in medium to large populations.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No recorded benefits. The plant may provide harbor for some species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Seeds are believed to be toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: It “affords cover for pest animals such as rabbits.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Its effect in agricultural situations is limited as it mostly occurs in poorer pastures. In these situations, however, “it forms dense thickets, which exclude most other vegetation and thus affect the carrying capacity.” It would have at least a minor impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: The plant reproduces sexually and takes about two years to reach sexual maturity. In cropping situations the plant would not develop sufficiently to produce seed that may contaminate seed crops.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: On arable land control is easily effected by mechanical means. Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not a serious weed of agriculture. Control is easily effected by mechanical means.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence it increases harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Optimum temperature for germination is between 20 and 35oC. Day-time temperatures below 15oC and above 45oC are unfavourable for germination (Reddy & Singh 1992). Requires natural seasonal disturbances for germination, e.g. Spring/Summer temperatures

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: In one study, shading by the leaf canopy was shown to be effective in inhibiting germination of B. pilosa, (Fenner 1980) and in another study, no seedlings survived in a shade environment typical of that found in a rainforest understorey (Pattison, Golstein & Ares 1998). Can grow in partial shade (ESC 2002) but unable to establish under a moderate canopy. Requires access to light to establish (Holm et al 1977).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Documented as invading grassland, heathland and forest (Weber 2003) as well as ‘remnant grassy vegetation’ in NSW (ESC 2002). Disturbance need only be minimal for B. pilosa to invade (SSC 2003). Establishes in only minor disturbed natural ecosystems, e.g. grasslands.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Erect annual or short-lived perennial shrubby herb to 150 cm in height (Smith 1985; Holm et al 1977). Lifeform: Other

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments:
Several studies have shown Bidens pilosa to have strong allelopathic influences. Leaf or root extracts significantly suppressed germination and seedling growth of a number of crops, including, soya beans, mung beans, rice, maize, radish, cucumber, lettuce, sorghum and ground nuts (Bhatt, Tomar & Misra 2001; Zeng & Luo 1995; Stevens & Tang 1985; Singh & Hazarika 1996). It has also been suggested that the allelopathic compounds remain active in the dried parts of the weed and are released during decomposition (Singh & Hazarika 1996).
Allelopathic properties seriously affect some plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: In one study, regular manual ‘topping’ of B. pilosa plants increased the shoot and leaf yield of plants, with more regular 2 weekly harvesting producing greater yields. Plants harvested 9 times, at 3 weekly intervals, demonstrated development of flower buds (Norman 1994). Plants are likely to exhibit a similar response to herbivory. Species recovers quickly, and capable of flowering under moderate herbivory pressure.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: This species will out-compete native species on exposed margins and in revegetation sites (SSC 2003).  Found to grow three times faster than a species of similar life-form, Bidens sandwicensis (Pattison, Golstein & Ares 1998). Moderately rapid growth that is likely to equal competitive species of the same life form or exceed some other species of the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerates arid conditions (GCW 2001), dry infertile soils and is often most prolific on warm north facing rocky slopes (ESC 2002). It will survive all but the most extreme droughts (Labrada 2001). Above ground parts are killed by heavy frosts but plants will grow back quickly from roots. It can withstand temperatures down to –15oC (Labrada 2001) and known to grow at an altitude of 3,600 m in Peru (Becker et al 1998). Occurs in wetlands (Calflora 2007) and wet dune slacks (Moreno-Casasola P & Vazquez G 1999). It is not fire tolerant but quickly
invades burnt areas (Smith 1985). Evidence suggests it is moderately tolerant of drought, water logging and frost but is susceptible to fire. The level of tolerance is not clear from the information available so a medium rating has been assigned.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Sexual (self and cross pollination) (Grombone-Guaratini, Solferini & Semir 2004).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: A single plant may produce 3,000-6,000 seeds per year (Weber 2003). Produces above 2,000 propagules.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds were found to survive for 3-4 years in the soil seedbank (Voll et al 2001). Seeds survive less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Forms dense stands that cover large areas eliminating native vegetation (Weber 2003). 
Evidence suggests that species forms self-sustaining monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: In Argentina, the majority of a population was found to start flowering 4 months after germination (Gurvich et al 2004). Reaches maturity and produces viable propagules in under a year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds are widely dispersed by adhering easily to clothes and animal fur (Weber 2003) and are also spread by wind, water and soil (SSC 2003; ESC 2002).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘The aggravating little needles will embed themselves in your clothing by the dozens every time you brush past the stems’ (Floridata 2007)’. Seeds are widely dispersed by adhering easily to clothes and animal fur (Weber 2003). Due to the ease of seed attachment to clothing and fur, it is very likely that at least one propagule will disperse greater than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Forms dense cover along roads and trails (Smith 1985). ‘The aggravating little needles will embed themselves in your clothing by the dozens every time you brush past the stems’ (Floridata 2007). Due to the described nuisance value of the burrs (ESC 2002; Floridata 2007), its presence along trails and its growing height to 150 cm (Holm et al 1977), it is likely this species could impede individual access in to certain areas.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Its ability to form dense cover along roads and trails (Smith 1985), height to 150 cm (Holm et al 1977) and the described nuisance value of its burrs (ESC 2002; Floridata 2007), may deter some people from utilising certain recreation areas. Minor effects to recreational uses.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The roots, leaves and flowers are strongly phototoxic. Substances isolated from the leaves can kill human skin in the presence of sunlight at concentrations as low as 10 ppm (PFAF 2007). This plant is sometimes used as a food source in southern Africa (Holm et al 1977) and the leaves can be used to make a tea (PFAF 2007). It is unlikely to be used locally as a food source, however there are some potentially injurious properties present. A medium rating has been assigned.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Grows in cracks in pavements and walls (Labrada 2001). May have a moderate negative visual affect on some cultural sites or infrastructure.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Predominantly a terrestrial species, not likely to have an impact on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Predominantly a terrestrial species, not likely to have an impact on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The extensive fibrous root system (SSC 2003) and strong taproot (Labrada 2001) of this species may give it the potential to decrease the probability of soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Its ability to form dense stands that cover large areas, (Weber 2003) and attain a height of 1.5 m, (Holm et al 1977) could lead to a biomass increase in more open communities.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: It is not fire tolerant but quickly invades burnt areas (Smith 1985), however, no information was found documented on the capacity of B. pilosa to alter the fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Creekline Grassy Woodland (BCS= E); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Goldfields; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Can form dense stands that cover large areas eliminating native vegetation and preventing the regeneration of native species (Weber 2003; Smith 1985; Labrada 2001). Likely to cause major displacement of some dominant species within the lower vegetative strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Hills Herb-rich woodland (BCS= D); CMA= North Central; Bioreg= Goldfields; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Can form dense stands that cover large areas eliminating native vegetation and preventing the regeneration of native species (Weber 2003; Smith 1985; Labrada 2001). Likely to cause major displacement of some dominant species within the lower vegetative strata.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Shrubby Riverine woodland (BCS= LC); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Can form dense stands that cover large areas eliminating native vegetation and preventing the regeneration of native species (Weber 2003; Smith 1985; Labrada 2001). Likely to cause major displacement of some dominant species within the lower vegetative strata.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Can form dense stands that cover large areas eliminating native vegetation and preventing the regeneration of native species (Weber 2003; Smith 1985; Labrada 2001). Potential to have major effect (<60%) on the lower vegetative strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Its impact specifically on threatened flora was not found documented but its capacity to form dense stands eliminating and inhibiting the establishment of native vegetation (Weber 2003; Smith 1985) is likely to similarly affect threatened species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Its capacity to eliminate native vegetation and prevent its establishment (Weber 2003; Smith 1985) is likely to reduce faunal habitat, however, no specific information was found documented.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: A study in NSW, found that seeds of Bidens pilosa made up approximately 50% of the Winter-Spring diet of Red-browed finches (Todd 1996). Provides an important alternative food source.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Burrs are described as being a nuisance on sheep and other fleece producing livestock (ESC 2002), however, no information was found documented to suggest the species is injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: In India, bees were found to forage throughout the year on flowers of Bidens pilosa (Reddy & Jacob 2001). In Malawi it is a plant commonly cut to feed rabbits and yields the highest gross energy content of the 16 plants tested (Ayoade, Makhambera & Kayange 1985). Known to be palatable and fed as forage to rabbits, however the extent to which it would be eaten under natural browsing conditions is unknown. Provides food for a minor pest species and may provide food for a serious pest species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Its ability to form dense stands (Weber 2003) and attain a height of 1.5 m (Holm et al 1977) gives this species the physical capacity to harbour small to medium pest animals. However no specific information was found documented on its observed capacity to harbour pest animal species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: In a study in Uganda, B. pilosa reduced dry bean, Phaseolus vulgaris, cropping yield by a mean of 48% (Ugen, Wien & Wortmann 2002) and in Peru, yield was reduced by 18.75 - 48.9 % (Cerna & Valdez 1987). Serious impacts on quantity, > 20% reduction.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Burrs are described as being a nuisance on sheep and other fleece producing livestock (ESC 2002). It is also documented as a seed contaminant of several crop species and described as a difficult weed seed to separate from grain (Bogdan 1966), however, no specific information was found documented on the level of impact it would have on agricultural quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Described as a principal weed of numerous crops in many countries (Holm et al 1977). It can form dense stands (Weber 2003) and significantly reduce crop yield (Cerna & Valdez 1987;Ugen, Wien & Wortmann 2002). It has also developed resistance to some herbicides, (Christoffoleti 2001; Nyabundi & Kimemia 1998) which could result in normal control practises not being effective against this species. However, no information was found documented to indicate that the presence of this species has caused reduction in land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Described as a major weed of numerous crops in many countries (Holm et al 1977). It can form dense stands (Weber 2003) and significantly reduce crop yield (Cerna & Valdez 1987;Ugen, Wien & Wortmann 2002). It has also developed resistance to some herbicides, (Christoffoleti 2001; Nyabundi & Kimemia 1998) which could result in normal control practises not being effective against this species. The serious impact on yield and herbicide resistance, could lead to a change in the type of crop that is grown, or perhaps, a more major change in land use. However no specific information on the capacity to which it alters land use practises was found documented.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Documented as a seed contaminant of several grain crop species and described as a difficult weed seed to separate from grain (Bogdan 1966), indicating it may increase harvest costs. However, it is unclear from the information available, the level of impact it would have on harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: A host of Root knot nematode (Ijani, Mabagala & Nchimbi-Msolla 2000) and Tomato spotted wilt virus (NSW Agr. 1953). Also known as a host of Schlerotinia sclerotiorum (Cottony Rot) and is found naturally growing infected with this disease in fields of cauliflower, maize and soya beans (Phillips 1992). Host to pest and diseases of important agricultural produce.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: C.albida (syn C.sumatrensis) was found to require temperatures between 10o and 25oC and light to germinate (Zinzolker et al, 1985) in a laboratory environment. Most seeds emerge in autumn but some seeds can also germinate in Spring (Thebaud et al, 1996). However Spring seedlings have a reduced survivorship compared to autumn germinants. Seed germinates within 1-4 weeks in acid, sandy soils (Case and Crawley, 2000). The species requires certain conditions such as temperature and moisture to be adequate in order to germinate.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: The likelihood of C.sumatrensis recruitment was positively correlated with the extent of bare ground and increased disturbance (Case and Crawley, 2000). The plant has been noted as being a poor competitor against native species (Case and Crawley, 2000). The plant most commonly established in areas of disturbed open ground with access to light and minimal interspecific competition. The plant appears to require more specific requirements to establish such as open space and direct light.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
C.sumatrensis is a plant widely naturalised in disturbed soils (Calflora) open cultivated fields and pasture and wasteland (Everett, 2002; Walsh and Entwisle, 1996). It has been found in roadsides, disturbed wetlands and wasteland from Perth to Albany (Hussey et al, 1997) with the occasional plant often found in undisturbed bush (ESC, 2004). In France C.sumatrensis occurs in gardens, vineyards and in old fields (Case and Crawley, 2000).
In the Mediterranean C. sumatrensis typically establishes and persists in old fields whose age ranges from 0-30 yr abandonment (Thebaud et al, 1996). In Greece it grows mainly in urban habitats (Economou et al, 2002) but also occurs in natural and agricultural ecosystems (Economou and Nekarios, 2003). Has been found to establish in disturbed areas of native vegetation and in natural sand dunes and grasses (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995). In Australia it is able to establish in dry coastal heath, heathland, mallee shrubland, grasslands, sclerophyll forests, woodland, riparian vegetation and freshwater wetland (Carr et al, 1992). It is a successful coloniser that can take advantage of disturbances (Case and Crawley, 2000) and can tolerate a variety of habitats and environmental conditions (Economou et al, 2002). The species requires low interspecific competition, long distance dispersal and regular disturbance for successful establishment and colonisation (Case and Crawley, 2000). The species prefers highly disturbed areas and has the capacity to establish in native ecosystems also.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Winter annual-biennial herb to 2 m high (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: The stems, leaves and inflorescence of C.albida (syn C.sumatrensis) have been recorded as having an allelopathic influence on oat growth. Oat (Avena sativa) growth was inhibited from phytotoxic activity of upper leaves and inflorescence tissues of C.albida (syn C.sumatrensis) (Economou et al, 2002).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Case and Crawley (2000) found that rabbit grazing had strong negative effects on C. sumatrensis recruitment and survival. Unprotected plants seldom developed beyond rosette phase under such grazing conditions (Case and Crawley, 2000). The authors noted that the species cannot survive high intensity rabbit grazing. Weed is palatable to livestock and native browsers such as wallabies (ESC, 2004). In addition Thebaud et al (1996) found that
herbivory weakly but significantly reduced survival to flowering. The plant tolerates grazing however potential fitness may be sensitive under extreme grazing pressure. Sensitive to extreme grazing but withstands moderate grazing pressure. Reproduction strongly inhibited by herbivory but weed may still persist.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Denser more competitive than other Conyza spp (C. canadensis) (Thebaud et al, 1996). The plant exhibits vigorous rapid growth (Economou and Nektarios, 2003) that exceeds species of the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Seedlings from the spring cohort generally experience very high post emergence mortality through desiccation in the Mediterranean region (Thebaud et al, 1996) indicating an intolerance to drought conditions. Early seedling mortality was recorded by Thebaud et al (1996) due to abiotic stresses such as autumn frosts or spring drought.
Rosettes are able to flower under moderate shade (Ohtsuka, 1998) however germination requires sufficient light.
The plant is killed by fire and has been described a establishing in disturbed wetlands (Hussey et al, 1997) indicating a degree of tolerance to waterlogging. Therefore the plant is defiantly susceptible to three environmental stresses, drought, fire and frost, but little information exists on its tolerance to salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The species reproduces by seed (Case and Crawley, 2000). Species are self fertile (Thebaud et al, 1996). No information was found on reproduction of this species.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: A related species C. bonariensis (Pruski, 2006) plant produces on average of 110,000 seeds (Wu and Walker, 2004). One single flower head contains 190 to 550 seeds with an average of 400 per flower head (Wu and Walker, 2004). C. sumatrensis has been noted as having a prolific seed set; it produces and average of 94.6 florets per head (capitulum) (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995). Based on the above numbers and sited images of inflorescence (RBGSYD, Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) show numerous flower heads indicating that the plant produces over 2000 seeds per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds do not remain dormant and under laboratory conditions, seed longevity is only 2-3 years (Thebaud et al, 1996). Seeds germinate whenever conditions are ideal (Case and Crawley, 2000). In the closely related species C. bonariensis (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995) seeds were 6% viable after being buried for three years (Wu et al, 2007)

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: The species is a winter annual-biennial herb to 2 m high (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) and the flowering period lasts 1-4 months (Thebaud et al, 1996). Therefore the mature plant produces viable propagules for only 1 year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: The species is a winter annual-biennial herb to 2 m high (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996). Thebaud and Abbott (1995) recorded the average time to bolting in C. sumatrensis as 11 weeks. Subsequently the average age at flowering in the same species was recorded as 19.8 weeks (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995). In addition Cleland and Suding found that the mean day of peak flowering in C. floribunda (Syn C. sumatrensis) occurred at 120 days after  germination.  Therefore the plant will produce propagules in under a year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
C.sumatrensis seeds are very light and all bear a pappus that facilitates wind transport (Thebaud et al, 1996, Carr et al, 1992). Seeds are also dispersed by water (Carr et al, 1992) and human dispersed through vehicles and mechanical means (ESC, 2004). There is a possibility that seeds are transported by animals externally (Carr et al, 1992). The propagules are very light and mostly spread by wind but are also spread by humans, animals, water or
vehicles.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: High dispersal potential (Economou and Nektarios, 2003). Very likely that at least one propagule will disperse greater than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Plant architecture is one erect stem with an apical panicle of capitula (flowering head) (Thebauud et al, 1996) that can produce dense stands (Economou et al, 2002) up to two metres high (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996). Sited images of infestations indicate that accessibility is likely to be inhibited presenting a moderately low nuisance value.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: C.albida (synonym C.sumatrensis) has been reported in athletic fields including soccer pitches and golf courses as well as in urban parks, historical sites and monuments, cemeteries and private gardens (Economou and Nektarios, 2003). Populations of this weed are likely to affect aesthetics and activity in recreational areas such as golf and soccer.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Not known to be injurious to people, no prickles, spines (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) or toxins (ref) present in this plant.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: In England the species has been found in cracks of concrete, gravel car parks and building sites (Case and Crawley, 2000). This indicates that the plant can establish within and around infrastructure potentially having both a moderate visual and unlikely to have a structural effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Essentially a terrestrial species that occurs in relatively disturbed areas. However the plant has been described as establishing in disturbed wetlands (Hussey et al, 1997); but has been mostly referred to in the literature as having most impact terrestrially. However it may have a minor impact on surface or substrate flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Given that the species has the capacity to establish in disturbed wetland (Hussey et al, 1997), it may subsequently have a noticeable but minor effect on light levels through increased foliage subsequently effecting waterbody function and water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The species usually invades already bare and disturbed areas where competition is low between the invader and established vegetation (Case and Crawley, 2000). It easily invades and grows under the canopy of the summer annual communities, succeeded by perennial grassland species (Ohtsuka, 1998). Its invasive nature could suppress the native flora in the more open habitats it favours (Bevan, 1992). Dense stands can smother native vegetation, particularly in grassy remnant vegetation of farming areas (ESC, 2004). However it is a poor competitor and undergoes significant decrease with increasing competition (Case and Crawley, 2000). It has a huge root system that can cause soil erosion (Addison, 2007). In open habitats it may improve soil stability, however its invasive nature could suppress other species, presents a moderate probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The existence of C. albida (syn C. sumatrensis) exhibits direct and indirect effects on the structure of plant communities (Economou and Nektarios, 2003). Its invasive nature could suppress the native flora in more open habitats it colonises (Bevan, 1992). Dense stands can smother native vegetation, particularly in grassy remnant vegetation of farming areas (ESC, 2004). The species can easily invade and grow under the canopy of the summer annuals, succeeded by perennial grassland species (Ohtsuka, 1998). This suggests that the plant is a displacing species and direct replacement of biomass by the invading species may occur.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: On the basis that the plant does not significantly alter the biomass of a community, it can be concluded it has a small or negligible effect on fire risk. Unk

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Creekline Grassy Woodland (E); CMA= Corangamite; Bioregion= Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Dense stands can smother native vegetation, particularly in grassy remnant vegetation of farming areas (ESC, 2004). C. sumatrensis can easily invade and grow under the canopy of the summer annuals, succeeded by perennial grassland species (Ohtsuka, 1998). The plant can grow up to two metres in height (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) coupled with its invasive potential the species has the ability to cause significant displacement within the lower stratum.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Grassy Dry Forests (D); CMA= Goulburn Broken; Bioregion= Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Dense stands can smother native vegetation, particularly in grassy remnant vegetation of farming areas (ESC, 2004). C. sumatrensis can easily invade and grow under the canopy of the summer annuals, succeeded by perennial grassland species (Ohtsuka, 1998). The plant can grow up to two metres in height (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) coupled with its invasive potential the species has the ability to cause significant displacement within the lower stratum.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Heathy Dry Forests (LC); CMA= East Gippsland; Bioregion= Heathy Dry Forest; VH CLIMATE potential.
Dense stands can smother native vegetation, particularly in grassy remnant vegetation of farming areas (ESC, 2004). C. sumatrensis can easily invade and grow under the canopy of the summer annuals, succeeded by perennial grassland species (Ohtsuka, 1998). The plant can grow up to two metres in height (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) coupled with its invasive potential the species has the ability to cause significant displacement within the lower stratum.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: The existence of C. albida (syn C. sumatrensis) exhibits direct and indirect effects on the structure of plant communities (Economou and Nektarios, 2003). It can easily invade, colonise and grow under the canopy of the summer annuals communities, succeeded by perennial grassland species (Ohtsuka, 1998). Dense stands can smother native vegetation, particularly in grassy remnant vegetation of farming areas (ESC). Its invasive nature could suppress the native flora in more open habitats it colonises (Bevan, 1992). The plant can grow up to two metres in height (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) therefore it can have a major impact on species diversity and abundance in both the lower and mid stratum.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The effect on threatened flora is unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The flowers have been reported to be eaten by the Crimson Rosella Platycerus elegans (RBGSYD) and are palatable to livestock (ESC). Furthermore deer were noted to graze on C. sumatrensis at the beginning of the flowering period during Case and Crawley (2000) trial. Although the plant can change plant community structure (Economou and Nektarios, 2003) it does provide an additional food source for some non indigenous fauna. It is likely to have minor effects on fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments:
C. sumatrensis is palatable to native browsers such as wallabies (ESC, 2004). This suggests that it provides some
assistance as an additional food source. However little other information exists on the benefits to native flora.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: After consulting the literature (Case and Crawley, 2000; Economou and Nektarios, 2003; Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) there was no reports of the plant begin toxic or injurious to indigenous fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Deer were noted to graze on C. sumatrensis at the beginning of the flowering period during Case and Crawley (2000) trial. Although deer is not a pest, this finding supports the assumption that other pest species such as goats may also find it palatable. Evidence also exists that the Crimson Rosella eats the flowers (RBGSYD) again suggesting that pest bird species may also use it as a food source.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The species can grow to heights of two metres (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996). Sited images suggest that dense stands have the capacity to harbour rabbits or foxes temporarily at low densities.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Closely relate C. bonariensis (Flaxleaf fleabane) and C. canadensis (Canadian fleabane) (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995) are major weeds in dryland minimum tillage production systems (Wu et al, 2007). They are quick to colonise bare non–cropped areas including bare fallow or in poorly competitive crops (Walker et al, 2004; Moore, 2004). Colonisation appears best in wide-row chickpea, skip row (wide row) sorghum and in areas of poor crop establishment irrespective of the time of year and crop type (Ward and Hamilton. 2004). More specifically C. sumatrensis is a persistent weed problem in vineyards and orchards in Europe where it is the main plant species in lemon orchards in Portugal (Vasconcelos et al, 2006; Economou et al, 2002). It has also been recognised as an emerging weed species in minimum tillage systems in Australia (Wu and Walker, 2004), however it is not yet as common or prevalent in these systems as its two closely related species mentioned above. Subsequently little information exists on the species impact on quantity or yield of agricultural produce. However it would be correct to say based on the prevalence of Conyza species in agricultural systems that it is likely that C. sumatrensis
has the capacity to become a serious weed of agricultural systems.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments:
Closely related C. bonariensis (Flaxleaf fleabane) and C. canadensis (Canadian fleabane) (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995) are major weeds in dryland minimum tillage production systems (Wu et al, 2007). They are quick to colonise bare non–cropped areas including bare fallow or in poorly competitive crops (Walker et al, 2004; Moore, 2004). Colonisation appears best in wide-row chickpea, skip row (wide row) sorghum and in areas of poor crop establishment irrespective of the time of year and crop type (Ward and Hamilton. 2004). More specifically C. sumatrensis is a persistent weed problem in vineyards and orchards in Europe, where it is the main plant species in lemon orchards in Portugal (Vasconcelos et al, 2006; (Economou et al, 2002). It has also been recognised as an emerging weed species in minimum tillage systems in Australia (Wu and Walker, 2004) however it is not yet as common or prevalent in these systems as its two closely related species mentioned above but with C. bonariensis it is the main species in the cropping areas of northern NSW and Southern Queensland (Storrie, 2007). A paucity of information exists on the species impact on quality of agricultural produce. However that it is
likely that C. sumatrensis has the capacity to become a serious weed of agricultural systems like C. bonariensis and C. canadensis.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: A known weed of agricultural systems (Walker, 2004). However there is no information in the literature that indicates how this species may change land use.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Closely related C. bonariensis (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995) is the most common and persistent fleabane in agricultural systems particularly in the northern cropping region (Rollin and Tan, 2004). For effective management of Fleabane (C. bonariensis) farmers have resorted to growing more competitive crops, such as winter cereals, in heavily infested areas. (Walker et al, 2004). Furthermore in an effort to manage the weed zero-till growers are now cultivating (Loveday, 2004). However little information exists on the impact C. sumatrensis has had on land value.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments:
Closely related C. bonariensis (Flaxleaf fleabane) and C. canadensis (Canadian fleabane) (Thebaud and Abbott, 1995) are major weeds in dryland minimum tillage production systems (Wu et al, 2007). The cost of Fleabane has been loss in production and increase in herbicide costs, both contributing to less profit to the producer (Milne, 2004). The prevalence of Fleabane in fallows has meant a doubling in weed control costs in the last 10 years (Walker, 2004). It has also required a change from zero-til to cultivation (Loveday, 2004) and a change in farming configurations and rotations to maximise competition against fleabane (Walker et al, 2004). More specifically C. sumatrensis has been recognised as being problematic during the cultivation period (van Keer and Turkelboom). Unlike the above two Conyza species C. sumatrensis has not yet developed resistance to a number of herbicides (Storrie, 2007). Resistance in C. sumatrensis is still limited to paraquat (Storrie, 2007). C. sumatrensis is not as common in agricultural systems as C. bonariensis and C. canadensis however is likely to establish as a persistent problem in these systems based on the behaviour of other Conyza species and
subsequently have an impact on harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments:
C. albida Willd ex Spreng (syn C. sumatrensis) tested positive for the Pepino mosaic virus in Spain (Cordoba et al, 2004).
Host of turnip mosaic virus in Zimbabwe (Chivasa et al, 2002). C. sumatrensis was found to be infected by the yellow leaf curl virus in Spain (Jorda et al, 2001). C. sumatrensis is host to several common viruses.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Most seeds germinate with the opening rains in April or May but a few continue to germinate through winter”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Established in sclerophyll forest and woodland where it would receive some shading.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Invades lowland grassland and grassy woodland, dry sclerophyll forest and woodland.

Also invades grazing and cropping land.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect woody shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Animals rarely eat the plant”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Seedlings establish quickly…it competes aggressively with developing pastures and crops”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of drought (occurs in central and northern Victoria).

“Tolerates a wide range of soil conditions”.  Perhaps some salinity/water logging or perhaps some moderate fires as ‘new growth is produced from the crown’ annually.  (P & C 1992 p. 307).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
“Reproducing from a perennial crown and by seed”.

 - New growth produced from crown, not a dispersal mechanism.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Mature plants produce about 50,000 seeds annually”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Some plants persist for 7 to 10 years”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Seeds germinate in April or May  - flowers and seeds produced in November.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wind, water, animals, clothing, agricultural produce, machinery.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: All above mechanisms (except wind) could disperse many seeds. 200-1,000 m

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Woody, bushy shrub. Invades dry sclerophyll forest and woodland. Generally 1 to 1.5 m in height. “In rainfall areas >500 mm pa can reach 3 m height and 2 – 2.5 m in diameter.” Potential to limit the activities of bushwalkers.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Weeds presence is obvious, particularly during flowering, November to autumn. Major negative affect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Not known to affect humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Existence of plant is quite noticeable, but is not likely to cause any structural changes.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial sp.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Perennial. Fibrous, densely branching roots to 20 cm depth and up to 6 m in diameter.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It competes aggressively with developing pastures and crops, and becomes dominant in the early years of infestation.” Bushy property of plant suggests biomass not negatively affected. However, in woodland areas it is likely to reduce biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: While predominantly a weed of open areas (e.g. pastures, wasteland), as a woody, bushy shrub, it may have a minor impact on frequency of fire in native ecosystems.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential
In the Mt Napier State park, it occurs in, “large patches significantly altering native vegetation.” Invades lowland grassland & grassy woodlands, dry sclerophyll forest and woodlands. Major displacement of species within different strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Box-Ironbark forest (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential
Can occur on forest margins. Minor impact on grasses/forbs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Montane dry woodland (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highland Southern Falls; VH CLIMATE potential.  Can occur on forest margins. Minor impact on grasses/forbs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In the Mt Napier State park, it occurs in, “large patches significantly altering native vegetation.” Invades lowland grassland & grassy woodlands, dry sclerophyll forest and woodlands. Likely to have a minor impact on lower strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “In natural areas the plant is a strong competitor, forming dense thickets that exclude native species.” Reduction in habitat for non-threatened fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: None recorded.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Plant contains alkaloids. May be hazardous.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: See comment at Q16.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “In natural areas the plant is a strong competitor, forming dense thickets.” This growth habit may provide harbor for birds.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Competes aggressively with developing pastures and crops…and often becomes dominant in early years of infestation rendering infested lands unproductive.”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No recorded impact on agricultural quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “…heavily infested lands (become) unproductive.”

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See question 23 above. “Left undisturbed, however, it gradually thins out and is rarely a problem in well managed pastures and cereal crops.”

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence of increased harvest costs. “…it is rarely a problem in well managed cereal crops.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in both autumn and spring”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Young plants survive even in 90% shade”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Broom is found in grassland/woodland/open forest including a wide range of disturbed as well as undisturbed communities”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
“Once established, English Broom fixes nitrogen in the soil”.
  
Legume.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Once established, English Broom fixes nitrogen in the soil, which inhibits the growth of native species adapted to nutrient poor soils.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Consumed by stock, (cattle, sheep, horses and goats), but not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“Competing strongly with native species”.

“Once established it dominates the vegetation of an area, smothering quite large shrubs”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Tolerates frost, mature plants tolerate summer drought, mature plants generally killed by fire but may survive if intensity not great”.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “9650 seeds per plant have been recorded”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seeds, remain dormant in the soil for at least 20 years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
“Plants are believed to live for about 10 to 15 years”.
If lived for 15 years would produce seeds for > 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants do not flower until at least 2 years old”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: See below for comment: also spread by machinery, animals, agricultural products and mud.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
“Pods: open during summer, bursting open on hot days to eject the seeds several metres”.

“Earthmoving equipment, including road graders are responsible for much spread”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Dense stands seriously impede movement.”

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “English broom is a devastating species capable of totally transforming invaded habitats. It simplifies the structure and diversity of the ground-flora…eventually preventing overstorey regeneration.” The weed would have a major impact on recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant does not have spines or burrs, however, the seeds are poisonous if eaten in quantity.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The root system does not appear to be vigorous, however, the notable presence of the plant would have a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. It will not grow in swampy places.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant provides dense coverage, and it has been planted to stabilise sand dunes and to bind soil in road cuttings or following fire. It would not contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It simplifies the structure and diversity of the ground flora, and crowds or shades out shrubs and tree seedlings, eventually preventing overstorey regeneration.” Broom infestations left undisturbed can prevent the re-establishment of overstorey eucalypts.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “English broom…burns with intense heat.” Once established it makes the native vegetation much more susceptible to fire because of its flammability and the intense heat with which it burns.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Sub-alpine grassland (V); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.  
“Once established, [it]…dominates the vegetation of an area, smothering quite large shrubs and preventing re-establishment of native species.” Fixes nitrogen. Major displacement of dominant species within different strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Sub-alpine woodland (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
“It simplifies the structure and diversity of the ground-flora, and crowds or shade out shrubs and tree seedlings.”
Major effects lower and mid strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Threatens ANZECC rated rare or threatened native plant species

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Habitat is significantly reduced. C. scoparius infestations dominate ground-flora and can prevent access to water.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The seed is spread by a number of animals (ants, cattle, horses and pigs), and seedlings have been found growing along wallaby tracks. Possible minor food source for native fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The seeds are thought to be poisonous if eaten in quantity.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Possible food source to pest animals such as birds or ants.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: It provides harbour for pest animals including feral pigs and blackbirds.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Although a significant weed of natural ecosystems it is also a serious weed in orchards and pastures in some areas. “It establishes very rapidly after forests are harvested and out competes naturally regenerating as well as planted species.” In forestry situations it is likely to have a serious impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect the quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Eliminating English broom infestations can take several years due to the large number of long-lived seeds that accumulate in the soil.” Attempted broom control in pasture areas in the Barrington Tops and elsewhere have proved expensive and largely ineffective. Presence of the plant is likely to reduce land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Presence of the plant may dictate a temporary change in land use. “Dense patches have been eliminated by bulldozing and repeated disc cultivations over 2 years.”

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seedling establishment appears to be enhanced by soil disturbance” (Tunison, 1985). Requires cold stratification for seed germination (NPDC, 2006). Requires natural seasonal low temperatures to germinate.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Moderately shade tolerant…[as] under a sparse canopy. It can be shaded out or severely suppressed by deep shade” (Tunison, 1985).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Able to invade and take over native ecosystems without any apparent disturbance” (Smith, 1985).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Shrub (NPDC, 2006).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Low hedging tolerance by livestock or wildlife with medium palatability (NPDC, 2006).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Rapid (NPDC, 2006).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Occurs in wet to mesic habitats…Resprouts quickly following fire (Smith, 1985). Recorded in boggy sites (Tunison, 1991). Tolerates temperatures as low as –25�C (NPDC, 2006). Medium drought tolerance.  Not tolerant to salinity (NPDC, 2006). Highly resistant to frost, fire and waterlogging, some drought tolerance but susceptible to salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Seed and vegetatively (NPDC, 2006) by root sprouting and aerial shoots forming roots with soil contact (Smith, 1985).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: High fruit/seed abundance (NPDC), 2006).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Lifespan is moderate (rather than long or short) relative to most other plants (NPDC, 2006) and forms dense clonal thickets (monocultures) (Tunison, 1991).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Floricanes develop in the second year (Tunison, 1991).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Frugivorous birds (Smith, 1985).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Bird dispersal (Smith, 1985) makes it very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Propagation in response to seasonal factors – “Perennating buds form on the stock and woody rhizome between autumn and winter and emerge to give vertical shoots in the following spring”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Study showed plant was ‘shade intolerant where the photon flux density was < 20% full daylight’. Beerling et al (1994) p. 959.  Most commonly found in ‘open’ habitats. E.g. “In its native habitats in Japan, it occurs on hillsides and mountain slopes in open sunny sites…In North America…it is most common and vigorous in open moist sites and occurs along riverbanks, wetlands, roadsides and in a variety of disturbed areas”.  (Haber 1999 p. 1). 

 “Grows best in full sunshine, providing sufficient nutrients and water are available, is affected even by moderate shade”. Beerling et al (1994) p. 964

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed ecosystems, (e.g. wetlands, riparian areas, on the fringe of, or in open woodland).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A geophyte according to the Raunkiaer system.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
“In Britain sheep, cattle, horses and donkeys graze the above ground shoots”. Beerling et al (1994) p. 976.so consumed, but assumed to recover quickly from rhizomes. Most commonly found in ‘open’ habitats. E.g. “In its native habitats in Japan, it occurs on hillsides and mountain slopes in open sunny sites…In North America…it is most common and vigorous in open moist sites and occurs along riverbanks, wetlands, roadsides and in a variety of disturbed areas”.  (Haber 1999 p. 1). 

 “Grows best in full sunshine, providing sufficient nutrients and water are available, is affected even by moderate shade”. Beerling et al (1994) p. 964.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “The vigorous growth potential of this sp. Is reflected in its ability to regenerate from rhizomes buried up to 1 m deep…young  shoots grow as rapidly as 8 cm a day.  The plant’s deep root system and spreading rhizomes provide a competitive advantage in acquiring water and nutrients compared with other less vigorous species”.  (Haber 1999. P. 3).  Also described as being – ‘fast growing’ (Haber 1999, p. 5).  “Considered by Crawley (1987) to be one of the ‘top 20’ invasive aliens of Britain”.  (Beerling et al (1994) p. 967).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of frost (moderate).  “Plants are vulnerable to late spring and early autumn frost”.  However, a study in Japan revealed that “by October seedlings survived only the – SC treatment, whereas by November seedlings survived temperatures of -15oC”.  (Beerling et al 1994 p. 969).  “Fire is also a poor control method and seems not to affect the viability of the underground rhizomes”.  (Beerling et al 1994 p. 967).  

Also assumed to be tolerant of some water logging as commonly occurs in wetlands and riparian areas, riverbanks and flood plains. (Beerling et al 1994 : Haber 1994).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
“In its native habitats in Japan, there is high seed set but low seedling survival”.
So in Australia (Victoria), seed set is also assumed unlikely.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Outside its native range in Japan, reproduction is limited almost exclusively to vegetative spread, due to the rarity of male plants with fertile pollen.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “No systematic study of the longevity of seed has been undertaken, but seed from a tetraploid F. x bohemica, stored at room temperature retained viability for 4 years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
