inv_repro_period.comments: “The stand-forming habit of F. x bohemica, produces a dense summer canopy beneath which few other species can survive”. (Beerling et al 1994 p. 959).   “Dense monocultures” observed (De Waal et al 1995 p. 203).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Following quote in qu. 1…”Woody stocks continue to increase in mass with age and also provide lateral creeping rhizomes within their first year “.  (Beerling et al 1999, p. 959).

“Effective reproduction appears to be entirely by means of the extensive and rapidly-growing rhizome system”.  (Grime et al 1990 p. 285).  These new rhizomes are propagules, capable of germination and establishing if fragmented.  “Even rhizome fragments as small as 8 g (fresh weight), are capable of regenerating new plants”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Vegetative fragments spread by water, wind, and earthmoving activities.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Road making activities dispersed fragments  200 m.

Winds in coastal areas have carried fragments “a few hundred metres”.

Many colonies along rivers are result of down stream dispersal of fragments.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect, much-branched perennial herb to 90 cm high. It is armed with stout spines on rigid leaves and dense infestations become almost impenetrable to grazing stock. Humans too, would also have difficulty in walking through an infestation; the spines would be a significant nuisance.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Infestations are known to occur along riverbanks and dense infestations may restrict access to water-based recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The stems can remain on the plant after the aerial parts die off in autumn. Spines would be present for much of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The root system is not vigorous and would not affect the structure. Dense patches would have a moderate impact on the visual aesthetic of an area.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Although the plant has a robust taproot the aerial parts of the plant die back in summer leaving areas of soil exposed. Moderate probability of large-scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Not documented as dominating species, it replaces existing biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Dry flower stems break off and are carried by the wind to collect against any obstruction. Large collections of this dry matter may create a minor change in the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Creekline grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.  
“…much of the present Victorian infestation is along the Loddon River downstream [of Smeaton].” New rosettes can grow to 60 cm in diameter, which would restrict growth of other plants. Not recorded in Carr et al (1992). Minor impact in grassland/riparian situations.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact similar to 10(a) above, however, growth under open forest canopy may restrict population density.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy dry forest (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Does not appear to significantly affect the structure of an invaded site. Where it does occur in pastures, it is weedy because animals will not graze the plant. Clumps may prevent the regrowth of desirable forage species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Grazing animals do not eat the aerial growth because of the stout spines on the rigid leaves, and the spiny nature of the plant discourages animals from grazing near it. Likely to have similar effect on native fauna. Some reduction in habitat.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No documented benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The stout spines present for much of the year may injure animals.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not documented.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “Clumps of golden thistle provide effective harbor for rabbits.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Stock do not eat the aerial growth and, “avoid grazing close to plants [thus] valuable pasture is neglected.” Dense infestations become almost impenetrable and are likely to reduce carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: It occurs in vineyards and orchards in part of its native range and does not appear to impact on the quality of harvest.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The plant is effectively controlled by mechanical or chemical methods. Until the plant is controlled, grazing areas may be of limited use. May reduce land value slightly

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Left untreated, the plant would restrict grazing on permanent pasture. It can be controlled by cultivation, so land may have to be used for cropping activity.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No know effect on harvesting costs. Assume limited impact.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Most germination occurs in autumn and spring to mid summer”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in ecosystems receiving shading e.g. dry and damp sclerophyll forest.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades undisturbed ecosystems – heathland and heathy woodland.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Of Fabaceae family therefore a legume.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Young seedlings, which are not armed with stiff spines, are readily grazed by sheep and rabbits”.  “Animals eat seedlings and young shoots but mature plants are rarely grazed”.  (P & C (1992 p. 483)

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“Rapidly growing”.

“Control is made difficult by the vigour and comprehensiveness of the plant”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
“While the plant will grow…in Mediterranean climates with dry summers and in areas with significant winter frost, it does not thrive”.  “Tolerates many soil types, frost to -20oC (young plants are sensitive), salt laden wind and drought”.  

(Blood 2001 p. 82).  “Burns readily but not killed – re sprouts and seeds germinate”. (Blood 2001 p. 83).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Seed production is prolific with an annual input of up to 6 million seeds per hectare”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Have a high viability and even seeds 25 years old is 85% viable”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
“Plants are long lived, producing new growth each spring”.

“Living to a maximum life of 29 years”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants may flower first when about 18 months old”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Refer to ‘dispersal’ in P & C (1992 p. 482)  wind, birds, ant’s etc.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Birds are important in spreading seeds and patches of weeds are often found under trees or posts where birds have perched”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: It is widespread in a broad range of vegetation communities in medium to large populations. Grown as a hedge plant and armed with numerous spines to 5 cm long, the plant forms dense impenetrable thickets that prevent access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Because of its ability to form dense thickets that prevent access, infestations would have a significant impact on limiting recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant is armed with spines to 5 cm long throughout the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: An erect much-branched shrub to 3 metres that can form dense thickets. The root system is not vigorous and thus not likely to cause structural damage. The plant would have a moderate visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant was recommended for sandbinding in coastal areas. Would not contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Gorse forms dense, impenetrable thickets that eventually exclude all other indigenous vegetation and prevent any regeneration occurring.” Likely to increase biomass initially.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
“Furze burns readily and dense patches are a considerable fire hazard.”

Not greatly changes but just moderate – fire frequency isn't necessarily increased because of gorse (David Boyle).

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Valley grassy forest (V); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Falls; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Fixes nitrogen. “…exclude[s] all other indigenous vegetation and prevent[s] any regeneration occurring.” Major effect on species within low to mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Damp heathland (R); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Forms dense impenetrable thickets that eventually exclude all other indigenous vegetation and prevent any regeneration occurring.” Would have a major effect on low to mid strata..

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: It eliminates native forage plants reducing food source for native fauna and restricts access. “Animals eat seedlings and young shoots, but mature plants are rarely eaten.” Overall reduction in habitat for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Gorse thickets often provide habitat for small native birds and mammals.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The plant is armed with spines on leaf tips for all of the year. But is unlikely to be injurious

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Birds and ants spread seeds. Possible pest species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “Dense furze growth provides excellent harbor for rabbits.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: The plant restricts animal movement and access to other pasture species. Dense infestations severely reduce carrying capacity. In New Zealand, “it is a major problem in forestry, where it interferes with establishment operations and competes strongly with young trees.”  Probable does decrease quantity but is not unviable to harvest probable less than 5%. Tolerance to the weed – put up with it for many/few years. Impact on yield is not significant.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to impact quality of produce. Not a weed of cropping situations.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Control is made difficult by the vigour and competitiveness of the plant.” Seed banks can be as large as 100 million per hectare and seeds remain viable for several decades. Having this plant on agricultural land would reduce its value significantly due to the cost and duration of control activities.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: If left unmanaged, it would result in a major detrimental change to agricultural use. Animals do not graze mature plants and significant works are required to eliminate its occurrence in forestry situations.  Tolerance to the weed – put up with it for many/few years.-  some alteration but no major change – In New Zealand Canterbury plains and hillsides – move to forestry to suppress Gorse – but does not downgrade priority land use in Vic.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence of increased harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not known as a vector/host for disease.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Insufficient information to determine germination requirements for this plant. Score medium.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Found on waste ground, on roadsides (Brummitt 2002). ‘Weed of waste places and forest margins’ (TWS 2002). ‘Hedgerows, gardens, ungrazed pastures and waste places (Roy et al 1998). Would suggest that plant requires more specific requirements to establish but insufficient information to determine establish requirements. Score medium.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Found on waste ground, on roadsides (Brummitt 2002). ‘Weed of waste places and forest margins (TWS 2002). ‘Hedgerows, gardens, ungrazed pastures and waste places (Roy et al 1998). Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Herb. ‘Robust, sprawling, climbing, hairless perennial’ (Roy et al 1998). Life form – climber.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Insufficient information to determine tolerance to herbivory pressure. Score medium.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘An aggressive climbing weed’ (TWS 2002). Insufficient information to determine growth rate of plant in comparison to species of the same life form. Score medium.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Has been found in the Tamar area, Tasmania along a walking trail and margins of the River Tamar (TWS 2002). Would suggest that the plant is frost tolerant. Not enough information to determine other stress tolerances. Score medium.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Rhizomatous. Seed dispersal is less significant than vegetative spread (Brummitt 2002). ‘All plants in this complex are self-sterile and single populations normally do not set seed at all’ (Brummitt 2002).  Vegetative reproduction.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Spread vigorously by rhizomes’ (Brummitt 2002). Insufficient documentation to determine number of propagules per flowering event. Score medium.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Plant vegetatively reproduces (Brummitt 2002).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Perennial plant. ‘ .. in great abundance on waste ground over a distance of perhaps 100 m, swamping other vegetation and climbing to a height of 3 m  (Brummitt 2002). Possible that the plant forms self-sustaining dense monocultures where it occurs but not enough evidence to determine reproductive period. Score medium.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Not enough evidence to determine plant’s time to reach reproductive maturity. Score medium.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘.. there is no obvious dispersal mechanism and the seeds tend to merely fall to earth beneath the parent plant’ (Brummitt 2002). Propagules mainly spread by gravity.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘.. there is no obvious dispersal mechanism and the seeds tend to merely fall to earth beneath the parent plant’ (Brummitt 2002). Very unlikely to disperse greater than 200 m, most will be less than 20 m.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs along forest margins and woodland areas (e.g. damp sclerophyll forest), so can establish under moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Established in minor disturbed natural ecosystems (e.g. woodlands and wetlands).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
An erect shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Consumed but not preferred due to spines.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“Slow early growth”.

“Competitive ability low at first then aggressive”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to drought, cold (frost), salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed and suckers.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Produce large amounts of seed.  Well over 2,000 berries (1 seed per berry) would be produced on a mature tree. (See pic. P & C 1992).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Plants are long lived, possibly > 70 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants do not flower until the 2nd or 3rd year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Contaminated machinery, vehicles, animals (including birds) agricultural produce, mud and other animals (foxes, possums and wallaroos).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Seeds are not equipped in any special way to aid dispersal”.  However, seeds consumed by mammals especially and also birds is likely to be dispersed > 200 m.  Also, Cooke (1991) states that seeds are spread “far into the bush” by birds and possums that eat the fruit.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A deciduous, dense shrub or small tree to 7 metres high and wide. Forms dense thickets that seriously impede movement. It invades a broad range of vegetation communities including riparian and coastal areas. Infestations likely to be a major impediment to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations would have a major impact on tourism. It seriously impedes movement and has a major impact on bushland habitats.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “…many stout branchlets terminating in spines, armed with thorns 5 to 25 mm long.” Spines present all year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: C. monogyna forms dense thickets, which have a major impact on bushland habitats. It presence would create a moderate negative visual impact on the area. The root system is deep and spreading and may cause some structural damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The deep spreading root system would effectively bind soil. Although deciduous, the dense growth habit of the plant still provides significant soil cover. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Where it occurs in thickets along roadsides, forest margins, and poorly managed pastures, the dense vegetative growth would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: In forest margins dense infestations may create an increased risk to the frequency of fire risk. The flammability of the plant is not documented.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“When climate and soil are suitable it…forms dense stands.” It shades out ground-flora, “affecting the growth and regeneration of overstorey plants. Major impact on species within different layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Montane grassy woodland (D); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential.
Similar impact as above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Similar impact as above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dense thickets…have a major impact on bushland habitats, shading out ground-flora and affecting the growth and regeneration of overstorey plants.” Has a major effect on the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: It has a major impact on bushland habitat. Spines deter grazing animals. Dense stands would significantly reduce habitat of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Birds, possums and wallaroos are known to eat the fruit. Provides habitat and food for smaller native animals.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Spines all year round; may injure larger grazing animals. “Some species of Crataegus contain hydrocyanic acid [and] should be considered potentially hazardous.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Birds and foxes are known to eat the fruit of C. monogyna.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “Dense patches provide good cover for rabbits and other pests.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Dense stands reduce grazing capacity by direct competition and because the spines deter grazing animals. It is known that milk yields are reduced in the British Isles when cows graze hawthorn foliage.” Potential to establish dense patches would have a major impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a plant of cropping. No documented effect on animal produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Removing large infestations demands a major effort. Likely to have an impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: It colonises poorly managed pastures. Depending upon the density of infestation, availability of land may be restricted until plant is controlled.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a plant of cropping; would have no impact on harvesting costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments:
“In the British Isles, hawthorn is an important reservoir of the fire blight bacterium which affects pears and apples.” 
“It hosts Mediterranean fruit fly and light brown apple moth.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds mostly germinate in autumn, but sometimes in spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in ‘shady’ habitats.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in minor disturbed natural ecosystems, e.g. grassland, grassy woodland, riparian vegetation, warm temperate rainforest.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect annual or biennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: When green, it is rarely eaten by cattle and sheep, probably because of its offensive odour.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Can preclude most other vegetation.

Is capable of rapid establishment after autumn rains.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerance to water logging (occurs on riverbeds), assumably also frost (occurs in southern Tasmania and Canada).
Rutledge & Gupta (1996)

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: (Estimated using pictures in Kleinschmidt & Johnson (1977) & US Department of Agriculture (1976).   30 inflorescence x 10 umbels/inflorescence x 10 florets/umbel x 1 seed/floret = 3,000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds are believed to be short-lived in the soil.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms dense infestations.  See pic. P & C (1992) p. 168

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Some plants produce flowering stems in the first spring.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Machinery, vehicles, agricultural produce, mud and clothing.

Also water, wind, gravel and soil.  Annuals (e.g. stock & dogs).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As occurs near waterways, some seeds likely will disperse > 200 m especially in floodwaters.  Most more likely to disperse < 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect herb to 3 metres high, similar in form to Foeniculum vulgare. Hemlock is capable of rapid establishment on disturbed sites or where little vegetation exists. Once firmly established, hemlock precludes most other vegetation. The stems emit an offensive odour when damaged. This plant would be a significant nuisance to humans, but unlikely to create a serious physical barrier.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: In Victoria, it grows mainly on moist neglected areas, usually near streams. Dense infestations may inhibit some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “…all plant parts are toxic to humans.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Growth to 3 metres; in dense stands its presence would create a negative visual impact seriously affecting the aesthetics of a cultural site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Roots comprise a large taproot, sometimes branched, with numerous lateral roots. Dense infestations may provide some soil binding. However, it is an annual/biennial plant, can preclude most other vegetation in dense infestations, and favours moist areas such as stream banks. Possibility of moderate large scale soil movement in riparian situations.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Dense growth mostly on disturbed sites or where there is little vegetation. Biomass likely to increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Dense patches would produce a large amount of litter in late summer when the plant dies. May increase the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Riparian scrub (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“…growing mainly on moist neglected areas, usually near streams. Once firmly established…hemlock precludes most other vegetation.” Major displacment of dominant species within the lower layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (D); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Once firmly established…hemlock precludes most other vegetation.” Major displacment of dominant species within the lower layers.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Once firmly established…hemlock precludes most other vegetation.” Major displacment of dominant species within the lower layers.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Dense infestations can develop in disturbed areas and preclude most other vegetation. “Poison hemlock may act as a pioneer species quickly colonising disturbed sites and displacing natives during early succession seres.” Would have a major negative impact on the 20–60% of the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “The presence of C. maculatum degrades habitat quality and could indicate a management problem on an ecological reserve.” The plant is poisonous; would reduce the habitat of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: C. maculatum is poisonous to livestock, but livestock rarely eat the plant due to its offensive odour. Some risk to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The plant is poisonous. Unlikely to be a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense infestations may provide limited harbor to minor pest species such as rodents.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Because the plant is poisonous, it can reduce yield either through the non-availability of pasture or directly through stock deaths. “Losses of cattle have been recorded in all southern States of Australia.” It can reduce milk yields.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “It also taints milk.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Because of the poisonous nature of the plant, it may have a negative impact on the value of agricultural land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Seeds are believed to be short-lived in the soil.” Infestations can be controlled readily with cultivation or by chemicals. Plant residues remain poisonous; infested areas would have to be quarantined until all plant matter is removed. Temporary change to land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping. No evidence of impact on harvesting.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “In the British Isles, hemlock acts as a host for the carrot fly, Psila rosea, when growing close to carrot fields, and is also host for the celery yellow spot virus.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: All the hoary cresses grow under similar open unshaded conditions.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establish in vigorously growing crops e.g. wheatlands.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Erect perennial herb. Geophyte → aerial growth dies in summer with new growth in autumn/spring.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Consumed but not always preferred.

Capable of rhizome production under moderate herbivory assumed.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Hoary Cress is a strong competitor in the plant world & being more hardy than most cultivated plants, causes appreciable reduction in yield of both pasture & crops.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of fire (heat presumably breaks seed dormancy), waterlogging (occurs along river), drought (occurs on semi arid rangelands).  Also tolerates freezing conditions (frost) as occurs in very cold climates such as Finland (Lyons n.d.).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from perennial roots & by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: A single plant can produce b/w 1,000-5,000 seeds with a viability of ~80%.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seed viability rapidly declines with age of seed.  0%  seeds germinate after 3 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forming large patches (monocultures formed).  Very dense patches may be found in some areas of Southern Australia. See pic P&C 1992 p.340.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants do not usually flower in the first year, assumed to flower in 2nd year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The main method of dispersal is by movement of pieces of cut root adhering to mud or caught on the lines of cultivation equipment.  Seed also dispersed by stock, farm machinery & vehicles, in hay, silage & grain & in water (Anon).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Many propagules caught in cultivation equip are likely to reach 200-1,000 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect herb, 15 to 75 cm high, with aerial growth dying in summer. Its presence in dense patches would be a nuisance to pedestrian traffic.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations would have a minor effect on aesthetics, and may reduce some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Stock losses from grazing the plant have occurred, but are rare. “…the seeds were ground and used as a substitute for pepper and the leaves are eaten as a vegetable in Afghanistan.” Not known to be poisonous to humans; no spines or burrs.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches likely to create a negative visual impact. The root system is extensive, but not vigorous. Unlikely to cause structural damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. “…occurring in dry, unshaded situations.”

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Root system comprises, “A main root to 2 metres or more deep with numerous horizontal roots.” However, aerial parts of the plant die back in summer leaving surface soil exposed to erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It occurs as a weed of cereal crops, pastures, roadsides and neglected sites.” In these situations, biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Aerial growth dies in summer.” Possible increase in dry matter leading to minor change in the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains grassland (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Falls; VH CLIMATE potential
Not known as a weed in natural ecosystems (not recorded in Carr et al 1992), however, in the United States it is known to compete aggressively with native vegetation. “…eventually eliminates the desirable plants completely.” Possible monoculture within the lower stratum. Australian experience: more a weed of agriculture.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC= Grassy woodland (D) CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Falls; VH CLIMATE potential. As above, however, as species grows best in unshaded situations, population density may be restricted. In Australia, it occurs in dry unshaded situations. Minor displacement of indicator spp. in lower stratum.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “It also occurs commonly in pastures and market gardens in many parts of Australia but is not as competitive in these situations as in cereals.” In the US State of Montana C. draba, “…is a very aggressive plant. It is competitive with the native plants and eventually eliminates the desirable plants completely.” “It is found most often in open, unshaded areas.” Would have a major impact on the lower stratum (ground covers, grasses, forbs).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In the US State of Montana C. draba, “…is a very aggressive plant. It is competitive with the native plants and eventually eliminates the desirable plants completely.” “The plant…is seldom eaten by stock.” Potential to significantly reduce food source of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The plant, “is potentially mildly toxic.” Fauna may lose condition.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “Aerial growth dies in summer.” In pasture/grassland situations, it may provide some limited harbor to pest animals such as rodents.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “In early trials with 2,4-D in the Victorian Wimmera, treated plots yielded 20% more wheat than the plots where hoary cress was unchecked.” The plant has serious impact on crop yields.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “…it is seldom eaten by stock. When it is eaten, however, milk and possibly meat are tainted.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Due to the limited control methods available during the 1930s, presence of the weed in cropping situations, “…greatly reduced land value.” In spite of improvements to control methods, its occurrence in paddocks today would most likely reduce the land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Fortnightly cultivations killed all plants after 2 years.” Temporary loss of land for productive activities that would lead to significant loss.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “…it also interferes with harvesting in some areas.” Interference may increase either time or labour to conduct harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: In the US, Cardaria spp. have been found to host viral pathogens that cause beet western yellows and potato leaf roll. Potential threat to Victorian producers?

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Forms dense thickets (Weber 2003). Has spiny leaves, therefore holly could be of high nuisance value restricting people and vehicles, however due to its slow growing nature it would be unlikely to cause tracks to become impassable.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Unknown

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
Has poisonous berries, and leaves have spines (Blood 2001).  The berries and leaves of the species are toxic, especially to  children. Reported symptoms included nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, collapsing and unconsciousness (Shepherd 2004).
The spines on the leaves of holly are not however considered large and while toxic the fruit is not considered fatal and does not occur year round.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
The species is reported to be valued in some historical situations (Blood 2001).
Unknown if the species has any negative impact on infrastructure, cultural or heritage sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species, not reported to occur in flowing water.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Terrestrial species not reported to impact on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Unknown; The species is reported as strong rooted and from an early age develop a tap root (Muyt 2001).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Can create a taller shrub layer, therefore invasion by holly could increase biomass or result in direct replacement (Weber 2003).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown; After an intense fire damaged plants can regrow from the root stock (Peterken & Loyd 1967).

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Creekline Herb-rich Woodland (V); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Holly can form dense thickets, creating a tall species poor shrub layer which also impacts upon the lower strata (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is capable of causing major displacement within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Lowland Forest (D); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Holly can form dense thickets, creating a tall species poor shrub layer which also impacts upon the lower strata (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is capable of causing major displacement within a layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Forest (LC); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Holly can form dense thickets, creating a tall species poor shrub layer which also impacts upon the lower strata (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is capable of causing major displacement within a layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Holly can form dense thickets, creating a tall species poor shrub layer which also impacts upon the lower strata and can prevent regeneration (Muyt 2001; Weber 2003). Therefore the species is capable of causing major displacement within the shrub layer and possibly the lower strata and prevent the regeneration of canopy species.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Unknown; The impact the species has on the vegetation of the invaded ecosystem could effect available habitat and alter food supply; however this is not specifically reported.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments:
Fruits eaten by birds and possibly possums (Muyt 2001; Williams et al 2000).
Forms thickets which may be used for shelter (Weber 2003).
Unknown how important this can be to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The leaves are spiny, the fruit is toxic to people not reported to effect birds or animals (Blood 2001).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments:
Fruit eaten to some extent by foxes (Garcia, Martinez & Obeso 2007).
Browsed by goats and deer (Obeso 1997).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
It is reported to invade pasture and could occur in Forestry (Blood 2001).
As grazing limits the species growth and it is reported to be slow growing it is unlikely to have significant impacts on product yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments:
It is reported to invade pasture and could occur in Forestry (Blood 2001).
As grazing limits the species growth and it is reported to be slow growing it is unlikely to have significant impacts on product quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Unknown.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments:
It is reported to invade pasture and could occur in Forestry (Blood 2001).
As grazing limits the species growth and it is reported to be slow growing it is unlikely to cause a change in land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments:
The species could occur in forestry and while it’s slow growing it is reported to form thickets (Blood 2001; Weber 2003). This may restrict access to plantations and slightly increase the time taken for maintenance.
It is reported to invade pasture (Blood 2001). However as grazing limits the species growth it is unlikely to impact upon the cost of production.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not reported to be a host or vector of pest species of agricultural crops.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Sow seeds from mid-summer to autumn (van der Walt, 2002).

Pulses of germination…when temperature above 25�c…relatively high temps required (Williams et al. 1999). Germinates in wetter conditions from early autumn through winter (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Fire also seems to stimulate germination (see Brown and Brooks, 2002) but is not necessary for germination. Requires natural seasonal rainfall/temperatures.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes in full sun to light shade, either winter or all-year-round rainfall (Williams et al., 1999) in Eucalyptus woodlands and Allocasuarina open woodlands (Brown & Brooks, 2002). This suggests that S. glastifolius can establish under moderate canopy cover

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades coastal areas (Dept. cons., 2002), motorways and hillsides, river mouth, dunes, wasteland, sparingly on the coast, embankment, spreading very aggressively into Banksia woodland and coastal shrubland on deep sands, occurs naturally in pastoral areas, is abundant on old burn sites, a troublesome weed in newly planted plantations and a general ruderal [poor land or waste] and agricultural weed, strongly associated with sparsely vegetated sites, partially stabilised sand dunes, recently felled pine plantation. Often seen after fires and in disturbed areas where it is one of the first pioneers to germinate (Williams et al., 1999). The aggressive spread into Banksia woodland indicates that it has the potential to invade relatively intact natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Asteraceae herb (Dept. cons., 2002). Perennial herb (sometimes annual) (Williams et al., 1999).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: In NZ leaves are eaten by the larvae of the native magpie moth. Appears to be palatable to sheep.  Williams et al states that “vegetative response to damage is…not a significant method of … persistence” and that a few plants were sprouting new shoots after the top parts had died off (Williams et al., 1999). Not enough evidence was found to support either herbivory suppressing reproduction (ML) or the ability to seed under moderate herbivory pressure (MH), so a medium rating was chosen between the two.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Displacing low-growing herbs and ferns and preventing establishment of native seedlings (Dept. cons., 2002). Stems 1-1.5 m tall and occasionally up to 2 m tall. Plants can be 0.5 m wide (Williams et al., 1999). Has the ability to dominate understorey vegetation in open damp areas (CRC Weed Management, 2003). All evidence points to the potential for this species to exceed the growth of most forbs.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Prefers wetter areas…often seen after fires (van der Walt, 2002). This is most likely from fire stimulated germination of seeds, as documented in Brown and Brooks (2002): “fire followed by good rains led to prolific germination.” Terrestrial dry and terrestrial wet substrates and…on nutrient-poor deep sandy soils , some tolerance of high soil moisture, unlikely to tolerate permanently saturated soils. Some capacity to tolerate salt as indicated by its…proximity to sea water at Motueka and Whitiau. In drought conditions it may not grow at all over summer (Williams et al., 1999). Some tolerance to salt, probably susceptible to permanent waterlogging and drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Seed or cuttings (van der Walt, 2002). The main method of reproduction is sexual but can be grown from cuttings in ornamental horticulture. May occasionally form roots where stems lie horizontally, but vegetative reproduction not a significant method of spread or persistence (Williams et al, 1999).  Potential may exist for self and cross pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: 2–3 to several hundred flower heads x 12-22 ray florets (Williams et al., 1999) (so presume more than 12-22 disk florets) = >6,600 propagules

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Some evidence for a persistent soil seed bank” (Williams et al., 1999). But no specific information found.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Not very long-lived perennial (van der Walt, 2002). No evidence for plants older than 4 years
(Williams et al., 1999).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Cultivation of S. glastifolius suggests that if plants germinate early enough and develop a bushy habit before spring, they will flower in the same year that they germinate. If they are too small, they will delay flowering until the following year (van der Walt, 2002).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seed spread by wind and dumped in garden waste (Blood, 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Seed spread by wind and dumped in garden waste (Blood, 2001). Seed has a pappus 7-9 mm long and “fluffy” (Williams et al, 1999). Presume that the pappus would likely carry it at least 20 m but few would reach 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: As a short-lived herbaceous perennial (Williams et al, 1999) it is not likely to prevent human access to any destination.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: 1 - 1.5 m tall, occasionally up to 2 m, to 0.5 m wide, pink to mauve to nearly white daisy flowers. “Most conspicuous to the casual observer where it grows on road cuttings and banks…The most obvious impact …is aesthetic-it is a spectacular plant” (Williams et al, 1999). Although it is not “native-looking,” the plant is cultivated in gardens for its “cheerful flowers” (van der Walt, 2002) which wouldn’t bother most people.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Hand pulling…required thick gloves and trousers” (Brown & Brooks, 2002). “The edges of the…leaves are coarsely toothed and can be quite prickly” (van der Walt, 2002). The toothed edges of the leaves may cause some discomfort if grasped, but unlikely to cause injury to most people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: At 1 - 2 m tall and with pink to mauve to nearly white daisy flowers (Williams et al, 1999) this plant may have a moderate visual effect on the aesthetics of cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: As it is “unlikely to tolerate permanently saturated soils” (Williams et al, 1999), it is unlikely to grow near enough to waterways to impact on them.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: As it is “unlikely to tolerate permanently saturated soils” (Williams et al, 1999), it is unlikely to grow near enough to waterways to impact on them.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Displacing low-growing herbs and ferns and preventing establishment of native seedlings (Dept. cons., 2002). Ability to dominate understorey vegetation in open damp areas (CRC Weed Management, 2003).  Given its ability to replace native vegetation and that “in drought conditions it may not grow at all over summer” (Williams et al., 1999), S. glastifolius may leave patches of soil that could be prone to soil erosion until there is enough soil moisture for the Senecio to germinate and establish. Without evidence of this having happened and no record of it forming monocultures, the likelihood of this occurring is presumed moderate, given the chain of events that would have to occur.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Seems to have a particular affinity for the open areas of scree and bare ground between the shrubs…[some species] vulnerable to shading by the invasion” (Williams et al,1999). When colonising bare ground this plant would increase biomass. Where it prevents the establishment of native vegetation it may replace or slightly increase or decrease biomass depending on the type of vegetation that it suppresses.  Given the sparse nature of the sites that it tends to invade and its “strong association with sparsely vegetated sites,” (Williams et al, 1999) on balance it is likely to slightly increase biomass, but as a shortlived perennial will not act as a carbon sink.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Whilst fire seems to stimulate germination (see Brown & Brooks, 2002), there is no evidence of mature plants surviving fire. As an herbaceous perennial (i.e. not woody) that tends to fall over as it grows older (Williams, 1999) there is no evidence that it provides fuel for fire. As it can replace native vegetation, it has the potential to reduce the incidence and perhaps the intensity of fires in some vegetation types e.g. Grasslands and possible heaths, but the effect would probably be minor.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Coast Banksia Woodland (V), CMA=West Gippsland, Bioreg.=Gippsland Plain, CLIMATE=VH.
Ability to dominate understorey vegetation in open damp areas (CRC Weed Management). There is the potential for this plant to cause major displacement of some dominant species in the grass and herb layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Coastal Alkaline Scrub (D), CMA=West Gippsland, Bioreg.=Gippsland Plain, CLIMATE=VH.
Ability to dominate understorey vegetation in open damp areas (CRC Weed Management). There is the potential for this plant to cause major displacement of some dominant species in the grass and herb layers.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy Woodland (LC), CMA=West Gippsland, Bioreg.=Gippsland Plain, CLIMATE=VH. Ability
to dominate understorey vegetation in open damp areas (CRC Weed Management). There is the potential for this plant to cause major displacement of some dominant species in the grass and herb layers

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Ability to dominate understorey vegetation in open damp areas (CRC Weed Management). There is the potential for this plant to have a major effect on the grass and herb layers and a minor effect on the low shrub layer of some communities.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Displacing low-growing herbs and ferns and preventing establishment of native seedlings (Dept. cons., 2002). Ability to dominate understorey vegetation in open damp areas (CRC Weed Management, 2003).  There is the potential for a minor effect on food sources and/or shelter for some fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: As it is eaten by the larvae of the native magpie moth and diurnal moth in NZ and seems to be palatable to sheep (Williams et al, 1999), it may provide an alternative food source for some animals.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Although it is somewhat prickly (Williams, 1999), S. glastifolius is unlikely to cause fauna to lose condition.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Although recorded as palatable it is not noted as a food source for pests in Williams et al (1999).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: As an herbaceous perennial with widely spaced branches (CRC Weed Management, 2003), this plant is unlikely to provide habitat or harbor for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Occurs naturally in pastoral areas.  A general agricultural weed (Williams et al, 1999). However it is palatable to sheep (Williams et al, 1999), so it may simply provide an alternative fodder source and its ability to out compete pasture would probably be controlled by grazing.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: See q. 19, the plant is unlikely to reduce form in stock and does not have spines or burrs that might affect meat or wool quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: See q. 19, without significantly reducing yield or quality, land value is unlikely to be affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Would not require a change in land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “A troublesome weed in newly planted plantations” (Williams et al, 1999). Possibly increases harvest costs in weed control costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None recorded

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Most seeds germinate after autumn rains but some germination also occurs through winter and spring”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Tolerates full sun, shade of woodland canopy”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades Mallee communities as well as red gum, black box and grassy woodland, dry coastal vegetation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Perennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Because of its bitter taste, horehound is not palatable to stock and is therefore, encouraged by heavy grazing”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Able to establish without competition.  In contrast, seedlings do not establish in dense pastures”.  “Young seedlings are not very competitive but, once established, they make rapid growth”.  (P & C 1992 p. 497)

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
“Horehound is relatively drought tolerant”.  May be tolerant of some water logging if occurs in channel banks.

“Tolerates drought and frost”.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Mature plants can produce over 20,000 seeds per year”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “May survive in soil for 7-10 years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Perennial herb.

“New growth is produced each year in autumn and spring”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants may or may not flower in the first year, depending mainly on soil fertility”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Burr attaches to wool, fur, bag, clothing, etc.: water; “and horses are known to pass the seeds in a viable condition”.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Also burrs attached to sheep responsible for much spread in Australia. “and horses are known to pass the seeds in a viable condition”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A bushy perennial herb, 30 cm tall and 75 cm wide. In dense infestations, its growth habit may present a minor nuisance to pedestrian traffic.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: A low growing plant (30 cm); dense patches would have a minor effect on aesthetics, recreational activities not seriously affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant is not toxic, but the fruit has 10 backward-curved hooked spines; not known to be harmful or cause injury.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Roots or growth habit unlikely to cause structural damage. Dense patches would create a moderate negative visual impact on a cultural site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In one area in Victoria where horehound has flourished, soil erosion has increased markedly.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Generally invades neglected areas such as fence lines, roadsides, channel banks, around buildings, on sheep camps and neglected urban areas. Biomass would increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Bushy perennial. Increase in biomass would likely cause an increase in the intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential
Prefers open areas. “…has the potential for dense establishment.” “Seedlings do not establish in dense pastures.” Impact lessened with overstorey cover. Major displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Rocky outcrop shrubland (LC); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. Impact as in 10(a).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Has the potential to establish in pastures and open areas as dense monocultures.” It is present in Victoria in medium to large populations. Monoculture in lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In Victoria it is widespread in medium to large populations and invades dry coastal vegetation, mallee shrubland, lowland grassland & grassy woodland, and rock outcrop vegetation. “Because of its bitter taste, horehound is not palatable to stock.” “Horehound is relatively drought tolerant and has the potential for dense establishment in many more areas of Australia.” This plant would reduce the habitat for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits apparent.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Burrs are not injurious; no toxic properties.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A low growing plant (30 cm tall) it may provide limited harbor for rodents or rabbits in low densities. The plant does occur near rabbit warrens mainly due to the seeds sticking to the animal’s fur.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “In early trials with 2,4-D in the Victorian Wimmera, treated plots yielded 20% more wheat than the plots where Horehound was unchecked.” The plant has serious impact on crop yields.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “…it is seldom eaten by stock. When it is eaten, however, milk and possibly meat are tainted.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Due to the limited control methods available during the 1930s, presence of the weed in cropping situations, “…greatly reduced land value.” In spite of improvements to control methods, its occurrence in paddocks today would most likely reduce the land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Fortnightly cultivations killed all plants after 2 years.” Temporary loss of land for productive activities that would lead to significant loss.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “…it also interferes with harvesting in some areas.” Interference may increase either time or labour to conduct harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: In the US, Cardaria spp. have been found to host viral pathogens that cause beet western yellows and potato leaf roll. Potential threat to Victorian producers?

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Requires alternating periods of flooding and dryness to establish and survive (Weber 2003).  It is adapted to fluctuating water levels and massive regeneration by seed may occur after drought.  Plants usually flower from April to June but have been observed flowering in September and there’s evidence that the plant can flower and set seeds over a longer period of time in unusually wet years (DNRM 2005).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Sets viable seed after flowering – the seeds germinate on damp bare ground
Seeds set from late autumn to early spring (KEC 1991).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in shallow waters of swamp margins and river banks (Weber 2003).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A robust perennial grass / semi-aquatic (Wildin 1989).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: It has been established for use in ponded pastures in Central Queensland (Kibbler & Bahnisch 1999).  One of the major forages of buffaloes on the flood plains east of Darwin (Wildin 1988).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Is a large species that can grow in deeper water than other species of the same life form giving it the potential to infest wetlands and choke streams (KEC 1991). It has the ability to smother native vegetation and form dense and extensive monospecific stands (IPIF 2005).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought and flood (Wildin 1988).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Rhizomatous and sets seed (Hill 1996).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
‘Massive regeneration by seed may occur after drought’ (Weber 2003).

Germination is variable – ranging from 86% to 0%. Factors affecting seed fertility are not clearly understood (Hill 1996).

Prolific seed production (greater than 2000/m2) (IPIF 2005).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Trial work indicates that in field conditions, the seed viability is still high after more than a year. Not enough information to determine propagule longevity. Therefore score as medium.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Species forms self-sustaining dense monocultures (Hill 1996).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Perennial grass (Wildin 1989) – therefore assume maturity within first year

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seeds are dispersed by water (Weber 2003).

Possibility of natural introduction to Central America via migratory birds (Hill 1996).

Migratory aquatic birds (DNRM 2005).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As dispersed by migratory birds (DNRM 2005)– assume that it’s very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Perennial grass to 2.5 metres high. It invades waterways including drains, lagoons, creeks and rivers (Diaz et al 2003). Heavy infestations may be a major impediment to access waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “Overseas, hymenachne forms floating mats and grass islands” (NRM 2001). Serious impact on water-based recreation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant has no physical or toxic properties that may injure humans. However ‘…the mats that the plants form create a haven for mosquitoes that are vectors of Ross River Fever and encephalitis’ (NRM 2001). Therefore score as medium.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Plant not likely to cause damage to indigenous or cultural European sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: “Hymenachne can choke drains and small watercourses, increasing flooding by reducing the flow capacity of the drainage networks” (Diaz et al 2003). Major impact on either surface or sub-surface flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: “Heavy infestations reduce the infiltration of sunlight…[and] prevents the exchange of air, which normally occurs on an open water surface. As plant material decomposes it uses oxygen causing water pollution and stagnation” (Diaz et al 2003). High effects in dissolved O2.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Hymenachne can choke drains and small watercourses, increasing flooding” (Diaz et al 2003). High potential for erosion with offsite implications

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Density of infestations suggests biomass would significantly increase. (Cruz & Salazar 1989). In aquatic situations, increase in biomass is a negative attribute.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Occurs in wetland situations (NRM 2001). Unlikely to contribute to fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Swamp scrub (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioregion=Victorian Volcanic Plain; CLIMATE=M.
“Hymenachne can form pure stands that replace native wetland plants.” High CLIMATE potential would restrict impact. Unlikely to establish as monoculture, but would still significantly displace grass species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Damp heathland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioregion=Glenelg Plain; CLIMATE=M.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Wet heathland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioregion=Victorian Volcanic Plain; CLIMATE=M.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Hymenachne can form pure stands that replace native wetland plants” (ARMCANZ 2000)

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “A large infestation of hymenachne is a physical barrier for aquatic and semi-aquatic animals, restricting their territorial movements and breeding activities” (NRM 2001). Can ‘reduce resources available for feeding, breeding and shelter of native fauna’ (Diaz et al 2003). Reduction in habitat for fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits to native fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be harmful to fauna. It was grown in Queensland for a high-quality ponded pasture grass (NRM 2001) and in Florida (Hill 1996).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Originally grown in Queensland for a high-quality ponded pasture grass, the species would have no negative impact on yield in grazing situations. It may restrict access to watering points, and its capacity to occur in irrigation channels may impact on the yield of irrigated crops (NRM 2001). However, there is no data to support the level of impact.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No data on effect on quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No data available to determine impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No data available to suggest change in land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Does not affect harvesting activities.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None described

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds may germinate at any time of the year but most do so after autumn rains”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Mostly establishes in ‘open’ habitats, e.g. pastures.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in vigorously growing pastures.  (See pic. P & C 1992 p. 222).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect annual or biennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Not grazed by stock because of the dense spines.

Consumed by (sheep and goats), however still capable of propagule production.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Competitive in pastures.

Described as a ‘rapid spreader’. (Anon.)

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproducing by seed.

“Cultivation can spread root pieces which may grow”. “Onopordum thistles are not capable of vegetative reproduction”. (Pettit et al 1996).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “A heavy seeder”. (Anon).  5 flower heads per plant x 200 seeds per flower = 1,000 seeds per plant (Estimate using pic. & illustrations)

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: > 6 years (See Sindel 1997 p. 2).  However unsure if large/small % are viable > 6 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual or biennial.  “Some plants develop flowering stems in the first spring, whilst others do not flower until the second spring”.  Therefore only produces propagules for 1 year. .

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Some plants flower in the first year, others in the second year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Wind; contaminate wool, other agricultural produce and equipment.

Also spread by water.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “The pappus of the seed attaches to wool, vehicles, clothing, etc or it can be a contaminant in hay.  The stems with seed heads attached can break off and be blown some distance “.  (ACT Parks & Conservation Service).  Above mechanisms, particularly seed attaching to wool, vehicles and clothing could be transported well > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Dense patches pose a physical barrier to humans.” The spiny nature of the plant is an annoyance to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “…occurs on neglected sites and pastures of reasonable fertility.” Not a significant weed of recreational areas. However, where it does occur in dense patches, some recreation activities may be affected

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Dense spines are present for much of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: An erect herb to 2 m high; Infestations uncommon, but plants can be locally abundant at infested sites; dense infestations would have a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Even when plants die, they usually remain standing for a long period of time and, by keeping the area bare of other vegetation, can maintain a niche for recruitment of the next generation.” Not an extensive root system; bare patches of soil may be subjected to erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: An annual that grows best on fertile soils. Direct replacement of biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Stems can persist into the next season with spiny phyllaries and receptacles attached. In dense patches, this dry matter may introduce a minor change to the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
“It grows best on high-nitrogen soils…rather than unimproved native vegetation.” Would have a minor effect on grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
