“It grows best on high-nitrogen soils…rather than unimproved native vegetation.” Would have a minor effect on grasses/forbs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Plain; H CLIMATE potential.
“It grows best on high-nitrogen soils…rather than unimproved native vegetation.” Would have a minor effect on grasses/forbs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “[Thistles] will often grow above the pasture canopy and dominate the grazing landscape throughout much of the year” “…an effective invader and a strong competitor to establish in grassland communities.” However, “It grows best on high-nitrogen soils…rather than unimproved native vegetation.” Would have a minor effect on the lower stratum in natural ecosystems.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Illyrian thistle…is not grazed by stock because of the dense spines.” Its presence in natural ecosystems would reduce forage for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “If it is eaten, the spines cause mechanical damage, particularly around the mouths and eyes of animals.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Illyrian thistle is competitive in pastures and is not grazed by stock because of the dense spines.” “Plants can be locally abundant at infested sites.” Likely to reduce carrying capacity and have a major impact on the yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Plants contribute to vegetable fault in wool.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Seeds below 4–5 cm may remain viable for many years.” “…an infestation of Onopordum illyricum was able to flare again after 6 years control during which time no seeds were allowed back into the soil seed bank.” With the necessity for ongoing control measures and the associated cost, the value of land may decrease.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: In pasture situations, some degree of control can be achieved by grazing goats and cattle. “Goats graze flowering plants…and also eat smaller plants and rosettes.” No serious impact on agricultural return.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Seeds germinate after spring and summer rains.

Roots producing new aerial growth annually.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy, i.e. occurs in orchards and crops.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Established in pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
A prostrate creeping perennial (occasional annual) herb.

Also geophyte – stems can take root at nodes.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not really eaten, although at times young plants are moderately palatable to sheep and are consumed.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Establishes occasionally in native pastures where it out-competes most other species”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance t drought, water logging (occurs in wetlands).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed, roots and stems taking root at nodes.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Seeds prolific and viable for years”. (Web page).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: See above comment  “years”.  But number years unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Forms dense monocultures.

 See picture P & C (1992) p. 159.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Seeds germinate spring/summer  Plants flower and seed next summer and autumn.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Prickly burrs attach to animals, equipment, clothing and tyres.

Also by water and wind, wool, hay and impure grain from affected areas.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Many propagules will reach 200-1,000 m due to prickly burr that can even attach to car tyres and travel long distances.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A prostrate creeping perennial. Would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: A prostrate perennial, the plant growth habit would not restrict recreational activities. However, “the sharp spines of the heads are a great annoyance to bare-footed children [and adults?] and fruit pickers.” As it commonly occurs in, “irrigated recreation areas and caravan parks,” it would affect some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “The sharp spines of the heads are a great annoyance to bare-footed children…[and] it is claimed also to cause hay fever, asthma and dermatitis in some people.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Khaki weed forms, “a dense ground cover [on]…bare or disturbed areas.” It has a deep, woody taproot only. Not likely to affect the structure of a cultural site but because of the dense ground cover, would create a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Roots form at stem nodes producing new plants and a dense ground cover.” The plant would not increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Colonises bare or disturbed areas…[and] establishes occasionally in native pastures where it out-competes most other species.” Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Aerial growth dies off by late autumn.” Not likely to increase fuel load greatly. Small or negligible change to fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Establishes occasionally in native pastures where it out-competes most other species.” Would have a major impact on ground flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Plains sedgy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Establishes occasionally in native pastures where it out-competes most other species.” Prefers open situations. Overstorey cover may limit impact. Would have a minor impact on grasses/forbs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10 (b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Establishes occasionally in native pastures where it out-competes most other species.” Would have a major impact on ground flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “It occasionally invades native pastures on sandy soils but usually does not persist.” Where it does establish it, “out-competes most other species.” Animals rarely eat the plant. Would reduce food source for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Animals do not eat the plant; the heads cause mechanical damage to the feet and mouths of stock.” No benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The heads cause mechanical damage to the feet and mouths of stock.” “Khaki weed is believed to be poisonous to animals and to cause a skin ailment in cattle.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals. Stock does not readily graze the plant.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not known to affect agricultural yields greatly. “In New South Wales…it competes with both irrigated and dryland lucerne.” No similar impacts in Victoria.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: It, “contributes to vegetable fault in wool and…in New South Wales…its burrs contaminate lucerne hay.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not a serious weed of agriculture in Victoria; not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Does not affect harvest activities; not a weed of cropping in Victoria.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Aquatic species. Does not affect human access on land.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: An “aggressive freshwater weed,” it may affect some recreational activities such as swimming or boating.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The physical properties of the plant are not harmful to humans, however, “it has the ability to accumulate considerable amounts of arsenic from the surrounding medium.” Tests conducted on sheep in New Zealand revealed the arsenic does not pose a serious threat to health.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “in spite of one of its common names, oxygen weed, in a dense infestation of Lagarosiphon major there often is less oxygen present than in the surrounding water: thus dense infestations, ‘in such quantities confer no oxygen benefit on fish and other animals in the lake’.” Potential to obliterate the historic/cultural feature.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Establishes in slow-moving streams and, “…in sheltered areas protected from wind and waves…it forms dense stands which impede water flow.” Major impact on subsurface flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: It, “interferes with water utilisation and shades out other plants.” “Heavy infestations of Lagarosiphon deplete oxygen levels in water, killing fish.” High effect on dissolved O2 levels.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Aquatic species.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Dense stands would significantly increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “can form a light-blocking canopy so dense and thick (3 feet thick) that Lagarosiphon major easily out competes even tall non-canopy forming native species.” "Lagarosiphon major successfully out-competed native species wherever it has colonised New Zealand lakes in the depth zone 2-6 m--normally occupied by native milfoils (Myriophyllum spp.) and pondweeds (Potamogeton spp.)." Would have a major impact on the floral strata in aquatic situations.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Heavy infestations of Lagarosiphon deplete oxygen levels in water, killing fish.” Its presence may also impact on waterbirds. Serious reduction in habitat.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “it has the ability to accumulate considerable amounts of arsenic from the surrounding medium.” Tests conducted on sheep in New Zealand revealed the arsenic does not pose a serious threat to health. Unlikely to affect native fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: In New Zealand, grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella) readily ate the plant in feeding trials. However, this species does not occur in Victoria.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Aquatic species.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Aquatic species.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Aquatic species.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Aquatic species.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Aquatic species.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘[Seeds] appear to germinate from only a few millimetres deep, and have only been found in well lit areas’ (Swarbrick 1999). Prefers warm, damp or seasonally moist locations (Muyt 2001). ‘Mature aerial tubers drop off the plant and either sprout into tuberlings immediately ..’ (Helensburgh and District Landcare n.d.). Opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘Regrowth from vegetative propagules is faster [and more common] than the growth of seedlings, and can occur in dense shade under existing infestations of Madeira vine.’ Shade-tolerant vine (Swarbrick 1999).  Although prefers sun, can establish under moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Found in ‘dry coastal vegetation, damp sclerophyll forest, riparian and outcrop vegetation, cliff faces, rail embankments, rainforest edges, tall open forest, gardens and waste places’ (Blood 2002). Thrives in moist sunny sites such as riverbanks and gully edges (Eurobodalla Shire Council 2003). Can establish in minor disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Succulent climbing vine (ISSG 200).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not known to be eaten by animals or insects. No known biocontrol agents in Australia or New Zealand.  Has even be ‘suspected of poisoning livestock’ (Blood 2002).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Can grow rapidly to 10 m in one growing season’ (Blood 2002). ‘Aggressive vegetative growth which competes with and replaces other vegetation’. Growth can ‘exceed 1 m per week and up to 6 m in a growing season’. (ISSG 2005). Although will out compete other species, appears that has moderately rapid growth rate that will equal competitive species of same life form

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘Tolerates dry conditions, snow and frost (will die back to tuber and reshoot), salt, sand and frontal dunes.’  ‘Very drought-resistant’ (Blood 2002). Highly tolerant to at least 2 (drought, salinity) and tolerant of another (frost). Susceptible to at least 1 (not described but no reference made to fire or waterlogging tolerance).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Vegetative – from dormant buds on tubers or sections of rhizome in the soil. Through ‘rhizome, stem tubers, stem fragments and leaves, rarely seeds’ (Swarbrick 1999). ‘The production of seedlings by this serious environmental weed has not previously been recorded in Australia, and may help to explain its dispersal to new sites and areas’ (Blood 2002). Has both male and female flowers but rarely produces sexually – although it can (ISSG 2005).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Reproduces prolifically from the production of multitudes of aerial tubers’. ‘Thousands of small aerial tubers develop along stems and can remain viable on vines or on the ground for five to ten years’ (Wilsons Creek Huonbrook Landcare 2003). ‘There may be up to 1,500 fallen aerial tubers per square metre’ (Muyt 2001)

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Thousands of small aerial tubers develop along stems and can remain viable on vines or on the ground for five to ten years’ (Muyt 2001).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘Thousands of small aerial tubers develop along stems and can remain viable on vines or on the ground for five to ten years’ (Muyt 2001). Mature plant produces viable propagules for 10 years or more.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Growth commences during spring .. can grow rapidly up to 10 m in one growing season’ (Blood 2002).  ‘Aerial tubers develop in large numbers along the stems, break off readily and shoot once they touch soil’ (Sutherland Shire Council 2003). No documented evidence regarding time to reach reproductive maturity.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The seeds ‘may be dispersed by birds … although the majority probably fall to the ground .. and are dispersed by the movement of soil and water’ (Swarbrick 1999). ‘Spread by contaminated and eroding soil, machinery, road clearing and water’ (Blood 2002)

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Seedlings have been found well away from infestations of parent plants .. likely to have been through the gut of a bird ..’ (Swarbrick 1999).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: ‘Has spread along the waterways and through forests’ ‘ Because of its thick fleshy leaves and bunches of tubers, it is the heaviest of the problem vines and can smash the branches of trees by its weight’ (Wilsons Creek Huonbrook Landcare 2003). Climbs vigorously over shrubs and trees with rope-like stems, up to a few centimetres in diameter (Muyt 2001). Would have a low nuisance value with the ability to impede individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: ‘Starting to noticeably expand its range’ (Environment Waikato 2002). ‘It is highly visible, and receiving adverse comments from landholders..’ (BREC 2004). Weed has the potential to have a minor effect on the aesthetics of the land.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No known toxic principles.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: ‘Can completely smother indigenous vegetation and prevent natural regeneration’ (Blood 2002). Weed could have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Has tap and fibrous roots systems. ‘Spreads over the ground, smothering native groundcover plants and preventing regeneration’ (Eurobodalla Shire Council 2003). As it is an evergreen vine assume a low probability of large-scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Climbs over shrubs and trees, smothering and breaking them down. Also spreads over the ground, smothering native groundcover plants and preventing regeneration’ (Eurobodalla Shire Council 2003). Likely that the biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Suppression of all indigenous vegetation may reduce fire risk. Thrives in moist habitats (Muyt 2001). Not likely to have an effect on the frequency or intensity of fires.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Sedgy Riparian Woodland (V); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Ranges; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘Capable of obliterating all indigenous vegetation. Vines climbing vigorously over shrubs and trees while trailing stems smother all ground-flora and prevent any regeneration’ (Muyt 2001). Displaces all species in all layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Riparian Scrub (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plains; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘Capable of obliterating all indigenous vegetation. Vines climbing vigorously over shrubs and trees while trailing stems smother all ground-flora and prevent any regeneration’ (Muyt 2001). Displaces all species in all layers.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (LC.); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Ranges; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘Capable of obliterating all indigenous vegetation. Vines climbing vigorously over shrubs and trees while trailing stems smother all ground-flora and prevent any regeneration’ (Muyt 2001). Displaces all species in all layers.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘By time, invaded forests become degraded and displaced with vine growth, preventing the establishment of native trees’ (Weber 2003). ‘Capable of obliterating all indigenous vegetation. Vines climbing vigorously over shrubs and trees while trailing stems smother all ground-flora and prevent any regeneration’ (Muyt 2001). Capable of having a major effect on all layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: ‘This part of the creek area is heavily infested with Madeira vine, camphor laurel and other weeds, while the vine is killing melaleucas and putting at risk rainforest trees’ (BREC 2004). This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In Queensland, an area which is heavily infested with weeds including Anredera cordifolia ‘needs an urgent upgrade … to provide access for fauna and facilitation of movement’ (BREC 2004). Suggests that the weed could have a minor impact upon wildlife corridors.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: In a forest in NSW ‘ the Madeira vine… took over the exposed understorey, further impeding regeneration… Flying foxes found the increasing number of sun-warmed gaps one of the few places left ideally suited for them’ (BCI 1987).  Provides very little support to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: ‘Suspected of poisoning livestock’ (Blood 2002). No documented evidence to suggest that fauna would eat the weed.  Unlikely to have an effect on indigenous fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: ‘Suspected of poisoning livestock’ (Blood 2002). Unlikely to provide a food source for pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: ‘Involved the total removal of exotic weeds [including Anredera cordifolia] from .. a riparian habitat, which harboured a high density of native rodent, Uromys caudimaculatus’ (Ward, Tucker & Wilson 2003). May provide harbour for minor pest spp.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture. Not likely to impact upon agricultural quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture. Unlikely that the weed would affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture. Unlikely that there will be a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in summer after periods of very warm temperatures and rain.” Requires natural seasonal disturbance.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Requires a period of very warm temperatures. “Temperature appears to be more important than available water.” Optimal germination temperature is 29�C. 

“Honey mesquite seeds must be covered with a small amount of soil or dung for seedlings to establish. Seeds that germinate on the soil surface usually die.”

Requires specific conditions to germinate.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Commonly found in intermittently flowing streambeds from where they spread into adjacent areas depending upon favourable rainfall. “…often found along roadsides near areas of habitation.” Occur mostly in highly disturbed areas (riverbeds, watercourses) in open areas. 

“In Australia, all forms of mesquite tend to grow on heavier soils which support open woodland or grassland.”

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Shrubs to small trees, nominally deciduous. Part of the Fabaceae family, mesquites are leguminous.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Extracts from the ground litter (mesquite pods and leaves) have an allelopathic effect on germinating seeds of other plant species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Grazing animals eats pods, but spines may discourage animals from browsing on the leaves and stems. 

“Livestock do not consume the foliage to any great extent. Foliage consumption is high only during drought years.”

Grazing does not affect the survival or reproductive ability of the tree.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Shoot growth is slow (compared to root growth). Maximum growth rate may be less than other species of similar life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
In the U.S., mesquite is found in areas where average minimum temperature is –5�C and the frost-free growing season is longer than 200 days. The deep root system (15 to 20 metres) would ensure most trees survive periods of drought. 

“Fire mortality is usually low in honey mesquite. Following most range fires, honey mesquite is top-killed and then re-sprouts.” Survives fire. Information on tolerance to salt or waterlogging is not available.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Deciduous shrubs or small trees, reproducing by seed and suckers.” Reproduces sexually and vegetatively.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “…honey mesquite produces pods in… abundance.” Trees produce more than 100 pods per season, and in a Californian study, each pod contained an average of 12 seeds. Produces between 1,000 and 2,000 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
“Little is known about honey mesquite seed banks [or] seed longevity in the field.” 

“Mesquite seeds have a relatively short seed longevity when the pods are kept on the soil surface. Within 12 months, less than 20% of the seeds are still viable in good seed production years while <0.1% remain viable in some years.” Seeds survive less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Maximum ages that plants attain is unclear. Near Amarillo, Texas, the maximum age of plants within a stand of multi-stemmed honey mesquites ranged from 40 to 110 years. On the Rio Grande Plains of Texas, Archer found that 89% to 93% of honey mesquite plants were less than 100 years old, and the maximum age of plants sampled was 172 to 217 years.” Plants are very long-lived (more than 10 years).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Young plants do not flower until they are 2 to 3 years old and from 1 to 1.5 metres high.”

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Prosopis spp. spread is mostly by seed. Both livestock and native animals consume the seed pods, and many of the seeds pass through the digestive system intact. The pods and seeds float, so they may be dispersed long distances in floodwater. Propagules spread by water and animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Floodwaters are likely to spread seed much greater than one kilometre, animals to a lesser extent.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: In Western Australia, “because of their thicket-forming characteristics, they…limit ingress to watering points.” Dense patches would create an impediment to accessing waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense patches limiting access to waterways may affect some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No toxic principles, however, the stems are “armed with paired stipular spines just above each leaf axil.” A deciduous shrub, the spines are present all year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Root system not documented as being vigorous; not known to cause structural damage. The plant can grow as a many stemmed shrub 1 to 3 metres high, large single-stemmed tree 6 to 15 metres high, or branching almost from the base and forming dense thickets 5 to 8 metres high. Dense patches would be obvious and create a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant was grown in, “Pakistan and India…to combat erosion.” However, due to the plant removing all grass cover under the canopy, “…erosion problems are exacerbated.” Moderate probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “In Australia, all forms of mesquite tend to grow on heavier soils which support open-woodland or grassland. They spread rapidly [which] usually results in the complete loss of grass cover.” Would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: With increased biomass in grassland situations, dense infestations may result in a moderate change to both the frequency and intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Mesquites tend to grow in open-woodland or grassland situations where they spread rapidly. The mass of surface roots usually results in the complete loss of grass cover. Major impact on grasses and displacement of mid storey species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Box Ironbark forest (D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; M CLIMATE potential.
Impact similar to above, however, medium CLIMATE potential only, limiting population size.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Appears unlikely to occur in any low value EVC in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In open-woodland or grassland situations, “competition from the mass of their surface roots usually results in the complete loss of grass cover. The allelopathic effects from ground litter (mesquite pods and leaves) extracts, prevents the seeds of other species germinating.” Major effect on the lower and mid strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Prosopis spp. are aggressive invaders and competitors. Because of their thicket-forming characteristics, they reduce available grazing area and limit ingress to watering points.” Dense infestations would reduce habitat of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Pods are sweet, fairly nutritious, and relished by livestock, but heavy consumption can cause digestive problems.” Possible limited food source for native fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Although the stems are armed with spines, there is no evidence to indicate they injure animals. Potential exists.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Pods are eaten and then dispersed by domestic and wild animals.” Potential food source to pest animals such as rabbits.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Prosopis spp. are aggressive invaders and competitors. Because of their thicket-forming characteristics, they reduce available grazing area and limit ingress to watering points. In some situations competition from the roots results in the complete loss of grass cover.” Reduces carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping. Not known to affect quality of yield.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Reproduces sexually and vegetatively. Dense infestations can be difficult to eliminate due to the longevity of the seed. In southwestern United States, “Many species of mesquite respond positively to overgrazing and grasslands are subsequently converted to mesquite brushlands. Conversion back is very difficult and temporary with reduced grazing pressure.” Dense infestation likely to have a major impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: As above. “American experience convincingly demonstrates that the best means of obtaining control of larger colonies is by integrating available techniques, including mechanical, cultural, chemical and biological.” This may lead to extended non-availability of grazing land.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: In Western Australia infestations, “hinder mustering.” Increased time to harvest animals.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds generally germinate when first wetted and have a high germination rate (ARMCANZ 2000).  Opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Adapted to seasonally flooded habitats and can regenerate under some degree of canopy cover (Binggeli 1997).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Establishes in ‘agricultural areas, coastland, disturbed areas, natural forest, planted forests,
range/grasslands, riparian zones, scrub/shrublands, urban areas, water courses, wetlands’ (ISSG 2005).  ‘Can also regenerate under a canopy of Melaleuca fringing the floodplain’ (Binggeli 1997).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Leguminous, thorny shrub (ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not palatable to mammalian herbivores but biological control agents (insect and fungal) are being used (ARMCANZ 2000). Neurostrota gunniella, particularly, has been found to stunt plants but insufficient to control the plant (Paynter 2002).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Smothers pastures and has densely covered river floodplain and swamp forest with monospecific thickets (ISSG 2005). Although seedlings are susceptible to competition from native grasses, once established will generally out-compete most flood plain species (Marko 1999).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Can survive up to seven months drought. Can withstand flooding. Fire resistant and fire alone may stimulate re-growth and enhance seed germination. Tolerant to saline conditions. (Marko 1999)

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Assumed that most of the seeds are produced by autogamy in Australia but is also bee-pollinated and possibly wind pollinated (ISSG 2005). Does not naturally reproduce vegetatively but can do from cut stems (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001)

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Average production is 9,000 seeds per square metre (ARMCANZ 2000). Per plant, production has been measured at up to 220,000 (ISSG 2005).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: On sandy soils, seeds can survive at least 23 years, but viability will decrease more rapidly on clay soils (ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Flowering will continue for as long as water is available. Species can form dense monocultures (ISSG 2005).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants can begin flowering from 6 to 8 months after germination under ideal conditions (ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Bristles covering the seed pods assist in water dispersal. Within catchments, spread by floodwaters. Also spread by vehicle movement and by animals (buffalo, cattle, horses, wallabies). Seeds can stick on magpie geese and other waders (ISSG 2005).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Due to the mechanisms of dispersal, it is assumed that seeds can spread over 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “This aggressive prickly shrub forms impenetrable thickets 4 to 5 metres high, making infested areas inaccessible to man” (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). “Traditional hunting areas have been choked by mimosa, so that people can no longer hunt [in some Aboriginal communities in NT]’ (CRC for Weed Management 2005). Dense infestations would create a major impediment to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Infestations of M. pigra create, “…perceptions of degraded natural landscapes; reduced wildlife attractions; reduced area and access for tourism activities; reduced access to fishing, hunting and scenic areas” (ARMCANZ 2001).  Dense infestations would have serious implications for recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Stems are armed with broad-base prickles to 7 mm long” (Groves et al 1995). Prickles exist throughout the year.  Potential for minor injury.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “…perceptions of degraded natural landscapes; reduced wildlife attractions; reduced area and access for tourism activities; reduced access to fishing, hunting and scenic areas” (ARMCANZ 2001). Infestations would create a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species invading, “…sedgeland and grassland communities on open floodplains” (Groves et al 1995).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “A large central taproot penetrate 1 – 2 m into the soil, together with a lateral root system that extends up to 3.5 m from the stem” (Groves et al 1995). Unlikely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The plant invades,“…sedgeland and grassland communities on open floodplains,” and can grow to a height of 6 m (Groves et al 1995). Biomass would increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Mimosa is fire resistant (Marko 1999). In dense infestations, it would decrease horizontal continuity, thereby decreasing fire frequency and extent (Brooks et al 2004). Minor change to frequency of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Climate modelling predicts that this species is not likely to establish as a weedy species in Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Climate modelling predicts that this species is not likely to establish as a weedy species in Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Climate modelling predicts that this species is not likely to establish as a weedy species in Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “In Australia, a largely intact natural landscape has been completely altered. Some 450 km2 of floodplain and swamp forest have been covered by dense monospecific stands of M. pigra which have little understorey except for seedlings and suckers of M. pigra” (Groves et al 1995).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The potential for M. pigra to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations. No impact on threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Braithwaite et al. (1989) found that M. pigra thickets had fewer birds and lizards” (Groves et al 1995). Reduces habitat for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “…the rare marsupial mouse Sminthopsis virginiae (Tarragon) has become more abundant as a result of M. pigra. It probably shelters from predators in the dense thickets” (Groves et al 1995). Provides some assistance to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not documented as causing injury. Not toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Occurring, as it does, in damp situations along riverbanks and billabongs, mimosa interferes with stock watering, [and] irrigation projects. It also moves out onto the drier floodplains away from rivers, where it smothers pastures, [and] reduces the available grazing area” (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). “The rate of population increase in river systems is rapid, with infestations able to double in area every 1.2 years” (Groves et al 1995). Major impact on carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Primarily a weed of natural ecosystems, in the Northern Territory, it does occur on grazing land (ARMCANZ 2001).  As an aggressive shrub that can spread rapidly reducing grazing and water resources, land prices may be somewhat affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “If mimosa continues to spread, large stands could develop very quickly in pastoral and agricultural areas of eastern Queensland and in the Ord River region of Western Australia. The cost of mimosa control under these circumstances would be exorbitant” (ARMCANZ 2001). Land use may be seriously affected.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Infestations make stock management and mustering difficult. Increase in time and labour to harvest animals (ARMCANZ 2001).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Germinate as temperatures rise after spring and summer rains or after irrigation”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in unshaded situations.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Weed of cultivated and grazing land.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect annual herbs.

Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “part of the plant’s competitiveness could be due to Allelopathic chemicals known to occur but this aspect has not been studied in depth”.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Adult plants are not readily eaten by stock due to their rough texture”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Rapid growth rate make these plants strong competitors both in pasture and summer crops”.  (Drought, “Tolerates flooding at all growth stages”. (See distribution map P & C 1992)).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerates some water logging.  “Tolerates flooding at all growth stages”.  (P & C 1992).  “The tolerance of Noogoora burr to salinity ranges from moderate to quite high, depending on the ecotype”.  (Hocking & Liddle 1995 p. 262).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproducing by seed.

Self-compatible and predominantly selfing.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: A single vigorous open-growing plant can produce as many as 11,000 burrs.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “The viability of buried seeds…in the southern USA decreased from 100% at harvest to 66% & 18% after burial for 6 and 30 months respectively”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Noogoora burr can form very dense stands which are completely dominant and cover entire paddocks in pastoral areas”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annuals.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Burrs well equipped for dispersal because hooked spines readily entangle in wool, fur, bag, etc.  also spread by water, road making equipment, agricultural seeds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Burrs are known to have spread > 200 km along waterways.  Other dispersal mechanisms (animals, equipment) also could spread seed long distances.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Erect annual herb usually to about 1 metre high. Thick burr patches in pastures eliminate almost all other species, and may be so dense (up to 30 plants per square metre) that sheep are denied access to watering points.” Similarly, because of the prickly nature of the plant, patches would restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “In Victoria …it exists on flood-prone areas along the [Murray River] and its tributaries. Xanthium spp. is spread widely along waterways.” Dense patches would affect some recreational activities such as boating or fishing in these situations.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The fruit is a “woody ellipsoid burr 1.2 to 2.5 cm long.” “The seed and seedlings are poisonous to animals…both species cause contact dermatitis in humans and the pollen may cause hay fever.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual impact and seriously affect the aesthetics of an area.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A competitive annual, “thick burr patches in pastures eliminate almost all other species.” Potential to leave areas of soil exposed to erosion. “In Australia, it thrives on the banks of rivers and creeks.” In these situations there may be off-site implications associated with soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “…these plants [are] strong competitors in both pasture and summer crops.” Direct replacement of biomass by invader.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Plants die in autumn, but remain standing. Dense patches may increase the intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Creekline grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential 
It occurs along flood-prone areas of the Murray River and its tributaries. “Thick burr patches in pasture eliminate almost all other species.” Prefers unshaded situations. Major impact on grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; L CLIMATE potential 
Prefers unshaded situations. Likely CLIMATE potential and forest situation would limit impact.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Noogoora burr can form very dense stands which are completely dominant and cover entire paddocks. Some forms prefer open communities and die out if shaded or crowded.” Major impact on lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “An extensive root system and rapid growth rate make these plants strong competitors.” “Noogoora burr can form very dense patches…Californian burr occurs in thick patches, and occasionally in large dense stands.” Reduces food source for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits to fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The seeds and seedlings of both species are poisonous.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests. “The seeds and seedlings of both species are poisonous.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “These plants [are] strong competitors both in pasture and summer crops such as maize, cotton and soybeans.” Its presence in pasture seriously reduces carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Burrs contaminate wool reducing its value. “In 1978–79, between 7% and 8% of the wool sold in eastern Australia was contaminated with Noogoora burr.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The plant can be effectively controlled, but management programs can extend for more than six years to ensure the seed bank is exhausted. The cost of implementing such a program, plus the potential loss of income from reduced yields and quality, would likely have a negative impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: With an appropriate control program, land use would not need to change significantly. “Neither species is particularly important to cattle producers.” If the weed is left untreated, changing from sheep to cattle may be required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: The burrs “…damage carding machines.” The cost of processing contaminated wool increases. “…travelling stock must be inspected and any burrs removed.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “In North America, Noogoora burr is a host of two Sclerotinia pathogens which cause important diseases in soybeans. It is not known if it plays a similar role in Australia.” Potential host a threat to agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate at almost any time of the year.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes in ‘open’ areas e.g. roadsides, pastures and cultivated land.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes most readily in disturbed situations, e.g. roadsides and overgrazed pastures but does not dominate in well-maintained pastures.  Establishes minor disturbed ecosystems.  (Carr et al  1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
An erect annual biennial or perennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not eaten by stock or ‘seldom’ eaten by stock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “onion weed does not invade areas successfully when competing for moisture with perennial plants that have roots close to the surface”…BUT, in disturbed/other situations it ‘grows so thickly that other vegetation, particularly grasses, is reduced’.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Drought – hardy once established.

Assumed also tolerant to frosts (occurs in Southern Tasmania where frost occur).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
80 flowers per plant x 6 seeds per flower = 480 seeds per plant.
(See Felfoldi & Meadly).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds remain viable in the soil for many years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Some plants flower and die in the first year thus becoming annuals, others are biennials or short-lived perennial.  (At least three years).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Young plants develop slowly and generally do not flower until they are about 18 moths old.  Annual species.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Vehicles, machinery, animals, wool, clothing, produce and water, wind blowing dead plants still bearing seeds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Vehicles, machinery, animals, humans, water and wind are likely to disperse propagules > 200 m.  however, main dispersal mechanisms is wind blowing dead plants.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect annual, biennial or perennial herb to 75 cm high. Its presence would have minimal impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Commonly occurring on roadsides, disturbed areas and overgrazed pastures. In flower, the plant would be noticeable and would have a minor negative impact on the visual aesthetic.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Onion weed allegedly causes dermatitis in some people.” Minor physiological effect

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: During flowering, dense patches would create a major effect to aesthetics.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Onion weed grows so thickly that other vegetation is reduced. [Although] the flower stem dies back, most leaves remain alive through summer.” It would not contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “…an invasive weed occupying roadsides, disturbed areas and overgrazed pastures.” Weed replaces biomass

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No great change in biomass; not likely to change fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“Onion weed grows so thickly that other vegetation, particularly grasses, is reduced.” Major effect on annual grasses.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Herb-rich heathy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“Onion weed grows so thickly that other vegetation, particularly grasses, is reduced.” Does not establish when having to compete for moisture with other perennials. Minor effect on species within the lower stratum.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Onion weed grows so thickly that other vegetation, particularly grasses, is reduced. In dense patches, lowered soil nitrogen prevents other plants establishing and competing with the weed.” Likely to have a minor effect on the lower strata. Occurs on roadsides, disturbed areas and overgrazed pasture..

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Farmers’ organisations claim that the original carrying capacity of much grazing land in the drier parts of southern Australia has been reduced by 75% because of onion weed.” The plant, ”…is not eaten by stock.” Likely to have at least a minor impact on the source of food for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Onion weed grows so thickly that other vegetation, particularly grasses, is reduced, and because it is not eaten by stock, carrying capacity is also reduced. Farmers’ organisations claim that the original carrying capacity of much grazing land in the drier parts of southern Australia has been reduced by 75% because of onion weed.” Likely to have a serious impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Its impact on yield and the cost associated with control may reduce the value of land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The plant can be readily controlled by cultivation and sewing lucerne or a cereal crop undersown with lucerne. If sown to lucerne, it is recommended that the area is not grazed in the first year. This makes the area temporarily unavailable, which would lead to some economic loss.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No a weed of cropping

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in autumn”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Occurs in damp sclerophyll forest where it would receive some shading.

“It thrives in a wide range of conditions and in full sun to semi shade”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades undisturbed vegetation e.g. alpine and sub alpine vegetation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect perennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “It is not readily grazed by stock”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Grows so densely that it excludes almost all other vegetation”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of frost – occurs in alpine/subalpine communities.

Assumed tolerant of some drought as occurs in Coastal Victoria, Coastal and Northern NSW and Perth.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing from creeping roots and by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Seed production is prolific, most seed is viable”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Some may remain dormant for at least 20 years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
“Its life span is indeterminate”.

Assumed  3 years as a perennial herb that produces new aerial growth annually.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Seeds germinate in autumn – seed is produced during the summer (> 1 year since).

“Young plants develop slowly through winter and spring and do not flower in the first year”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Mud, water, agricultural produce, animals, vehicles – road graders and earth moving equipment.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Vehicles could spread seed/root long distances.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect perennial herb commonly 30 to 60 cm high (mainly stem growth). Narrow, fleshy stems. Infestations of this plant would have minimal impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: During flowering, the weed is quite noticeable. At distance, dense patches appear as carpets of white. The growth habit of the plant would not affect recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No harmful physical properties. Not toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “Ox-eye daisy grows so densely that it excludes almost all other vegetation.” It would create a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: It occurs mostly on disturbed sites and degraded pastures and can grow so densely, “…that it excludes almost all other vegetation.” Aerial growth dies back after summer which may leave areas of soil exposed. Potential for surface soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: It occurs mostly on disturbed sites and degraded pastures. A strong competitor, it replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aerial growth dies back in summer leaving little material for fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
“…occurs commonly in grasslands of the British Isles. Ox-eye daisy grows so densely that it excludes almost all other vegetation.” In Victoria it occurs in large to medium populations in lowland grassland and grassy woodland. Major displacement of grass species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riparian shrubland (R); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Damp forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Where it occurs on disturbed sites and degraded pastures it, “grows so densely that it excludes almost all other vegetation.” Would have a major impact on ground flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Dense infestations exclude most other vegetation…[and] it is not readily grazed.” Would reduce the food source for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be poisonous to animals.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Ox-eye daisy grows so densely that it excludes almost all other vegetation. Because it is not readily grazed by stock, carrying capacity of infested areas is reduced, and the weed’s chances of survival and spread are enhanced.” Carr et al (1992) indicates infestations are widespread in medium to large populations. Likely to have a major impact on quantity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “If eaten, it imparts a disagreeable taste to milk.” Minor impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Although infestations can be readily control by mechanical or chemical methods, the impact on yield in grazing activities may reduce the value of land in those situations.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No impact on harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “Ox-eye daisy hosts virus diseases in the United States, including the yellow dwarf virus of potatoes, but its importance in this role in Australia in not known.” It has the potential to affect Australian agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate from spring to early summer.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes under moderate canopy/litter cover (e.g. in woodlands and sclerophyll forests).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes as an environmental weed minor disturbed natural ecosystems (e.g. heathland/heathy woodland, sclerophyll forest, riparian vegetation).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial herb-aerial growth dies in autumn and new growth develops in late winter and spring therefore geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Is grazed.  However, assured to recover quickly: 1- has a thick, woody, extensive rootstock: 2 – not mentioned by P & C (1992) as control technique.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Once firmly established (it) smothers all other vegetation killing large shrubs and trees”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerates drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from roots and by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Fruit containing several seeds.  Has numerous stems trailing to 3 m long.
 ~ 100 berries per plant x 20 seeds per berry = at least 2,000 seeds per plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Perennial herb.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Due to the rapid growth rate of this perennial herb, assumed to be around two years after germination.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Roots – cultivation equipment, road graders and garden refuse.

Seeds – contaminated equipment, clothing, mud birds and other animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Above mechanisms could transport many seeds > 200 m / 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A semi-erect, semi-prostrate perennial herb, with stems to 3 metres in length. Unlikely to impeded individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Infestations occur in medium to large populations and would be noticeable to visitors. Not likely to inhibit recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “It is claimed to be poisonous to stock but no losses have been reported in Australia. The fruit is sometimes used in preserves and is sold I the markets of Argentina and Paraguay for this purpose.” Consider harmless

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “Once firmly established pampas lily-of-the-valley smothers all other vegetation, killing large shrubs and fruit trees.” On cultural sites it would have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Extensive perennial root system to 1 metre deep. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “…grows on home sites and neglected areas, trailing over fences, low bushes etc.” Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No evidence to suggest the plant would support fire or its establishment. Increase in biomass may result in a minor change to the frequency of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
“Once firmly established, pampas lily-of-the-valley smothers all other vegetation, [and] killing large shrubs.” Current distribution is limited. High impact on low and mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Coastal dune scrub (D); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; H CLIMATE potential
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Once firmly established, pampas lily-of-the-valley smothers all other vegetation, killing large shrubs and fruit trees, and making vegetable and flower culture difficult.” Serious impact on all strata. Possibly monoculture.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: While limited in distribution, it does occur in medium to large populations. Would limit food source for native species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Claimed to be poisonous but no evidence of this in Australia.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Rats, mice and ants are known to disperse seed in urban areas.” Possible limited food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: No evidence; not a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping. No evidence of stock eating the plant.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germinate any time of year if moisture is available and can germinate over a wide temperature range. Requires wet soil conditions for several days to stimulate germination (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Found in moist areas receiving run-off. Growth is impeded in shaded areas (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). “It requires full or nearly full sunlight to survive and reproduce” (Francis, 2003).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Found especially near creeks, rivers, bores or dams. Needs some kind of disturbance to become established. Will establish in areas of only minor disturbance ” (Francis, 2003).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Leguminous shrub (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Livestock, especially sheep, browses foliage and pods. Under a biocontrol program with several insects showing potential as control agents (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Can be attacked by snow scale and termites (World Agroforestry Centre, n.d.).

Research has shown up to 95% of seed banks can be destroyed by two Parkinsonia seed  beetles.  Rhinacloa callicrates is a leaf bug having no significant impact in Queensland to  date. Weeds still persist (van Rangelrooy & Flanagan, 1999).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Forms dense thickets and shades out pasture species (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). 

Noted for its rapid growth (minimum estimate for a fast growing woody shrub) (World Agroforestry Centre, n.d.).. Will exceed most other species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Extremely drought resistant. Can survive in saline soils. Frost tolerant up to -5�C (World Agroforestry Centre, n.d.). Sensitive to waterlogging. Seedlings will not withstand fire but mature plants have high survival rate (DNRE, 2001).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Grows from seed, root or shoot cuttings although vegetative reproduction is not part of the plants natural cycle. Pollinated by bees but unknown if self-pollinator (World Agroforestry  centre, n.d.).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: One pod usually contains between 2 to 6 seeds but can contain up to 9. Produces “large numbers of seeds and pods” (DNRE, 2004). “Profusely produces seeds” (World Agroforestry Centre, n.d.). Assume that produces greater than 2,000 seeds per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Two types of seeds and about 25% of the light brown seeds germinate readily. The rest of the light brown seeds and all of the dark brown seeds have hard seed coats that must be  scarified before they will germinate (Francis, 2003). Viable for up to three years (World Agroforestry Centre, n.d.).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: The plants can live up to 30 years. Species is capable of forming dense monocultures (Francis, 2003).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Flower in the second or third growth season (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Moved by floodwaters and streams. Birds eat seeds. Movement through mud, humans and machinery (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Due to the dispersal mechanisms (see above), it is very likely that some of the propagules will be dispersed greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A branching spiny shrub or small tree of irregular habit, from 2 to 8 m high. “It may form dense thickets especially along creeks and rivers…limiting access to watering points” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).  “Parkinsonia can form dense impenetrable thickets making areas of land inaccessible for people” (van Rangelrooy & Flanagan, 1999).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “The value of the outback tourism industry is increasing and Parkinsonia infestations reduce this natural attraction.” ARMCANZ (2001). “Thickets can be up to several kilometres across” (van Rangelrooy & Flanagan, 1999). Serious impacts to aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Each leaf is subtended by a needle-sharp spine 5-15 mm long” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Thorns present at all times of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “Some colonies along rivers are many kilometres in length” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). “Watercourse infestations can cause stream course alteration in subsequent floods by diverting the water flow contributing to erosion and inhibiting flood mitigation” (ARMCANZ, 2001). Weed may have a minor impact on surface or subsurface flow.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Watercourse infestations can cause stream course alteration in subsequent floods by diverting the water flow contributing to erosion and inhibiting flood mitigation” (ARMCANZ, 2001). High probability of large scale soil movement with major off-site implications. However, in Victoria, chance of flooding events is reduced.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It may form dense thickets” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Where the plant occurs on open grassland, riverine or wetland areas biomass would increase significantly.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No data available.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Parilla Mallee (V); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
“Formation of thickets seriously affects ground vegetation through competition for light, water and nutrients.”  (ARMCANZ, 2001). Major displacement of some dominant species within the groundcover layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Riverine Chenopod woodland (D); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
“Formation of thickets seriously affects ground vegetation through competition for light, water and nutrients.” (ARMCANZ, 2001). Major displacement of some dominant species within the groundcover layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Loamy Sands Mallee (LC); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
“Formation of thickets seriously affects ground vegetation through competition for light, water and nutrients.”  (ARMCANZ, 2001). Major displacement of some dominant species within the groundcover layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Formation of thickets seriously affects ground vegetation through competition for light, water and nutrients. It may in time displace trees such as the coolibah (Eucalyptus microtheca) and river red gum (E. carnaldulensis)” (ARMCANZ, 2001). Major impact on <60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
