fauna_threatened.comments: “Infestations eliminate or reduce open water areas. These wetlands are waterbird habitats of national significance, as they provide refuges and breeding grounds and they may buffer against drought and habitat losses in other areas of Australia” (ARMCANZ, 2001). Reduction in habitat for fauna spp. leading to reduced populations.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Birds and animals eat the seed, which enhances its germination capacity (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). This suggests that fauna do not gain much from eating the seed.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Each leaf is subtended by a needle-sharp spine 5-15 mm long” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Thorns present at all times of the year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not documented in ARMCANZ (2001) as a food source to pest animals

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Impedes access to water by stock; Reduces pasture production and carrying capacity lowering cattle and wool production” (ARMCANZ, 2001). Impact >5% reduction.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not documented in ARMCANZ (2001) to impact quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “All control programs require several years of follow-up treatments and many years of vigilance, which increases the cost several fold. The long-term costs may cause control of large dense infestations to be uneconomic. The current poor financial performance of agricultural industries and low land values of infested areas extenuate this” (ARMCANZ, 2001). As infestations may be uneconomical to control, land value would drop further.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See comments in 19 and 21 above. In time infested land may become useless for pastoral activities.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “Increased difficulty and expense of mustering” (ARMCANZ, 2001). Increase in both time and labour.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None documented in ARMCANZ (2001).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at any time of year provided moisture is available.” Opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Seeds exposed to light showed higher germination than those in darkness but with time this difference tended to become smaller.” Can establish without additional factors.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
“It occurs as a weed in disturbed areas on roadsides, railway reserves, stock yards, cultivated fields, run-down pastures and vacant lots.”

“Parthenium does not compete with established perennial grasses as it requires bare soil to germinate.” Requires some disturbance or bare soil to establish.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Short-lived annual. Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “The allelopathic nature of P. hysterophorus has been well documented.” It is known to inhibit the germination of a large number of trees, shrubs and crops. Examples of such species are Casuarina, Acacia, Eucalyptus, rice, wheat, barley mung beans and sorghum. Major allelopathic properties inhibiting the growth of many plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
“Livestock do not normally eat the weed but hungry animals, particularly sheep, may do so if nothing else is available.”

“Under continued grazing pressure, parthenium weed will completely dominate the pasture, forming pure stands over areas up to 5,000 hectares.” Even under grazing, the plant can still dominate leading to monoculture.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “…plants commence flowering within 4 to 8 weeks of germination, 4 weeks being more likely in dry periods.” Rapid growth to flowering stage likely to exceed the growth rate of similar species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Flowering… continues until drought or frost kills the plant.” Not tolerant to either drought or frost.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Annual herb, reproducing by seed. “Self-compatibility of parthenium weed has not been observed in plants grown in isolation in Australia.” Cross-pollination only.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Parthenium weed seeds prolifically, each plant producing about 15,000 seeds.” Above 2,000 seeds produced annually.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Some field evidence exists that parthenium weed achenes can remain viable after being buried for at least 4–6 years.” Many seeds survive for a period of less than 10 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Short-lived annual. Produces propagules for one growing season (i.e. annually).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plant commences flowering within 4 to 8 weeks of germination. Reaches maturity in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
“Dispersal of parthenium weed achenes occurs locally by wind and water. Wind transport is usually only in the order of a few metres.”

“Most of the really long-distance spread is by animals, vehicles, farm machinery, and in mud.”
Spread by wind, water, vehicles and farm machinery.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
In the majority of cases of long distance dispersal, achenes are transported on motor vehicles or machinery, on livestock, with crop and pasture seed, or in fodder. As a result, new infestations of the weed may appear thousands of kilometres from the nearest plants.” 
It is quite possible that many propagules will disperse more than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect annual herb 30 cm to 150 cm high. “…an aggressive coloniser of fallows, wasteland, roadsides, and overgrazed pastures.” Dense infestations may impede individual access, though not seriously.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Weeds would be obvious, but recreational activities would not be greatly affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Regular contact with the plant, usually over a prolonged period, produces an acute form of dermatitis, and asthma in humans.” Potentially harmful for most of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Parthenium weed becomes established in disturbed, degraded or bare soil.” Vigorous growth (“In good conditions Parthenium weed can germinate, flower and set seed within four weeks.”) would provide some protection against erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Parthenium weed becomes established in disturbed, degraded or bare soil.” Likely to increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Although the woody stems remain after the plant dies, there would be insufficient fuel to support fire. Low risk of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; H to VH CLIMATE potential.
It is not a problem in undisturbed vegetation. However, native pastures may not be able to compete with parthenium weed, and dense infestations can eliminate most other species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Does not appear likely to invade medium value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to invade low value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Parthenium weed is a vigorous species that colonises weak pastures with sparse ground cover.” “Most seeds germinate at the one time, producing a mat of seedlings. The young rosettes, with their leaves closely appressed to the soil prevent the emergence of other species leading to pure stands of parthenium weed.”  Open situations only; affects grasses and forbs.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: As an aggressive coloniser it would impact on the food source of native species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Causes contact dermatitis and asthma in humans. “Cattle may also be affected, and more importantly, pass the toxic principle into their milk.” Potential also to be harmful to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No evidence of pest species using the plant as a food source.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “The weed is a menace to agriculture because it competes with pastures and reduces carrying capacity.” “Some grain sorghum crops are infested with sufficient parthenium weed plants to suppress yield.” Because of its aggressive nature impact on yield likely to be of major significance.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Meat from animals who graze the plant is badly tainted, “and unfit for the table unless the animals are grazed on parthenium-free paddocks for at least a month prior to slaughter.” Major impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “If allowed to spread, the weed will become a serious and persistent problem in NSW, resulting in a downgrading of property values.”

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Parthenium weed will become dominant if pastures are overgrazed and not managed properly. Carrying capacity will be reduced and the area will cease to be economically viable.” This could lead to a serious loss of income.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not know to affect harvesting activities.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Can germinate at any time, however most seed germinates after the first and subsequent rains of autumn and winter.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Est. Open Areas

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Est. crops, mainly pasture.  * also a ‘serious’ weed of Mallee shrub land,  low and grassland & grassy woodland, dry sclerophyll forest & woodland & riparian veg. (Carr et al 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual/biennial herb

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Consumed by sheep but not preferred : avoided by cattle and horses

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Competes strongly with more valuable pasture species”. “Has been shown to compete with & reduce product growth from  T. subterraneum”.   *  “It’s high early growth rate allows Paterson’s Curse to out compete other seedlings” P & C 1992 p. 329)

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerates moisture stress and frost (see distribution map).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed – cross & self pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Individual plants can produce up to 10,000 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Small amount of seed remains dormant in the soil for at least 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms dense monocultures (See picture P & C 1992 p. 327).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual/biennial.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Water, animals (internal & external), contaminant of hay or grain.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
“Birds eat seed of E. plantagineum and may spread it over large distances”.

“Movement of seed in water is important, particularly in hilly country where run off water carries them to lower areas”.  “The most important means of spread, however, has been as a contaminant of hay or grain”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Although a weed of agriculture, it does occur in natural habitats such as grasslands, woodlands and heathlands. It can form very extensive persistent populations. The plant can cause skin irritation. No physical barrier but skin issue covered in quest 3

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The presence of this weed is obvious to the average visitor particularly during flowering.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Some medical practitioners have established a link between the plant and hay fever.” “…the rough hairy texture of the leaves and stems causes skin irritation.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: While the presence of this plant is quite noticeable, there appears to be no evidence that it negatively affects cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial spp.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
“…in heavily grazed pasture, [it leaves] bare ground when it dies back in summer.”
Potential for erosion from both wind and water.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: It is primarily a weed of grazing land. Significant change to biomass unlikely. However, it competes “vigorously with smaller indigenous plants and impedes overstorey regeneration.” “The broad rosette leaves shade and smother most other species.”

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “…it seeds and dries off in spring leaving little residue.” Little or no change to fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“Paterson’s curse can form very extensive, persistent populations in disturbed areas, competing vigorously with smaller indigenous plants and impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major impact on lower stratum, minor impact on mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Hillcrest herb-rich woodland (D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Not as competitive in high quality, intact native vegetation. Minor impact on grasses/ forbs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Paterson’s curse can form very extensive, persistent populations in disturbed areas, competing vigorously with smaller indigenous plants and impeding overstorey regeneration.”

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Changes to structure may limit suitable fodder for non-threatened fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “The seed forms a large part of the diet of [Australian] crested pigeons (Ocyphaps lophotes) in summer and autumn.” Also a food source for two species of Australian ants (Iridomyrmex discors and Prolasius spp.)

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “…presence of pyrrolizidine alkaloids contained in the plant cause cumulative chronic liver damage.” “Stiff bristles on all parts of mature plants irritate the udders of cows.” Potentially toxic and cause allergies in fauna. May not be grazed – No info on native spp. – Native spp more mobile unlikely to be grazing just on patto

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Food source for introduced ant Pheidole megacephala. May be a food source for pest birds.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “…most graziers argue that the weed’s presence reduces both quantity and quality of useful fodder in pastures.” Cattle and horses tend to avoid the plant.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: The plant can dominate in pastures reducing the quality of fodder.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The cost of control and eradication would add to farm operating costs over several years. A significant seed bank with seeds that last for over five years. Land value would decrease.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Sheep find Paterson’s curse more palatable than do cattle and horses.” This may dictate a change in stock until the plant is controlled.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “The plant can occur, and make harvesting difficult, in crops if seed bed preparation is poor and sowing is early.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Tufted or rarely stoloniferous perennial grass to 0.7 m high (Jacobs & Hastings 1993; Smith et al. 1999). Unlikely to limit human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Tufted or rarely stoloniferous perennial grass to 0.7 m high (Jacobs & Hastings 1993; Smith et al. 1999). Unlikely to be obvious to the average visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Leaf blades described as glabrous (without hairs) with a ciliate (hairy) ligule (Oram 1990). Not described as having features that might be injurious to people, such as silicas that can give leaves a sharp edge. “No known health risks” (Virtue & Melland 2003).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
Tufted or rarely stoloniferous perennial grass to 0.7 m high (Jacobs & Hastings 1993; Smith et al. 1999).
Negligible effect on aesthetics of a site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Does not tolerate waterlogging (Frey 2005) and not described in association with waterways. Unlikely to impact on aquatic environments.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Does not tolerate waterlogging (Frey 2005) and not described in association with waterways. Unlikely to impact on aquatic environments.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Used for erosion control (Frey 2005) although this species can become dormant over winter under heavy frosts (Oram 1990). However, it does have an extensive root system (Frey 2005) that may still allow it to bind soil, even when dormant. No record was found of this species failing as erosion control.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Tufted or rarely stoloniferous perennial to 0.7 m high (Jacobs & Hastings 1993). Able to suppress germination of shrub seedlings (Frey 2000) and under-storey and tree seedlings and even some larger perennial vegetation (Virtue & Melland 2003). Capable of replacing woody vegetation, significantly reducing biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “E. erecta’s extensive root system may increase the fuel load in forested systems. [This] may change the intensity or frequency of fires” (Frey 2005).

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Parila Mallee (BCS =E); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Tufted or rarely stoloniferous perennial to 0.7 m high (Jacobs & Hastings 1993). “Demonstrated capacity to form understorey monocultures in remnant native vegetation in SA” (Virtue & Melland 2003). Displaces all species within the understorey.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Hills herb rich woodland (BCS =D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; CLIMATE potential=VH
Tufted or rarely stoloniferous perennial to 0.7 m high (Jacobs & Hastings 1993). “Demonstrated capacity to form understorey monocultures in remnant native vegetation in SA” (Virtue & Melland 2003). Displaces all species within the understorey.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (BCS =LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg= Gippland plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Tufted or rarely stoloniferous perennial to 0.7 m high (Jacobs & Hastings 1993). “Demonstrated capacity to form understorey monocultures in remnant native vegetation in SA” (Virtue & Melland 2003). Displaces all species within the understorey.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “This species appears to be rapidly changing the composition and dynamics of California central coastal dune systems.” Able to suppress germination of shrub seedlings (Frey 2000) and under-storey and tree seedlings and even some larger perennial vegetation. “Demonstrated capacity to form understorey monocultures in remnant native vegetation in SA” (Virtue & Melland 2003). Major effect on all vegetation layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The “demonstrated capacity to form understorey monocultures in remnant native vegetation in SA” (Virtue & Melland 2003) suggests that this species could have a significant impact on threatened forbs, however no specific information was found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Due to its “demonstrated capacity to form understorey monocultures in remnant native vegetation in SA” (Virtue & Melland 2003) and ability to suppress germination of shrub seedlings (Frey 2000) and under-storey and tree seedlings and even some larger perennial vegetation (Virtue & Melland 2003), this species is likely to reduce habitat for fauna species, leading to reduction in numbers, but not to local extinction.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Introduced as a forage crop (Frey 2005), so may provide some food for grazing animals. Provides food source for butterfly larvae for species such as the white-banded grass dart and marbled xenica (Grund 2006), however other food sources are available for these species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Introduced as a forage crop (Frey 2005), so unlikely to be toxic. Leaf blades described as glabrous (without hairs) with a ciliate (hairy) ligule (Oram 1990). Not described as having features that might be physically injurious to animals, such as silicas that can give leaves a sharp edge.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Introduced as a forage crop (Frey 2005) and highly palatable, so likely to provide a food source for serious browse pests such as rabbits.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: An important and highly palatable pasture species in low rainfall areas with sandy soil (Virtue & Melland 2003) and a dominant grass in otherwise sparse pasture (Frey 2005). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: An important and highly palatable pasture species in low rainfall areas with sandy soil (Virtue & Melland 2003) and a dominant grass in otherwise sparse pasture (Frey 2005). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: An important and highly palatable pasture species in low rainfall areas with sandy soil (Virtue & Melland 2003) and a dominant grass in otherwise sparse pasture (Frey 2005). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: An important and highly palatable pasture species in low rainfall areas with sandy soil (Virtue & Melland 2003) and a dominant grass in otherwise sparse pasture (Frey 2005). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: An important and highly palatable pasture species in low rainfall areas with sandy soil (Virtue & Melland 2003) and a dominant grass in otherwise sparse pasture (Frey 2005). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Introduced as a forage crop (Frey 2005). Not found to be a host to pests or diseases of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds are thought to germinate in spring, about the same time that shoots develop from the root system.” Requires natural seasonal disturbance to germinate.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: It prefers alkaline, poorly drained soils. In Australia, it occurs in a few areas on cultivated land and pastures. Requires open areas with access to sunlight and moisture.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In California, U.S., the plant occurs on, “… alkaline plains, edges of salt marshes, cultivated fields, pastures, roadsides [and] waste places.” Establishes in highly disturbed ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial herb, reproducing from creeping roots and seed. Geophyte.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “Poverty weed is allelopathic; extracts from the leaves reduce germination and root and shoot development of wheat, and root extracts inhibit growth of several grasses and legumes.” Allelopathic properties seriously affecting some plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “… it is seldom grazed because of its strong smell and taste.” Not eaten.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Iva axillaris competes strongly with cereal crops. No records exist of its competitiveness with other weedy perennials. It develops new growth in spring and matures and flowers in summer. Its growth rate may exceed other species of the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
“Food reserves in the deep roots allow new growth to develop in drought years.” The plant occurs on saline soils and the deep root system may ensure it survive periods of frost. 
“… poverty weed… is a natural component of many grassland communities that experience periodic fire.” Able to survive fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces from creeping roots and seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: About 6 or 7 seeds produced in each flower head, of which there are many on each stem. Stems numerous. Possibly more than 2,000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Little is known of the viability or longevity of seed. In the U.S., “… studies have shown some seed may be viable after two years of freshwater storage.”

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Poverty weed is a long-lived perennial.”

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Seeds germinate in spring; plants mature in summer producing flowers and seed. Mature in under one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The seed is not equipped with a pappus, so is not adapted to wind dispersal. It can contaminate agricultural produce, seed, machinery and can survive c. 8 months submerged in water. Within a property dispersal can occur through the distribution of root fragments on cultivation equipment.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Much of the spread of this plant is due the creeping roots. In Canada viable seed is seldom produced. This may also be the case in Australia, where the current infestation has not spread. The main method of spread may be on contaminated agricultural machinery; thus, dispersal would be limited to less than 1 kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A perennial herb commonly 20 cm to 30 cm high. It would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: It produces dense aerial growth and its presence would be obvious. The leaves produce an unpleasant aromatic odour when crushed. This aspect of the plant may limit some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “it causes contact dermatitis in some people while its abundant pollen has exacerbated hay-fever problems.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: As a strong competitor with dense aerial growth. It would create a negative visual effect seriously affecting the aesthetics of a site.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: An extensive perennial root system to 2.5 metres deep consisting of both vertical and horizontal roots. Colonises cultivated land or overgrazed pastures. Aerial growth dies in autumn leaving the potential for surface soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aerial growth dies in autumn. Little matter remains to establish or support fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential.
In the U.S., it occurs mostly in grassland (rangeland) situations. It sometimes forms large clonal colonies on disturbed sites where it is difficult to eradicate. Major displacement of grasses/forbs in open situation. Effect in woodland situation may be limited.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Distribution limited to northwest of Victoria. Limited data on EVC available. It does not appear to affect any medium value EVCs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: As in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “With its extensive root system and dense aerial growth, poverty weed competes strongly with other plants. Almost no crop is produced in heavily infested areas. Poverty weed is allelopathic.” Occurs in open disturbed or neglected areas. Likely to have a serious impact on the lower stratum in open situations.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: It, “competes strongly with other plants…and large areas of infested pasture in western Canada have little or no grazing value.” As it is not grazed by livestock, its presence would lead to a reduction in available food for native species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: In Canada “there have been reports that poverty weed is a selenium accumulator and may be toxic to livestock when ingested. However, this is very rare due to the unpalatable nature of the plant.” Not considered toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “It is highly competitive when established in agricultural fields and may significantly reduce crop yields.” “Almost no crop is produced in heavily infested areas.” Major impact on production.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Its seeds are a common contaminant of legume and grass seed crops in some areas.” Impact not documented, though contaminated crop may be difficult to sell due to the competitive nature of the weed.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Its impact on yield in both grazing and cropping situations, and the difficulty in controlling the plant, suggest land value may be seriously affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “…cultivation and repeated workings over 3 years in Canada did not eliminate the weed…herbicides offering the only effective treatment. Large areas of grazing land in Canada have little or no grazing value.” Potential for significant agricultural loss.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No known effect on harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
A summer growing plant of open grazing land.

Withstands shading.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: A summer growing plant of open grazing land.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: The aerial growth dies in autumn without flowering but roots remain alive producing new shoots in the following spring therefore Geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Rarely eaten by stock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Competition is effective (for control) if vigorous summer growing species can be established.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Withstands drought, but does not persist under constant irrigation.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from creeping roots and by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Estimate: 15 berries per plant x 20 seeds per berry = 300 seeds per plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Perennial herb.

Flowers and fruit are produced in summer and the cycle is repeated annually.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Seeds germinate in spring  aerial growth dies in autumn without flowering  flowers and fruit are then produced in summer and the cycle is repeated annually.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Cultivation, wind and water: animals – birds, foxes and stock eat the fruit, and it seems that germination is enhanced after seeds pass through animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: The frequent occurrence of prairie ground cherry along railway lines is probably due to birds and animal droppings falling from railway trucks.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect perennial herb 25 cm to 60 cm high. It would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: A summer growing plant of open grazing land, its presence would not affect tourism. Dense patches may create a negative visual effect.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches may create a moderate negative visual impact.  More on agricultural land that has been cultivated

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Occurs in open grazing land. Perennial roots are deep and extensive. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aerial growth dies in autumn. Little material left to establish or support fire.  Green in summer

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Occurs on open grazing land where it can form dense patches. Major impact on grasses/forbs. Possible Minor impacts as lots of space around plants

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Most commonly found in open grassland or disturbed situations. Does not appear likely to occur in medium value EVCs.  (Possible Minor impacts as lots of space around plants )

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Most commonly found in open grassland or disturbed situations. Does not appear likely to occur in low value EVCs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “It is a perennial herb that is very invasive, forming dense coverages in pastures, crops and roadsides.” Likely to have a major impact on ground flora. 20 – 60%

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “…forming dense coverages in pastures, crops and roadsides.” In natural ecosystems, its presence would reduce available fodder for native species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Prairie ground cherry is suspected of being poisonous but the foliage is rarely eaten by stock, however, sheep readily eat the ripe fruit, apparently without ill effect.” Not considered injurious.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “The fruit is eaten by birds and foxes.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “…forms dense coverages in pastures and crops…reduces stock summer carrying capacities.” Likely to have a major impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “The distribution of hay cut from infested areas is an important means of dispersal.” Contaminated product may be unsuitable for sale. Original infestation in the Goulburn Valley of Victoria was through contaminated lucerne seed.  Grain quality maybe reduced through water competition with PGC.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Because of the deep root system control by cultivation is not effective. Chemical controls, while effective, are expensive over large areas. Due to persistence of the weed and its impact on both pastures and cropping, its presence may reduce land value. Not fussed

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Land use could continue, though with reduced agricultural return.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “It interferes with crop harvesting.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “Closely related species are known hosts of virus diseases affecting tomatoes in the United States but similar problems are not known in Australia.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
‘Seeds germinate after significant rainfall in late spring and summer’ (DNRME 2004)
‘germination does not occur until triggered by water penetrating the hard seed coat. Germination occurs between 14� and 37�C. (Mackey 1998). Requires natural seasonal disturbance of rainfall and summer temperatures.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘..but seedlings are shade intolerant. Although seedling establishment can occur in drier times, survival is low. If rainfall following germination is below average, the majority of seedlings on black soil will die within two years’ (Mackey 1998). Seedlings require open conditions and regular rainfall.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Dense infestations occur where there is a plentiful supply of water, for example, along watercourses and bore water drains. With an abundant supply of water and little shading by other plants, growth is rapid, but, ‘on open downs where it is drier, a good grass cover may reduce growth’ (Mackey 1998). More likely to establish in disturbed situation where there is little competition.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Tree, commonly to 6 metres, but can grow to 15 metres in optimal situation (Mackey 1998). Other life form.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: None described. Growth of perennial grasses under the canopy is greatly inhibited particularly during dry periods, however, annual and ephemeral species appear to be unaffected. Effect due to competition perennials for moisture and nutrients ( Mackey 1998).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Seedlings are spiny, but sheep are known to browse on the lower branches of established plants.  Domesticated animals consume the abundant seedpods in preference to the tree (Mackey 1998). Tolerates herbivory pressure.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Given access to water, seedling growth is rapid (Mackey 1998).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: It is reported that frost kills young plants and prevents seed set in older, established trees (Mackey 1998).  However, in some frost prone areas in Queensland infestations of prickly acacia are established and spreading. Prickly acacia tolerates salinity if fresh water is present. It has a deep taproot, which enables it to survive dry periods. In Africa it is known to tolerate seasonal waterlogging (Duke 1983).  Tolerates two or more stressors.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually; self and cross pollination. Most flowers are functionally male while others are hermaphroditic (Mackey 1998). Prickly acacia does not reproduce vegetatively.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Annually each tree produces an average of about 30000 seeds (Mackey 1998).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: In bore drains (i.e. where water is plentiful) seed half-life was found to be 10 months, but some seed is known to survive up to seven years (Mackey 1998).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Prickly acacia is known to live for up to 60 years (DNRME 2004).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: The plant reaches sexual maturity between 2 to 5 years (DNRME 2004).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Domestic animals, particular cattle are the most important vectors of seed. Ingested seed can remain in cattle for up to six days leading to viable seed being dispersed over large distances. Other vectors are floodwaters and wind (<25 m) (Mackey 1998).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Depending upon cattle movement, dispersal would be at least one kilometre, possibly greater (Mackey 1998).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Shrub or small tree from 7 to 9 m high. ‘Because of its rapid growth in favourable seasons and the presence of long spines or prickles, dense thickets of prickly acacia, impenetrable to stock, develop. Thickets along thousands of kilometres of bore drains prevent access to water’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Major impediment to access waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Because of infestation by prickly acacia, “…the Mitchell grass downs are being converted into a thorny scrubland similar to the African thornveld” (Mackey 1998). Weeds presence is obvious to visitors.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Young stems are armed with stout stipular spines 5 to 50 mm long, Spines may be absent on older stems. Dogs cannot be used for mustering purposes because of spines on the ground (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Potential for injury throughout the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Shrub or small tree from 7 to 9 m high (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “…a moderate canopy cover of prickly acacia reduces grass cover markedly and changes the relative abundance of native plant species in favour of forbs and annual grasses” (Mackey 1998). “Exacerbates and accelerates soil erosion” (ARMCANZ 2001).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “In Australia, it occurs as a weed, principally along streams and bore drains, in the semi-arid tussock and hummock grasslands” (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Biomass would increase in these situations.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “…prickly acacia does not seem susceptible to fire” (Mackey 1998). Suppression of grass species also reduces fire risk. Minor change to frequency and intensity of fires.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains Savannah (E); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Murray Mallee; Climate=VH. 
An infestation in Queensland has converted parts of the Mitchell grass downs into a thorny scrubland. “…a moderate canopy of prickly acacia reduces grass cover markedly” (Mackey 1998). Major displacement of some dominant species (grasses) within a strata (groundcover layer).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplantds; Climate=VH.
An infestation in Queensland has converted parts of the Mitchell grass downs into a thorny scrubland. “…a moderate canopy of prickly acacia reduces grass cover markedly” (Mackey 1998). Major displacement of some dominant species (grasses) within a strata (groundcover layer).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplantds; Climate=VH.
An infestation in Queensland has converted parts of the Mitchell grass downs into a thorny scrubland. “…a moderate canopy of prickly acacia reduces grass cover markedly” (Mackey 1998). Major displacement of some dominant species (grasses) within a strata (groundcover layer).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: An infestation in Queensland has converted parts of the Mitchell grass downs into a thorny scrubland. “…a moderate canopy of prickly acacia reduces grass cover markedly” (Mackey 1998). Serious impact on grasses.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The potential for A. nilotica ssp. indica to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations (Thorp & Lynch 2000). No impact on threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Since even a moderate canopy cover of prickly acacia reduces grass cover markedly and changes the relative abundance of native plant species in favour of forbs and annual grasses, this, and the shift in structure toward a shrub community, is producing a dramatic effect on native fauna habitat and the overall ecology of the system” (Mackey 1998). Major impact on habitat.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Its leaf is very digestible and has a high protein content” (Mackey 1998). May provide alternative food source for larger native herbivores.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Dogs cannot be used because of the many thorns on the ground” (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Potential for injury to non-ungulate species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “…the Australian plague locust (Chortoicetes terminifera (Walker)) is reported to feed on it,” though without any known flow-on to impact on agricultural activities (Mackey 1998). Provides food for an environmental insect pest.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Dense infestations significantly reduce pasture production…and the access of stock to water. Under normal grazing pressure a 25–30% canopy cover of prickly acacia reduces pasture production by 50% compared with acacia-free pasture” (Mackey 1998). Significant reduction in carrying capacity leading to reduced yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect the quality of produce

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Heavily infested land is almost worthless since reclamation costs are often close to, or exceed, the value of uninfested land” (Mackey 1998). Serious impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See comment in 21 above. Land may be abandoned for agricultural use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “Dense infestations of prickly acacia…increase mustering time and cost.” An increase in cost of more than 10 times the usual cost is reported (Mackey 1998). Increase in both time and labour to harvest produce.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “Prickly acacia is a host for a variety of organisms which attack it, but it does not appear to be a primary host for any other pests in Australia, though the Australian plague locust (Chortoicetes terminifera (Walker)) is reported to feed on it” (Mackey 1998).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds need between 5 and 15 days exposure to moist, warm (20-30�C) conditions before they will germinate. Germination occurs following good rain (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishment is enhanced by the presence of mulch on the soil surface (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).  Plants tolerate shade and grow in a wide range of temperatures but are well adapted to a monsoonal climate (DNRME 2004). Wet shaded areas that protect the seeds from drying out are ideal with seeds readily germinating on riverbanks and other moist areas (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  However, the plant can also establish in dry forest (ISSG 2005).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Plants are common in disturbed situations where there is temporary or permanent water, such as gullies, rivers, creeks, waterholes (IPIF 1999).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: It is a woody perennial vine (DNRME 2004). Climber.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
It is poisonous to stock, however, if animal is stressed or other feed is scarce, they may eat it. 

Biological control agents are being used (DNRME 2004).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: This plant aggressively colonises areas and forms thickets which can smother other vegetation (DNRME 2004). No evidence to suggest that it can exceed other species of the same life form but assumed that the growth rate will equal competitive species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Does not occur in areas with more than 100 days frost per annum, and from 50-100 days frost per annum being a less suitable habitat. Needs absence of frequent fires to survive (Mackay 1996). Tolerant to water logging and drought tolerant up to 80 days. Survives in saltmarsh areas (ISSG 2005).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Propagates by seeds – known to be insect-pollinated. Cannot vegetatively reproduce (Starr , Starr & Loope 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Rigid seed pods (mostly grow in pairs) mature about 6 months after flowering and each contain an average of 350 brown seeds but can contain up to 450 seeds (DNRME 2004). Can produce more than 8,000 seeds in a single reproductive episode and can set seed at least twice per year (Starr , Starr & Loope 2003).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
Approximately 95% of seeds are viable (DNRME 2004).

Seeds remain viable for approximately 12 months (Starr , Starr & Loope 2003).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Individual plants have been known to live for more than 80 years (DNRME 2004).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants can begin to reproduce after about 200 days although dependent on soil moisture, it can take more than four years to flower (Starr , Starr & Loope 2003).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: As each seed has a tuft of long white silky hair, wind and water easily disperse them (via both fresh and salt-water courses) (DNRME 2004). Animals, especially birds, also spread the seed. Seeds can spread in mud sticking to machinery and in the hooves of animals – spreading along watercourses then to pastures and open country (Starr , Starr & Loope 2003)

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As seeds are very light with the tuft to aid dispersal, it is assumed that it is very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than one kilometre. Also bird dispersed (DNRME 2004).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “The important properties of rubber vine are its ability to climb over and smother tall trees and to extend into rundown pastures. In such situations it forms dense thickets, particularly along waterways which, being impenetrable to man and beast, restrict access to water” (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Major impediment to access waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “…it is a twining vine, smothering vegetation. The Undarra Volcanic National Park in Queensland was affected when rubber vine covered the entrance of the volcanic lava tubes, thus decreasing the appeal of this attraction” (ARMCANZ 2001).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Extracts of the stems are…toxic and the plant has been implicated in human as well as animal deaths. Fortunately rubber vine is unpalatable and seldom eaten, so deaths are few” (Tomley 1998). Potentially fatal for humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “In thickets or supported by other vegetation it forms a dense tangled mass, smothering vegetation up to 40 m above the ground” (Tomley 1998). With the smothering habit of rubber vine, infestations on culturally significant vegetation (e.g. historical trees) could have a major impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Tomley 1998).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: ‘.. severely threatens riverine vegetation, and can potentially displace the plants and animals that inhabit riverbanks, thereby affecting the water quality of streams’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Potential to have minor effects in dissolved O2.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Rubber vine increases soil erosion due to, “…loss of grasses and other ground covers” (ARMCANZ 2001). It commonly occurs along watercourses (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001), thus there is a high probability for large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Rubber vine invades and dominates…riverine forest, eucalypt woodland and vine thickets” (Tomley 1998). The smothering nature of rubber vine suggests biomass would increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Heavy grazing and drought reduced the amount of available fuel, and so reduced the frequency and intensity of fires” (Mackey 1996). Although the plant burns vigorously, it requires a significant dry fuel load to cause ignition (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Minor change to frequency of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: The potential for C. grandiflora to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations (Mackey 1996). No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: The potential for C. grandiflora to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations (Mackey 1996). No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: The potential for C. grandiflora to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations (Mackey 1996). No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Rubber vine invades and dominates…riverine forest, eucalypt woodland and vine thickets. As a result some of these communities could be largely degraded” (Tomley 1998). “It is a vigorous climber which will smother and kill plants and shade out the ground layer; potential to destroy all deciduous vine thickets in Queensland” (ARMCANZ 2001).  Major impact on <60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The potential for C. grandiflora to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations (Mackey 1996). No impact on threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: See comment in 11 above. “Fauna living in such communities are also threatened. Rubber vine destroys the habitat of the greater glider Petauroides volans Kerr and the squirrel glider Petaurus norfolcensis Kerr” (Tomley 1998). Reduction in habitat leading to reduced numbers but not local extinction.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The plant is highly toxic to cattle, goats, sheep and, especially, horses” (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).  Potentially injurious to native herbivores.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “…there is a direct loss of pasture on better soils where rubber vine competes directly with pasture grasses, [with] dense infestations reducing carrying capacity by nearly 100%” (Tomley 1998). Serious impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping. Not known to affect the quality of other agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Chippendale (1991) reported that landholders perceived that property values…had dropped …due to infestation by rubber vine. …landholders recognise that rubber vine is a serious enough problem to affect their capital investment” (Tomley 1998).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Rubber vine is toxic, it seriously hinders day-to-day stock management of cattle and increases mustering costs (Tomley 1998). With such a serious impact on grazing activities, land may no longer be viable for grazing purposes.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “Mustering costs are almost doubled” (Tomley 1998). Major increase in time and labour to muster animals.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn & early winter.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in mostly ‘open’ areas e.g. paddocks, grasslands.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Weed in cultivated paddocks.

Invades lowland grassland & grassy woodland.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual herb → Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Has little fodder value although it is eaten to some extent when very young and later as the stem emerges from the rosette.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: In crops, competition reduces yield…does not invade perennial pastures nor does it withstand competition from improved annual pastures.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to frost & drought (See Australian distribution).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Individual seed heads can produce 10-16 seeds.

8 seed heads/plant x 16 seeds/head = 128 seeds/plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Some survived for up to 8 years but most seemed to be destroyed by bacteria, fungi or termites.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual her.  Forms dense infestations (see pick p196) yet doesn’t appear to be a monoculture.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual herb.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seed spread by clothing, bags, wool, fur, mud stuck to implements & vehicles, ‘tumbleweed’ effect & the flow of water along channels.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: The dried seed heads tangle in wool & the whole plant breaking off at the base, acts as a ‘tumbleweed’ spreading the seed over long distances.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect annual herb commonly 40 to 90 cm high. Saffron thistle grows on disturbed sites of low fertility and, “often grows in dense patches which restrict stock movement.” Patches may inhibit direct access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The flower stems are rigid and the leaves are reflexed and rigid, and armed with stout spines. Dense patches may restrict some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The flower stems are rigid and the leaves are reflexed and rigid, and armed with stout spines. Spines are present for most of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual impact the spiny nature of the plant would seriously affect the aesthetics of a cultural site. An annual herb, the root system would not cause structural damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “In the Western Plains of New South Wales, C. lanatus helped to provide ground cover and prevent erosion.”

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Direct replacement of biomass by invader.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: When the plant dies it leaves very little fuel to establish or support fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“Saffron thistle often occurs in dense patches. [However, it] does not invade perennial pastures.” In Victoria, it occurs in small populations. Minor impact on grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Plains sedgy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to occur in low value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: C. lanatus is widespread across Victoria in small populations. It is found in lowland grassland and grassy woodland. It establishes on disturbed sites competing for moisture, light and soil nutrients. Minor effect <60% of the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Competes with perennial grasses and, as the stout spines discourage grazing, it would reduce the food source for native species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Several reports from New South Wales and South Australia have indicated that C. lanatus have some feed value.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Causes or predisposes the livestock to eye and mouth injury.” Potential to injure fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Restricts or eliminates pasture growth in low fertility soils, thereby reducing carrying capacity and preventing livestock grazing. Reduces grain yield by 50–70%.” Serious impact on agricultural yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Seeds and broken plant parts contaminate wheat, leading to dockage by the Australian Wheat Board. It also causes vegetable fault in wool.” “Produce such as hay or seed which contains seeds of any noxious weed is usually prohibited from sale.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Decreases property values and potential income.”

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “A persistent approach [to control] is necessary. One effective program combines cropping and pasture establishment.” Change to land use in grazing situations. Alternatively, goats can be used to control infestations.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “…the hard stems increase wear and tear on harvesting machinery.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “There is veterinary evidence that the spiny leaves and bracts are involved in transmitting virus diseases in grazing animals.”

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Dense mats…obstruct or prevent the use of water for fishing, transport and recreation.”

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “Dense mats…obstruct or prevent the use of water for fishing, transport and recreation.” Major impact on recreation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The plant itself has not toxic or injurious properties. However, “the weed mass acts as a harbour for disease vectors.” In Queensland, “the plants also create a haven for mosquitoes, which are vectors of Ross River Fever and Encephalitis.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “Under flood conditions, rafts of weed material build up at fences and bridges that, in turn, collect other floating debris. The combined weight may cause theses structures to collapse. As native aquatic plants, birds and animals are displaced, the natural beauty of an open water body can be spoilt and further degraded.”

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: “Growth is best in still or slow-moving fresh water. Currents sweep the free-floating plants away.” Would have a minor impact on surface flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: “Light penetration and oxygen levels are adversely affected.” Serious depletion of light and oxygen.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Aquatic species.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Salvinia reproduces vegetatively from fragments and can form large, thick mats that can completely cover water storage areas in a relatively short time.” Biomass would increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Aquatic species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Initial infestations produce pure cultures. However, “…the interwoven stems build up a mass of dead material which provides a suitable substrate for the growth of other wetland plants.”

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “As plant material decomposes it causes water pollution and stagnation through a reduction in the water quality and oxygen content, resulting in the death of aquatic wildlife and fish.” Habitat changed dramatically.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “In Australia, the native insects Hedotettix bolivari (Sjostedt) (Orthoptera: Acrididae), Nymphula tenebralis Walker (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae) and Rhopalosiphum nymphaea (L.) (Hemiptera: Aphididae) feed on the plant. Many other insects and arachnids hide and hunt amongst the floating leaves.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The plant has no toxic or injurious properties.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Salvinia may establish in rice fields during irrigation and subsequently compete directly with the crop. Spread in this situation may be so explosive that, as has occurred in Sri Lanka, whole fields have been abandoned.” In this situation impact is serious.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No impact on quality

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Rice growers in particular, and other users of irrigation in general, may be affected by the existence of S. molesta in water storage/supply areas, either by direct competition or through associated water supply problems.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: As in Q23 above.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No impact on harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a host or vector for agricultural pests or diseases.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate after autumn rains.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in mostly ‘open’ areas e.g. pastures, roadsides, waste areas and open natural ecosystems.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems, e.g. grass lands & riparian.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
“Aerial growth dies in late autumn and new growth is produced at the crown”, therefore geophyte.

* However, not recorded as a geophyte by Carr et al (1992).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not always readily eaten by stock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Invades poor pastures & becomes the dominant species, but it does not cause problems in established, well managed pastures”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerates water logging (occurs along watercourses and riparian areas). ?  * However, stated as preferring ‘porous’ or ‘well-drained sandy soils’ P & C (1992), AgWest 2000).  Presumably tolerates drought.  * Forms a long tap root which utilises water from deep underground, which enables it to survive and grow throughout the dry West Australian summer. (AgWest 2000). Frost (occurs in Southern Tasmania & N. UK).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from a taproot and by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Equal to 10 flower clusters per plant x 5 fruits per cluster x 50 seeds per fruit = 2,500 seeds.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Can form monocultures (picture P & C (1992) p. 343).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Germinates in autumn – flowering in spring/summer.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Cultivation equipment, vehicles, animals, clothes, bags, water and mud etc.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Seed said to be ‘readily transported as a contaminant on vehicles including rail cars’.  Many seeds could therefore be dispersed > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect perennial herb commonly 30 to 70 cm high. It does not present a large physical barrier so would not impede individual access. It may be somewhat of a nuisance to walk through an infestation.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: In Victoria, it is widespread in medium to large populations on coastal vegetation, lowland grassland & grassy woodland, riparian vegetation and rock outcrop vegetation. Dense patches would have a minor negative impact on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No toxic properties.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Its presence in dense patches would create a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “In South Australia it was…sown for sand binding in pastoral country of the north east.” Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Occurs as a weed in neglected areas, roadsides, railway easements and pastures in southern Australia.” Weed replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Aerial growth dies in late autumn.” Little matter left to establish or support fire. Negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Occurs in open disturbed areas (roadsides, railway easements). Can become the dominant species. Major displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Plains sedgy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: � low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to invade any low value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 13. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Sand rocket invades poor pastures and becomes the dominant species.” Major impact on ground covers and grasses.

fauna_threatened.question: 16. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In some areas it is not eaten by stock except to some degree when in flower. The plant would establish successfully if fauna do not graze it. This would lead to a reduction in suitable fodder.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 17. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 18. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Claimed to be poisonous but details are lacking.” No evidence of toxicity.

pest_food.question: 19. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 21. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Sand rocket invade poor pastures and becomes the dominant species. It reduces the value of fallows by depleting moisture and nutrients.” Major reduction in fodder, and potential to limit agricultural yield.

ag_quality.question: 22. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: In some areas where stock does eat the plant it taints meat and dairy produce. “When occurring in cereal crops, sand rocket discolours and downgrades the harvested grain because it is green at the time of harvest.”

ag_land_value.question: 23. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: With the potential impact the weed can have on agricultural yields it may reduce land value somewhat.

ag_land_use.question: 24. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: In arable areas the plant can be easily controlled by deep ploughing and sowing a competitive pasture species. Not likely to affect land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 25. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “In some areas it competes with hay crops and makes cutting difficult.” Increase in time to harvest.

ag_disease.question: 26. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at any time of year”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occur in open areas e.g. pastures.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Favours clover and Lucerne pastures and fertile river flats more than areas of unimproved native vegetation”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Annual or biennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “The weed is rejected by stock because of the above spines”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
