inv_growth_rate.comments:
“It is a competitive weed of Australian pastures”.  “In New South Wales, Scotch Thistle occurs with the closely related Illyrian thistle and some infestations in the State are a mixture of the two species plus various intermediate taxa”. 
(P & C 1992 p. 218).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Assumed tolerant of frost (occurs in S. Tas.) and drought (occurs in C. Vic. & NSW).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
“Reproducing by need”.

“There can be some local spread of severed root pieces”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “A prolific seeder and a single plant may produce over 20,000 seeds”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Buries seed is long lived and germinates when brought near the surface hence, plants may appear on recently cultivates areas where there has been no seeding for several years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual or biennial herb.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual or biennial herb.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Equipment, wool, clothing, wind, animals (internal) and possibly birds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Seeds remain viable after passing through the digestive tracks of sheep”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Erect annual or biennial herb commonly 1 to 1.2 metres. Comprises one main stem with numerous branches and broad spiny wings. Leaves also spiny. Dense patches would impede individual access, and the spiny nature of the plant would be highly annoying.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Because of the spiny nature of the plant, dense patches occurring in recreational areas would restrict human activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Spines can be present for most of the year. “Dead plants remain standing for many months.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Roots comprise of a stout taproot; unlikely to affect structures. Dense patches would create a moderate negative visual effect particularly with dead plants remaining, seriously affecting the aesthetics of an area.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Seeds germinate at any time of year, hence infestations consist of plants of various ages and sizes.” Root system is a stout taproot. Not likely to affect soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It occurs as a competitive weed of Australian pastures.” Plant replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Dead plants remain standing for many months.” Dense infestations may create a minor change to the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Grows best on moderate to high fertility soils rather than unimproved native vegetation. Competes with pasture species. Likely to have a minor impact on grasses/forbs in natural ecosystems. Impact also limited by overstorey cover.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (E); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to occur in any low value EVC in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “…its relatively large leaves smother other plants. As it survives well into summer, there is little chance of the other species recovering.” However, it grows best on moderate to high fertility soils rather than unimproved native vegetation. Likely to have a minor effect on the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “The weed is rejected by stock because of the dense spines.” Competitive nature and physical properties would reduce food source for native animals.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits to fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “If it is eaten, the spines cause mechanical damage, particularly around the mouths and eyes of animals.” Spines present for much of the year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Birds are known to eat the seed. Potential food source to pest birds.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Newly sown pastures are often overrun by a high germination of thistle seeds and, later, its relatively large leaves smother other plants. As it survives well into summer, there is little chance of the other species recovering.” Serious impact on forage production leading to reduced carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “…contributes to vegetable fault in wool.” Major impact on quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No evidence of effect on land value. Reduction in forage production due to presence of the weed may reduce values slightly.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Goats are known to graze the flowering plants in summer and autumn. To control the plant while retaining some agricultural return, a change in land use may be dictated.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at any time of the year but mostly in autumn and winter”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Occurring as a weed in open pastures and lightly timbered areas”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Invades nature grasslands, grassy woodlands, drier forests and rocky shrublands”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial tussock-forming grass.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “The plant is eaten by sheep and cattle only if nothing else is available”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Most seedlings that establish in a dense strand of N. trichotoma or in a vigorous improved pasture are killed by competition in the first or second spring or summer”.  Seedlings not killed by competition will grow as fast as comparable grasses in the surrounds.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Tolerates, fire, drought and frost”.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproduction is by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Seed production is prolific and a hectare of dense tussock growth is estimated to produce more that 2 tonnes of seed per year”.  “Large vigorous plants can produce 100,000 seeds annually”.  (Muyt 2001 p. 75)

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Some seeds remain dormant in the soil for up to 15 years, possibly more”.  “Soil in a forest that had no fresh seed added for 13 years had a germination capacity of 8%”. (Campbell & Vere 1995 p. 194).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Tussocks persist for many years producing new flowering stems and some new leaves each year”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants rarely flower in the first year but continue vegetative growth until the second summer when flowers and seeds are usually produced”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: See ‘dispersal’ section.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “The seed head breaks off near the base of the plant and may be blown considerable distances, even up to several kilometres”.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in autumn”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes in open areas (i.e. pastures and crops).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Invades pastures and crops
 “Perennial pastures do not check its growth”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Perennial herb.
Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “It has been suggested that germination may be inhibited by the mucilaginous material surrounding the seed either because it forms a physical barrier to water imbibition or it contains a germination – inhibiting chemical”.  “Allelopathic effects have been demonstrated in cotton”. ( P & C 1992 p. 611).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Consumed by cattle, sheep and goats.

However, probably not preferred due to its highly toxic properties.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Competes directly with summer-growing crops and pastures and reduces production of winter crops such as cereals”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of drought.  (See distribution in P &C 1992 p. 609).

“Not confined to any particular soil type”.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed and from roots”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: About 75 seeds in each fruit x 30 fruits per plant.  (See picture on page 609), = 2,250 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seeds are … long lived”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Perennial herbs: aerial growth dies at end of summer, but new shoots are produced each spring.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Seeds germinate in autumn…flowering commences in November”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Numerous - See ‘dispersal’ (P & C 1992 p. 611).

Including birds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Birds could disperse seeds > 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect summer-growing perennial herb, commonly 30 to 45 cm high.” The low growth habit would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “The stems are usually armed with numerous slender prickles 2 to 4 mm long. Aerial growth dies at the end of summer but the dead stems usually remain standing for several months.” The prickly property of the plant may affect some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: See comment in 2 above. Prickles present for much of the year. Potential for minor injury.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches may create a negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Root system comprises deep, much branched, vertical and horizontal roots to 2 metres deep and wide. However, aerial growth dies at the end of summer leaving bare areas of soil. Potential for moderate probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “An erect summer-growing perennial herb, commonly 30 to 45 cm high. Silverleaf nightshade competes directly with summer-growing crops and pastures.” Replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “In Victoria…it usually occurs in discrete patches.” Although aerial growth dies at the end of summer and dead plants remain standing, the plant would not influence fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=North Cental; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
A weed of open pasture/cropping situations. Not known in natural ecosystems in Victoria. Minor displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=North Cental; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Grassy dry forest (LC); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Highlands – Northern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Primarily a weed of cropping, it also occurs in summer-growing pasture and, “ perennial pasture does not check its growth.” The extensive root system enables the plant to draw moisture and nutrients from a large volume of soil and thus compete effectively against other species. Although it infests broad areas, the infestations tend to be populated as discrete patches. Infestation aided by cultivation. Minor effect on 20–60% of the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Primarily a weed of agriculture. Limited threat due to fauna not co-existing within infested area.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Birds and animals eat the fruit.” Minor food source.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Feeding trials have confirmed that all parts of the plant, but particularly the fruit either green or ripe, is toxic to animals.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Birds and animals eat the fruit.” Possible limited food source for minor pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Silverleaf nightshade competes directly with summer-growing crops and pastures, and reduces production of winter crops such as cereals because of the depletion of nutrients and moisture from the soil in the previous summer. In Texas…it considerably reduces cotton and grain sorghum yields.” Major impact on yield

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “…the plant’s spiny leaves and coarse stems may lower the quality of hay taken from infested areas.” Contaminated hay may be rejected for sale outside infested area.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Silverleaf nightshade is one of the most difficult weeds to kill.” The value of land infested with this plant would be reduced due the weed’s persistence and its potential impact on agricultural production.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: In cropping situations, land use may not need to change depending upon the impact on production. In pasture situations, however, as “sheep are more resistant to the toxins and goats are unaffected,” choice of grazing animal may change.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate after autumn rains.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy cover (See details of experiment by McVean (1966) p.355).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in relatively healthy natural ecosystems e.g. mallee shrubland, Wyperfield N.P.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: An erect, much branched perennial herb.  Geophyte → aerial growth dies autumn, new rosettes autumn/winter.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Biocontrol agents.  “Once established, the plant will survive any amount of cutting.”  The stems prior to flowering are palatable to sheep & other domestic animals while goats & wild herbivores will consume the older, more fibrous stems also (McVean 1966).  Plants may be prevented from flowering where animal browsing is constant. (McVean 1966). – Should/assumed to be capable of flowering under mod herbivory.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Very competitive in cereal crops, but subterranean clover can be an effective competitor with established skeleton weed.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to drought, frost, waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from a long taproot & by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: A single plant can product >27,000 seeds in a season, although the average is much less

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds are relatively short-lived and probably do not survive > 6 months

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Long-lived perennial.  Forms ‘dense colonies’.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Germination in autumn (March-April-May), with the main flowering period beginning in mid to late December throughout Australia.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wind, wool, fabric, machinery, vehicles, railway trucks, contaminated hay & chaff, seed-harvesting ants.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Parachute like seeds easily spread by wind.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect, much branched perennial herb, commonly 60 to 90 cm high. The stem is much branched almost from the base and plants growing close together become entangled.” Such infestations may be a nuisance to people on foot.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: In dense clumps the plant would have a minor negative impact on the aesthetics of an area.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense growth may produce a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Chondrilla juncea is essentially a weed of cultivation and of open, waste areas with disturbed soils.” The deep root system is likely to provide some soil stability. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “In autumn, aerial growth dies.” Little or no change to fuel load. Not likely to affect the fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Occurs on temperate, sub-humid and semi-arid open scrublands. In Victoria, it occurs in small populations and is limited in distribution. Minor impact on ground-flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Hillcrest herb-rich woodland (D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Chondrilla juncea is essentially a weed of cultivation and of open, waste areas with disturbed soils.” Optimum growth in open plant communities with a minimum of shadowing and root competition. In Victoria, its distribution is limited to small populations in mallee shrubland and lowland grassland & and grassy woodland. Affecting the lower stratum only.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “It is palatable and nutritious in the rosette stage and during flowering until the stems become lignified. Flowering stems are largely unpalatable.” Minor effect on fauna spp. through reduced food source.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The rosettes are palatable and nutritious. “Seed harvesting ants are known to remove skeleton weed seeds, although they are also known to consume many seeds.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Competition for nitrogen and other nutrients by severe infestations is indicated by cereal yield losses as high as 50% in wet years and 80% in dry years.” Serious impacts on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “In most cases, cereal grain is harvested before skeleton weed produces seeds.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: With the serious impact on agricultural yield in cropping areas and the difficulty in controlling the weed, the value of infested land may be seriously affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “The very deep root system and vigour of the plant makes skeleton weed difficult to control by the use of competing species. However, lucerne and other legumes are effective competitors in some areas and if a good stand can be established and carefully managed, the density of skeleton weed is considerably reduced over a number of years.” Land would be unavailable for a number of years for cropping activities.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “Light infestations can cause appreciable wear and tear to harvest machinery as well as delays through breakdowns, whilst heavy infestations can prevent harvesting because the stems are so entangled that many moving parts of the machinery become jammed.” Potential to affect harvest costs seriously.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Most bulbs germinate after autumn rains.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy - occurs in olive, citrus and vineyards, as well as woodlands.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems,  (See Car et al 1992), as well as vigorously growing crops (e.g. cereal) and pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Erect perennial: geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Owing to a high oxalic acid content – the cause of the sour taste – soursob is not eaten readily by stock”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Its rapid growth rate is a key feature of the plant's competitiveness.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of frost, water logging (infests drainage ditches), drought (occurs in semi arid parts of Morocco).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from bulbs and bulbils.  Viable seed is produced on some plants in Western Australia.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
20 flowers per plant x 3/5 seeds per flower = 60/100 seeds per plant.  (estimate using illustrations).

Seeds not commonly produced in Victoria.  (DCFL 1987, Pierce).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms dense monocultures.  (See picture P & C (1992) p. 532).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants arising from bulbils produce bulbs in their first year but do not flower”.  So flower in second year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Bulbs/bulbils-machinery, water movement, birds eat bulbs.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Ejection of seeds up to 2 m from the parent plant.  “Because they are light.  Clark (1934) considers that wind plays a major role.  Bulbs float on water so this would be significant, particularly in Western Australia where Oxalis pes-caprae is associated with some major rivers and drainage systems”.  (Pierce 1997).  Above mechanisms could transport many seeds/bulbs > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect perennial herb, commonly 15 to 35 cm high.” Its presence would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations are obvious, particularly during the flowering stage when areas are covered by a dense carpet of yellow flowers. Recreational activities not affected, but aesthetic of site would be.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Although the plant is considered toxic to animals (it contains oxalic acid), “its flowering stems are occasionally chewed and sucked by children for the sour taste.” Toxicity is a problem of prolonged consumption. Consider mildly toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense infestations would create a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Because of its potential for dense growth, “death of top growth in late spring – early summer leaves large patches of bare soil prone to erosion..” High probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Infestations of 3000 plants per sq m not uncommon.” Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: When aerial growth dies, “it does not leave any hard trash.” Not likely to affect fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Soursob has a severe impact on indigenous ground-flora with dense infestations eradicating most smaller plants.” It grows in a broad range of vegetation. Major displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
“Soursob has a severe impact on indigenous ground-flora with dense infestations eradicating most smaller plants.”
“Initial growth low and spreading, quickly covers ground, preventing germination of other seedlings and smothering surrounding plants.” Major effect on ground flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
“Soursob has a severe impact on indigenous ground-flora with dense infestations eradicating most smaller plants.”
It occurs in medium to large populations in a number of different vegetative communities including; dry coastal vegetation, heathland & woody heathland, lowland grassland & grassy woodland; dry sclerophyll forest & woodland, riparian vegetation, and rock outcrop vegetation. Additionally, “it is not usually eaten by livestock because of its high oxalic acid content which makes the plant sour.” Such infestations would have a serious impact on the habitat of fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Prolonged consumption by livestock can cause chronic kidney damage and death.” Potential to affect fauna species, however, the plant is not usually eaten because of the high oxalic acid content.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Yield losses in wheat of up to 50% have been recorded in South Australia but soursob appears to be less competitive in Victoria. Although primarily a weed affecting cultivated areas, soursob is also important in pastures where it may replace almost all desirable plants from the time of the autumn rains to well into the spring.” Potentially serious reduction in carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect the quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Although a number of control methods are available, the serious impact on agricultural yield due to the presence of the plant may reduce land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Cultivation is a recommended method of control. In cropping situations, land use would not need to change.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “Oxalis pes-caprae is not known to host diseases that affect crops. However, Lovett Doust et al. (1985) reported that O. stricta L., O. corniculata L., O. dillenii ssp. dillenii Jacq. and O. dillenii Jacq. ssp. filipes (Small) Eiten host the maize rusts Puccinia sorghi Schw. and P. polysora Underw., sorghum rust P. purpurea Che. and Andropogon rust P. andropogonis Schw.” Potential host?

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds mainly germinate after autumn rains but a few shoot at other times when adequate moisture is available.  “Although seeds can germinate at any time of year, there are two main germination times in late summer to autumn and late winter to spring”. (Bruzzese 1996).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Mostly occurs in ‘open’ areas/habitats, such as pastures, fields, etc.  Also stated that ‘shade’ is known to inhibit C. Vulgare.  Occurs in forest woodland.  Carr et al (1992).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in minor disturbed ecosystems (e.g. wetlands, riparian areas), and highly disturbed areas (e.g. pastures, cultivated fields, waste places).  However, mostly occurs in highly disturbed areas.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect annual or biennial herb.

Geophyte – fleshy storage, roots that can produce new aerial growth.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not readily grazed by stock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Competes with cereal crops.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to water logging assumed as occurs in riverine habitats (e.g. dam margins, riverbanks, wetlands). Occurs in locations where frosts would occur – Tasmania, Alaska, Canada and others.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed: capable of both self-pollination and cross-pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Up to 200 flower heads and 8 000 seeds have been counted on individual plants.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: A Canadian study shows some seed remaining viable for about 36 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual or biennial.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: A flowering stem is produced in late spring of the 2nd year.  Biennials.  Annuals – first year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wind, water, vehicles, machinery, animals, mud, pasture seed, contaminated hay.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Most of the seeds land within a few metres of the parent plant and only about 10% are dispersed out of the local population”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect perennial herb, commonly 15 to 35 cm high.” Its presence would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations are obvious, particularly during the flowering stage when areas are covered by a dense carpet of yellow flowers. Recreational activities not affected, but aesthetic of site would be.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Although the plant is considered toxic to animals (it contains oxalic acid), “its flowering stems are occasionally chewed and sucked by children for the sour taste.” Toxicity is a problem of prolonged consumption. Consider mildly toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense infestations would create a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “During winter an extensive root system, consisting of several branched fleshy storage roots, develops. Rosettes grow rapidly through spring, reaching a diameter of about 60 cm. Normally, rosettes persist through summer and continue growth into the second autumn and winter.” Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “As a weed it occurs…particularly [in] annual pastures and neglected areas.” Dense infestations may increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Dead plants often remain standing for one or two years.” In dense infestations this dry matter may lead to an increase in the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Dry valley forest (V); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Falls; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Although it grows best on exposed sites, in Victoria, it is known to occur in a wide range of vegetation communities including woodlands and forests. It occurs in medium to large populations. The rosettes are large suppressing germination of other species. Carr et al (1992) consider C. vulgare to be a serious threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria. Minor  displacement of species in the lower stratum.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Uplands; H to VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Montane dry woodland (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; East Gippsland Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In Victoria, Cirsium vulgare invades a wide range of vegetation communities including woodlands and forests, and occurs in medium to large populations. Likely to have a major impact on 20 - 60% of the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: C. vulgare occurs in medium to large populations in a great number of vegetative communities. “Dense patches of spear thistle are common in much of southern Australia. The spiny nature of the plant deters animals from grazing” Infestations are  likely to have minor reduction on habitat for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits to fauna species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No evidence of injury to fauna, however, animals avoid the plant due to its spiny nature, and dead plants can remain standing for one to two years. Potential to harm fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not documented as a food source to pests. However, the “fleshy roots of spear thistle have been prized in the past as a bait for rabbit poisoning,” and rabbits are known to use the plants for harbor. Rabbits may eat the roots of growing plants. Wild pigs love em

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “A large spear thistle rosette covers about one-third of a square metre and, because it is not readily grazed by stock, the carrying capacity of paddocks with dense patches of thistle is reduced considerably.”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “…contaminated hay is downgraded in quality and price. The plant is an important component of vegetable fault of wool.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Spear thistle is so well established in much of southern Australia this it is accepted as a permanent part of the vegetation.” As such, its presence is unlikely to affect land values greatly.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “The level of spear thistle infestations varies from year to year which reflects the changing opportunities for seedling establishment provided by climate and grazing pressure in the autumn.” Grazing activities may change somewhat to ensure minimal infestations to limit impact on agricultural return.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Shearing costs may increase as, “spines in wool also cause difficulties in shearing.”

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “There is veterinary evidence that the spiny leaves and bracts are responsible for transmitting virus diseases, including myxomatosis and scabby mouth, between animals.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate mostly in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Only known to occur in ‘open’ habitats.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in highly disturbed areas e.g. roadsides & waste places.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Leguminous shrub.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Although animals graze young shoots, they find established plants unacceptable b/c of the spines.”

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants rarely flowering before they are 2-3 years old.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds ejected from pod, also equipment, machinery, produce, animals, mud, etc.  Also by clothes, water & in chaff, hay, grain & silage.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A much branched spiny shrub, commonly 1.5 to 2.5 metres high. Stems usually multi-branched from the base, armed with sharp rigid spines to 7.5 cm long. Spiny broom forms an effective hedge because of the dense growth of spiny branches. Dense patches limit access to watering points [for animals].” In dense patches, the plant would create a major impediment to human access, though not requiring significant works or closing tracks

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Although the plant can occur in dense patches, it does so in small populations. Some recreational activities may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The stems bear rigid spines to 7.5 cm long, which could be a hazard to humans and likely to cause injury.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A shrub with a stout taproot, sometime forked. Dense stands (as hedges) provide ground cover. Unlikely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In Victoria, it invades lowland grassland & grassy woodland and dry sclerophyll forest & woodland. Biomass may increase where dense patches occur.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Not documented. However, the related plant Cytisus scoparius is known to be highly flammable and burn with an intense heat. Calicotome spinosa may also display similar fire response. Moderate change to the frequency and intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Nitrogen fixing. Widespread, but in small populations. Minor displacement of ground covers/forbs/shrubs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Herb-rich heathy woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Like Cytisus scoparius, the dense growth possibly shades out other plants and, as brooms fix nitrogen in the soil, establishment of native species may be prevented. The plant only occurs in small populations. Minor effect on the lower and mid strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Dense patches reduce grazing and limit access to watering points.” As it occurs in small populations, it is likely to have a minor effect on the habitat of fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits to fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Young plants are claimed to be toxic but evidence of this is lacking.” Spines are present all year; may be dangerous to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Dense patches reduce grazing and limit access to watering points.” Minor impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping. Not known to affect the quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Small populations only. Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Small populations only. Change to land use not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at almost any time of year if soil moisture is adequate”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Occurs in mostly ‘open habitats’.  (See Habitats section).

“Grows best in the open rather than in the shade of other plants”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Is an envil weed in “lowland grassland and grassy woodland”.

Serious weed of crops and pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
A semi prostrate annual herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not readily eaten by stock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “It competes with cereal crops and pastures because it is fast growing”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of moisture stress.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed-male and female flowers separate on the same plant.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Up to 1 100 seeds have been recorded on individual plants”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Fruit is long-lived in soil (>4 years).  “On undisturbed areas, very little seed germinates after 2 years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms dense monocultures, sometimes > 900 plants per sq. m.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Germination mostly occurs in autumn/winter – flowering late winter/early summer – seed maturation spring and through summer.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Fruit (with spines) attach to shoes, rubber tyres, feet of animals or containers of produce.  Also contaminated fodder and water.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Above mechanisms could transport seeds > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A semi-prostrate annual herb.” The physical growth of the plant would not restrict human access. However, the spiny fruits, which are hard and woody and bear 3 rigid, sharp spines, may prevent access to some recreational areas. This would particularly apply to bare-footed humans. It may impede individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The spiny fruits may affect some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “The spines cause discomfort and inconvenience to humans, particularly when bare-footed. The fruit can cripple animals, particularly dogs. The fruit is long lived in soil (more than 4 years).”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: A low growing annual its presence would create a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “…it may, in association with other annuals, contribute to the stabilisation of sandy soils.” Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “A semi-prostrate annual,” growing on grazing and cropping lands, saleyards, vineyards and neglected areas. Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Most plants die in summer.” As a low-growing plant it would not contribute to a change in the fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. “Spiny emex is mainly a weed of cultivated areas and tends to decline in pastures.” It occurs in small populations and is limited in distribution. May displace ground cover species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Hillcrest herb-rich woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential. Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: E. australis does not appear to occur in any low value EVC in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Spiny emex is mainly a weed of cultivated areas and tends to decline in pastures.” In Victoria, it occurs in small patches of limited distribution in lowland grassland & grassy woodland. Minimal impact on structure.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Limited distribution in small patches in lowland grassland & grassy woodland. Minimal effect on fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Emex australis has become a major source of food for Major Mitchell cockatoos (Cacatua leadbeateri (Vigors)) and the inland red tailed black cockatoo (Calyptorhynchus magnificus).” Both these bird species occur in Victoria where current infestations of E. australis are known.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The fruit can cripple animals.” Potential to harm fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “Rodents are known to destroy many seeds each year.” Rodent spp. not documented; potential for pest rodents.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A semi-prostrate annual, it is not known to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Infestations of spiny emex can be very dense and counts of more than 900 plants per square metre have been made in Western Australia. South Australian studies show that an infestation of about 11 plants per square metre reduces wheat yields by almost 40%.” Major impact on quantity of produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Several surveys of the presence, abundance and importance of E. australis in crop, pasture and horticultural situations in South Australia show that it is a serious problem and that its presence in grain leads to rejected loads at silos, contaminated and rejected dried fruit, pulse grains, barley, peas, lupins and chickpeas.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: With the potential to affect agricultural production seriously, its presence would have a major impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Spraying infested cops with herbicides often doubles wheat yield in Western Australia. Trials in Western Australia have shown the benefit to be derived from controlling spiny emex in pastures.” The cost of control measures is covered by an improved economic return. Little or no change.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not documented to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “It is not known to be an alternative host to insect pests and disease organisms.”

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Some seeds germinate at any time of the year if moisture is available, however, most germ occurs after the autumn break.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Mostly occurs in ‘open, unshaded situations’.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: An environmental weed in grasslands, grassy woodlands, dry sclerophyll forest & woodlands.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: An erect annual or biennial herb → ‘Other’.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: May be consumed, but not preferred due to the presence of spines that injure grazing animals.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Competes with crops & pastures.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerance to drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Flower heads are numerous.  (Using pictures – NSW Dept Ag (1962) & P&C (1992) no. of propagules./plant was estimated.  50 flowering heads x 20 flowers/head x 1 seed/flower = 1,000 seeds/plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seed is relatively short-lived, surviving for only 2-3 years in soil.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Forms dense masses of growth.

Wide spread, medium to large population.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Mostly annual, sometimes biennial.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Spread to some extent by water along channels & by contaminating agricultural produce, equipment etc.  Also by wind.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Lacking long-distance dispersal mechanisms.  Most effective means probably ‘tumbleweed’ mechanism

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
“An erect bushy annual or biennial herb, commonly 40 to 80 cm high. Flower heads…surrounded by numerous bracts each ending in a rigid, sharp, white or yellowish spine 1.5. to 3 cm long and at the base of which are 2 to 6 shorter spines.”

It is found in medium to large populations in lowland grassland & grassy woodland and dry sclerophyll forest & woodland. The spiny nature of the plant may hinder individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The spiny nature of the plant may restrict some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “…once the heads are formed, their spines injure grazing animals.” Potential to injure humans. Spiny heads present for much of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Large populations may create a negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “…is most commonly confined to roadsides, channel banks and neglected areas.” Not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “…is most commonly confined to roadsides, channel banks and neglected areas.” Biomass may increase in those areas where it is commonly found.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Plants die in autumn. However, there is no information regarding what hard matter is left that may contribute to fire. Assume little change.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
In Victoria, it is present in medium to large populations. Potential to displace species in lower stratum.  Occurs in open, unshaded situations. Overstorey cover may restrict population density.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Box Ironbark forest (D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.  
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (LC); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; H CLIMATE potential.  
Impact similar to 10(a) above, however, CLIMATE distribution potential is HIGH only.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
“It is confined to roadsides, channel banks and neglected areas.” Occurs in open, unshaded situations. In Victoria,
it is present in medium to large populations. In natural ecosystems likely to have a minor effect on species in the
lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “…is most commonly confined to roadsides, channel banks and neglected areas.” Minimal impact on fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “…once the heads are formed, their spines injure grazing animals.” Potential to injure fauna species where they co-occur.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “The spines also make clumps of the plant an effective harbour for rabbits.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “It occurs but is not important …in the Victorian Wimmera and southern Mallee. Star thistle competes with crops and pastures.” Level of competition not documented; assume minimal"

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Seeds…are spread to some extent by contaminating agricultural produce.” Minor impact on quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “It occurs but is not important …in the Victorian Wimmera and southern Mallee.” Unlikely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “It occurs but is not important …in the Victorian Wimmera and southern Mallee.” Not a serious weed of agriculture. Change in land use not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate after autumn rains.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Only known to establish in ‘open’ habitats.  (See pic. P & C 1992 p. 220).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: An environmental weed (of ‘serious’ risk) in ‘Mallee shrubland’ and ‘lowland grassland and grassy woodland’.  Also established in crops and pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Prostrate annual or biennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Rarely eaten by stock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Reduces the carrying capacity of pastures so assumed to be at least = other herbaceous species.  Also described as a ‘rapid spreader which can quickly take over in pasture or crops and seriously reduce production’.  (Blood nd).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought (occurs in Africa, Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
8 flower heads per plant x 150 seeds per head =  1,200 seeds per plant.  
(Estimate based on pic. and descriptions),

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Reproductive period = 1 year for annual species or 1-2 years for biennial species.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual (sometimes biennial).  < 1 year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds – prevailing winds, contaminate agricultural produce, vehicles, animals, etc. and water.  Also, birds (not mentioned in published material), and in hay, silage, chaff and commercial seed (Anon.).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “The seeds are well adapted for wind disperse with a large feathery pappus”.  In Victoria the spread of the plant has clearly been with prevailing wind, therefore wind assumed capable of spreading seed > 200 m.  Other mechanisms could also disperse seed > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A prostrate annual herb.” Would not hinder human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “Leaves [are] very woolly, deeply lobed, many spines on margins. Each flower head is surrounded by numerous sharply spined bracts.” Spiny nature of plant may restrict some recreational activities where it occurs on channel banks.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The sharp spines may cause minor injuries to humans. Spines present for much of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches may create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “It commonly occurs in volunteer pastures, and on fallows, roadsides and channel banks.” Unlikely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It commonly occurs in volunteer pastures, and on fallows, roadsides and channel banks.” Biomass replaced by invader.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: A prostrate annual. Would not affect the fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential.
Large rosettes (up to 60 cm dia.). Can shade other species preventing germination. Major displacement of ground cover species and annual grasses. Currently occurs in medium to large populations.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Does not appear likely that O. acaulon would occur in any medium value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely that O. acaulon would occur in any low value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In Victoria, it occurs in medium to large populations. Major effect on ground covers/grasses.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: According to Carr et al (1992), the plant is widespread in Victoria occurring in medium to large populations in mallee shrubland and lowland grassland & grassy woodland. As stock do not graze the plant, its presence may reduce the amount of available fodder for fauna spp.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “When stock have been forced to eat the plant cases of impaction and suspected liver damage have occurred.” Potential risk to fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A prostrate annual, it would not provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Stemless thistle is rarely eaten by stock…and, therefore, the carrying capacity of heavily infested paddocks is reduced.” Level of impact not quantified, but as the weed is distributed widely in medium to large populations, assume at least a major impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect the quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Seeds survive in soil for several years making eradication difficult.” Land value may be slightly reduced in pastoral areas.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “It is not known how demanding stemless thistle is for soil nutrients and what effect heavy patches may have on subsequent crops. Lucerne competes well with stemless thistle and should be established wherever practical.” No data to conclude a change in land use is required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvesting costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect, much branched, strongly aromatic herb, commonly 30 to 60 cm high.” Does not present a physical barrier. However, because of the strong odour produced by the plant, it may be a minor nuisance to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “Because of the aromatic oil produced by glandular hairs on most parts of the plant, stinkwort is one of the strongest smelling of all weeds.” Because of the strong odour, some recreational activities may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “…some people are allergic to the oil and develop severe dermatitis.” Toxic properties are present for most of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: During summer, dense patches may create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “In summer, infested paddocks appear to be carrying a dense growth of lush green fodder.” This suggests that plant density is high. As it is a summer annual with a taproot and numerous laterals, it is unlikely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “In summer, infested paddocks appear to be carrying a dense growth of lush green fodder.” Biomass may increase slightly.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No data available on changes to fire risk; assume to be no change.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Prefers open, unshaded areas. Occurs in medium to large populations. Major displacement of annual grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Coastal dune scrub (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact similar to 10(a) above, however, population density limited due to overstorey cover.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In Victoria, it is widely distributed in medium to large populations in dry coastal vegetation, mallee shrubland, lowland grassland & grassy woodland, and dry sclerophyll forest & woodland. “In summer, infested paddocks appear to be carrying a dense growth of lush green fodder.” Potential to affect ground covers/grasses seriously.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In Victoria, it is widely distributed in medium to large populations in dry coastal vegetation, mallee shrubland, lowland grassland & grassy woodland, and dry sclerophyll forest & woodland. “…grazing animals find it disagreeable, eating the plant only when it is very young.” Likely to have a minor effect reducing fodder for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Sheep eat the flower heads at times and serious losses have been attributed to the plant.” It occurs in a broad range of vegetation communities in Victoria; potential to harm fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Sheep eat the flower heads at times and serious losses have been attributed to the plant.” Serious impact on quantity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “The oil also taints meat and milk of animals forced to graze the plant.” Minor impact.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “…it is no longer an important agricultural weed because of a general increase in soil fertility.” Unlikely to affect land prices.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “…it is no longer an important agricultural weed because of a general increase in soil fertility.” Change in land use is not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at almost any time of the year”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Would receive shading in forest communities and pine plantations. “Occurs primarily in lightly shaded and sunny positions”. “Invades lowland grassland and grassy woodland, dry and damp sclerophyll forest and woodland, riparian, rock outcrop, alpine and sub-alpine vegetation, pastures and pine plantations”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Invades lowland grassland and grassy woodland, dry and damp sclerophyll forest and woodland, riparian, rock outcrop, alpine and sub-alpine vegetation, pastures and pine plantations”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Sweet briar is not a hardy plant in its young stage and is kept well in control by grazing animal, particularly sheep and rabbits”. However, once mature “the prickly nature of sweet briar deters grazing animals from feeding close to the plant”. (P & C 1992 p. 574).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Seedlings lack early vigour and few survive in competition with other plants”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
“Tolerates frost, wide range of conditions except poorly drained soils”.

Tolerant of drought as occurs in arid areas of Australia. See map in P & C.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing from perennial roots and by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
“Seeds numerous”.

- Shrub producing many fruits – see picture in Blood (2001 p. 79).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seeds remain viable in the soil for 3 – 4 years”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Shrub assumed to produce propagules > 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants do not flower until they are about 3 years old”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “The fruit is brightly coloured and appears to be an attractive food to fruit – eating birds and other animals which then excrete the seed in a viable conditions”.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: This accounts for the rapid spread in much of the native bushland of south-eastern New South Wales and eastern Victoria”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “Deciduous multi-stemmed shrub to heights and widths of 3 m. Plants commonly form thickets that prevent movement through areas.” It occurs in a broad range of native vegetation including riparian situations. Major impediment to human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “Deciduous multi-stemmed shrub to heights and widths of 3 m. Plants commonly form thickets that prevent movement through areas.” Thickets seriously reduce aesthetics and some recreational uses may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Older stems are rough and woody and bear numerous backward curving prickles of varying length to 1.5 cm. Prickles present all year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: A deciduous shrub, its presence would be obvious and create a moderate negative visual impact. Although the root system is stout and extensive, there is no evidence to suggest it would cause structural damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. “It seldom establishes on poorly drained sites.”

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A large deciduous shrub with a stout, extensive root system. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It invades lowland grassland and grassy woodland, dry and damp sclerophyll forest and woodland, riparian, rock outcrop and alpine and sub-alpine vegetation, pastures and pine plantations.” It is widely distributed in Victoria in medium to large populations. Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Impact on fire regime is not documented; assume little change.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Dry valley forest (V); CMA=West Gipplsand; Bioreg=Highlands Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Plants commonly…crowd out competing shrubs and prevent most overstorey regeneration.” Major displacement of species in the mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Montane grassy woodland (D); CMA=North East; Bioreg=Highlands – Northern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Montane dry woodland (D); CMA=North East; Bioreg= Highlands – Northern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Plants commonly form thickets that…crowd out competing shrubs and prevent most overstorey regeneration.” In dense patches would have a major effect on the lower and mid-storey species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In Victoria, it is widely distributed in medium to large populations. “It invades lowland grassland and grassy woodland, dry and damp sclerophyll forest and woodland, riparian, rock outcrop and alpine and sub-alpine vegetation, pastures and pine plantations.” Likely to reduce habitat for fauna leading to a reduction in numbers.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits to fauna species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Although the plant is prickly, it is not documented to cause injury to animals.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Rabbits are known to graze the plant in its young stage.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “…provides harbour for rabbits and foxes.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “The species has no fodder value and once clumps of the weed become numerous there is a considerable loss of pasture production because of competition with, and reduced space for, productive species.” Serious impact on pastoral activities.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect the quality of agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “In some cases [in New Zealand] farms have been abandoned.” Serious infestations likely to lead to significantly devalued land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “In some cases [in New Zealand] farms have been abandoned.” Change in land use would occur in some situations.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in autumn and root growth during winter is rapid” It occurs in areas with winter dominant rainfall. Requires natural seasonal disturbance (rainfall) to germinate & grow.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Requires winter rainfall to stimulate growth in established plants. It occurs on open woodlands, so may tolerate some degree of shading.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
“In Australia, it has very limited occurrence as a weed of open woodlands encroaching onto grazing land.”

Establishes in relatively intact habitats (i.e. open woodland).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial herb. Reproduces from rhizomes. Geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: As with H. perforatum, grazing animals may consume tangled hypericum. Although flowering stems may be consumed, the plant is a perennial with rhizomes, which would ensure survival of the plant. Weed may persist.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: A winter growing species with deep vertical roots and horizontal rhizomes, it grows rapidly. “Where established in Victoria, it has eliminated most other vegetation.” Exceeds growth of other species of similar life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
