No information is recorded for this species, however, as it is a deep-rooted perennial and occurs in subhumid, semi-arid warm-temperate to subtropical regions, it may tolerate drought. Additionally, the deep root system may ensure the plant can survive fire.

It is known to occur near Dunolly in Victoria, which is subject to low winter temperatures and possibly frost.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces vegetatively and sexually.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Not documented. The related H. perforatum produces up to 33,000 seeds p.a. Likewise, H. triquetrifolium may produce a large number of seeds (i.e. > 2000) annually.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Not recorded

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Not documented. Other Hypericum species live for several years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Seeds germinate in autumn… stems develop in spring and the first flowers are produced by early summer.” Reproduces in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds are not equipped in any special way to aid dispersal. Spread can due to seeds or vegetative material occurring in contaminated agricultural produce, vehicles, farm machinery, water, mud and fodder.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Most seeds fall at the base of the parent plant. Some seed may disperse up to one kilometre, though most will be about 20 to 200 metres.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect perennial herb with tangled branches, to 45 cm high.” In dense patches, it may me somewhat of a nuisance due to the tangled branches.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Infestation densities not documented. “It is very competitive.” Dense patches my have a minor effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Not known to be injurious to humans. However, as with H. perforatum, the plant may cause a contact rash in some people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense infestations may create a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
A perennial plant with deep vertical roots and horizontal rhizomes, it would improve soil stability. 

“It is very competitive and, where established in Victoria, it has eliminated most other vegetation.” Aerial growth dies off in summer no doubt leaving bare ground. Surface soil potentially affected by erosion where large patches occur.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “In Australia, it has very limited occurrence as a weed of open woodlands encroaching onto grazing land.” As it is very competitive, biomass may reduce slightly.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No data available; assume little change to fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
“It is very competitive and, where established in Victoria, it has eliminated most other vegetation.” Small (2 ha), isolated infestation in Victoria. Contained and possibly kept in check by control efforts. Potential to affect all strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian forest (E); CMA=North East; Bioreg=Highlands – Northern Fall; VH/H CLIMATE potential.
Similar impact to 10(a) above. However, high CLIMATE potential only may restrict infestation.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “It is very competitive and, where established in Victoria, it has eliminated most other vegetation.” Invades similar habitats to H. perforatum. Potential to have a major effect on <60% of the floral strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Considering its competitive nature, dense patches may reduce available fodder for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Like H. perforatum, the plant contains hypericin, which causes photosensitivity in grazing animals.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbour.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “It is very competitive and, where established in Victoria, it has eliminated most other vegetation.” Potentially similar impact to H. perforatum by replacing useful vegetation. Additionally, as the plant contains hypericin, some stock losses may be indicated.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect the quality of agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Currently small (2 ha), isolated patch in Victoria. However, it is poisonous to stock and is very competitive. If it were to establish, land values may be affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No documented evidence to suggest land use would change.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “…in eastern Europe and the Mediterranean region [it] is considered a weed in orchards, vineyards and field crops.” The tangled branches of the plant may affect harvesting some crops. Potential increase in time taken to harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate at most times of the year.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Mostly occurs in ‘open’ situations, such as pastures, roadsides, and open vegetation formations (grasslands and grassy woodlands).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed ecosystems e.g. grasslands and grassy woodlands, as well as highly disturbed habitats.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not eaten by stock.  Not known to be under a biocontrol program in Australia or New Zealand.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Forms dense patches, which eliminate most other vegetation.

Crowds out all other vegetation in pastoral areas and improved land.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of drought and as occurs in creeks also assumed tolerant of water logging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed roots and crowns.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
(Estimate using pic. P & C).

 50 inflorescence x 60 flowers per inflorescence x 1 seed per flower = 3,000.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
Seed is long lived in the soil.

However, period unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms dense patches – monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants are at least two years old before flowering.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seed – water, wind and birds.

Roots and crowns – cultivation equipment and road graders.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Many propagules likely to spread through dispersal by birds, water, cultivation equipment, etc.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect shrub, commonly about 60 cm high.” Minimal impact on human access

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: During flowering, the presence of the plant is obvious. Dense patches may have a minor impact on recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No spines, burrs or toxic properties.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense infestations may create a negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “It was advocated for sand-binding in the early days.” Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “In Australia, it occurs as a weed of neglected areas and poor pastures.” A shrub, biomass would increase in such situations.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No data available. Assume negligible effect on risk of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy Woodland (E); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“…occurs in disturbed grassy woodlands…dense stands eliminate all other ground flora and smaller shrubs while severely impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major displacement of species in the lower strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Box Ironbark forest (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (LC); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
“It grows most prolifically in open, sunny position.” Similar impact as in 10(a), though overstorey cover may limit population density.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “As a weed it forms dense patches which eliminate most other vegetation.” Infestations would have a major impact on grasses and forbs.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
In Victoria, it occurs on mallee scrubland and lowland grassland & grassy woodland in medium to large populations.
“As a weed it forms dense patches which eliminate most other vegetation and, because it is not eaten by stock, the loss of production can be considerable.” Reduces availability of fodder.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not injurious to fauna

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Birds are known to disperse seeds. Possibly, pest species are implicated.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “Dense patches also provide harbour for rabbits.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “As a weed it forms dense patches which eliminate most other vegetation and, because it is not eaten by stock, the loss of production can be considerable.” Serious impacts on quantity of agricultural produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known as a weed of cropping, or as contaminant in agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “As a weed it forms dense patches which eliminate most other vegetation and, because it is not eaten by stock, the loss of production can be considerable.” Land value may be somewhat affected.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: In grazing situations, it occurs mostly on poorer pastures. Land use unlikely to change.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Seeds germinate in spring.

Roots sucker freely.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: As a weed in dry sclerophyll forest and woodland, gullies and riparian areas, it is assumed to establish under moderate canopy and litter in these environments.  “It survives without sun, water and seemingly earth”.  (Shah 1997).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems – riparian vegetation, dry sclerophyll forest and woodland.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect deciduous shrub.

Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “Leaf extracts contain Allelopathic substances which adversely affect the growth of other plants”.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Stock feed on lower leaves, so still capable of flowering under moderate herbivory.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: As aggressive intruder that tends to displace indigenous flora.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of drought and saline soils.

Occurs in areas prone to frosts (e.g. Austria, China, Ontario etc).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing from creeping roots and by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Well over 2000 seeds on large tress.

(see picture P & C 1992 p. 591).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Can produce virtually pure stands remaining for long periods of time.

Form thickets.  Tress also known to survive > 35 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Flowering does not occur until plants are > two years old.

“It flowers during its second year of growth” . (APB 1992).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wind, water,  birds, farm produce, machinery etc.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Cultivation equipment, birds, and other mechanisms capable of dispersing propagules between 200-1,000 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A medium to large tree to 25 m tall. Freely suckers from roots forming thickets.” Occurs in a broad range of vegetative communities including riparian areas, artificial waterways and urban areas. Access to recreational areas may be severely restricted where thickets establish.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Some water-based recreational activities may be affected where plant has formed thickets in riparian areas.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Direct contact with the bark and leaves can cause dermatitis in humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
“[It] is blamed for blocking sewers and disturbing foundations of buildings.”
“In Greece and Italy it threatens ancient walls and other significant ruins.” Potential to lead to major structural damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Root system comprises a deep taproot as well as many shallow laterals. Not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: As a medium to large tree, biomass would increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: It occurs in medium to large populations, and in dense patches it may increase the frequency and intensity of fire risk. Doesn’t burn readily – fire suppression in dry schlerophyll forest

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Lowland forest (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Tree to 20 m. “Important competitor for both nutrients and light, the latter being the more severe because of the very large leaves and density of foliage.” It often occurs in monospecific stands. Displaces most species in lower or mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Valley grassy forest (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Lowlands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian forest (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Leaf extracts contain allelopathic substances which adversely affect the growth of other plants, which might help explain the occurrence of the plant often in monospecific stands.” Major effect on all layers.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Its potential to establish a monoculture within an infestation would have a serious impact on fauna species. However, its distribution in Victoria is rare or localised thus limiting the impact. Reduction in local habitat.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Stock feed on the lower leaves, and sheep poisoning in New South Wales is suspected, but not confirmed.” Potential to be harmful to fauna species. Unknown for fauna spp to feed on plant

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Primarily a weed of urban areas. It is known to occur on undisturbed grazing land, but its impact on agricultural output is not documented.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: See repines in Q19 above

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: See repines in Q19 above

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See repines in Q19 above

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: See response in Q19 above

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at any time of the year if moisture is available”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Habitats appear to be ‘open’.  (See picture P & C 1992 p.251).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “It grows mainly in disturbed situations or degraded pasture”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect , much branched shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “The objectionable odour deters grazing animals and the plant is rarely eaten”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “A rapid spreader which can quickly take over on arable land and seriously reduce production”. (Anon.)

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of water logging (occurs in permanent and seasonal streams).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed and from the crown.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Fruit contains up to 8 seeds.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Form “very dense clumps”.  (See P & C 1992 p. 521).

Monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Flowers are not produced until plants are at least 2 years old”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wind, water, contaminated agricultural produce, vehicles , > 200 m etc.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Wind and water play important roles in dispersal because the bladder – like capsule containing seeds is light enough to be blown long distances and to float on water”.  (P & C 1992).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect, much branched shrub, commonly 1.2 to 2 m high. Very dense clumps which restrict animal movement develop.” People would access areas with difficulty.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Limited distribution in Victoria. Population sizes not documented, but the plant is known to grow in watercourses. As the plant has the ability to form very dense clumps, at least some water-based recreational activities may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “…all parts of the plant are toxic.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species, however, the plant is known to grow in watercourses and, “…can divert streams.” Possible major impact on waterflow in streams.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Not known to affect water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The root system is woody, rather shallow but extensive. Can form dense clumps; not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Plants are evergreen and can grow to a maximum height of 2.5 metres. Biomass likely to increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Not data available on flammability. As an evergreen shrub it may not support fire very well. Not likely to change the risk of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Swamp scrub (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Forms dense stands. Grows in full sun or part shade. Dense stands can eliminate all other species. Monoculture.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not occur in any low value EVCs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Infestations of tufted honey flower may become so dense that they eliminate all other species.” Usually confined to open areas. Affects ground flora, possibly some shrubs.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Although all parts are toxic, the objectionable odour deters grazing animals and the plant is rarely eaten. Very dense clumps which restrict animal movement and reduce pasture production, develop.” Reduces available fodder for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “All parts of the plant are toxic. Drenching trials show that death occurs within about 4 hours of ingestion.” However, the plant is rarely eaten due to the objectionable odour it produces.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: “Very dense clumps…provide harbour for pest animals.”

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Although all parts are toxic, the objectionable odour deters grazing animals and the plant is rarely eaten. Very dense clumps which restrict animal movement and reduce pasture production, develop.” Reduced pasture and possible animal losses; potentially major impact on quantity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect cropping or to contaminate agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: It only occurs in a few areas of southern Australia. Minimal effect on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Although all parts are toxic, the objectionable odour deters grazing animals and the plant is rarely eaten.” And, it only occurs in a few areas of southern Australia. Change in land use not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping. Does not affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can tolerate shade (moderate canopy) cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Establishes in virtually indisturbed bushland”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect shrub.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Unpalatable and rarely eaten”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Whole hillsides may be covered to the exclusion of most other vegetation.

Competes strongly with native species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of frost, (occurs in Mansfield, Blue Mountains- Australia: Britain, etc), water logging? (occurs in riparian vegetation).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Produce “large numbers “ of seeds. > 20 fruits per plant x 100 seeds - > 2,000 seeds per plant.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Forms dense monocultures (see P & C 1992 p. 386).

“Widespread, medium to large populations”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants do not flower until they are 18 months or two years old”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Small seeds readily contaminate agricultural produce, vehicles, machinery, animals, water and mud.  Also bird dispersed.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Bird dispersed.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
“An erect shrub, commonly about 1 m high.” Occurs, “…on damp, shaded sites and forest edges.”

“Infestations spread rapidly and often form dense closed stands.” Herbaceous species; may be a nuisance to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments:
“An erect shrub, commonly about 1 m high.” Occurs, “…on damp, shaded sites and forest edges.”

“Infestations spread rapidly and often form dense closed stands.” Some recreational activities may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Not considered injurious to humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense stands would create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A shrub with numerous shallow roots to 30 cm deep, a few deeper. Not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Tutsan is a serious weed in moist forests, woodlands and riparian areas. Infestations…often form dense closed stands that smother ground-flora and smaller shrubs.” Biomass may increase slightly.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Effect on fire regime not documented, however, as a semi-deciduous plant, it may have little impact on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC=Cool temperate rainforest (V); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. Establishes in disturbed and undisturbed bushland. Tolerates deep shade and can establish in open, sunny locations. Smothers ground flora and smaller shrubs. Major displacement of species in lower strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Warm temperate rainforest (R); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Uplands; H to VH CLIMATE potential. Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Wet forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “There is an area near Mansfield, in Victoria, where it extends as the dominant species from a roadside for several hundred metres into native bushland greatly reducing the density of native species.” Serious impact on lower strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: In Victoria, it is widely distributed in damp and wet sclerophyll forest, riparian vegetation, warm and temperate rainforest. As the plant is unpalatable and rarely eaten and it forms dense close stands, it may have a some impact on reducing fodder.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “It is suspected of poisoning cattle in New Zealand, and of causing skin ailments in sheep and cattle although this is not well documented.” However, the plant is unpalatable and rarely eaten.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “…tutsan encroaches onto semi-improved areas or pastures which have been severely overgrazed when, in Victoria, whole hillsides may be covered to the exclusion of most other vegetation.” These infestations greatly reduce the pasture available to stock.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known as a weed of cropping or to contaminate agricultural produce greatly.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not considered a significant weed of agriculture. Little effect on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not considered a significant weed of agriculture. Where it occurs on steep hillsides or in the presence of other vegetation in pasture situations, herbicides provide some degree of control. Change in land use not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known as a weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds mainly germinate after autumn rains.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Seedlings are quite shade tolerant”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Establishes as an environmental weed in minor disturbed ecosystems.
E.g. dry sclerophyll forest and woodland and riparian vegetation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect annual or biennial herb.
Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not readily eaten by stock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Very competitive in pasture and when well established, eliminates most other plants”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of drought (occurs in arid areas), water logging (occurs in irrigation banks), frost (occurs in very cool
areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: 50-200 seeds per head =125  30 flower heads per plant x 125 seeds per head = 3,750 seeds per plant.   Champion (1995) states plants produce 6,350 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Some seeds may remain viable in the soil for at least 9 years “.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Annual or short lived perennial herb (NZ).  Can form dense infestations.  (See picture P & C 1992 p. 231).
Annual or biennial (Australia).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual/biennial  < 1 year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seed, wind, contaminant of hay, water, mud agricultural produce, vehicles, machinery, grain, etc.  Birds also stated by Anon., but not other references.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Because the seeds are heavy (20 mg), and plumes drop when mature, most seeds fall near the parent plant”.  (Roche 1991).  However, other mechanisms could transport many seeds further.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: For propagation of cotoneaster species, seed is recommended to be sown in autumn, or stratified over winter and then sown under glass in spring (Griffths 1992). Therefore there is a seasonal component to the germination of cotoneaster species.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: The species is reported to invade shaded habitats such as damp sclerophyll forest (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992). The species is therefore considered to be able to establish under at least moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: The species is reported to invade relatively intact habitats such as damp sclerophyll forest and riparian vegetation (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; large shrub (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: There are no reports of allelopathy for this species, however C. salicifolius has been reported to have allelopathic potential (Morita, Ito & Harada 2005).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Unknown.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Not specifically known, however Cotoneaster species in general are known to be fast growing (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Hardy to Zone 7a, tolerant of temperatures to –17�C (Dave’s Garden 2007).
Reported to thrive in drought soils (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is considered tolerant of drought.
Unknown tolerance to waterlogging, salinity and fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproduces by producing seed which can occur through apomixes or pollination and may be able to hybridise with other cotoneaster species (Randall & Marinelli 1996).
Cotoneaster species are capable of layering, where branches that are in constant contact with the ground can set root (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Each fruit contains two seeds (Weber 2003).
The potential fruit yield for this species is not specifically known, however cotoneaster species generally have abundant fruit crops (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000; Muyt 2001). The species is therefore considered to have the potential to produce more than 2000 seeds annually.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Cotoneaster species are reported to live for over 20 years (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Bird dispersed (Blood 2001).
Blackbirds have been reported to be a major dispersal agent in central Victoria (Rozefelds et al 1999).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: The species is bird dispersed, however as the species is reported by Rozefelds et al (1999) to largely be dispersed by blackbirds, which have a territory size less than 1 ha they are not likely to disperse the seeds far (Bowman 2003). Cotoneaster species are however reported by (Loyn & French 1991) to be dispersed by Grey Currawongs, which can potentially disperse seeds many kilometres (Spennemann & Allen 2000).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: As large shrub species that can grow to 3 m, and is reported to branch profusely at ground level, this species could pose an imposition (Blood 2001; Weber 2003). As the species is not described to form thickets however it is thought to only have high nuisance value.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Ornamental species may alter the aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The berries are toxic but not fatal (Shepard 2004).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
Ornamental species may alter the aesthetics.
Has aggressive root system, may therefore cause structural damage (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species can occur in riparian vegetation, there is no evidence however of it occurring in flowing water and obstructing flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species can occur in riparian vegetation, there is no evidence however of it occurring in water and affecting water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Reported to have an aggressive root system (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Therefore the species is considered to be able to reduce the potential of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The species is reported to displace other vegetation by shading out, however it is also reported to branch profusely near the ground (Weber 2003). Therefore presumably any net loss of vegetation biomass from the lower strata the species would compensate for.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Grassy Woodland (E); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
A large shrub species it is reported to eventually be able to displace the native vegetation from large areas (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is considered capable of cause displacement of some dominant species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Herb-rich Foothill Forest (D); CMA Corangamite; Bioreg Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
A large shrub species it is reported to eventually be able to displace the native vegetation from large areas (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is considered capable of cause displacement of some dominant species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (LC); CMA Corangamite; Bioreg Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
A large shrub species it is reported to eventually be able to displace the native vegetation from large areas (Weber 2003). Therefore the species is considered capable of cause displacement of some dominant species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: A large shrub species it is reported to eventually be able to displace the native vegetation from large areas (Weber 2003). As a shrub species it would have the most impact on the middle and lower strata, therefore the species is considered capable of impacting on greater than 60% of the flora strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
Displacement of the native vegetation and alteration of the vegetation structure could impact upon habitat suitability and food availability. Like other berry producing shrubs such as privets the fruit this species could support larger populations of aggressive bird species which could then have flow on impacts on other species (Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999).

The exact extent this species can impact on fauna populations is unknown.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: May provide some assistance; food the berries could be eaten by native bird species and shelter as it is a large shrub

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this reported.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Blackbirds eat the fruit (Rozefelds et al 1999).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Only reported as an environmental weed.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Only reported as an environmental weed.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Only reported as an environmental weed.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Only reported as an environmental weed.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Only reported as an environmental weed.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: May be a host of fireblight (Spencer 2002).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Plants in all stages of growth are found at virtually any time of the year”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Occurs in ‘dry sclerophyll forest and woodland’, where it would receive some shading.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems (e.g. grassland, grassy woodland, forest/woodland, as well as pastures and crops.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
An erect, biennial sometimes perennial herb.
Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Consumed, but not preferred – cattle and horses tend to avoid the plant.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “High early growth rate allows (Paterson’ s Curse) to out compete other seedlings”.  However, growth E. Vulgare assumed not to be > E. plantagineum.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of moisture stress, frost (occurs in Northern Norway, Sweden, Finland).  Water Logging (occurs in riverbeds). Tanacs & Gulyas (1986) – Web et al (1988)

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed (self and cross pollination)

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Prolific seeder > 30,000 seeds per sq. m. have been measured.  Produces 500 to 2000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: A small number of seeds remain dormant in the soil for at least 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: E. plantagineum produces dense monocultures, however unsure if E. vulgare does.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Most seeds germinate in autumn and winter – flowering commences in early spring.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wool and fur of animals, animals (internal), run-off water, contaminant of hay and grain.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
See Piggin (1982) p 10 & 11.

Dispersal mechanisms described could transport many seeds > 200 metres.  * See Klemow & Raynal (1985)

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect biennial, sometimes perennial, commonly 30 to 60 cm high.” It occurs in mallee shrubland and lowland grasslands & grassy woodland. The plant can cause skin irritation and may be a minor annoyance to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The presence of this weed is obvious to the average visitor particularly during flowering.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Similar properties to E. plantagineum. “Some medical practitioners have established a link between the plant and hay fever.” “…the rough hairy texture of the leaves and stems causes skin irritation.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense infestations of the plant would create a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial spp.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Similar properties to E. plantagineum. “…in heavily grazed pasture, [it leaves] bare ground when it dies back in summer.” Potential for erosion from both wind and water.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invasiveness similar to E. plantagineum. Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “…it flowers several weeks later than E. plantagineum and flowering extends over a longer period.” But similar to E. plantagineum, it leaves little residue after it dries off. No change to fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Similar properties to E. plantagineum. Early growth rate out competes other seedlings; rosette leaves shade and smother most other species. Major displacement of ground covers/grasses.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Northern Inland Slopes; VH CLIMATE potential. Similar impact as in 10(a) above. Forest canopy cover may limit population density. Major displacement of ground covers/grasses.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Lowland forest (LC); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. Similar impact as in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Properties of Viper’s bugloss are similar to Paterson’s curse and, “Paterson’s curse can form very extensive, persistent populations in disturbed areas, competing vigorously with smaller indigenous plants and impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major impact on lower strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “[E. vulgare] appears less palatable to stock [than E. plantagineum].” Changes to structure may have minor effect on non-threatened fauna by limiting food source.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No documented benefits assume provides no benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Similar properties to E. plantagineum. “…presence of pyrrolizidine alkaloids contained in the plant cause cumulative chronic liver damage.” “Stiff bristles on all parts of mature plants irritate the udders of cows.” Potentially toxic; may cause allergies in fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A biennial. Unlikely to provide permanent harbor for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Similar properties to E. plantagineum. “…most graziers argue that the weed’s presence reduces both quantity and quality of useful fodder in pastures.” However, “…it is less competitive [than E. plantagineum].”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “…most graziers argue that the weed’s presence reduces [the] quality of useful fodder in pastures grazed by sheep.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Similar properties to E. plantagineum. The cost of control and eradication would add to farm operating costs over several years. Land value may decrease somewhat.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Similar properties to E. plantagineum. “Sheep find Paterson’s curse more palatable than do cattle and horses.” However, “…[E. vulgare] is less competitive [than E. plantagineum].” This may dictate a change in stock until the plant is controlled.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect crops or harvesting.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Late summer to mid winter depending on rainfall.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Cold hardy: tolerant of arid soils.  Found in partly drained heavy soils of pasture and stream banks.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Tolerant of wet soils.  Pest of cereals.  Waste spaces and roadsides.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect perennial herb.  Liliaceace.

Geophyte, aerial growth dies in summer.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Heavy grazing prevents the formation of bulbils.

Reduced the number and size of bulbs produced.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Not generally considered to be a strongly competitive plant.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Temperate to frost and salinity, drought: (pods die off in sun), water logging: (occurs in stream banks).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Seeds, bulbs and bulbis.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: 50-100 per metre square.  Bulb and # 15,600 – 13,500 per metre square.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Bulbs maybe dormant for up to 6 years.  All others either grow or die.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Perennial.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Even bulbis and seeds produce bulbs in first year but flower in second.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds, bulbs and bulbis spread by movement of agricultural produce, vehicles, animals, mud and water.  Animals can spread seed in faeces – water can carry seeds and bulbs.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect strong-smelling perennial herb, commonly 30 to 60 cm high.” Would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The strong garlic odour produced by the plant may discourage people from some recreational activities. Minor impact.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No toxic or physically harmful properties

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Infestations may create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A shallow (to 60 cm deep), fibrous root system. It commonly occurs in cereal crops and pastures. Competitive properties in pasture not documented. Not likely to increase soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Commonly occurs in cereal crops and pastures. Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: When aerial parts die in summer little material remains to establish or support fire. Assume no change to fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Creekline grassy woodland (E); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
“Crow garlic is cold hardy, tolerant of wet soils and often occurs on poorly drained, heavy soils of pastures and streambanks.” Not known as a weed of natural ecosystems (Carr et al 1992). Competitiveness not documented.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Damp forest (LC); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Prefers open situations. Population density limited.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Data on population density or competitive nature of plant not available. Not known as a weed of natural ecosystems (Carr et al 1992).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Data on population density or competitive nature of plant not available. Grazing stock are known to eat the plant. Assume minor impact on food source for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “There is little evidence that crow garlic is toxic to animals, although milk production is lowered on infested pastures and suspected cattle poisonings are reported occasionally in the British Isles.” Possible minor effect on fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not known to affect yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Crow garlic…impart[s] a strong garlic odour and flavour to agricultural produce, particularly cereal grain, grain products, milk and meat.” Contaminated grain is rejected at grain silos, but may be sold as stockfeed at a reduced rate. Significant impact on quality of produce due to contamination.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Control of the plant is difficult. Considering the impact on agricultural quality, the value of infested land may be reduced slightly.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Cultivation from late autumn to spring kills many plants but must be repeated for several years to ensure that all dormant bulbs have germinated and the resultant plants destroyed. Such a programmed is seldom practical because it requires the area to be virtually out of production for several years.” Potential threat to agricultural return for a time.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes in ‘open’ habitats (e.g. roadsides, fields and gardens).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in vigorously growing crops (e.g. carrots) and pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect annual or biennial herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Is grazed but assumed to recover quickly as “slashing or mowing…removes the top growth but stimulates new flowering stems from basal buds”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Once established (it) competes with pastures and crops but is rarely considered an important weed”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Assumed tolerant of frost (occurs in southern Tasmania and Great Britain and Ireland), drought (occurs in arid areas of Australia and New South Wales and Western Australia).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
15 spike like clusters per plant x 70 flowers per cluster x 2 seeds per flower = 2,000 seeds per plant.   
(Estimate using illustrations).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seeds of Resed aceae do not remain viable for more than 3-4 years and there is no evidence for seed longevity > 4 years in this family”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual/biennial  one year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual/biennial  one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds contaminate agricultural produce, vehicles, machinery, animals, fodder, mud, etc, but, most spread in water and road making materials.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Seeds small (1 mm diameter) therefore could be transported > 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “An erect annual or biennial herb, commonly 1 to 1.7 m high. A weed of neglected areas. It occurs in all Australian states, but is generally confined to scattered plants and small patches.” May be a minor nuisance to humans.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: A weed of neglected areas. It occurs in all Australian states, but is generally confined to scattered plants and small patches.” Minor effects to aesthetics or recreational use.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Not injurious to humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Infestations may create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: An annual or biennial that commonly occurs in neglected areas. Soil erosion not likely to increase as a result of infestation.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: An annual or biennial that commonly occurs in neglected areas; dense infestations are rare in Australia. Little or no change to fire regime.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Prefers exposed, moderately dry sites. “…confined to scattered plants and small patches.” Minor impact due to scattered infestations.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In Australia, it is generally confined to scattered plants and small patches. “Once established, wild mignonette competes with pastures and crops but is rarely considered an important weed.” Occurs in neglected areas. Consider minor effect on structure.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: No data available. Competition with other species may reduce the amount of available fodder. However, “…it is viewed as reasonable sheep feed in poorer pastures.” Minimal impact.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No significant benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “…wild mignonette is suspected, but not confirmed, of poisoning stock.” Potential harm to fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Once established, wild mignonette competes with pastures and crops, but is rarely considered an important weed.” Minor impact on quantity of produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Seeds are known to contaminate agricultural produce. Degree of contamination not documented. Assume of minor importance.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: R.. luteola, “…is rarely considered an important weed.” Little impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Control can be readily achieved by mechanical methods. No change to agricultural activities required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Corms and cormils germinate in late autumn.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Mostly occurs in ‘open’ habitats (e.g. pastures, roadsides, neglected areas, grasslands).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems (e.g. ‘lowland grassland and grassy woodland’), and pasture. Cooke (1998)

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Erect perennial herb, reproducing from corms and cormils  geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Animals do not graze mature plants but young shoots are eaten”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Highly competitive in cleared areas on heavy soil…can build up dense colonies which exclude other species”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of water logging, drought (occurs dry areas of Western Australia), fire (re-grows from underground structures, frost (occurs in Southern Tasmania).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproducing from corms and cormils.

Also reproducing from seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Estimate based on pictures and descriptions:  15 flowers per plant x 10 seeds per flower = 75.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Aerial growth does annually (in summer), however re grows from corms.  Some corms have been observed with 35 plates, indicating the minimum age of some Watsonia ‘stands’. (Wilson & Conran 1993).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants developing from  cormils do not flower in first year, but in either the second or third year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Corms and cormils – graders and other earth moving equipment.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Seeds and bulbils usually fall to the ground and germinate next to the parent plant, resulting in a slow expansion of an existing infestation”.  (RPPSWG 1991).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
“An erect perennial herb, commonly 1.2 to 1.8 m high.” It is widespread in medium to large populations invading a broad range of vegetation formations including riparian areas and seasonal freshwater wetland. 

“Bulbil Watsonia forms dense stands.” May be a high annoyance to humans; makes access difficult.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Some recreational activities such as fishing may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Poisoning of livestock has been reported overseas.” It is not considered harmful to humans.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense stands would produce a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The root system is shallow and fibrous. Dense stands may provide cover. “All aerial growth dies in summer but dead plants often remain standing for several months.” Not likely to contribute to erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Occurs on, “heavy soils in moist conditions, becoming a weed of roadsides and neglected areas.” Biomass may increase as a result of dense clumping of plants.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “All aerial growth dies in summer but dead plants often remain standing for several months.” Increase in biomass due to dense clumping may increase the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grass woodland (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
A highly invasive species. Dominates ground flora and prevents most overstorey regeneration. Tolerates sun, semi-shade, moist conditions, flooding fore several weeks, most soil types. Major displacement of species in lower and mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Wet heathland (D); CMA=West Gipplsand; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (E); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Bulbil Watsonia forms dense stands that dominate the ground-layer and prevent most overstorey regeneration occurring.” Infestations would have a major impact on the ground flora and affect mid-storey species..

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Threatens ANZECC rated rare or threatened native plant species

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
It invades, “dry coastal vegetation, heathland and heathy woodland, lowland grassland and grassy woodland, dry and damp sclerophyll forest and woodland riparian vegetation, freshwater wetland (seasonal), roadsides, unimproved pastures, gardens, wasteland and railway lines.”

“Bulbil Watsonia forms dense stands that dominate the ground-layer and prevent most overstorey regeneration occurring.” Presence may lead to a reduction in habitat.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “It is claimed to be poisonous to stock, and losses of horses have been reported overseas but this is not a problem in Australia. Animals do not graze mature plants but young shoots are eaten without any apparent effect.” Potentially mildly toxic?

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Wild watsonia does not invade improved pastures or cultivated land and, therefore, is of little agricultural importance.” Little or no impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Wild watsonia does not invade improved pastures or cultivated land and, therefore, is of little agricultural importance.” Little or no impact quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “Wild watsonia does not invade improved pastures or cultivated land and, therefore, is of little agricultural importance.” Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Wild watsonia does not invade improved pastures or cultivated land and, therefore, is of little agricultural importance.” Change in land use not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Does not affect harvesting.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in autumn or spring if sufficient moisture is available”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Invasive in heathlands, woodlands. Would receive some shading in such ecosystems.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Invasive in heathlands, woodlands. Would receive some shading in such ecosystems.  Forest, grasslands and riverine environments”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial grass.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Generally considered to be an unpalatable weed although in South Africa, Argentina and the United States some strains are looked on as valuable pasture grasses”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “It is an aggressive, tenacious species capable of dominating the ground flora”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Drought and frost tolerant.

Occurs in freshwater wetland (seasonal).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing apomictically (without fertilisation) by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
“Ability to produce copious quantities of seed”.

“Plants produce large quantities of seed”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ?  Likely produces propagules > 3 years as a perennial spp.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Germinates autumn/spring  plants re sprout the following spring  flowers in early summer.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Wind, animals, humans, vehicles, etc.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “One of the most important means of spread is as a contaminant of soils and gravel’s used in road making and during road grading”.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grass 30 to 120 cm high. Low nuisance value to humans; not likely restrict access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “Found in disturbed soils on roadsides, railway tracks, river banks and waste places.” Apart from its nuisance value when accessing rivers, it is unlikely to affect tourism.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No recorded toxic effects.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: As a grass, this sp. unlikely to affect the structure of historical or cultural features. Presence is noticeable and it is, “capable of dominating the ground-flora on lighter soils.” Moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Although it grows on riverbanks, there is no indication it affects water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Not known to affect water quality

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
A cultivar of E. curvula complex is used in New South Wales to control soil erosion.
“Some cultivars are still promoted for…soil stabilisation use.”

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments:
“…ultimately dominates sparse, overgrazed pastures.” “…dominating ground-flora on lighter soils.”
Direct replacement of biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Is recorded as a fire hazard in the Eurobodalla Shire in New South Wales.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC=Hills herb-rich woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. “…capable of dominating the ground-flora on lighter soils.” Major displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential
“…infestations thin out over time under dense overstorey canopies.” Minor displacement of grasses.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Greater Grampians; VH CLIMATE potential
“…infestations thin out over time under dense overstorey canopies.” Major displacement of grasses/forbs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: It is “…capable of dominating the ground-flora on lighter, low-nutrient soils,” and thus likely to have a major effect on the lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Although a weed of disturbed neglected areas it also, “highly invasive in heathlands, woodlands, forests, grasslands and riverine environments.” It is highly persistent, dominant, and largely unpalatable, and therefore may have a minor negative impact on food sources for non-threatened fauna. This may lead to reduced populations

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No recorded benefits. “Mature plants are largely unpalatable.”

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of the plant having toxic properties. It does not produce any spines or burrs.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No evidence of a food source for pest animals. “Mature plants are largely unpalatable.”

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Clumping nature of plant may provide limited harbour for rodents.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “In arable areas, cultivation and cropping or the establishment of perennial pasture …gives good control.” The weed is unlikely to have a significant impact in well-managed paddocks.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Is not recorded as a weed of cropping; no evidence of contamination in grass seed crop. Pasture hay is a known vector.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: In arable areas, its presence controlled with good pasture management practices. “…in non-arable areas, it may be better to utilise the plant as a pasture species.” Little influence on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The weed is not a problem in well managed pastures.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence of increase in harvest costs

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Propagate by division in late winter, or from seed in Spring or Autumn (Burnie et al 1998)’. Appears to require natural seasonal disturbances, such as warmer temperatures, for germination. It is documented to reproduce primarily by vegetative means in Victoria (Walsh & Entwisle 1994) but spreads also by seed (Blood 2001), and has been described as a ‘notorious self seeder (Robertson 2007)’.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Grows in full sun or under partial shade from trees (Leszczynska-Borys et al 1995). Invades dry schlerophyll forest & woodland and damp schlerophyll forest (Carr et al 1992). Able to establish under moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Not specifically documented occurring in undisturbed vegetation but does establish in natural ecosystems, e.g. heathland & heathy woodland, lowland grassland & grassy woodland, dry schlerophyll forest & woodland, damp schlerophyll forest, riparian vegetation & rock outcrop vegetation (Carr et al 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Bulbous geophyte (Carr et al 1992).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No alleleopathic properties described from an extensive literature.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘Plants seem to be immune to the predation of rabbits (PFAF 2008)’. Described as having ‘low’ palatability to goats (MLA 2007). Leaves and rhizomes poisonous. Sticky sap can cause severe ulceration in the mouth (Blood 2001). Evidence of minimal herbivory, but appears rarely consumed.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
