inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Naturalise readily soon forming large clumps (Burnie et al 1998)’, ‘Fast-growing perennial (Gardening World Online 2002)’. Spreads rapidly down drainage lines (BMCC 2008). Rapid growth rate.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Drought resistant (Bodkin 1986). Tolerates light frost (Notten 2004). ‘Marginally frost hardy (Burnie et al 1998). Grows on foreshores (GCB 2003) - tolerance to salt spray. Spreads rapidly down drainage lines (BMCC 2008) - some tolerance to waterlogging. A. africanus ‘Blooms profusely after veld fires (Burman & Bean 1985) and A. praecox as a bulbous geophyte with thick underground rhizomes, is assumed to also survive fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Documented as reproducing both sexually by seed and vegetatively (rhizome growth or fragments) (Blood 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Seeds numerous (Walsh & Entwisle 1994). No. fruits/ umbel = 30-120 (Av. = 75); seeds/fruit =6-10 (Av. = 8) - 4 inflorescences x 75 fruits x 8 seeds = 2400 seeds/plant (Leszczynska-Borys et al 1995).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘It [seed] must be kept in the refrigerator or it will perish (Notten 2004). An indication that seed unlikely to survive 5 years under natural conditions.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Forms dense monocultures (ARC 2004), suggesting infestations would be self-sustaining.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Flowering can be expected from their third or fourth year (Notten 2004)’. The time taken for vegetative propagules to become separate individuals was not found described.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘Spread in dumped garden waste and contaminated soil (Blood 2001)’, ‘water and wind (Carr et al 1992)’. ‘Spreads rapidly down drainage lines…seed may wash down waterways (BMCC 2008)’.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Dispersal via garden waste, contaminated soil (Blood 2001) or water (Carr et al 1992) could spread a few propagules greater than 1 km, but many to 200-1,000 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Clumps reach height of 60 cm (Blood 2001), likely to cause minimal restriction to human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Not described as affecting recreational uses, but as a well known ornamental species (Walsh & Entwisle 1994) with the ability to form monocultures (ARC 2004) it would impact on natural area aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Leaves, rhizome and sap are poisonous. Can cause severe ulceration in the mouth and burning sensation and rashes on skin. Especially toxic to children (Shepherd 2004). Highly toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: ‘The large growing varieties will crack restricting concrete (Robertson 2007)’. Potential to cause moderate structure effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Described to invade terrestrial habitats (Carr et al 1992), so unlikely to impact on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Described to invade terrestrial habitats (Carr et al 1992), so unlikely to impact on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘A. praecox is also an excellent plant to use to stabilize a bank and to prevent erosion (Notten 2004). Decreases the probability of soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Biomass may increase in understorey due to extensive underground root mass, dense clumping habit (BMCC 2008) and ability to form monocultures (ARC 2004).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: The presence of thick fleshy leaves (BMCC 2008) could indicate low flammability, and although not documented, in the event of fire may reduce fire intensity of the understorey.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC=Plains Grassland (E); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. ‘Forms dense monocultures that exclude all other species (ARC 2004)’. ‘Dense clumping roots of Agapanthus displace all other vegetation (BMCC 2008)’. Described as a ‘serious threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria’, invading lowland grassland & grassy woodland (Carr et al 1992). Monoculture; displaces all species within understorey.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Coastal Headland scrub (D); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
‘Forms dense monocultures that exclude all other species: one cliff infestation at Piha was found to cover an area of over 1,000 m2 (ARC 2004)’. Has spread widely along foreshores (GCB 2003) and described as a ‘serious threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria’, invading dry coastal vegetation (Carr et al 1992). Monoculture; displaces all species within understorey.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC= Rocky Outcrop Shrubland (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. ‘Forms dense monocultures that exclude all other species: one cliff infestation at Piha was found to cover an area of over 1,000 m2 (ARC 2004)’. Invades rocky inland cliffs and low scrub (ARC 2004) and described as a ‘serious threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria’, invading rock outcrop vegetation (Carr et al 1992) Monoculture; displaces all species within understorey.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘Forms dense monocultures that exclude all other species (ARC 2004)’, though largely only understorey layer affected. Major effect on <60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Dense clumping roots of Agapanthus displace all other vegetation (BMCC 2008) forming monocultures (ARC 2004), However, not specifically described impacting on threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Dense clumping roots displace all other vegetation (BMCC 2008) forming monocultures (ARC 2004), with potential to reduce faunal habitat and food source, however, was not specifically described impacting on native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: ‘Leaves and rhizomes poisonous, Sticky sap can cause severe ulceration in the mouth (Blood 2001)’. ‘Plants seem to be immune to the predation of rabbits (PFAF 2004)’. Described as having ‘low’ palatability to goats (MLA 2007). No benefits to native fauna were found documented - Unlikely to provide support to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Described as being toxic to humans, causing severe ulceration in the mouth and skin rashes (Shepherd 2004), and is also documented as toxic to other mammal species (P & P Inc. 2007). It presumably would have an injurious affect on some native animals if consumed, though the level of impact is unknown.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: ‘Plants seem to be immune to the predation of rabbits (PFAF 2004)’. Described as having ‘low’ palatability to goats (MLA 2007). Provides minimal food for pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Its dense clumping habit to a height of 60 cm (Blood 2001, BMCC 2008) and formation of monocultures (ARC 2004), gives it potential to provide short term harbour to rabbits, however, no information about its ability to provide harbour was documented in the literature.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Documented to invade pasture and form monocultures in some habitats (ARC 2004), and it is described as having low palatability (MLA 2007) and as containing toxic properties (Shepherd 2004). However, its potential to reduce available grazing land and impact on agricultural yield is unknown.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Documented to invade pasture (ARC 2004) but there is no information to suggest would affect agricultural quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Documented to invade pasture (ARC 2004) but and there is no information to suggest would cause a change in land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Documented to invade pasture (ARC 2004) but and there is no information to suggest would cause a change in land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Documented to invade pasture and form monocultures in some habitats (ARC 2004), and it is described as having low palatability (MLA 2007) and as containing toxic properties (Shepherd 2004). However, its potential to increase harvest costs due to control or animal health costs is unknown.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Plants were found infected with tomato spotted wilt virus in Tasmania (Wilson et al 2000) . It is unknown if this is an isolated occurrence or if plants occurring on vegetable growing properties would pose any risk.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination is reported to be rare, occurring in autumn. However vegetative propagules (pieces of stem and stolons) which is the main form of reproduction can root and grow when conditions are suitable (Blood 2001)

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Reported to invade rainforest (Carr, Yugovic and Robinson 1992). Therefore can establish under low light conditions.
Cut stems can survive months, then set root and grow when exposed to suitable conditions (Blood 2001).
Therefore has some requirement for establishment.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in undisturbed /minor disturbed natural ecosystems: heath land: sclerophyll forest and woodland: riparian vegetation: rainforest (Carr, Yugovic and Robinson 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Vine (Carr, Yugovic and Robinson 1992).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments:
No allelopathic properties described.
However the species does contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids and xanthones, which are known to be toxic to fauna but not flora (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids and xanthones that make it unsuitable forage for most fauna and if slashed to ground level plants can regrow from rootstock (Bossard, Randell &  Hoshovsky 2000).
Bio-Control agents have been researched in Sth Africa and a program developed in California, however no such efforts are reported in Australia (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000 and Balciunas & Smith 2006).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Reported to be a fast growing vine (Weber 2003).
In California it has been reported as spreading more rapidly than any other weeds species. Average growth rates of plants around San Francisco have been calculated to one foot of growth per month. (Alvarez 1997).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerates some salinity (recorded on salt exposed bluffs) (Alvarez 1997).
Drought tolerant (Blood 2001).
Reported in seasonal wetlands, therefore tolerant of waterlogging (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
Frost tender (Blood 2001), however Nelson (1999) reports that hard frosts appear to stimulate seed set, therefore while frost may damage the plant, it may not kill it.
Foliage has high moisture content and therefore resistant to burning also plants can regrow from rootstock (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Produces seed, however primary mode of reproduction is vegetative, through stolons and stem fragments (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000 and Muyt 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Large plants can produce more than 40,000 seeds annually (Muyt 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
Reproduction primarily through vegetative means .Stem fragments can persists for months before setting root under favourable conditions (Blood 2001).
Seed longevity unknown. Seed doesn’t germinate readily and the seeds are tiny, 2 mm long (Muyt 2001).
Therefore assume propagule longevity <5yrs

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Long lived, can form monocultures (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Reach sexual maturity within two years (Muyt 2001)

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seeds are 2 mm with hairs attached, spread by wind and water (Muyt 2001).
Vegetative propagules spread by water and deliberate human actions (Alvarez 1997).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Wind dispersed seed can travel distances of more than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Can from dense tangled curtains of vegetation, including in riparian areas (Muyt 2001). Access would be difficult and would require significant works to control the species to maintain access due to the species rapid growth.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Fragrant ornamental species can alter aesthetics (Blood 2001).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Toxic to people (Richardson, Richardson & Shepherd 2006). Toxins include pyrrolizidine alkaloids and xanthones, which are contained in the leaves and present all year (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). No reported fatalities.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Fragrant ornamental species could alter aesthetics (Blood 2001).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Flood mitigation strategies can be impacted upon by this species invading riparian areas (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments:
No reported evidence that this species impacts on water quality factors such as dissolved oxygen or temperature.
However the plant is said to contain compounds that are toxic to fish and may be released into the water (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Can contribute to soil erosion on hillsides (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The weight of the ivy can cause trees to fall, and dense canopy of the vine can smother species of the lower strata and reduce growth (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
Foliage has high moisture content (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
This would constitute a change in fuel properties and have some impact on fire intensity (Brooks et al 2004).

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (V); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
The weight of the ivy can cause trees to fall, the dense canopy of the vine can smother species of the lower strata and reduce growth and regeneration of species and can form monocultures (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Lowland Forest (D); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
The weight of the ivy can cause trees to fall, the dense canopy of the vine can smother species of the lower strata and reduce growth and regeneration of species and can form monocultures (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Forest (LC); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
The weight of the ivy can cause trees to fall, the dense canopy of the vine can smother species of the lower strata and reduce growth and regeneration of species and can form monocultures (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: The weight of the ivy can cause trees to fall, and the dense canopy of the vine can smother species of the lower strata and reduce growth and regeneration of species (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Can significantly reduce the species richness and diversity of an area, and render habitat in protected reserves for plant species worthless (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Significant alteration of habitat; reducing plant species richness and diversity and therefore diversity of food and shelter available. Invasion by cape ivy can render habitat in protected reserves for animal species worthless (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Nothing reported. Insects may visit flowers, dense foliage may provide some shelter.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments:
Foliage contains compounds toxic to mammals, spiders and fish (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
Compounds toxic but not necessarily lethal to rats (Connor 1977).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Little reported to eat the plant.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense foliage could provide shelter.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Reported to be primarily a weed of conservation areas and public amenity (Scott & Delfosse 1992).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Reported to be primarily a weed of conservation areas and public amenity (Scott & Delfosse 1992).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Reported to be primarily a weed of conservation areas and public amenity (Scott & Delfosse 1992).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Reported to be primarily a weed of conservation areas and public amenity (Scott & Delfosse 1992).

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Reported to be primarily a weed of conservation areas and public amenity (Scott & Delfosse 1992).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: No evidence of this reported.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Its vegetative cycle starts in Autumn (Manzanares et al, 1993). Requires natural seasonal disturbances.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Grows in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1980).

Requires open space to establish.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Grows in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1980).  

Establishes in highly disturbed ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Biennial (Tutin, 1980).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: None found, but there is very little information about this species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Leaves and stems bear spines up to 1 cm long (Tutin, 1980), which would deter most vertebrates, except perhaps for goats who eat the seed heads of the related O. illyricum (Holst & Allan, 1996). Weevils were introduced to Australia to control this genus in 1992, but it was found that less than 20% of O. tauricum capitula were attacked (Briese, 2000). These thistles are still capable of seed production under most herbivory pressure.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: No information found.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Grows in dry habitats (Tutin, 1980). No further information about tolerances found.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Onopordum reproduce only by seeds (Healy, Enloe & DiTomaso, 2005). No further information found.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Average of 218 capitula per plant (Briese et al, 1995). Each capitualum appears composed of over 100 florets (see picture in ENG, 2002). 218 x 100 = 21 800.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Buried seed [of Onopordum spp.] may persist for up to twenty years” (Healy, Enloe & DiTomaso, 2005).  Deep dormancy has been observed in O. nervosum seeds (Perez-Garcia & Duran, 1990).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Biannual plant. Its vegetative cycle starts in Autumn…ending the cycle in summer with flowering and fructification (Manzanares et al, 1993). Produces propagules for more than one year but less than two.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Its vegetative cycle starts in Autumn…ending the cycle in summer with flowering and fructification (Manzanares et al, 1993). Produces seed in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: No information found.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: No information found.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: No information about the extent of infestations of this plant was found.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Flowers purplish-pink on thorny plants (ENG, 2002) up to 2.7 m (Tutin, 1980) are likely to be very obvious to the average visitor and have a moderate visual effect. The density of infestations is not known so more serious impacts may be possible, but are not known.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The stems are spinose-winged, …and the involucral bracts spine-tipped (Tutin, 1980; ENG, 2002). Spines on the infloresence stems may cause some damage at most times of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Flowers purplish-pink on thorny plants (ENG, 2002) up to 2.7 m (Tutin, 1980) are likely to be very obvious to the average visitor and have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Most species grow in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1980). Terrestrial species.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Most species grow in rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1980). Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Biennial species (Tutin, 1980) that may leave large bare patches after it dies off, however the extent of infestations is unknown.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invades rocky or stony ground, roadsides, waste places and similar dry, open habitats (Tutin, 1980). In this type of vegetation, the plant is likely to replace other herbaceous species.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Post senescence “stems can persist into the next season with spiny phyllaries and receptacles attached” (Healy, Enroe & DiTomaso, 2005). In dry, open habitats, where this plant invades (Tutin, 1980) this dried vegetation adds to the fuel load, most likely causing a moderate increase in the intensity of fires.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (BCS = E) CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Species has potential to occur in high value EVC although impact on composition unknown. Score medium.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Chenopod grassland (BCS = D) CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Species has potential to occur in medium value EVC although impact on composition unknown. Score medium.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Dunefield heathland (BCS = C) CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH.
Species has potential to occur in low value EVC although impact on composition unknown. Score medium.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: No information was found about the density of infestations.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: No information found.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The structure of this spiny plant (as seen in BBG, 2006) is unlikely to provide harbour or food to desirable fauna species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The stems are spinose-winged…and the involucral bracts spine-tipped (Tutin, 1980). Spines on the infloresence and stems may cause some damage at most times of the year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The stems are spinose-winged…and the involucral bracts spine-tipped (Tutin, 1980). Spines on the infloresence and stems would deter herbivory by vertebrate species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The structure of this spiny plant (as seen in BBG, 2006) is unlikely to provide harbour to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: No information about the invasiveness of this plant was found.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No information about the invasiveness of this plant was found.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No information about the invasiveness of this plant was found.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No information about the invasiveness of this plant was found.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No information about the invasiveness of this plant was found.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: No information about disease host/vector of this plant was found, however there was very little information available about this species.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Unknown.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
The species is only reported to occur in open areas, of beach and dune systems and arid pasture (Willmer 1986; Snowball 2002).
Therefore the species is presumed to require open space for establishment.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Reported to occur as a composition of pasture in arid areas (Mokhtar et al 2006; Snowball 2002).
The species is native to coastal areas of the Mediterranean (Martinez et al 2000).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial legume (Vignolio et al 2002).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Reported to act as fodder for sheep in Israel (Tsuriell 1977).
The species has importance in pastoral systems in Tunisia (Mokhtar et al 2006).
Reported present in an area of pressure exposed to high grazing pressure (Snowball 2002).
Therefore it is presumed to be capable of recovering from moderate grazing.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: The species is reported to be a small shrub with a fast growth rate (Martinez et al 2000). Therefore he species is considered to have a growth rate equal to that of species with the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Shown to have adaptation to drought conditions (Sav�, Biel & de Herralde 2000).
Tolerant of saline conditions (S�nchez-Blanco et al 1998).
Reported not to be adapted to waterlogged conditions (Real et al 2006).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The species reproduces sexually producing seed through insect pollinated flowers (Tsuriell 1977; Willmer 1986).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Unknown

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Unknown

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The species seeds are dispersed by wind (Tsuriell 1977).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Unknown

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: The species is described as a prostrate herbaceous plant (Vignolio et al 2002). It is therefore presumed not to have minimal potential of restricting access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The species is described as a prostrate herbaceous plant and occurs on beaches and dunes systems (Vignolio et al 2002; Willmer 1986). The species is therefore unlikely to inhibit any recreational activities; however it may have some aesthetic impact.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this occurring.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Unknown.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species is largely a coastal species and is not reported in riparian areas and is therefore unlikely to impact on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species is largely a coastal species and is not reported in riparian areas and is therefore unlikely to impact on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
Recommended for use as a vegetation cover in soil restoration projects to prevent wind and water erosion (Vignolio et al 2005).
Used for sand dune stabilisation in Israel (Tsuriell 1974).
Therefore the species is considered to decrease the probability of soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments:
The species is a prostrate herb, which occurs in beach and dune systems (Vignolio et al 2002; Willmer 1986).
Invading bare sand the species would therefore increase biomass; however it is unlikely to act as a significant carbon sink.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Spray-zone Coastal Shrubland (E); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is reported to dominate the vegetation of the beach and fore-dunes in its native Israel (Willmer 1986).
The species therefore has potential to cause major displacement of species if it is able to dominate the vegetation of the lower strata of invaded beach and fore-dunes.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Spray-zone Coastal Shrubland (R); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Bridgewater; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is reported to dominate the vegetation of the beach and fore-dunes in its native Israel (Willmer 1986).
The species therefore has potential to cause major displacement of species if it is able to dominate the vegetation of the lower strata of invaded beach and fore-dunes.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Coastal Dune Scrub (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Bridgewater; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species reportedly becomes less common within a few hundred meters inland from the coast (Willmer 1986).
Therefore the species may be present in this vegetation but is unlikely to cause any significant displacement.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
The species is reported to dominate the vegetation of the beach and fore-dunes in its native Israel (Willmer 1986).
The beach and fore-dune vegetation is often only comprised of the lower strata. Therefore if the species is capable of dominating the vegetation as it does in its native range, it could have a minor effect on more than 60% of the flora.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Unknown.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: It is reported to be grazed by sheep and pollinated by insects (Snowball 2002; Tsuriell 1977; Willmer 1986). It may therefore provide some assistance in way of food to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this reported.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: It is reported to be grazed by sheep and pollinated by insects (Snowball 2002; Tsuriell 1977; Willmer 1986). It may therefore provide some food to pest species such as feral bees and goats.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The species is a prostrate herb (Vignolio et al 2002). It is unlikely therefore to provide any significant cover.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate with rains at any time of year (CABI 2005). Opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Requires light to establish and grow, very sensitive to shade (CABI 2005).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Common on riverbanks and watersheds (CABI 2005). Likes open woodlands and grasslands with a tendency to invade degraded areas such as overgrazed grassland. Can establish in relatively intact ecosystems (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Leguminous, perennial non-climbing tree (CABI 2005).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: A common fodder species browsed by wild and domesticated animals in its native range. Over thirty beetle species have been identified with eight linked to defoliation of trees (CABI 2005). Weed still persists.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Relatively ‘slow-growing’ tree in natural environments (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Can tolerate frost (to -1�C), saline soil tolerant, tolerant of fire and drought. Seeds susceptible to waterlogging (CABI 2005).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by seed only. No information on whether self and /or cross- pollination occurs so scores as ML (CABI 2005).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Seedpods contain between four and seven seeds. Mature trees produce ‘large numbers’ of seeds.  

Assume greater than 2000 propagules produced per flowering event (CRC for Australian Weed  Management 2003).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Exact length not known but ‘probable that some seeds remain viable for about 20 years’ (CRC for Australian Weed management 2003).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Not specified although in areas where grown for forestry rotated every 20 years. Trees live up to 60 years.

Score High as likely that produces viable propagules for greater than 10 years and records of the tree forming monocultures in some areas in Asia (CABI 2005).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Life cycle under Australian conditions is unknown and time to reproductive maturity is unclear (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Therefore score as medium.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Transported by cattle, water, humans, machinery movement (CABI 2005).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Can be transported long distances by cattle therefore likely that some propagules will spread greater than 1 km (CRC for Australian Weed management 2003).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Trees range from 3 to 15 metres with average height when fully grown between 10 to 15 metres (CABI 2005). Trees have a light feathery crown. Forms ‘dense impenetrable stands and the sharp thorns .. can impede the movement and mustering of stock’. When fully grown, stems up to 30 cm diameter (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). As common on riverbanks and watersheds, plant would be a major impediment to access waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: As the weed can be found on riverbanks and watersheds, it is possible that some recreational uses may be affected e.g. swimming, fishing, boating (World Agroforestry Centre 2005).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The branchlets have ‘twin hooked prickles’. These prickles are present throughout the year (CABI 2005).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Not likely that the plant would do any structural damage but due to size and potential to spread (CABI 2005), would have moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (CABI 2005).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘..apart from checking soil erosion. On steep slopes, its roots bind the soil and prevent landslides or excessive erosion’. Tree has a strong primary root (up to 2 metres deep) which is long and wiry with lateral short, fibrous roots (CABI 2005). Does not replace ground cover so unlikely to leave ground exposed. Low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: As the plant likes open woodlands and grasslands with a tendency to invade degraded areas (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003), biomass may increase.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Potential distribution of Acacia catechu excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Potential distribution of Acacia catechu excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Potential distribution of Acacia catechu excludes Victoria. No impact on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Found with other dry deciduous species, and grasses. Can occur in both open grasslands and also within dry forests (CABI 2005). ‘Occurs as a weedy shrub on overgrazed grasslands’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Therefore, it may exclude understorey species e.g grasses. Will affect only one of the stratum.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The potential for Acacia catechu to establish and naturalise in Victoria is highly unlikely due to ecoclimatic limitations. No impact on threatened flora in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: ‘The sharp thorns .. can impede the movement and mustering of stock’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). In agricultural situations the plant may be a problem but in natural situations may not hinder or affect fauna e.g. access to water, but may have a minor effect

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: In India it is known to be ‘an excellent source of food for wildlife’ (CABI 2005). May provide an alternate food source for native fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: ‘The bark is toxic and contains an alkaloid’ (CABI 2005). However, it is a common fodder species within its native range for both wild and domesticated animals so toxicity likely to have little effect. Forms ‘dense impenetrable stands and the sharp thorns .. can impede the movement and mustering of stock’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: ‘Is a useful fodder species.. browsed by cattle, rhinoceros, deer and elephants’. Rodents are also reported to damage the tree’ (CABI 2005). May supply food for one or more minor pest spp.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: No evidence in CABI (2005) that the weed provides harbour for pest spp.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Dense patches ‘impede stock movement and access to other pasture plants’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Could impact stock access to water with potential to have minor impact on quantity of produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to effect quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No documented evidence that weed would affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: No evidence to suggest that the weed would cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence to suggest that the weed would increase the cost of harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for diseases of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘It regrows and germinates during the spring months’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Requires natural seasonal conditions.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Generally grows in damp areas. ‘..has been observed breaking through special weed proof matting in a revegetation area alongside a creek line’. ‘Shows a preference for damp open areas or rock outcrops ..grows beneath an overstorey of eucalypt [in the Blue Mountains] .. but will also grow in full-sun environments’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Can establish without additional factors.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Found alongside creeks. ‘. A weed of both semi-arid agricultural crops and damp grasslands’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Can establish in relatively intact or only minor disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A perennial sedge (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Life form– other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: None described in CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No information regarding herbivory pressure. Score medium

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Insufficient information to determine this species rate of growth. Score medium.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘Does not go dormant during winter, but slows its growth during cool periods’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Has been found in Katoomba in the blue mountains. Likes damp areas and grows in monsoonal climates. Tolerates waterlogging. Not enough information to determine whether this species is susceptible to drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduction ‘via rhizome, stolons and seed’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Both vegetative and sexual reproduction.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘The main flowering spike is .. made up of many tiny spikelets ..the fruit contains one seed’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). By counting the spikelets on the photo from the NCW Beadle Herbarium photograph, it would appear that one spike contains approximately 100 spikelets.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Not much is known about the life cycle of C. teneristolon in Australia’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Not enough definitive information. Score as medium.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
A perennial sedge (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003), therefore likely to live greater than 3 years. No definitive information to establish whether it would produce propagules for 10 years or more.

Therefore medium high.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Not much is known about the life cycle of C. teneristolon in Australia’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Not enough definitive information. Score as medium.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Stolons and rhizomes break off and propagate downstream (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Propagules spread by water.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘ .. in Australia .. has spread 2 km from its source since approximately 1999’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Few propagules will spread greater than 1 km but many will reach 200-1,000 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grows up to 500 mm. Although found around creeks unlikely that the weed would impede access (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Minimal or negligible impact.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Due to the areas the weed is known to grow (around creeks, agricultural areas) (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003), weeds would not be obvious to the ‘average’ visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Weeds not known to be injurious to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Weeds not known to occur on cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Evergreen plant. ‘Roots are fibrous and the plant has an extensive rhizome system’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Shows preference for damp open areas and rocky outcrops (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Likely that the biomass would increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Weed tends to grow in riparian areas. Unlikely that the weed would have any effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC= Parilla Mallee (E); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=H. Impact unknown.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC= Grassy Riverine Forest (D); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=H. Impact unknown.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC= Dune Field Heathland (LC); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=H. Impact unknown.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
‘Shows a preference for damp open areas or rock outcrops.’ In the Blue Mountains, it ‘grows beneath an overstorey of
eucalypt along Yosemite Creek but will also grow in full-sun environments’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Likely to have at least a minor impact on the lower stratum.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information available.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: No documented evidence that the weed has an effect on non-threatened fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Not known to provide benefits to indigenous fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be toxic to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not a known food source to pest animal species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbour for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: ‘..has become a significant weed of crops of the East African highlands, in particular Kenya… seen as a potential threat to Australia’s environment and agricultural productivity’. ‘..locally common and important as a weed of crops in the highlands [of Kenya and Tanzania]’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Insufficient information available to determine the extent of impact. Score medium.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No evidence to suggest that this weed would impact upon the quality of crops.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not known to affect the value of land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed not documented to cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No documented evidence to suggest that the weed increases the cost of harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for disease.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Can interfere with boating, had could cause drowning due to entanglement (Champion 1995). Therefore a high nuisance impeding people and vehicles.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Can interfere with activities such as fishing, swimming and boating (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). However evidence of major impact and visitor complaints not reported.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Poses the risk of drowning, due to entanglement (Champion 1995). This risk would be greatest at the highest biomass levels reported in February to March, when the species forms a thick mat of intertwining stems below the surface (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Can interfere with infrastructure, including, irrigation works, hydro-electric outputs and water supplies (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: An attached submerged species preferring slow moving water, reported to seriously retard flow (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Can help to stabilise shallow systems, by reducing wave action and stabilising sediment. However, when the species builds up to high biomass levels, the system can collapse. Benthic anoxia leads to death of large proportions of the egeria. This can cause the wetland to flip and become turbid and dominated by phytoplankton (Champion 2002).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Can act as a semi-permeable dam, slowing flow and increasing stream depth (Champion & Tanner 2000).  However during times of high flow, can cause flooding and therefore increase the chance of erosion (DiTomaso & Healy 2003).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: This species would either be a direct replacement or potentially increases biomass, as can form dense monospecfic stands to depths of 5 m (Coffey & Clayton 1988).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species; not present in vegetation exposed to fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Shallow Freshwater Marsh (E); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Can form monospecific stands (Coffey & Clayton 1988). Reported displacing native submerged macrophytes (Roberts, Church & Cummins 1999)

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. com).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. com).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Can form monospecific stands (Coffey & Clayton 1988). Reported displacing native submerged macrophytes (Roberts, Church & Cummins 1999)

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Has been reported to displace native submerged macrophytes (Roberts, Church & Cummins 1999). However no specific information on threatened species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Reported to harbour different fish assemblages than those of native submerged macrophytes (Growns et al 2003).  Therefore decrease in populations of some species with an increase in population of other species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Provides a major food source for black swan (Cygnus atratus) (Champion 2002).  Fish assemblages and invertebrate species are reported living amongst it, and can act as protection from predators (Duggan et al 2001; Growns et al 2003). Therefore it provides an abundant food source for at least one species and it creates a habitat and shelters various species. However unknown specifically for native species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No evidence of this reported. However it is reported to have potential to drown people through entanglement, it may therefore be able to drown animal species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: There are exotic fish species reported to eat significant quantities of the species that they could be used for biocontrol measures, However they are not reported in Australia (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Provides habitat for a fish assemblage (Growns et al 2003). Therefore could provide harbour for exotic fish species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Aquatic species, no evidence of this reported.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Aquatic species, no evidence of this reported.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Aquatic species, no evidence of this reported.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Aquatic species, no evidence of this reported.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Can interfere with irrigation activities and block pumps, therefore increased maintenance costs (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Aquatic species, no evidence of this reported.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: No information on the germination requirements of Carex divisa was found documented.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: It is recorded as inhabiting creekline grassy woodland and herb-rich woodland communities, (pers.com.) an indication that it may be able to establish under a moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Naturalised along creek flats in Victoria (Walsh & Entwisle 1994) and documented as invading grassland, (Richardson et al 2006, K. Roberg pers.com.) and riparian and creek line grassy woodland (I. Higgins pers.com.).
Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems e.g. grassland, riparian vegetation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Tufted sedge to 80 cm with long creeping rhizomes (Richardson et al 2006; Walsh & Entwisle 1994, eflora 2007). Lifeform: geophyte.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No information was found documented to indicate C. divisa possesses any allelopathic properties, however, literature on this species is limited.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: There is information from France indicating that C. divisa is a species of grasslands and is grazed by sheep (Aich, O’Rourke & Bourbouze 1980). Observations in Victoria indicate it is rarely grazed unless animals are forced through starvation (I. Higgins pers.com.). It appears that this species is consumed, but it is not preferred by grazing animals.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
A rapid rhizome spreading species that can be difficult to control (Walsh & Entwisle 1994).
Has rapidly invaded adjacent pasture and grassland areas (Richardson et al 2006). Growth rate in comparison to species of the same life-form was not found documented.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
‘The frequent flooding of permanent pastures in winter, favours the development of Carex divisa…’ (Jeannin & Lafon 1975). Known to occur on coastal marshes (Aich et al 1980), ‘halophytic meadows’ (Vanden Berghan 1965) and often found in brackish situations (Richardson et al 2006). Known to occur in the Atlas mountains with a mean minimum Winter temperature of -2oC and precipitation mostly falling as snow from December to March.
Possesses thick, woody rhizomes (Jermy & Tutin 1982).
Likely to be tolerant of frost, salt and water logging and the presence of thick rhizomes may indicate some tolerance to fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Inflorescence is a spike containing both male and female flowers and the seed is a dark yellow-brown nut (Walsh & Entwisle 1994). Spreads by rhizomes (Walsh & Entwisle 1994). Reproduces both sexually and vegetatively.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: No information was found on the number of propagules produced by C. divisa.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: No information was found on the longevity of propagules produced by C. divisa.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
‘Theoretically, clones of many [Carex] species may survive for many hundreds of years by growing at one end and dying at the other…’ (Bernard 1990). Examples of documented life-spans of some Carex species include: C. flava more than 10 years, C. comosa, more than 20 years and C. pilosa & C. stricta, more than 50 years. From this information on Carex as a genus, it appears likely that mature C. divisa plants would continue to produce
propagules for at least 10 years. It has also been described as being a ‘long lived’ species (I. Higgins pers.com.).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Described as being able to produce seed ‘by two years post-germination’ (I. Higgins pers.com.).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Introduced for Stream bank stabilisation but has rapidly invaded adjacent pasture and grassland areas (Richardson et al 2006, Walsh & Entwisle 1994). In Victoria recorded growing in riparian situations with spread being via soil movement and probably water flow (I. Higgins pers.com.). Viable seeds of C. divisa have been found in the dung of red deer (Malo & Suarez 1995). Dispersal is most likely by water and soil movement and potentially by animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Although no information was found on the dispersal distance of propagules, through water and potentially animal dispersal, it is possible that propagules could travel at least 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Described as a tufted sedge or as a creeping perennial herb with slender and wiry stems arising singly along a creeping rhizome, to 80 cm/1 m (Marchant et al 1987, Richardson et al 2006; Walsh & Entwisle 1994). Likely to have minimal impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments:
Described as being very similar in appearance to the rare native sedge Carex chlorantha, so it is probable that this
weed would not be obvious to the ‘average’ visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No information was found to suggest this species is injurious to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Possesses thick, woody creeping rhizomes (Jermy & Tutin 1982), but no information was found documented to suggest that this species causes damage to cultural sites or infrastructure.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Described as occurring adjacent to aquatic habitats but ‘rarely in the water’ (Jermy & Tutin 1982), and as a lower growing herbaceous monocot it is unlikely to have much affect on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Described as occurring adjacent to aquatic habitats but ‘rarely in the water’ (Jermy & Tutin 1982). No information was found to suggest this species impacts on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Has been deliberately introduced in some areas for the stabilization of stream banks (Walsh & Entwisle 1994; Richardson et al 2006). Rhizomes, thick woody, some-times far creeping and branched (Jermy & Tutin 1982). Likely to decrease the probability of soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Described as smothering a Poa grass community in Sunbury, Victoria (K. Roberg pers. com.) and because it grows to a similar height as many Poa and other grass species (80 - 100 cm), it is probable that almost direct replacement of biomass by C. divisa may occur rather than a noticeable increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: In Victoria, C. divisa has been observed forming a monoculture and completely smothering a Poa grass community (K. Roberg pers. com.). With Poa spp. having high flammability foliage (Chladil & Sheridan 2006) the replacement by C. divisa, with broader foliage that does not dry out as intensely as that of Poa spp., is likely to reduce fuel flammability and may cause some reduction to the intensity of fire in grassland situations.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Creekline Tussock Grassland (BCS= E); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Victorian Volcanic Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Inhabits wetland areas and creek edges displacing Poa and Bolboschoenus spp. ‘It formed monocultures; overtaking all native vegetation….it completely smothered what was once a productive Poa seed collection site’ (K. Roberg pers.com.). Monoculture within a specific layer; displaces all species within a strata/layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC= Sedgy Riparian woodland (BCS= D); CMA= North Central; Bioreg= Central Victorian Uplands; CLIMATE potential=VH. Inhabits wetland areas and creek edges displacing Poa and Bolboschoenus spp. ‘It formed monocultures; overtaking all native vegetation….it completely smothered what was once a productive Poa seed collection site’ (K. Roberg pers.com.). Monoculture within a specific layer; displaces all species within a strata/layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Seasonally Inundated Shrubby Woodland (BCS= LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Wimmera Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Inhabits wetland areas and creek edges displacing Poa and Bolboschoenus spp. ‘It formed monocultures; overtaking all native vegetation….it completely smothered what was once a productive Poa seed collection site’ (K. Roberg pers.com.). Monoculture within a specific layer; displaces all species within a strata/layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Inhabits creek and wetland edges displacing Poa and Bolboschoenus spp. (pers.com.). ‘It formed monocultures; overtaking all native vegetation….it completely smothered what was once a productive Poa seed collection site’ (K. Roberg pers.com.). It is described as forming a ‘monoculture’ but no information was found specifically of its specific on recruitment of upper strata species. However, the above information indicates it is likely to have at least a major affect on < 60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Inhabits creek and wetland edges displacing Poa and Bolboschoenus spp. (pers.com.). ‘It formed monocultures; overtaking all native vegetation….it completely smothered what was once a productive Poa seed collection site’ (K. Roberg pers.com.). It is likely to have similar impacts on threatened flora, however, no information specific to threatened flora was found documented.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: C. divisa has been observed forming monocultures, displacing native vegetation and more specifically smothering Poa tussock grass communities in the western outskirts of Melbourne (K. Roberg pers.com.). It is also described as invading grasslands in general as well as woodland and riparian communities (Richardson et al 2006, I. Higgins pers. com). Tussock grasslands provide important feeding and nesting habitat to small mammals, birds and insects (EWR 2007, MV 2005, Prober & Thiele 2005). The displacement of Poa grass communities by C. divisa would likely lead to reduced habitat and potential decrease in associated faunal populations.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Described as being low in palatability and rarely grazed unless animals are forced through starvation (I. Higgins pers. com.). Other information suggests that in Europe it is grazed by sheep and by red deer in low quantities (Aich et al 1980, Malo & Suarez 1995). Small numbers of seeds were found cached by mole rats in Israel (Heth, Golenberg & Nevo 1989). No information was found in the literature to suggest C. divisa benefits desirable native fauna, but there is potential for it to provide some assistance to native grazers and rodents.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Although the literature is limited, no information was found to indicate that C. divisa possesses any properties injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Seeds of C. divisa were found cached by mole rats in Israel (Heth, Golenberg & Nevo 1989) and in the dung of red deer in Spain (Malo & Suarez 1995) suggesting that C. divisa may provide some food source to one or more minor pest species, such as deer or rodents.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The habit of C. divisa to form substantial monocultures to 1 m high adjacent to riparian systems (Walsh & Entwisle 1994; Richardson 2006, K. Roberg pers.com.), gives it the potential capacity to provide some harbour to pest animals, however, no information in relation to pest harbour was found documented.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: C. divisa is known to invade pasture (Richardson 2006, Walsh & Entwisle 1994) and has been observed ‘colonising entire paddocks’ on creek flats near Castlemaine, Victoria. It is also described as being rarely grazed, having low palatability and disliked by farmers (I. Higgins pers. com.). Its ability to ‘colonise entire paddocks’ could lead to significant yield loss (>5%) because of reduced stocking potential due to low quality grazing land.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Although literature on this species is limited, it is described as being invasive in pasture (Richardson 2006, Walsh & Entwisle 1994) and has been observed ‘colonising entire paddocks’ (I. Higgins pers.com.), but no information was found to suggest C. divisa reduces agricultural quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Documented as being invasive in pasture (Richardson 2006, Walsh & Entwisle 1994) and observed ‘colonising entire paddocks’ (pers.com.). It is also described as being rarely grazed, having low palatability and disliked by farmers (I. Higgins pers. com.). However, no information was found documented to indicate that this species would affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Documented as invading pasture (Richardson 2006, Walsh & Entwisle 1994), ‘observed’ colonising entire paddocks’ near Castlemaine (I. Higgins pers. com.), and described as being rarely grazed, having low palatability and disliked by farmers (I. Higgins pers. com.). Although no information was found documented that C. divisa specifically causes a change in land use, it is documented as grazed by sheep in Europe (Aich et al 1980) and it is possible that a downgrading of land use priority, for example to a grazing species with less agricultural return, but that will eat C. divisa, may be necessary on invaded grazing land.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Although C. divisa is documented as invading pasture, being rarely grazed and having low palatability to stock (Richardson 2006, Walsh & Entwisle 1994, I. Higgins pers. com.), there is no information to suggest this species would cause an increase in harvest costs in grazing situations.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: No information was found documented to indicate this species acts as a host or vector for diseases of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Germination is stimulated by fire and soil disturbance (Muyt 2001).
Blood (2001) describes the species as having prolific recruitment. This may indicate the species is an opportunistic germinator.
Gandhi (1957) states that the above ground biomass is killed off by frost and then the plant regrows in spring. This may indicate a seasonal component, however in a frost free climate there may not be any restrictions on germination.
The germination requirements of this species are unknown.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Grows best in full sun but seedlings can establish under shady conditions (Muyt 2001).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Reported to be “highly invasive in heathland” (Muyt 2001).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Legume: A nitrogen fixing, climbing woody perennial of the Fabaceae family (Muyt 2001).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No allelopathic properties have been described for the species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
The species was suppressed by grazing of wallabies and possums on Rangitoto Island. The plants presence expanded from a few vines covering a few square metres to many hundred plants covering almost a hectare in five after an eradication program of the possums and wallabies reduced there population numbers by 90% (Wotherspoon & Wotherspoon 2002).
As the possums and wallabies were also introduced species and at population levels that they were damaging the native vegetation, the grazing pressure applied to suppress the
species was more than would be called moderate.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Reported to have a very rapid growth rate and can cover 3-5 m in one season (Blood 2001).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of salt laden winds (Muyt 2001).
Tolerant of fire; mature plants may be killed but germination is stimulated (Muyt 2001).
Tolerant of drought (Blood 2001).
Frost resistant (Bodkin 1990).
Well drained soils are recommended for the plant (Bodkin 1990).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Able to reproduce sexually, producing seed and vegetatively by suckering and the stems can layer (Blood 2001).
Spread by seed and rhizomes (Hussey et al 1997).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Reported to produce thousands of seeds annually (Muyt 2001). Thousands would indicate more than 2000 seeds are produced annually.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds can remain in the soil for several years (Muyt 2001). A more accurate period of seed longevity is not reported.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Can live for more than 10 years and the plant is also reported to smother all ground flora (Muyt 2001).
Smothering all ground flora would effectively mean the formation of a monoculture.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Reported to take 2-3 years to reach sexual maturity (Muyt 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seeds are forcefully ejected several meters when ripe and dispersed by birds (Muyt 2001).
Occasionally in trade the seeds are naturally dispersed by water and possibly by ants (Blood 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Unknown specifically how far the seeds may be dispersed but being dispersed by birds and by water it is very likely that seeds will be dispersed more than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: It is reported to grow over existing vegetation building up enough biomass so that the supporting plant collapses. It can from dense masses of dead stems and other biomass more than 1 m thick, including in riparian areas (Blood 2001). As this growth would be worst where the plant has something existing to grow over it is unlikely to cause track closure.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Reported to be the second most noticed species to Buddleja in a public survey of seven weeds in New Zealand, due to its substantial floral displays (McCluggage 2004).  Unknown if the species effect on access would also impede any recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: There is no reported evidence of the species causing injury.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Reported to be the second most noticed species to Buddleja in a public survey of seven weeds in New Zealand, due to its substantial floral displays (McCluggage 2004).  The species ability to build up so much biomass that it causes the supporting plants to collapse as reported by Blood (2001) may imply that the species would also be possible of collapsing infrastructure.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species is reported to invade riparian vegetation but no impact on water flow is reported (Blood 2001).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species is reported to invade riparian vegetation but no impact on water flow is reported (Blood 2001).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
The thick mat of vegetation the species forms protects the soil surface from wind and water erosion (Gandhi 1957).
Muyt (2001) describes the species root system as woody occasionally branched taproot which can be several metres long. A well developed root system would reduce the probability of large scale erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The species is able to build up so much biomass that the supporting plants collapse due to the weight (Blood 2001). This would be a short term gain, however Muyt (2001) describes the species invading gaps and margins where it can the bring down trees and preventing regeneration will continue to invade with the increased light levels which would lead to a significant decrease in biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: There is no specific data presented on this species effect on fire regime, fire kills mature plants and stimulates mass germination of seedling (Muyt 2001). The plant forms dense masses which contain dead material (Blood 2001). The alteration of biomass and the creation of fire ladders as the species can grow up trees and accumulate dead material could alter the fire intensity. It is unknown however the flammability of the living material and there for its effect on fire frequency.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Damp Sands Herb-rich Woodland (V); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Highly invasive in heathland and woodlands Dolichos pea is reported to be able to ‘smother all ground flora”, bring down shrubs and trees and prevent regeneration (Muyt 2001). Being able to smother all species in the lower strata it is effectively forming a monoculture.
