hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Sand Heathland (R); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Highly invasive in heathland and woodlands Dolichos pea is reported to be able to ‘smother all ground flora”, bring down shrubs and trees and prevent regeneration (Muyt 2001). Being able to smother all species in the lower strata it is effectively forming a monoculture.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Heathy Woodland (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Highly invasive in heathland and woodlands Dolichos pea is reported to be able to ‘smother all ground flora”, bring down shrubs and trees and prevent regeneration (Muyt 2001). Being able to smother all species in the lower strata it is effectively forming a monoculture.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Highly invasive in heathland and woodlands Dolichos pea is reported to be able to ‘smother all ground flora”, bring down shrubs and trees and prevent regeneration (Muyt 2001). The species is having a major effect on all layers by smothering all “ground flora” species and felling shrubs and trees.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Listed as threatening competitor to Villarsia calthifolia a rare species in Western Australia (Gilfillan & Barrett 2004). There is no evidence of its effect on threatened species in Victoria however.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Significant alteration of the vegetation and therefore habitat for species it is likely to affect fauna species, however there is no reported data.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The plant is eaten by possums and wallabies (Wotherspoon & Wotherspoon 2002). Birds disperse the seed (Muyt 2001). Unknown which species.  Produces prolific flowers (Blood 2001). Likely to be visited by insects.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of the species injuring fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The species is edible as it was suppressed by possums and wallabies (Wotherspoon & Wotherspoon 2002).  Therefore it may be eaten by species such as rabbits or goats but there is no evidence of this reported.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Grows over existing vegetation creating dense mats of biomass (Blood 2001). This may provide shelter for species such as rabbits or foxes but there is not evidence of this reported.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Interfered with harvesting in an organic soybean crop when trailed as a cover crop as it twined around the soybean plant (Hively and Cox 2001). However it is not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: There is no evidence reported of this species being host to a pest or disease of an agricultural crop.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in Spring” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 2001)

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: 6 hours of light or less cause seeds to germinate (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). “A large amount of stubble can…[shade] arrowhead seeds, slowing germination” (RIRDC, 2000). Require light to germinate (Flower et al, 1999). Less than 10% of seed germinated without light, compared to up to 50-65% with light (Flower et al, 1998). Can establish under moderate cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Usually found in warm-temperate shallowly flooded or marshy areas associated with rivers and streams…drainage ditches, rice fields and permanent swamps associated with irrigation drainage systems.” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). All evidence points towards highly disturbed aquatic environments, such as irrigation channels and rice fields.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: “Emergent, broad-leafed aquatic plant” (Flower et al, 1999)

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Spoonbills and carp have been observed feeding on the plant. Either or both of these animals may have been the cause of the plants disappearance on river flats along the River Murray but this is not certain (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). The weed may still persist.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Rice has been observed outgrowing S. montevidensis in California (Gibson et al, 2001) however Australian rice yields can be reduced by up to 75% (Flower et al, 1999). The ability of rice to out compete arrowhead depends on when it is sown after flooding (Flower et al, 2002). Equal competitiveness of same life forms.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: One study showed that draining rice bays for up to two weeks killed very young arrowhead seedlings, but didn’t kill more mature seed-grown plants (Flower et al, 1999). Survive in temporary dry ditches (Sagliocco & Bruzzese, 2005). Killed by frost and most plants killed by drought (Kaul, 1985 Angelo & Boufford (2005) record it growing in tidal mud flats of estuaries and salt marshes.  The rosette form may be able to tolerate submersion for years (MGW, nd). As a low growing aquatic species (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) will not be affected by fire. Tolerance of fire, waterlogging and salinity, but not frost or drought (severe enough to dry out damp areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed and rhizomes” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992)

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Can produce many thousands of seeds per plant (MGW, nd). 414,000 achenes per plant per year (Kaul, 1985).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “The viability of …seeds does not reduce significantly after three years in the soil, suggesting that they remain viable for many years after being deposited” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). Kaul (1985) found that scarified seed viability reduced to 50% after 7 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Species forms dense monocultures, as seen in photograph (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Seeds germinate in spring and plants mature during summer, producing flowers from January to March. Seeds mature in autumn” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Kaul (1985) describes S. calycina (syn. for subspecies ) as a fruit-bearing annual. “Two subspecies recorded in Australia, one perennial (ssp. Montevidensis and one annual ssp. calycina)” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft).  Produces propagules in under a year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Under Australian field conditions, spread of arrowhead is by seed. They move in water along channels and ditches and also in mud sticking to hooves and fur of animals…Some seeds are eaten by ducks and believed to be viable when excreted” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Under Australian field conditions, spread of arrowhead is by seed. They move in water along channels and ditches and also in mud sticking to hooves and fur of animals” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) “due to a slightly sticky surface” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft).  “The achenes produced by Altismataceous species have a pericarp that provides buoyancy…those of S. montevidensis float for a little under two weeks.” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km by sticking to animal fur, or transport by water.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An emergent aquatic perennial herb. Inhabits shallowly flooded (to 45 cm) or marshy areas associated with rivers and streams. In south eastern Australia it is commonly found in drainage ditches and permanent swamps associated with irrigation and drainage systems (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Would not impede human access to waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Although most commonly found in drainage ditches and irrigation canals, it has also been found in a number of creeks in Victoria including Nine Mile Creek, Wunghnu and Bullock Creek near the junction of the Oven and Murray Rivers. In drain and irrigation channels it can form dense infestations that block the flow of water (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Its presence may affect water-based activities such as fishing or swimming.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No prickles, spines or burrs described (Aston, 1973). Sagittaria species are eaten by ducks and sometimes humans, suggesting that they are not toxic either (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: An aquatic species (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Not likely to impact on sites of cultural significance.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: "Sagittaria forms extensive infestations in shallow waterways, seriously restricting water flow and increasing sedimentation, thus aggravating flooding." (BPRC, 2004). An emergent aquatic, firmly rooted.  “Dense infestations block channels and drainage ditches” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). “Arrowhead can severely retard and completely choke water flow in irrigation channels” (Gunasekera & Krake, 2001).  Serious impacts to both surface and subsurface water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: “Decaying plant material contributes to water pollution and sedimentation and may also increase the risk of algal bloom and microbial activity” (Sagliocco & Bruzesse, 2005). Likely to cause noticeable but minor effects on dissolved O2.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In New Zealand it, "forms extensive infestations in shallow waterways, seriously restricting water flow and increasing sedimentation, thus aggravating flooding" (BPRC, 2004). Increased chance of flooding would create the potential for large-scale soil movement with minor off-site implications.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Where it occurs in drainage channels and irrigation canals (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992) little other vegetation would normally exist. Infestations of arrowhead would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species (Flower et al, 1999). Fire not applicable in this ecosystem.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
Basin=East Gippsland- Cann River (ISC=Excellent); CMA=East Gippsland; CLIMATE=VH. 
“S. calycina [syn. S. montevidensis ssp. calycina] is very abundant in suitable years, sometimes forming vast beds” (Kaul, 1985). Can displace native water plants which occupy the same habitat (ESC, 2005). Able to form monocultures displacing all species within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)i.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)ii.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “S. calycina [syn. S. montevidensis ssp. calycina] is very abundant in suitable years, sometimes forming vast beds” (Kaul, 1985). Can displace native water plants which occupy the same habitat (ESC, 2005).  Able to form monocultures.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Has a negative impact on native species and on the integrity of natural waterways, such as the waterways of the Barmah-Millewa forest, where it has been recorded” (GMW). Large populations obstruct the movement of wildlife and fish (Sagliocco & Bruzzese, 2005). May reduce habitat and have a minor effect on native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Spoonbills have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). The plant may provide an alternate source of food.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No prickles, spines or burrs described (Aston, 1973). Spoonbills and carp have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Not harmful to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Carp (considered a serious aquatic pest) have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Carp (considered a serious aquatic pest) have been observed feeding on the plant Parson & Cuthberston (1992) and dense infestations (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) may also provide harbor for them.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Grain yields were not affected by Californian arrowhead densities up to 200 plants/m2 (Gibson et al, 2001). “Arrowhead reduced the yield of rice by up to 75% if completely unchecked” (Flower, Pratley & Slater, 1999). The ability of rice to out compete arrowhead depends on when it is sown after flooding (Flower et al, 2002). This species has the capacity to have a serious impact on rice yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Weed senesced well before rice maturity” (Gibson et al, 2001). Unlikely to impact on the quality of the produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Whilst this species can “severely retard and completely choke water flow in irrigation channels” (Gunasekera & Krake, 2001), it is the responsibility of the water service provider to control the weed (GMW) so is unlikely to have an impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Land use may need to change from rice growing to another crop (see Q. 19), however, this is unlikely to cause a reduction in income.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: One study showed that draining rice bays for up to two weeks killed very young arrowhead seedlings, but didn’t kill more mature seed-grown plants (Flower et al, 1999). Controlling arrowhead this way may cause a minor increase to the costs of harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Harbours several important plant viruses (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: The species is not reported to have any additional requirements for propagation unless the seed has been stored and other similar Ligustrum sp. have been found to germinate on a seasonal basis (Blood 2001; Burrows & Kohen 1983; PFAF 2007). The species is therefore considered to be capable of germinating on a seasonal basis.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: The species can establish under moderate shade conditions (Grubb et al 1996).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: The species invades riparian vegetation (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992). The species is therefore capable of establishing in minor disturbed environments.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; a shrub to small tree (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: A similar species, L. lucidum is suspected of having allelopathic properties (Blood 2001).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Obeso & Grubb (1993) found that this species is able to produce fruit after being defoliated to some extent.
The species is toxic to cattle, sheep and horses (Everist 1974). The species is therefore considered not to be a preferred browse species, and if it is browsed to still be able to sexually reproduce.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: The species is reported to have a medium growth rate (PFAF 2007). As it is also reported to crowd out native species and form dense thickets it is considered to have a growth rate similar to that of other of other competitive shrub species (Weber 2003).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Can tolerate drought stress (Tattini et al 2004).
Tolerant of frost and can tolerate maritime exposure (PFAF 2007).
Able to grow at least partly in waterlogged soil (Obeso & Grubb 1993).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The species is reported to reproduce sexually producing seeds and vegetatively via suckers (Weber 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Unknown; Other Ligustrum sp. have been reported to produce more than 2000 propagules per season.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: The species seeds are considered to loose viability before five years (Shelton & Cain 2002).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Unknown; Other Ligustrum sp.  have been reported to live for more than 100 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown; Other Ligustrum sp. have been reported to take four years before flowering.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The species has been spread by bird dispersed seed and commercially as an ornamental (Blood 2001; Weber 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Dispersal of more than 300 m of this species has been observed (Debussche & Isenmann 1994). The seeds of other Ligustrum sp. however have been reported to be dispersed by currawongs which have a dispersal range in excess of 1 km (Bass 1996; Panetta 2000; Spennemann & Allen 2000).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Reported to invade riparian habitats, the species can form dense impenetrable thickets (Weber 2003). This species could therefore pose a major impediment to access to waterways and require significant works to provide access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: While the species has not been reported to impact on tourism or recreation, its ability to form dense thickets and its toxic nature however could mean it has the potential to do so.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
The fruits and leaves of this species are toxic and in severe cases of the plant being eaten death has occurred (Everist 1974).
Can cause allergies.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Unknown.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Unknown; a similar species can reportedly impact on the flow of water along drainage lines (Blood 2001, Muyt 2001).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Chemicals released from the leaves of the similar species L. sinense have been reported to impact on aquatic macro invertebrates (Llewellyn 2005). The species does occur in riparian areas, and could have some impact on water quality by changing light levels and nutrient imputes. There has been however no quantifiable reports of this species impacting upon water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The species has been found to not to have a penetrating root system and while the species can have a large root system it is largely shallow (Jia-rong et al 2007). Therefore areas invaded by the species are viewed to have a moderate probability of large scale soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The species is reported to form dense thickets and crowd out the existing species (Weber 2003). This is similar to other Ligustrum species which have been reported to cause a reduction in biomass of the lower strata when this occurs (Muyt 2001; Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999). Invasion by the species is therefore considered to result in a net increase in biomass due to the significant increase in the middle strata.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: The similar species L. lucidum is reported to reduce the biomass within the grass/herb layer which can limit a fire from spreading, instead in SE Queensland during dry winters the species can defoliate which allows a hot fire to be carried (Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999). As L. vulgare is also able to form dense stands within the shrub layer it is thought to have the same potential of altering both fire intensity and timing.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Damp Forest (E); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Strzelecki Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is able to displace native species and form dense thickets within the understorey (Weber 2003). The species is therefore able to dominate a single layer and cause displacement of species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Wet Forest (D); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Strzelecki Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is able to displace native species and form dense thickets within the understorey (Weber 2003). The species is therefore able to dominate a single layer and cause displacement of species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Forest (LC); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Wilsons Promontory; VH CLIMATE potential.
The species is able to displace native species and form dense thickets within the understorey (Weber 2003). The species is therefore able to dominate a single layer and cause displacement of species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: The species is able to displace native species and form dense thickets within the understorey (Weber 2003). The species could therefore impact upon more than 605 of the flora strata, displacing species of the middle and lower strata and potentially preventing the regeneration of canopy species.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The increased food privet species provide through the fruit load supports increased populations of aggressive bird species such as currowongs (Blood 2001; Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999). This then has the potential to impact on other bird species populations, quantitative evidence of the impact on such species has not been reported however.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Being a large fruit producing shrub, the species is likely to provide some assistance in either food or shelter to desirable species (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Reported toxic to horses, cattle, sheep and people and can result in death (Everist 1974). There has been no evidence reported on if this species is toxic to native fauna and if so to what extent it impacts on them.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Blackbirds and starlings are also reported to eat fruit of other Ligustrum species (Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The species is not reported to provide shelter for any one pest species, however it is reported to form dense thickets (Weber 2003). Therefore there is the potential for the species to provide cover for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: The species is reported to be toxic and potentially fatal to horses, cattle, and sheep (Everist 1974). It is unknown to what extent this species could impact on yield, it is suspected however to be minor.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Honey collected from privet species is reported to smell like fish (Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999). It is unknown to what extent this species could impact on product quality, it is suspected however to be minor.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The species has been used widely as an ornamental (Blood 2001; Weber 2003). It is therefore unlikely to have any significant impact upon land values.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Unknown however as the species is considered to be largely an environmental weed this is unlikely.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Unknown however as the species is considered to be largely an environmental weed this is unlikely.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: The species can be a host of Plum pox virus (Pol�k 2006).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Germination generally takes place following rainfall and can be quite prolific when fire or mechanical disturbance create bare ground’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Opportunistic germinator.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Requires light to establish (Doussi & Thanos 1997).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘ .. occasionally found in swamps but mainly occurs in highly disturbed areas such as roadsides, railway lines, fire breaks and walking trails ’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Can establish in minor disturbed natural ecosystem.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial soft-wooded shrub (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Life form – other

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: ‘.. known to release substances that inhibit the germination of nearby plants’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Allelopathic properties seriously affecting some plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Known to be toxic to stock (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Favoured by heavy grazing as not eaten by animals/ insects.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Insufficient documented evidence to determine growth rate.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘ ..can grow and flower in saline conditions’. Has been found in swamps – tolerant to waterlogging (Curadi et al 2005). May be susceptible to drought and / or frost but insufficient information.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by seed only. Not known if self or cross-pollination or both (CRC for Australian Weed Management).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘.. a prolific seed producer’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘By estimation a medium sized plant may produce an average of 600-700 flowers per year each giving rise to about 50 viable seeds’ (Mifsud 2005).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Seeds of the closely related stinkwort Dittrichia graveolens are viable for about three years’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). No documented evidence on viability of D. viscosa propagules.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Perennial shrub. Plant produces viable propagules for more than 3 years (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Insufficient information to determine time to reach reproductive maturity.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Spread by wind, water, attached to machinery (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Very light wind dispersed seeds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Seed dispersal is aided by the ‘pappus’ .. which catches the wind and can assist flotation’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Shrub that grows between 1 to 1.5 metres tall and 1 metre wide (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Likely that the weed would have a low nuisance value.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: In WA it has been found on walking trails. ‘.. infestations of false yellowhead would detract from the aesthetic and natural values of bushland and could reduce its tourism appeal’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Likely that some recreational uses affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: ‘It can also cause contact dermatitis in people’. ‘ stems and leaves are covered with glandular hairs which exude a sticky foul-smelling oil [which] can cause allergic reactions’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Toxic properties at most times of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Due to the areas in which D. viscosa is known to grow, it is unlikely to have an effect on cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘.. roots can be quite substantial, even in small plants’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Occasionally found in swamp areas but assume low probability of large scale soil movement as shrub grows to 1 m wide and doesn’t leave bare soil exposed.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Has a ‘high fresh biomass production’ (Curadi et al 2005). Likely that the biomass would increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No data available on changes to fire regime. Assume no effect.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains Grassy Woodland (E), CMA=Glenelg-Hopkins, Bioreg.=Dundas Tablelands, CLIMATE=VH. 
Grows in swamps, roadsides, waste places. Occurs with other shrubs and ground layers. Alellopathic effects inhibit other plants from germinating but do not kill off existing vegetation (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Minor displacement of some donminant species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riparian Scrub (D), CMA=Glenelg-Hopkins, Bioreg.=Glenelg Plain, CLIMATE=VH. 
Grows in swamps, roadsides, waste places. Occurs with other shrubs and ground layers. Alellopathic effects inhibit other plants from germinating but do not kill off existing vegetation (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Minor displacement of some donminant species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian Forest(LC), CMA=West Gippsland, Bioreg.=Highlands- Southern Fall, CLIMATE=VH. 
Grows in swamps, roadsides, waste places. Occurs with other shrubs and ground layers. Alellopathic effects inhibit other plants from germinating but do not kill off existing vegetation (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Minor displacement of some donminant species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Grows in swamps, roadsides, waste places. Occurs with other shrubs and ground layers. Alellopathic effects inhibit other plants from germinating but do not kill off existing vegetation (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Likely to have a minor effect on strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information available.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Usually occurs in highly disturbed areas such as roadsides, railway lines, fire breaks and walking trails (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Although has allelopathic properties that inhibit the germination of nearby plants, unlikely to cause a reduction in habitat, food or shelter.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: ‘Stock that eat the flower heads of D. graveolens can develop enteritis ...thought that D. viscosa would have similar impacts on grazing animals’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Toxic with the potential to harm fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not a known food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbour for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not a weed of cropping or pastures.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping or pastures.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not likely to have an effect on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed not likely to cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping or pastures.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for diseases of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in early summer, however most reproduction is from the crowns and rhizomes during late spring and summer (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Requires natural seasonal disturbances, e.g. warm temperatures, for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Habitat information suggests it occurs primarily in open areas, e.g. pasture, roadsides (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992, Walsh & Entwisle 1994) and is documented to require a ‘full sun’ position (Dave's Garden 2008). Appears to need more specific requirements to establish, e.g. open space and access to light.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Appears to establish in areas that have a greater impact by humans, e.g. roadsides, urban & coastal areas, pasture (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992, Harden 1993). ‘Neglected pastures are invaded by longstyle feather grass (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992)’.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Rhizomatous, erect densely tussock-forming perennial grass 30-70 cm high (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992, Walsh & Entwisle 1994). Lifeform: Grass

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No reference to allelopathy was found within the reasonably extensive literature of this species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Young shoots may be eaten but the long serrated leaves of mature plants are unpalatable and rarely grazed by stock (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Not favoured as fodder by stock (Walsh & Entwisle 1994).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Establishment is slow, however once established can dominate infested pasture (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992).
Rate of growth and how it compares to other species of the same lifeform not clear from available information.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Displays tolerance to drought, as native to semi-arid areas, North Africa & the Arabian Peninsular (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992), and described occurring in ‘dry places (Tutin et al 1980). Some tolerance to salt spray, as occurs in coastal areas and on islands (Edgar & Connor 2000, Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992) and tolerates temperatures to -1oC (Dave's Garden 2008). May be tolerant of water logging, occurring in areas of run off, along
creeks and riverbanks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992), and fire, being rhizomatous (Walsh & Entwisle 1994).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproducing by seed and from rhizomes (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Both vegetative and sexual reproduction.
Some references suggest establishment by seed is uncommon, with seedlings rarely surviving (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992), while others indicate it is spreading quickly via seed (North West Weeds 2006).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Prolific seeder (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Images (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992, P121) indicate could produce greater than 2,000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Propagule longevity not found documented.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Perennial (Walsh & Entwisle 1994). Strong rhizomatous growth often produces large dense clumps, increasing the size and density of existing colonies. Most new plants establish vegetatively with the development of shoots along the rhizomes (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Extensive vegetative reproduction indicates colonies are likely to be self sustaining and/or produce propagules for 10+ years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Seed germination occurs in early summer and flowering in late Summer (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992), presumed to be the year after germination as establishment is described as slow (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). However, most reproduction is via vegetative means, with new shoots developing along rhizomes in the following Spring/Summer (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Time to reproductive maturity appears to be greater than 1 year but less
than 2 years.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘Major spread is the result of cultivation and road grading. Some seeds adhere to wool and fur of animals plus clothing bags and other fibrous material, and wind and water dispersal can occur (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992)’.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: The above dispersal mechanisms (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992) could spread propagules 200+ m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Tussock-forming perennial grass 30-70 cm high (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992), likely to have minimal impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: As a tussock forming grass (Walsh & Entwisle 1994) it could be mistaken for a native species and not likely to be obvious as a weed to the ‘average visitor’.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No information was found to suggest this species possesses properties injurious to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Not documented as having an impact on cultural sites or infrastructure, and as a grass to 70 cm high (Walsh & Entwisle 1994), it is likely to have little effect on the aesthetics or structure of sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: A terrestrial species (Carr et al 1992), so no likely effect on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: A terrestrial species (Carr et al 1992), so no likely effect on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Rhizomatous, densely tussock-forming perennial grass (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992, Walsh & Entwisle 1994), with characteristics suggesting it would decrease the probability of soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: As a tussock-forming perennial grass to 70 cm high (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992), it is similar in stature to some native tussock grasses so, ‘direct replacement of biomass’ is likely.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: No information was found to indicate it would have any significant affect on fire regime of habitats in which it occurs and would likely replace other grasses that have similar flammability.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC = Plains Grassland (E); CMA = Corangamite; Bioregion = Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
‘It may occasionally become an environmental weed of grassy woodlands and grasslands (South East Weeds 2008)’, and can occur in coastal areas and along creeks and river banks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). It forms spreading clumps (Kleinschmidt & Johnson 1977), and is described as being a ‘potential threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria (Carr et al 1992)’. However, no information was found on the level of impact it is having, or could have, on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC = Riverine Grassy woodland (D); CMA = North Central; Bioregion = Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential. 
‘It may occasionally become an environmental weed of grassy woodlands and grasslands (South East Weeds 2008)’, and can occur in coastal areas and along creeks and river banks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). It forms spreading clumps (Kleinschmidt & Johnson 1977), and is described as being a ‘potential threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria (Carr et al 1992)’. However, no information was found on the level of impact it is having, or could have, on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC = Coastal Tussock Grassland (LC); CMA = West Gippsland; Bioregion = Gippsland Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
‘It may occasionally become an environmental weed of grassy woodlands and grasslands (South East Weeds 2008)’, and can occur in coastal areas and along creeks and river banks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). It forms spreading clumps (Kleinschmidt & Johnson 1977), and is described as being a ‘potential threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria (Carr et al 1992)’. However, no information was found on the level of impact it is having, or could have, on EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘It may occasionally become an environmental weed of grassy woodlands and grasslands (South East Weeds 2008)’, and can occur in coastal areas and along creeks and river banks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). It forms spreading clumps (Kleinschmidt & Johnson 1977), and is described as being a ‘potential threat to one or more vegetation formations in Victoria (Carr et al 1992)’. However, no information was found on the level of impact it is having, or could have, on the structure of vegetation communities.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No reference to its impact on threatened flora was found in the literature.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: There is no indication this species possess any properties hazardous to fauna, but also no information of the impact this weed has on faunal habitat. However, effects to non-threatened fauna are likely to be minor as this species often invades disturbed areas (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992) that are already likely of poor habitat quality.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Young shoots may be eaten but the long serrated leaves of mature plants are unpalatable and rarely grazed by stock (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). May provide some assistance as a food source to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no suggestion that this species possess any properties injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Young shoots may be eaten but the long serrated leaves of mature plants are unpalatable and rarely grazed by stock (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). It may provide some food source to grazing pest animals but this is likely to be minimal and was not found documented in the literature.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: As a tussock-forming perennial grass 30-70 cm high (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992) does not have the capacity to provide harbour to serious pests, but because it invades urban and agricultural areas (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992) may provide harbour for minor pest animals such as introduced rodents.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Produces large dense clumps, which over time tend to dominate infested pastures and reduce the available grazing area (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). ‘Chokes out useful grasses (North West Weeds 2006)’ and ‘being unpalatable reduces carrying capacity (South East Weeds 2008)’. Because not specified, a moderate level of impact is assumed.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Described as a contaminant in wool (North West Weeds 2006), however, the level of impact on agricultural quality is not clear from available information.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Summer cultivation gives effective control but must be repeated regularly until weed is eliminated. A single cultivation only, spreads rhizomes to clean areas (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Not specifically documented, but unlikely to affect land value, as effective control is achievable using normal farm management practises.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Summer cultivation gives effective control but must be repeated regularly until weed is eliminated (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). Not specifically documented, but unlikely to cause a change in priority of land use, as effective control is achievable using normal farm management practises.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Summer cultivation gives effective control but must be repeated regularly until weed is eliminated. A single cultivation only, spreads rhizomes to clean areas (Parsons & Cuthbertson 1992). The need for repeated control, and thus increased time and labour costs, may lead to a minor increase in overall production costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not described as an alternative host or vector for diseases of agriculture.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: The species can form dense thickets in riparian areas (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). As it is a tree which can grow to 10 m and with its ability to reproduce vegetatively significant works would be required to provide access to the waterway.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Unknown.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
The leaves of the species contain triterpenoids which have been shown to cause potent and persistent irritation (Saeed & Sabir 2002).  The leaves contain two furocoumarin compounds which can cause skin irritation (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky
2000).  Anaphylaxis has been reported after the fruit of the species has been eaten (Gandolfo, Baeza & De Barrio 2001). Half ripe figs are reported to be poisonous (Polunin 1969). The species therefore has toxic properties through out the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: In Europe fig trees have been reported growing naturally on walls and in the stone work of ancient towers (Lisci & Pacini 1994). As could have a structural effect on the building.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Reported to invade and dominate riparian forests (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).  Unknown impact on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Reported to invade and dominate riparian forests (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).  Unknown impact on flow, being deciduous it could alter nutrient cycling and result in increased light levels during winter.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The fig tree is a fast growing tree (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).  Likely to therefore be able to bind the soil to some extent and reduce the probability of large scale movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: A tree to 10 m Ficus carica is reported to from dense thickets replacing much of the existing vegetation (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Therefore invasion by the fig tree would see direct replacement of biomass or possibly some net increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Riparian Woodland (E); CMA= North Central; Bioreg= Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Reported to invade and dominate riparian forests (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). This would result in major displacement of other canopy species since it is said to dominate.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Grassy Riverine Forest (D); CMA= North Central; Bioreg= Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Reported to invade and dominate riparian forests (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). This would result in major displacement of other canopy species since it is said to dominate.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Riparian Scrub (LC); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Greater Grampians; VH CLIMATE potential.
Reported to invade and dominate riparian forests and streamside habitats (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). This would result in major displacement of other canopy species since it is said to dominate.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: A tree to 10 m Ficus carica is reported to from dense thickets excluding most of the existing flora (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Therefore the species is capable of major displacement within all strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: There is no specific evidence of the species effect on fauna species. The species could significantly alter the habitat, potentially both structurally and in floristic composition as it is reported to form dense thickets excluding much of the other flora (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Such habitat change would have a flow on effect to the existing fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The fruit would likely be eaten by generalist frugivores.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The leaves of the species contain triterpenoids which have been shown to cause potent and persistent irritation (Saeed & Sabir 2002). Unknown how this could effect animals in the wild.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: In Europe the species is reported to be able to produce three fruit crops through out the year, in spring, over summer and into autumn and in winter. The fruit is eaten by foxes (Lisci & Pacini 1994).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments:
A tree species that can grow to 10 m and is reported to form dense thickets (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
Could provide habitat for pest species, however there is no reported evidence.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not reported as a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Can be effected by root knot nematodes, dried fruit beetle and Queensland fruit fly (NSW Agriculture 2002).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Flowers January to April (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996). In order to sprout it needs open space and sunshine with a warm temperature (Medio ambient Canarias). Under conditions of low water availability, invasive fountain grass had lower seedling survival compared with the native grass (Goergen and Daehler, 2001). Germination requires natural seasonal disturbance such as seasonal rainfall.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: P. setaceum productivity decreases with decreasing light availability (Litton et al, 2006) hence survives well in open sites. Requires full sun but tolerates partial shade (Floridata). However under conditions of low water availability, invasive fountain grass had lower seedling survival compared with the native grass (Goergen and Daehler, 2001). The rate of invasiveness and establishment is somewhat influenced by the amount of rainfall and moisture (Poulin et al, 2005). However it is a species that is native in arid areas. Furthermore in the United States it is limited to fairly dry areas where the median rainfall is less than 127 cm (NCPI). Making it a known serious seed in many dry habitats in the States (NPCI). In its native it establishes in open, scrubby habitats (Flordata). P. setaceum requires open space and access to direct light for successful establishment.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
In its native range P. setaceum establishes in open, scrubby habitats (Flordata). Outside its native range P. setaceum is a weed of pastures and alongside railway lines and roads (Johnson) and can grow in rock crevices and pavement cracks (CDFA). It grows in tropical to semi arid areas and prefers exposed, dry habitats, particularly rocky areas but can also grow in sandy soils such as coastal grasslands and coastal sage scrub (Johnson; CDFA;
Clayton, 1970). In southern California it invades grasslands, shrublands warm deserts, canyons and roadsides (NPCI, CDFA). The species is able to establish in minimal disturbed natural ecosystems such as grasslands.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial grass up to 1 m high (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996; Poulin et al, 2005)

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: In all of the literature there was no reference made to allelopathic properties of this plant.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Fountain grass is of little grazing value due to its coarse rough leaves (Johnson). A study conducted by Blackmore and Vitousek (2000) investigated cattle grazed P.setaceum. In Hawaii cattle eat fountain grass only when no other grass is available (California Uni). The grass is fed to horses during winter, although not a good pasture grass, still it is eaten by goats and camels (Sherif and Siddiqi, 1988; NPCI). The species is consumed but not a preferred species.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Growth rate of the species has been described as being fast (Gilman, 1999) that can live to up to 20 years (Johnson). Fountain grass out competes and grows faster than some native grass (Litton et al, 2006). It is an aggressive species that out competes native plants (NPCI). The species exhibits rapid growth rate that will exceed most other species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of high temperatures, high humidity, high wind, drought and acidic to alkaline soils (Floridata).
Extremely drought tolerant, established plants thrive in areas where annual rainfall is less than 127 cm of rain annually (Floridata, NPCI). However the species does not survive prolonged low temperatures (Drake, 1994) and does not tolerate saline conditions (CDFA). The species is well adapted to fire and can recover to pre burn density (D’Antonio and Vitousek, 1992). P. setaceum is highly tolerant of at least two and susceptible to two.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Can reproduce asexually and reproduce by seeds following pollination (Simpson and Bashaw, 1969) by either fertilized or unfertilized seeds (Simpson and Bashaw, 1969). The species can be propagated from seed and it will self sow in warm climates. Most cultivars do not produce seeds; they are propagated by dividing the root clumps (Floridata). The plant can reproduce by seed naturally and be cultivated vegetatively.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: An average of 100 seeds per plant was measured in a trial conducted by Poulin et al (2007) under greenhouse conditions.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
Seeds that were kept in the laboratory for 18 months decreased in viability from 80 to 44 percent (Tunison, 1992).
Can remain viable in soil for up to six years or longer (Tunison, 1992; NPCI, PCA, 2005). Therefore greater than 25% of seeds can survive 5-10 years in the soil.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: P. setaceum can form monospecific stands (Tunison, 1992) furthermore individual plants may live up to 20 years or more (CDFA).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: No information exists on time to reproductive maturity on this species.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Primarily wind dispersed (NPCI). Mainly spread by humans and wind, also animals and water (Poulin et al 2007). It is readily dispersed by vehicles, humans, wind, water and possibly birds (Tunison, 1992). The propagules are spread by wind, water and possibly animals and also humans.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Seeds can be dispersed greater distances by water, vehicles, livestock and humans (NPCI). New infestations were seen to establish one quarter of a mile upstream from other infestations (SDCP). Therefore it is very likely that at least one propagule will disperse greater than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Robust tussock forming perennial about 1 m high with creeping underground stems with inflorescences 30 cm long (Richardson et al, 2006). Densely tufted perennial grass growing to 1.5 m (Groves et al, 2005, Johnson) that can form dense monoculture stands that can exclude all other plants (Johnson; Poulin et al, 2005). Once the plant forms dense infestations it is likely to be of high nuisance value impeding both pedestrian and vehicular access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Flower heads are 8-30 cm long (Walsh and Enwisle, 1996) and are a long feathery spike which makes it attractive for garden cultivations (Groves et al, 2005). In a dry environment it remains attractive and in humidity it flowers constantly and bears fruits throughout the whole year (Medio ambiente Canarias, 1999). It makes a dramatic statement anywhere in the landscape (Floridata). Furthermore it is a densely tufted perennial grass growing to 1.5 m (Groves et al, 2005, Johnson) that can form dense stands that can exclude all other plants (Johnson). Its attractive flowerhead is obvious and is likely to have major impacts on aesthetics, however visitors may judge the display as aesthetically pleasing. Its ability to dominate and densely invade landscapes indicates that the plant is likely to have significant impact on recreation activities if invading such areas.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No reports of the plant being injurious to people (Walsh and Enwisle, 1996, Richardson et al, 2006).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Flowerheads are 8-30 cm long (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) and are a long feathery spike which makes it attractive for garden cultivations (Groves et al, 2005). In a dry environment it remains attractive and in humidity it flowers constantly and bears fruits throughout the whole year (Medio ambiente Canarias, 1999). It makes a dramatic statement anywhere in the landscape (Floridata). On this basis infestation of this plant on cultural sites it is likely to have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: This species is terrestrial it is unlikely to have an affect on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: This species is terrestrial it is unlikely to have an affect on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The species is rhizomatous, forming large tussocks (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) however it is shallow rooted (Litton et al, 2006). The plant has been noted as being good for erosion control (Floridata) and has been used for soil stabilisation (Johnson). However the plant is an aggressive species that can displace native species forming dense stands (Johnson) but maintains soil integrity by replacing existing species.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments:
In a study conducted by Litton et al, (2006) the site used was formerly a forested site that has been converted to P. setaceum dominated grassland. The presence of a dense P. setaceum understorey will lead to the eventual conversion of remaining forest fragments to grasslands without active control of P. setaceum (Litton et al, 2006).
Formerly extensive Heteropogon grasslands have been reduced to remnants surrounded by Pennisetum (Carino and Daehler, 2002). The species can destroy dry forests through increased fire frequency (Poulin et al, 2005). Therefore, this species has the capacity to significantly decrease the biomass of areas by replacing forested systems with grasslands.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Alters natural fire regime in Hawaii, it raises fuel load, which increases the intensity and spread of a fire subsequently threatening native flora (NPCI). Fountain grass has been noted to produce 51% more total biomass than native Hawaiian grass (California Uni) hence increasing fuel loadings (Tunison, 1992). Subsequently increasing the intensity and spread of a fire (Lloyd, 1992; PCA, 2005). P. setaceum produces large quantities of fine fuels that promote fire (Litton et al, 2006). The natural fire regime in Hawaii has been markedly altered by the rapid spread of alien grasses particularly P. setaceum amongst others (Smith and Tunison, 1992). Fountain grass turns brown and dry in the winter and becomes extremely flammable (Floridata). Dense stands are extreme fire hazard. By enhancing the fuel load it endangers native plant communities that are not fire tolerant (California Uni). Fires fuelled by fountain grass impact on ground- nesting birds and terrestrial animals as well (California Uni). P. setaceum is likely to greatly change the frequency and/or intensity of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains Grassland (E) ; CMA=Mallee; Bioregion= Lowan Mallee; VH CLIMATE potential
The plant typically forms dense monospecific stands in the understorey that can exclude all other plants (Johnson; Tunison, 1992). Has exhibited universally superior competitive performance compared to native species (Daehler, 2003). The presence of a dense P. setaceum understorey will lead to the eventual conversion of remaining forest fragments to grasslands without active control of P. setaceum (Litton et al, 2006). The species is aggressive and extremely competitive and is likely to dominant and displace existing vegetation in the lower stratum.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Shallow Sands Woodland (D) ; CMA=Wimmera; Bioregion= Lowan Mallee; VH CLIMATE potential
The plant typically forms dense monospecific stands in the understorey that can exclude all other plants (Johnson; Tunison, 1992). Has exhibited universally superior competitive performance compared to native species (Daehler, 2003). The presence of a dense P. setaceum understorey will lead to the eventual conversion of remaining forest fragments to grasslands without active control of P. setaceum (Litton et al, 2006). The species is aggressive and extremely competitive and is likely to dominant and displace existing vegetation in the lower stratum.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Coastal Dune Scrub (C) ; CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioregion= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential
The plant typically forms dense monospecific stands in the understorey that can exclude all other plants (Johnson; Tunison, 1992). Has exhibited universally superior competitive performance compared to native species (Daehler, 2003). The presence of a dense P. setaceum understorey will lead to the eventual conversion of remaining forest fragments to grasslands without active control of P. setaceum (Litton et al, 2006). The species is aggressive and extremely competitive and is likely to dominant and displace existing vegetation in the lower stratum.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: It is a highly aggressive, fire adapted coloniser that readily out competes native plants, prevents further regeneration of native trees and rapidly re establishes after burning (NPCI; Litton et al, 2006). The plant typically forms dense monospecific stands in the understorey that can exclude all other plants (Johnson; Tunison, 1992) and has done so in Hawaiian lowland dry forests (Litton et al, 2006). Has exhibited universally superior competitive performance compared to native species (Daehler, 2003). As a result enhancing fuel load thus endangering native woody plant communities it invades (Tunison, 1992). Hence altering existing native ecosystem structure. It is likely that the strong negative impacts associated with invasive grasses are likely to impact on the long term structure of native tree populations (Litton et al, 2006).Infestations of this species are likely to have a major effect on <60% of the floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The effect on threatened flora is unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The plant typically forms dense monospecific stands in the understorey that can exclude all other plants (Johnson; Tunison, 1992). The presence of a dense P. setaceum understorey will lead to the eventual conversion of remaining forest fragments to grasslands without active control of  P. setaceum (Litton et al, 2006). Translating to a loss of habitat for many terrestrial and avian species. Fires fuelled by fountain grass impact on ground- nesting birds and terrestrial animals as well (California Uni). It is eaten by some animals but not preferred, therefore infestations do not provide an alternative food resource (Johnson; California Uni; Sherif and Siddiqi, 1988; NPCI ). However the prominent seed heads are likely to be a good food source for birds. Therefore significantly modifying, permanently changing or eliminating habitat structure and food resources for animals subsequently affecting faunal populations.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No information exists in the literature that outlines the benefits this plant has on indigenous fauna. However the prominent seed heads are likely to be a good food source for birds. Dense monospecific stands (Johnson; Tunison, 1992) are likely to provide suitable habitat.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No reports on the plant being injurious to fauna (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996; Tunison, 1992).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The prominent seed heads (Walsh and Entwisle, 1996) are likely to be a good food source for pest birds. However little has been documented on how this plant assists in the success of pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Dense monospecific stands (Johnson; Tunison, 1992) are likely to provide suitable habitat and coverage for pest species like rabbits. However little has been documented on how this plant assists in the success of pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: This species has been noted as an aggressive effect on crops, especially vineyards (Medio ambient Canarias, 1999) overseas. A weed of pasture (Johnson) that is able to form dense monospecific stands that can exclude all other plants (Johnson; Tunison, 1992). It is not a good pasture species (MISC 2003). The impact has not been quantified, however.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Noted as a weed of agriculture, but no impacts on quality were recorded (Johnson; Tunison, 1992; MISC 2003).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Unknown.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Unknown.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Unknown.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Is pest free (Floridata).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Glasshouse trials have shown shoot cuttings can grow at any time of year (Kleinkopf et al, 1976), however, data on seed germination timing is lacking (Detmar 1999). The plant grows in areas with a winter-rainfall regime and in its native range in southern Africa it is absent from summer-rainfall areas (Ross 1994). Possibly the seed responds to seasonal rainfall and spring/summer temperatures, but this is not confirmed. It is a winter-growing perennial (Kleinkopf et al, 1976).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Noted as occurring in open situations (disturbed coastal situations, roadsides, rock outcrop, etc.). Likely to require direct access to sunlight and rainfall.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Commonly recorded as present on disturbed coastal sites (Marchant et al, 1987), roadsides (Rycroft 1956), and stony flats and rocks (Adamson & Salter 1950). West of Melbourne, Victoria it is recorded on roadsides, floodway, paddocks and nature strips (J. Forrester pers. coms). In New South Wales it is abundant around mining sites (Harden 1990). DSE (2003) record G. pubescens var. pubescens spreading in both disturbed and relatively undisturbed areas in a reserve west of Melbourne, while in Bacchus Marsh – Melton district west of Melbourne it is noted to occur in both woodlands and native grasslands (D’Ombrain &  Leversha pers. coms.). For establishment the plant prefers disturbed situations with little or no competition, but evidence in Australia indicates it can also establish in relatively undisturbed areas.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Low-growing perennial herb (Kleinkopf et al, 1976). Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: None described. Little is recorded of this plant.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
The plant is known to accumulate high levels of nitrates and oxalates where nitrogen and water are not limited (Williams 1984). However, within its native range (Sth Africa) the plant is used for fodder during periods of drought. In the U.S., one infestation was regularly mown (Ross 1994), but, “continued to flourish.” Anecdotal evidence from Australia is variable; in Victoria it is recorded that cattle do graze it, but rabbits and sheep avoid the plant (J. Forrester pers. coms), but in South Australia sheep readily graze the plant during summer (Honan
unpublished). Lazarides et al. (1997) note that G. pubescens is susceptible to grazing, but evidence to support this comment is lacking. Either the plant is not consumed or continues to flourish even if grazed

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Kleinkopf et al (1976) record that single plant can spread to a diameter of 2 to 3 meters [sic] in a single year.  
Such growth may exceed that of similar life forms.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Once established it tolerates salt (to seawater concentration under certain conditions) and drought (Kleinkopf et al, 1976). Ross (1994) and Williams (1984) note G. pubescens var. pubescens was tested for fire resistance, however, they offer no information on its tolerance.
Additionally, Kleinkopf et al. (1976) comments on its, “potential use as a fire-retardant ground cover. Highly tolerant of two (drought & salinity), possibly tolerant of fire, may be susceptible to frost.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Sexual reproduction. Flowers are perfect, but data is lacking on self- or cross-pollination.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Ross (1994) notes that a, “single well-established plant may also produce hundreds (if not thousands) of seeds in a single season.”

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: No data

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: No data. Plant is noted as a perennial species (Kleinkopf et al, 1976, Williams 1984). Plants likely to live beyond two years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: No data. The literature suggests that plants flower in the first year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Given that in areas of low rainfall and poor quality soils, the plant does not produce toxic quantities of nitrates or oxalates (Williams 1984); some animals may consume and spread the seed. This is the likely situation in those areas west of Melbourne where the weed is seen as a serious problem. Honan (unpublished) has observed galahs eating the seed of G. pubescens and suggests other bird species may be implicated in seed dispersal. Forrester (pers. coms) also notes that seed is likely distributed by machinery.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Birds and machinery are the most likely long-distance dispersal agents. Propagules easily spread more than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: The plant is a prostrate, spreading herb from 15 to 30 cm high (Kleinkopf et al, 1976). Negligible effect; would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Given this plant is found in the same locations as native saltbushes and herbs, and has a capacity to dominate and exclude those species (R. Reid, pers. coms.), its presence in dense infestations would certainly be noticeable. But such effect may not seriously alter tourism or recreational pursuits. It may impose a moderate negative effect on the aesthetics of an area, but not for the ‘average’ visitor, who may be unaware it is an exotic species.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: It is not known to cause any harm to humans. The plant has no prickles or thorns, nor has it been demonstrated to cause minor conditions such as skin irritations. It is not recorded on common Australian or international web sites that list poisonous plants. Consider low threat.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: No evidence this plant would affect the structure of a cultural site, or have a serious negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: West of Melbourne it is noted to occur as dense populations on the streamsides along stretches of the lower Lerderderg and Werribee Rivers (R. Reid, pers. coms.). Although known to occur in riparian areas, it is a terrestrial plant. There is no evidence is grows into or across the stream.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In New South Wales it is abundant around mining sites (Harden 1990), however, it seems its presence was perhaps due to disturbance by the mining activity rather than deliberate planting. Lazarides et al. (1997) suggests it was used deliberately to stabilise mine tailings, but no direct evidence can be found where G. pubescens has been used for soil stabilisation. The spreading, mat-forming habit of the plant, up to 3 metres in diameter, would provide a good cover for otherwise bare soil. Kleinkopf et al. (1976) notes, “Its widespread, low, dense growth habit makes it capable of protecting hillsides from erosion.” Unlikely to cause or contribute to soil erosion

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Most commonly found in highly disturbed situations such as coastal sites (Marchant et al, 1987), roadsides (Rycroft 1956), and stony flats and rocks (Adamson & Salter 1950). West of Melbourne, Victoria it is recorded on roadsides, flood ways, paddocks and nature strips (J. Forrester pers. coms). This plant exhibits somewhat woody stems and, with strong growth, it is likely to increase biomass slightly.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
The leaves are ‘slightly succulent’ (Richardson et al, 2006) and Ross (1994) and Williams (1984) note G.
pubescens var. pubescens was tested for fire resistance. There is no evidence of its effect on either fire intensity or
frequency. From the scant comments consider it is unlikely to change either.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; CLIMATE potential=VH
