In natural ecosystems it has demonstrated to displace native chenopods and other understorey species. In one area near Bacchus Marsh G. pubescens had displaced all chenopods. It has also been observed in grassland ecosystems affecting the growth of native grasses and forbs (D’Ombrain & Leversha pers. coms.) Potential for major displacement of indicator species within a single layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Riverine chenopod woodland(D); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH 
In natural ecosystems it has demonstrated to displace native chenopods and other understorey species. In one area near Bacchus Marsh G. pubescens had displaced all chenopods. It has also been observed in grassland ecosystems affecting the growth of native grasses and forbs (D’Ombrain & Leversha pers. coms.) Potential for major displacement of indicator species (chenopods) within a single layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Coastal Dune Scrub / Coastal Dune Grassland mosaic (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH
It has also been observed in grassland ecosystems affecting the growth of native grasses and forbs (D’Ombrain & Leversha pers. coms.) In grassland situations, it may have less impact on displacing indicator species, but in dune scrub and with little other competition, it may dominate the landscape.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In natural ecosystems it has demonstrated to displace native chenopods and other understorey species. In one area near Bacchus Marsh G. pubescens had displaced all chenopods. It has also been observed in grassland ecosystems affecting the growth of native grasses and forbs (D’Ombrain & Leversha pers. coms.) Serious impact on lower storey species and possible negative effect on mid-storey species (growth & regeneration).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: G. pubescens is known to occur in habitat occupied by Pterostylis truncata (brittle greenhood), a species listed as threatened under the Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act 1988. Given that G. pubescens has demonstrated capacity to suppress vegetation in the lower layer, it is likely to add further pressure on this endangered orchid species.  Potential to reduce populations of threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The evidence of domesticated animals browsing this species is variable, but it is clear that in some situations G. pubescens develops dangerous levels of nitrates and oxalates that can lead to animal death (Williams 1984). Native chenopod species known to be displaced by G. pubescens are known food sources for birds, wallabies, etc. (Watson 2005). Minor reduction in food source.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: None documented. Under drought conditions it may provide a source of food to fauna; sheep (Honan unpublished) and cattle (Forrester pers. coms.) are known to eat the plant.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: In the U.S., G. pubescens was shown to be highly toxic where nutrients (nitrogen) and water are not limited. The potential for this condition to occur might be limited, but is possible.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not documented. In areas west of Melbourne it has been observed that, “…not even rabbits will eat it” (Forrester pers. coms.).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Low growing, mat-forming plant. In dense infestations, large mats may provide temporary shelter for rabbits, though this has not been documented.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: G. pubescens is considered more of an environmental than agricultural weed. It is noted to occur on annual and perennial pasture (Forrester pers. coms.), but impact on stocking rates, if any, is not documented. Little or no effect.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not documented to affect the quality of agricultural production. Not known in horticulture or cropping situations.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Insufficient data to assess.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Insufficient data to assess. It is a growing problem on agricultural properties near Melbourne. “Previously productive grazing land…has been invaded by Carpet Weed. This has been made worse by below average rainfall for the last 11 years,” (Reid pers. coms.). There is no indication that agricultural activities have changed due to an inability to control this weed.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Mechanical removal and follow-up spraying with herbicide provides effective control. The extra time and cost of additional chemicals has lead to increased costs. It is also noted to tangle under farm machinery and catches on tynes on implements (Forrester pers. coms.).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None described.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Late Autumn to winter” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Natural seasonal disturbance.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Has become a naturalised weed in peppermint woodland…and has the ability to invade intact vegetation” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). This suggests that it can establish under moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Often found in disturbed areas” (van der Walt, 1977), but has the ability to invade intact vegetation (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Establishes in relatively intact vegetation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: “Low, sprawling plant…[with] an underground tuber up to 6 m in length” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No information found.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: No information found.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Can grow in…drought prone areas” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). No further information found. One study recorded garden geranium in more than 2/3 of unburnt treatment plots, but not recorded in burnt plots (Uys, Bond & Everson, 2004).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Tuber (rhizome) or seed” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Prolific seed producer” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Inflorescence may have up to 15 flowers (van der Walt, 1977) No further information found.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “It is possible for seeds to remain viable in the soil for a long period of time” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). No further information found.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “A single plant will die out after a few years” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Flowering…follows the regrowth period” (CRC Weed Management, 2003) suggesting that garden geranium flowers in its second year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds appear suited to wind dispersal (photo in CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: No information found.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Decumbent herb…usually 20 cm tall (van der Walt, 1977). Will not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: This small, herbaceous species (van der Walt, 1977) is very unlikely to be obvious to the average visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Silky leaves, no injurious properties noted in van der Walt (1977).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: This small, herbaceous species (van der Walt, 1977) would have a negligible effect on aesthetics of cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Habitats indicate that this is a terrestrial species (Kokwaro, 1971).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Habitats indicate that this is a terrestrial species (Kokwaro, 1971).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: This plant can dominate understorey species and when it becomes dormant (CRC Weed Management, 2003) it could leave large bare patches of soil that has a moderate probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: The ability of this small plant (van der Walt, 1977) to dominate understorey species (CRC Weed Management, 2003)will decrease biomass as the smaller plant replaces larger ones.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: The ability of this herbaceous plant (van der Walt, 1977) to dominate understorey species (CRC Weed Management, 2003) means that it has the potential to replace high fuel loads, such as grasses, with low fuel loads of herbaceous species. This could have a moderate effect on fire frequency and intensity.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Ridged Plains Mallee (E), CMA=Mallee, Bioreg.=Lowan Mallee, CLIMATE=VH.
 “Dominance of understorey species in the peppermint woodland” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Major displacement of
some dominant species within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Semi-arid Woodland (D), CMA=Mallee, Bioreg.=Lowan Mallee, CLIMATE=VH. 
“Dominance of understorey species in the peppermint woodland” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Major displacement of
some dominant species within a layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Woorinen Sands Mallee (LC), CMA=Mallee, Bioreg.=Lowan Mallee, CLIMATE=VH.
“Dominance of understorey species in the peppermint woodland” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within a layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dominance of understorey species in the peppermint woodland” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). This plant has the potential for a major effect on the groundcover layer.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The ability of this plant to dominate understorey species (CRC Weed Management, 2003) means that it has the potential to reduce the food sources for fauna, leading locally to reduced numbers.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No information found.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Silky leaves, no injurious properties noted in van der Walt (1977).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No information found.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: This small, herbaceous species (van der Walt, 1977) is very unlikely to provide harbour for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Not currently seen as a threat to agriculture, [but] it could have an impact on agricultural production…Could degrade pastoral areas.” Its ability to dominate understorey species (CRC Weed Management, 2003) and occurrence in grassland (Kokwaro, 1971) suggests that this plant has the potential to reduce the carrying capacity of pasture by more than 5%.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: This small, herbaceous species (van der Walt, 1977) is very unlikely to reduce the quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: This small, herbaceous species (van der Walt, 1977) is very unlikely to impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: If infestations degraded pastoral areas enough to make them unprofitable (see Q 19), a change to cropping may be necessary.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not predicted to be a weed of cropping (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not noted as a disease host/vector in CRC Weed Management (2003).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Gazanias in general germinate or spread vegetatively whenever conditions suit (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006). Grow from seed in March or April (van der Spuy, 1971). Require seasonal temperatures.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Grows in full sun to partial shade (Klett, 1999). Whilst many horticultural books state that G. linearis requires full sun, this is likely to refer to its ability to flower, rather than limits to its survival or establishment. “It can tolerate light shade under Coastal Wattle” (Pittwater Council, 2007). Able to establish under moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Has naturalised in an area of native grassland that was once in good condition, now no longer considered significant due to the Gazania infestation (Faithfull, 2006). Establishes in relatively intact grassland.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Clump-forming species recorded as growing in terrestrial environments (Faithfull, 2006). Rhizomatous (Webb et al, 1988).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments:
May have allelopathic properties, as Gazania patches are always bare of other plants (Cordingley & Petherick, 2005).
Major allelopathic properties.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No information found.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Spreads slowly (Linsley, 2007).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerates fairly severe frost (van der Spuy, 1971). Grows from sea level to 3,050 m (Hilliard, 1977). Withstands salt-laden winds (Groves et al, 2005). Tolerates some soil dryness, but overly moist soils can lead to root and stem rot (MBG, 2006). Drought tolerant and needs good drainage (Linsley, 2007). Fire resistant (Batten & Bokelmann, 1966). Highly tolerant of frost, salinity and drought; moderately tolerant of fire; not tolerant of waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Produces abundant wind-blown seeds and spreads rapidly. It also spreads vegetatively…It is often spread in garden waste” (Groves et al, 2005). Can be propagated from stem cuttings (Page & Olds, 1997). Both vegetative and sexual reproduction.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Abundant (Faithfull, 2006). No further information found.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Able to reproduce from a seedbank following control efforts (J. Virtue, 2007, pers. Comm., 23rd March). However, it is not known if seeds remain dormant for more than 5 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Gazanias in general grown in a hothouse, are capable of flowering within 4 months (Ball, 1985). Reaches reproductive maturity in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Seeds spread by water and wind” (Blood, 2001). Seeds are carried by water (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006; Carr et al, 1992).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Most propagules, spread by water and wind (Blood, 2001), could disperse 20-200 m, with few to none likely to disperse to 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: As a groundcover to 30 cm tall (Faithfull, 2006), unlikely to restrict human access at all.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: As a groundcover to 30 cm tall (Faithfull, 2006), unlikely to be noticed by the average visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Gazania species in general noted as a harbour for White Italian Snail, that can harbour a parasite that is harmful to human health (Enviroweeds, 2002). If the snails are eaten, humans can become infected with a flatworm that causes gastroenteritis, but the parasite cannot be contracted unless the snails are eaten (Horstman, 2002). No further injury to people has been found documented and this disease is not directly related to Gazanias.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: As a clump-forming groundcover to 30 cm tall (Faithfull, 2006), unlikely to cause structural or visual damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Invades streambanks (Webb et al, 1988), but is only recorded as growing in terrestrial environments (Faithfull, 2006). Unlikely to impact flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Invades streambanks (Webb et al, 1988), but is described as perennial (Batten & Bokelmann, 1966), rhizomatous (Webb et al, 1988) and as growing in terrestrial environments (Faithfull, 2006). Likely to bind soil near streambanks, reducing erosion, and consequently turbidity.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Described as perennial (Batten & Bokelmann, 1966), rhizomatous (Webb et al, 1988) and as growing in sandy soils (Faithfull, 2006). Likely to bind soil, reducing erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Prevents any regeneration of coastal native species (Pittwater Council, 2007). This article implies that G. linearis even suppresses the regeneration of tree species, such as coastal wattle. Major reduction in biomass, even replacing permanent woody vegetation.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Fire resistant (Batten & Bokelmann, 1966) and able to naturalise in grasslands (Faithfull, 2006) and prevent regeneration of native species (Pittwater Council, 2007). Likely to reduce the incidence and intensity of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Ridged Plains Mallee (E); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Only grow to about 30 cm (Faithfull, 2006), however, it prevents any regeneration of coastal native species (Pittwater Council, 2007). This article implies that G. linearis even suppresses the regeneration of tree species, such as coastal wattle. Patches of Gazania are “usually devoid of other species” (Cordingley & Petherick, 2005). Major displacement of some dominant species. Able to form monocultures, but only in discreet patches.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Woorinen Sands Mallee (D); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Only grow to about 30 cm (Faithfull, 2006), however, it prevents any regeneration of coastal native species (Pittwater Council, 2007). This article implies that G. linearis even suppresses the regeneration of tree species, such as coastal wattle. Patches of Gazania are “usually devoid of other species” (Cordingley & Petherick, 2005).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Loamy Sands Mallee (LC); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
Only grow to about 30 cm (Faithfull, 2006), however, it prevents any regeneration of coastal native species (Pittwater Council, 2007). This article implies that G. linearis even suppresses the regeneration of tree species, such as coastal wattle. Patches of Gazania are “usually devoid of other species” (Cordingley & Petherick, 2005).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Grow to about 30 cm (Faithfull, 2006). “Naturalised and known to be a minor problem [in natural ecosystems] warranting control at 4 or more locations” within Australia (Groves et al, 2003). Gazania species in general displace native vegetation and directly threaten a nationally threatened daisy on Eyre Peninsula” (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006). Has naturalised in an area of native grassland that was once in good condition, now no longer considered significant due to the Gazania infestation (Faithfull, 2006). Prevents any regeneration of coastal native species (Pittwater Council, 2007). This article implies that G. linearis even suppresses the regeneration of tree species, such as coastal wattle. Patches of Gazania are “usually devoid of other species” (Cordingley & Petherick, 2005). Major effect on all layers

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Despite evidence that Gazania species in general threaten a nationally threatened daisy on the Eyre Peninsula (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006), no evidence was found that G. linearis affects threatened flora in Victoria. However, this species appears to have a major effect on coastal native species (Pittwater Council, 2007) and is extremely competitive with ground flora in the Murray Darling basin (J. Virtue, 2007, pers. Comm., 23rd March).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: This species is capable of displacing native vegetation (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006) and degrading grassland (Faithfull, 2006). It may reduce the availability of food for some fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No evidence that this species benefits indigenous fauna. G. rigens is eaten (heavily damaged) by rabbits (Metzger & Weisberg, 2001), however, no evidence was found about the palatability or toxicity of the plant.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Taxonomic descriptions of G. linearis do not indicate that it has either spines or burrs (Webb et al, 1988). No evidence suggests that this species injures indigenous fauna. No evidence found about the palatability or toxicity of the plant, though.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: G. rigens is eaten (heavily damaged) by rabbits (Metzger & Weisberg, 2001), however, no evidence was found about the palatability of this plant.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Clump-forming species growing to 30 cm high (Faithfull, 2006). Not recorded as harbouring pest species, but it may be capable of harbouring minor pest species such as rodents.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Naturalised and known to be a minor problem [in agricultural ecosystems] warranting control at 4 or more locations” within Victoria (Groves et al, 2003). Naturalised populations in the Southern wheatbelt of WA appear to be on roadsides and wasteland around settlements, rather than on agricultural land (Hussey et al, 1997). Not considered an agricultural weed in South Australia (D. Cooke, 2007, pers comm., 23rd March), but form carpets in citrus orchards, competing with trees for nutrients and water (J. Virtue, 2007, pers. Comm., 23rd March). Considered an environmental weed in Victoria (Enviroweeds, 2002), but no further information about its seriousness as an agricultural weed was found. Likely to have a minor impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: A low-growing plant that appears to only affect horticultural crops (see Q.19). Unlikely to impact quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: A low-growing plant that appears to only affect horticultural crops (see Q.19). Unlikely to impact land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: A low-growing plant that appears to only affect horticultural crops (see Q.19). Unlikely to change land use.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Gazanias in general germinate or spread vegetatively whenever conditions suit (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006). Grow from seed in March or April (van der Spuy, 1971). Require seasonal temperatures.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Tolerates full sun to light shade (MSWN, 2005). Can establish under moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In its native range, in southern Africa, it is a strand plant [occurs up to the edge of stabilised dunes or inland vegetation] (Ross, 1972) and is a common sand coloniser (Pooley, 1988). It inhabits roadsides and coastal waste land, usually in sandy soils in NZ (Webb et al, 1988). In Australia, it appears to be confined to coastal dunes (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006; D. Cooke, pers. comm.). Major disturbance required with little or no competition from other species.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial with rhizomatous, creeping stems, recorded as growing in terrestrial environments (Faithfull, 2006). Geophyte.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments:
May have allelopathic properties, as Gazania patches are always bare of other plants (Cordingley & Petherick, 2005).
Major allelopathic properties.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Plants heavily damaged by rabbits (Metzger & Weisberg, 2001). Heavy damage implies that this species is preferred by rabbits; however, the plant may persist due to its rhizomatous nature.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: A later coloniser of coastal dunes “with slower growth” than another hummock plant (Elliot et al, 2000). “Moderately fast” growing (MSWN, 2005). Evidence about growth rate is mixed.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Grows well in dry districts and…tolerates quite severe frosts” (van der Spuy, 1971). Tolerates some soil dryness, but overly moist soils can lead to root and stem rot (MBG, 2006); requires good drainage (MSWN, 2005). A strand plant, “often [found] on the seaward side of the first line of dunes” (Hilliard, 1977); withstands salt-laden winds (Groves et al, 2005). Likely to be highly tolerant of salinity, drought and frost. Not tolerant of waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Produces abundant wind-blown seeds and spreads rapidly. It also spreads vegetatively…It is often spread in garden waste” (Groves et al, 2005). Stems tend to take root at the nodes (Richardson & Richardson, 2006). Can be propagated from stem cuttings (Page & Olds, 1997). Both vegetative and sexual reproduction.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Abundant (Faithfull, 2006). Detailed photographs of the plant show more than 40 seeds per seed head (T�bingen University, 2005). Photographs of the plant in the landscape show more than 75 flower heads per plant (Landscape Resources, 2007). 75 x 40 = 3,000. More than 2000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Considered as either an annual or short-lived perennial (Tippette, 2002). No further evidence found.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Able to flower 12 weeks after seed is sown (McCulley & McCulley, 2002). Gazanias in general grown in a hothouse, are capable of flowering within 4 months (Ball, 1985). Reaches reproductive maturity in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Seeds spread by water and wind” (Blood, 2001). Gazania seeds in general carried by water (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Most propagules, spread by water and wind (Blood, 2001), could disperse 20-200 m, with few to none likely to disperse to 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: As a groundcover to 30 cm tall (Faithfull, 2006), unlikely to restrict human access at all.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: As a groundcover to 30 cm tall (Faithfull, 2006), unlikely to be noticed by the average visitor.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Gazania species in general noted as a harbour for White Italian Snail, that can contain a parasite that is harmful to human health (Enviroweeds, 2002). If the snails are eaten, humans can become infected with a flatworm that causes gastroenteritis, but the parasite cannot be contracted unless the snails are eaten (Horstman, 2002). No further injury to people has been found documented and this disease is not directly related to Gazanias.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: As a creeping groundcover to 30 cm tall (Faithfull, 2006), unlikely to cause structural or visual damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: A strand plant [occurs up to the edge of stabilised dunes or inland vegetation] (Ross, 1972), only described as naturalised in coastal areas and along roadsides (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006), usually in sandy soils (Webb et al, 1988). Nor does it tolerate wet soil (MBG, 2006), and requires good drainage (MSWN, 2005).  Unlikely to occur instream or to impact flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: A strand plant [occurs up to the edge of stabilised dunes or inland vegetation] (Ross, 1972), only described as naturalised in coastal areas and along roadsides (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006); overly moist soils can lead to root and stem rot (MBG, 2006). Unlikely to occur near fresh waterways.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Perennial with branching stems that root at the nodes (Jeanes, 2002). “Common sand coloniser along the beach” (Hilliard, 1977). Listed as suitable for erosion control (Frost, 1998). Likely to reduce erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Tends to grow in highly disturbed places where there is little or no permanent vegetation (Ross, 1972; Groves et al, 205; Faithfull, 2006; Webb et al, 1988). Annual or short-lived perennial (Tippette, 2002).Likely to increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Listed as a fire resistant landscaping plant (Frost, 1998), however, tends to grow in highly disturbed places where there is little or no permanent vegetation (Ross, 1972; Groves et al, 205; Faithfull, 2006; Webb et al, 1988), and fire would not be expected as a regular occurrence, so unlikely to impact on fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Coastal Headland Scrub (V); CMA=Glenelg-Hopkins; Bioreg= Bridgewater; CLIMATE potential=VH.
See Q. 11. Major displacement of some dominant ground layer species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Coastal Alkaline Scrub (D); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg= Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
See Q. 11. Major displacement of some dominant ground layer species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Coast Banksia Woodland (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg= East Gippsland Lowlands; CLIMATE potential=H. 
See Q. 11. Likely to be capable of major displacement of some dominant ground layer species, however, the climate match is not as high, so in this EVC, more likely to be a minor displacement.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
Grow to about 30 cm (Faithfull, 2006). Forms extensive mats (Hilliard, 1977) and “completely covers the ground on which it grows” (Hesp & McLachlan, 2000). Significant environmental weed in Tasmania (Groves et al, 2005). “Naturalised and known to be a minor problem [in natural ecosystems] warranting control at 4 or more locations” within Australia (Groves et al, 2003). Gazania species in general are described as able to displace native vegetation and directly threaten a nationally threatened daisy on Eyre Peninsula” (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006). Considered an environmental weed in South Australia and New South Wales and a significant environmental weed in Tasmania (Randall, 2001). Patches of Gazania are “usually devoid of other species” (Cordingley & Petherick, 2005). This species has the potential to have a major effect on ground layer vegetation
(<60% of layers).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Despite evidence that Gazania species in general threaten a nationally threatened daisy on the Eyre Peninsula (DeLaine & Stokes, 2006), no evidence was found that G. rigens affects threatened flora in Victoria. However, this species is known to invade coastal areas (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006) and is capable of forming extensive mats (Hilliard, 1977). It has the potential to have a major affect in coastal areas

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: However, this species is known to invade coastal areas (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006) and is capable of forming extensive mats (Hilliard, 1977) which may displace food plants for some fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: G. rigens is eaten (heavily damaged) by rabbits (Metzger & Weisberg, 2001). May provide food for some fauna species, but not enough information is available to determine this.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Taxonomic descriptions of G. rigens do not indicate that it has either spines or burrs (Webb et al, 1988). Whilst it is eaten (heavily damaged) by rabbits (Metzger & Weisberg, 2001), there is not enough information to determine whether native fauna eat it, or if it is toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: G. rigens is eaten (heavily damaged) by rabbits (Metzger & Weisberg, 2001). A food source for a major pest.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A creeping groundcover, growing to 30 cm high (Faithfull, 2006). Not recorded as harbouring pest species, but it may be capable of harbouring minor pest species such as rodents.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Naturalised and may be a minor problem [in agricultural ecosystems] but not considered important enough to warrant control at any location” within Victoria (Groves et al, 2003). Gazanias are recorded as “a pretty bad weed on some South Australia farms” (Enviroweeds, 2002), however, this is likely to relate to G. linearis, as G. rigens is only found in coastal habitats in South Australia (D. Cooke, pers. Comm.).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Appears to be confined to coastal dunes (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006; D. Cooke, pers. Comm.) and roadsides (Webb et al, 1988). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Appears to be confined to coastal dunes (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006; D. Cooke, pers. Comm.) and roadsides (Webb et al, 1988). Not a weed of agriculture

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Appears to be confined to coastal dunes (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006; D. Cooke, pers. Comm.) and roadsides (Webb et al, 1988). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Appears to be confined to coastal dunes (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006; D. Cooke, pers. Comm.) and roadsides (Webb et al, 1988). Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Gazania species in general noted as a harbour for White Italian Snail, a crop and pasture contaminant (Enviroweeds, 2002), however, this species appears to be confined to coastal dunes (Groves et al, 2005; Faithfull, 2006; D. Cooke, pers. Comm.) and roadsides (Webb et al, 1988). Not a weed of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate at any time of the year providing moisture is available but mainly in December – January” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Sunny slopes, mixed forest in valleys, boggy thickets, roadsides, rock crevices” (Lingdi & Boufford, 2003). “Seeds germinated along forest paths and in clearings…Seed germination [occurred] in an opening in the forest canopy” (Baret et al., 2003). This suggests the need for some direct light.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Developing or run-down pastures, wet gullies, creekbanks, perimeter of rainforest areas, along roadsides (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Disturbed rainforest and logging tracks (DNRM, 2005). Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Scandent shrub to 5 m with arching or climbing branches (Lingdi & Boufford, 2003) that can reach to the top of the canopy in forest (Baret et. al, 2003).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No information found.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Vigorous (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Grows in boggy thickets (Lingdi & Boufford, 2003). “Proliferates on the…coasts…from sea level” (Baret et. al, 2003). Tolerates waterlogging and salinity. The types of vegetation in which this plant grows e.g. Rainforest (Bean, 1997) and other humid, wet habitats (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992), suggests that this plant does not tolerate drought and probably does not tolerate frost either.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Vegetative (Baret et. al, 2003) and seed (Baret et. al, 2004).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: More than 10,000 seeds per sq metre were found under patches of R. alceifolius (Baret, Bourgeois & Strasberg, 2005). Fruit production averaged between 30 and 80 fruits/m2 (Baret et. al, 2004). “Each flower possesses ~100 separate styles and stigmas” (Amsellem, Noyer & Hossaert-McKey, 2001) so you could predict that over a m2, this plant could produce 100 x 80 = 8,000 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “A small proportion of these seeds remained viable in the soil for many years” (Baret, Le Bourgeois & Strasberg, 2005), suggesting that they probably survive for more than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: No information found

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Flowers produced in second year of the plant’s growth (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seed. “Capacity to form roots…with or without soil contact” (Baret et. al, 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Spread occurs when the succulent fruit is eaten by birds and animals, and seeds are voided in their droppings” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) so some seeds are very likely to disperse more than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Reported to decrease the recreational value of infected areas (Capperino & Schneider 1985). This may imply the restriction of boating.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: In areas where it has become over populated recreational values have been reduced (Capperino & Schneider 1985). Unknown to what extent.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: There is no reported evidence for this.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Ornamental species may alter the aesthetics.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Only reported in slow moving water, however it is attached and semi-emergent in high density patches as the competition drives the leaves to be elevated above the water surface (Saity & Jacobs 1981). Abel to form dense infestations that impact on recreational activities therefore can have a major impact on both surface and subsurface flow (Capperino & Schneider 1985).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: There is no evidence for this species, however in dense infestations the shading by this species could reduce water temperatures and the reduction in water flow could alter dissolved oxygen especially at night when the plant respires.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Reported in areas of low to no flow and can further reduce water movement (Saity & Jacobs 1981). Therefore has a low probability of associated large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Clogs water ways that were open (Bailey 1900; Capperino & Schneider 1985). This would be a increase in biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species, therefore not affected by fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Billabong Wetland (E); CMA= Goulburn Broken; Bioreg= Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Has been noted to displace other submerged aquatics (Johnstone 1982).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. com).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. com).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Has been noted to displace other submerged aquatics (Johnstone 1982). Therefore having a major impact on all species within the water column.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Unknown.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Flowers visited by insects, used by duck species in its native range (Capperino & Schneider 1985; Alexander 1987). Unknown in Australia.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: None reported.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: May be eaten by duck species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: The cover produced by aquatic macrophytes is ideal habitat for the immature stages of mosquito species (Orr & Resh 1992).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not viewed as an agricultural weed.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not viewed as an agricultural weed.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not viewed as an agricultural weed.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not viewed as an agricultural weed.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Increases evaporation, therefore increases water costs (Capperino & Schneider 1985).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: There is no reported evidence for this.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: S. cinerea spreads by seed to riparian as well as other moist to wet habitats, and this is of special concern.” (Cremer, 1999). This species does not need uncommon natural events for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: S. cinerea “can invade undisturbed herbaceous wetlands…[and establish] even under dense wet sclerophyll forest” (Cremer, 1999).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: S. cinerea is “invasive in both disturbed and undisturbed situations” (Carr, 1996) “Can invade undisturbed herbaceous wetlands…even under dense wet sclerophyll forest [and] has invaded steeply sloping, mature pine forest, not just along water courses” (Cremer, 1999).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Semi-aquatic- All willows are described as growing on the banks of water courses or in moist locations and S. cinerea can also establish on drier soil (Cremer, 1999).

S. cinerea grows in swamps, riverbanks, wet areas behind coastal dunes (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988). “Occurs along streams or near seasonal to permanent swamps and bogs, from sea-level to above the treeline, invasive in both disturbed and undisturbed situations” (Carr, 1996). Invades riparian vegetation, and seasonal and permanent freshwater wetland, alpine and subalpine vegetation (Carr et al, 1992). “Can invade undisturbed herbaceous wetlands…even under dense wet sclerophyll forest…Has invaded steeply
sloping, mature pine forest, not just along water courses [and can] establish in undisturbed herbaceous communities above the tree line in National Parks” (Cremer, 1999). “In the Australian Alps…following disturbance by cattle in alpine and subalpine bogs” (Ladson et al, 1997).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Of the naturalised willows in Australia, allelopathic compounds have been demonstrated in S. rubra (Bokarev, Kefeli & Kapeljusnikova, 1966), S. babylonica (Koul et al, 1991), S. fragilis (Davison, 1965), S. viminalis (Bowen & Hoad, 1968), S. alba (Banzhaf et al, 1983) and S. purpurea (Gilliver, 1947). For other willow species, their “dense shade and mat-forming willow roots suppress and kill indigenous understorey” (Purtle et al, 2001b), suggesting that there might be an allelopathic basis for this lack of understorey beneath willow infestations, however no specific reference to S. cinerea.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Some Salix species provide good fodder for both ruminants and horses…particularly in Australia (Newsholme, 1992). However, many species tolerate this grazing and/or are able to resprout from stump, e.g. S. cinerea (Cremer, 1999).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Salix are fast growing trees or shrubs, rarely prostrate” (Spencer, 1997). Where growth rates are described, tree and shrub forms of Salix are recorded as vigorous or fast growing, e.g. S. alba (Spencer, 1997), S. glaucophylloides (Newsholme, 1992), S. nigra (Cremer, 1995), S. purpurea (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988) and S. x rubens (Meikle).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
FIRE: “If a tree is completely girdled by fire at ground level it may die without coppicing… however young trees tend to sprout from the buried portion of their stem” (Cremer, 1999), indicating some fire tolerance in tree and shrub willows in general.

FROST: All tree and shrub species (except S. humboldtiana) in this study are recorded as tolerating USDA hardiness zones of between 1 and 6 (average minimum temperatures between –46oC and –17oC) (Bailey & Bailey, 1976, Griffiths, 1992). S. humboldtiana is susceptible to frost (Newsholme, 1992).

DROUGHT: All willows are described as growing on the banks or in the riverbeds of water courses or in moist locations (Carr, 1996; Carr et. al, 1992; Cody, 1996; Davis, 1982; Howard, 1988; Ladson, et al, 1997; Maloney et al, 1999; Munz, 1963; Voss, 1972; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988) suggesting a low drought tolerance; and only few species (S. cinerea and S. exigua) can also establish on drier soil (but are not necessarily drought tolerant), with S. purpurea alone tolerating extremely dry, sandy soils (Newsholme, 1992).

WATERLOGGING: Those species able to grow in riverbeds must have high tolerance of waterlogging (S. exigua, Cody, 1996; S. fragilis, Maloney et al, 1999; S. alba, S. x rubens, and S. viminalis; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988) and also S. cinerea (Cremer, 1999).

SALINITY: S. alba is “the most tolerant of all willows to brackish water” (Zallar). S. cinerea “tolerates salt-laden air” (Newsholme, 1992), S. fragilis, S. matsudana & S. seringeana tolerate high levels of salinity (Crouch & Honeyman, 1986). S. nigra has moderately high tolerance of salt (Swift, 1997) and S. purpurea shows “considerable tolerance for salt water” (Newsholme, 1992). S. alba are highly tolerant of waterlogging, salinity and frost, have some tolerance of fire, but not of drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: S. cinerea reproduction is largely by seed (Carr, 1996). “Probably does not sucker and rarely breaks off live branches. Layering is rare until the trees are old and fall over” (Cremer, 1999). Capable of reproducing both vegetatively and by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “A large crown would produce over 500,000 seeds (Cremer, 1999). Seeds numerous, very small, each with a tuft of long hairs (Tutin, 1993).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Willow seed is very short-lived” with longer-lived species recorded at surviving 8-10 weeks (Cremer, 1999).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Following reproductive maturity “flowering tends to be ample and to occur every year” (Cremer, 1999). S. cinerea “stands are mostly monoculture excluding 97% of sunlight and most other species” (Cremer, 1999). The oldest stem S. exigua in this study was 31 years (Ottenbreit & Staniforth, 1992). An old S. fragilis tree was observed to 130 years (Meikle, 1984).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Flowering and the production of viable seed may begin two to three years after germination, provided the plant is at least 1 m tall if it is a shrub willow, or 2 m tall if it is a tree willow…In some taxa (e.g. S. alba) flowering tends to begin at larger sizes” (Cremer, 1999), which is probably still within 5 years.  For plants that have reproduced vegetatively, this may be reduced, as in S. nigra, observed flowering on cuttings produced from < 1 year old growth (Crouch & Honeyman, 1986).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Vegetative propagules and seed spread by water. “Seed is easily carried by wind” (Cremer, 1999).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Seed is easily carried by wind for more than 1 km and some travels for up to 50 km or even 100 km (Cremer, 1999) for species that commonly reproduce by seed: S. cinerea, S. nigra, S. purpurea, S. aegyptica, S. glaucophylloides, & S. viminalis (ARMCANZ, 2001).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Willows can form dense thickets several metres thick, with densely spaced stems (FEIS, 2000) that could be major impediments to access waterways. S. cinerea “is a multi-stemmed ‘shrub willow.’ Their multitudes of stems obstruct floods” (Cremer, 2001).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: S. cinerea is a thicket forming species (see Q. 1) that is especially adapted to waterlogging that may encroach into streams, trapping silt and reducing channel capacity (Purtle et al, 2001b), can create a shallow stream that boats and swimmers can no longer use.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No reference to human injury found in any reference. Toxicity rated as ‘none’ for the species summarised in the USDA Plants Database (2006) including S. purpurea, S. exigua, S. nigra, S. x sepulcralis, S. alba. Presume no toxicity for any Salix.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
As semi-aquatic species, confined to stream banks or beds or moist locations (Carr, 1996; Carr et al, 1992; Cody, 1996; Davis, 1982; Howard, 1988; Ladson et al, 1997; Maloney et al, 1999; Munz, 1963; Voss, 1972; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988) willows are unlikely to grow near enough to cause structural or visual damage to cultural sites. However, during floods, senescent trees can drop large branches or trunks into waterways and a build up of material behind these snags can destroy bridges (ARMCANZ, 2001).

Major damage to buildings can occur when streams change route because they have become clogged with mats of willow roots. A Tasmanian Landcare group was formed in response to flooded homes, the cause of which was attributed to stream blockages by willow roots encroaching into streams (Sarah Holland-Clift pers. comm.).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: S. cinerea is a thicket forming species (see Q. 1) that is especially adapted to waterlogging (Cremer, 1999) that may encroach into streams, trapping silt and reducing channel capacity (Purtle et al, 2001b), having a serious impact on both surface and subsurface water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments:
As deciduous plants (Carr, 1996), all shrub and tree willows have mass autumn leaf fall, which leads to decreased oxygen levels (Ladson et al, 1997).  

Intense shading by willows, which tend to have more dense canopies than native species decreases water temperature (Ladson et al, 1997).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “Willows encroaching into the centre of streams interrupt the flow of water which results in stream flows being directed into watercourse banks, causing erosion. In severe cases, willows can create complete blockages, causing the stream to change course (Purtle, 2001b). S. cinerea is capable of encroaching into streams (see Q. 5).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: As woody plants that can form dense thickets, or large shrubs or trees (Carr, 1996), willows are capable of increasing biomass where they replace lower or less dense vegetation as they commonly do in disturbed sites (Cremer, 1999).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Willows are low flammable/combustible trees (Carcaillet et al, 2001), likely to greatly change the frequency and intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
Basin=Snowy River- Brodribb River (ISC=excellent); CMA=East Gippsland; CLIMATE=VH. 
“Stands are mostly monocultures excluding 97% of sunlight and most other species (Cremer, 1999). Capable of forming monocultures displacing all species within a layer

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: All Victorian waterbodies are assumed to be high value EVCs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: All Victorian waterbodies are assumed to be high value EVCs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: S. cinerea is spreading, often forming dense thickets. Often forms dominant vegetation in swampy habitats (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones, 1988). “Stands are mostly monocultures excluding 97% of sunlight and most other species (Cremer, 1999). Capable of having the same major effect on all layers of native vegetation.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: “The sedge-rich Eucalyptus camphora Swamp Community, a dominant swamp vegetation of the Reserve, is also listed under the Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act 1988. This community type is very rare…one species is of state significance and 55 are of regional significance. Willows could easily overtop [E. camphora] and prevent its recruitment…The most serious willow [at this site] is S. cinerea” (Ladson et al, 1997).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
Intense shading decreases primary production in waterways, impacting on invertebrates and fish (Ladson et al, 1997).

Reduce indigenous vegetation which would otherwise provide habitat (especially tree hollows) and pollen and nectar food sources (Ladson, 1997).

“Dense shade and mat-forming willow roots suppress and kill indigenous understorey [which is] important habitat for insects, birds and mammals. Bare banks beneath willows provide little protection for frogs, water rats, snakes, lizards and other fauna. Willows do not provide nectar for native birds…Willows also have few hollows, important habitat for over half of our woodland birds and mammals” (Purtle et al, 2001b).

Reduction in habitat for fauna, leading to reduction in numbers of individuals but not to local extinction.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments:
Possums graze and defoliate isolated trees (ARMCANZ, 2001).

S. exigua “stands provide excellent cover for numerous wildlife species” in America (FEIS, 2000). Other thicket-forming species that might also provide habitat include: S. cinerea (Cremer, 2001), S. fragilis (Cremer, 1995), S. purpurea (Cremer, 1999) S. x rubens (Cremer, 1995), S. viminalis (Webb et al, 1988).  Willows are capable at most of providing some assistance as either food or shelter to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No reference to animal injury found in any reference.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The palatability of other species is unknown.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: S. exigua “stands provide excellent cover for numerous wildlife species” (FEIS, 2000). Other thicket-forming species that might harbour foxes and rabbits include: S. cinerea (Cremer, 2001), S. fragilis (Cremer, 1995), S. purpurea (Cremer, 1999), S. x rubens (Cremer, 1995), S. viminalis (Webb et al, 1988).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Species present as agricultural weeds: S. alba in NZ and USA, S. babylonica and S. cinerea in NZ, S. exigua in USA, S. nigra in USA and S. fragilis is a principal agricultural weed in NZ (Holm et al, 1979).  As willows are associated with waterways and not recorded as invaders of pasture or crops, their ability to form dense thickets that impede access to waterways for irrigation is likely to be the only impact they have on agriculture. Willow root mats reduce access to flowing water for irrigation purposes (Sarah Holland-Clift pers. comm.).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Generally willows are valued for shade and browsing for livestock (Besaans, 1995).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Whilst risk of floods and erosion may cause decrease in land value in some incidences, with a state wide view, this is likely to be negligible.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Willows are associated with waterways and not recorded as invaders of pasture or crops in the extensive literature. Whilst control may be required (see Q. 23) there is little risk that land use would need to change as a consequence of their invasion of agricultural land.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Some willow control to maintain waterways for irrigation may increase harvest costs by a minor amount.  This is likely to be for the thicket-forming species such as S. cinerea (Cremer, 2001). In the Jerilderie area 80% of farmers are donating a rebate to fund a project manager for willows in Yanco Creek, because their root mats reduce access to creek water for irrigation (Sarah Holland-Clift).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not found in the extensive literature.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn and spring”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Establishes in open habitats and ecosystems e.g. areas of abandoned cultivation.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades undisturbed ecosystems (e.g. alpine and sub-alpine vegetation).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect biennial herb.

Other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “Allelopathic effects have been reported on wheat seedlings but this is not a practical problem because the plant is not a weed of cereal crops”.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “The rosettes, which cover a large area, are rarely eaten by livestock”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“It prefers disturbed habitats with little other vegetation”.

“It is easily crowded out by grasses or other competing vegetation”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of frost (occurs in southern Tasmania); drought (occurs in central New South Wales and Western Australia). Occurs in ‘moist meadows and drainage’s’ in California.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
“Reproducing by seed”.

“Flowers are autogamous, that is they self-pollinate if cross-pollination does not occur’.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Single plants produce 200 to 300 capsuled with 500 to 800 seeds per capsule.  This seed production can be 100,000 to 240,000 seeds per plant”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “In Denmark, seeds recovered from soil samples claimed to be more than 650 years old were viable”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Most plants are biennial but occasionally they can be annual or short lived perennials”.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants usually bolt, flowering stem, in the second year and have a single stem covered with over lapping; woolly leaves from base to inflorescence”.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Seeds are not adapted to dispersal by wind or animals and usually fall to the ground.  Field studies report that seeds will disperse as far as eleven metres, but 75% fall within one metre of the parent plant”.  “Most seeds fall within 1.5 metres of the parent plant when it is moved by wind or large animals.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Erect biennial herb to 2.5 metres high. The population density of the invasion depends upon the level of disturbance of a site. In England, an infestation of 5.2 flowering plants per square metre was observed in coppiced woodland two years after they were cut (i.e. at the peak of the flowering cycle). Lesser infestations are more common. Dense infestations would be a nuisance to people.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: It invades natural meadow and forest openings. In dense infestations, it may affect some recreational activities such as bushwalking.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “The leaf hairs are said to irritate human skin. However, an admirable recent use is in gardens frequented by blind people where its velvet leaves are pleasing to the touch.”

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The plants are quite noticeable and would impose a moderate negative visual effect on cultural sites. The root comprises a single stout deep taproot, which would not cause structural damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In Victoria V. thapsus is most often found as small dense patches on roadsides, railway easements, poorer pastures and unimproved native grasslands. Although the plant does not have an extensive root system, the vegetative cover would limit soil erosion from wind.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Seedling growth rates were 4 – 7 times faster on bare soils [than on vegetated soils], producing 2000 times more biomass with the same period.” Its presence in poorer pasture and unimproved native grassland would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: A dense, broad-leaved biennial herb, the dead plant matter may increase the fuel load producing a slight increase in the frequency of fire risk. (“The thick woolly leaves were popular insoles in footwear and were even used as temporary outer soles in hard times.”)

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodlands (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Goldfields; VH CLIMATE potential.
“Intolerant of shade…will grow in almost any open area.” Occurs in medium to large populations in Victoria. Major impact on grasses and shrubs.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riparian scrub (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Rock outcrop shrubland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Once established, it grows more vigorously than many native herbs and shrubs, and its growth can overtake a site in fairly short order.” Dense infestations would have a major effect on grasses and forbs.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The rosettes are rarely eaten by livestock. Likely that native fauna also rarely use the plant as a source of food. The broad rosettes cover a large area thus reducing available fodder.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No documented benefits

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The leaf hairs are said to irritate the mucous membranes of animals’ mouths. Possible reason why animals rarely eat the plant?

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Animals rarely eat the rosettes, which cover a large area replacing a considerable amount of pasture. Potential to reduce carrying capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: As a biennial, it does not appear to be a problem in cropping situations. Animals rarely eat the rosettes.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The plant is easily controlled in pasture situations through pasture improvement. Occurrence of the plant in this situation is unlikely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The plant is easily controlled in pasture situations through pasture improvement. Land use not greatly affected.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Poisonous, symptoms can present after just contact with the plant, also has thorny capsules (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). A definite impediment to individuals.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: A shrubby herb with large ornate flowers, it would be noticed (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). However no reports of impacts on tourism.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
All parts of the plant are poisonous, especially seeds and fatalities have occurred after children have eaten seeds of the similar D. stramonium (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). 
Seed capsules are also thorny (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Has larger root system than other Datura species, however no reports of it causing structural damage. Could alter the aesthetics with its large leaves and ornate flowers.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Has a large root system, however it does die back during the winter months (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Can often create a shrubby herb layer, however as it is a short lived perennial, which dies back annually (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Therefore has little capacity for acting as a carbon sink.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Impact on fire not reported.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains Grassy Woodland (E); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Most invasive in highly disturbed habitats, if present would compete for moisture light and nutrients (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Heathy Herb-rich Woodland (D); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Most invasive in highly disturbed habitats, if present would compete for moisture light and nutrients (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Heathy Woodland (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Most invasive in highly disturbed habitats, if present would compete for moisture light and nutrients may cause some minor displacement (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Most invasive in highly disturbed habitats, if present would compete for moisture light and nutrients may cause some minor displacement (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No reports of this, most invasive in highly disturbed environments (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Poisonous plant (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Minor hazard

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Only insects seem to be able to use the plant as a food resource and no native species reported using it (Hare & Smith 2005 and Raguso et al 2003).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Poisonous (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Bees can use the nectar (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Shrubby herb that can cause poisoning symptoms from contact (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Little evidence for potential harbour.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Competes with crops for light, nutrients and moisture. Can also cause stock death especially in pigs and poultry (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001 and Haegi 1976).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Seed contamination of sorghum has lead to downgrading or rejection of the crop, and reported to cause birth defects in pigs (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No evidence of this reported.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Seed contamination can’t easily be removed from sorghum (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Therefore a different crop rotation would need to be put into place to produce a marketable product.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Can interfere with harvesting equipment (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments:
Alternate host for Xylella fastidiosa, the bacterium cause of Pierce’s disease of grapes (Wistrom & Purcell 2005).
Alternate host for pests and diseases of crops such as tomatoes, tobacco and potatoes (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Perennial herb. New growth develops from buds on the roots in spring and summer. Requires natural seasonal disturbance to grow.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: In the United States, Russian knapweed invades open, disturbed land. It is sensitive to decreased amounts of sunlight, does not compete well under heavy canopy, and is weakened by dense shade. Requires disturbance and direct access to sunlight.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In Australia, it has become a weed of both irrigated crops, such as vines, and dryland cereals in the 300 to 600 mm annual rainbelt. In the U.S., it occurs in disturbed western grassland and shrubland communities. Establishes in highly disturbed environments.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A perennial herb with creeping roots. Geophyte.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “Creeping knapweed has allelopathic properties, …[which] restrict the growth of such species as oats, beans and tomatoes. Extracts also have a stimulatory effect on some species.”

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “The leaves have a bitter disagreeable taste but, nevertheless, are grazed by sheep.” In the U.S., animals avoid grazing the plant. Consumed, but not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Hardheads is an extremely vigorous and efficient competitor for water and nutrients and releases allelopathic chemicals which can suppress the growth of other plants.” Ability to compete strongly with most other species of similar life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Survives through winter as a perennating root system, which may extend to 5 metres in depth. In both Australia and the U.S. it occurs in dryland areas (300 to 600 mm, and 245 mm respectively). Also, in the U.S., it is believed that Russian knapweed tolerates some flooding, but not severe drought.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The plant reproduces both vegetatively and sexually.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “A single Russian knapweed plant can produce about 1,200 seeds per year.” 1,000–2,000 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seeds are known to survive in soil for at least 5 years, however, the seedlings of creeping knapweed are not often found and it may be that seeds germinate, or seedlings survive, only under uncommon conditions.” Low viability.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: The U.S. experience is that, “Once established in open areas, however, it is highly competitive and spreads aggressively, often forming dense, single-species stands that can persist indefinitely.” Similarly in Australia, “In recent years it has established in the eastern Mallee of Victoria, forming dense patches to the virtual exclusion of other vegetation.” Self-sustaining colony.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Produces seed annually, though reproduces annually from adventitious buds on horizontal roots.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Most seeds fall within about a metre of the parent plant, but greater dispersal can result from water (in channels), contaminated seed and machinery, and animals (both internally and externally). Vegetative material, which is capable of producing new plants, is also spread by cultivation equipment. Propagules spread by humans and animals and occasionally water.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: The most common method of spread is by vegetative means, which can be exacerbated by cultivation and poor hygiene. Seedlings are not often found.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect perennial herb, 40 cm to 100 cm high, with narrow stems and leaves. Dense patches (100 to 300 stems per square metre) would be annoying to pedestrians, but is unlikely to restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense infestations would have a minor effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No spines or burrs. Not toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The plant has an extensive root system but there is no evidence to suggest it is sufficiently vigorous to cause structural damage. Dense infestations may create a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. The plant can be killed if inundated by water for a month.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Perennial with an extensive network of vertical and horizontal roots to 5 to 7 metres deep and several metres laterally. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Commonly a weed of irrigated crops, vines, and dryland cereals. Weed replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Aerial growth dies off by autumn.” This leaves dry matter that, in dense infestations, may increase fuel load. Minor change to the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential
