“Russian knapweed does not establish readily in healthy, natural habitats.” However, it can establish on neglected or disturbed areas where it would have a major impact on ground-flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Unlikely to occur in any medium value EVC

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Unlikely to occur in any low value EVC

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “In recent years it has established in the Eastern Mallee of Victoria, forming dense patches to the virtual exclusion of all other vegetation [i.e. agricultural vegetation].” Not known as a weed of natural ecosystems (not recorded in Carr et al 1992), but, “…establishes readily on…neglected areas.” Would have a minor effect on ground-flora (20 to 60%).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Not a weed of natural ecosystems. However, “…dense patches exclude almost all other vegetation and, in Victoria, the horizontal spread of a patch of creeping knapweed from root growth has been measured at 1 metre annually.” May slightly reduce habitat for native fauna through competition with other species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “The leaves have a bitter disagreeable taste but, nevertheless, are grazed by sheep.” Possible limited food source for native species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No physical properties such as spines or burrs. “Creeping knapweed is claimed overseas to be poisonous to livestock and to cause a neurological disorder in horses, but these problems have not been reported in Australia.” It is grazed by sheep, so may be mildly toxic to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No evidence of this plant being a food source for pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor for pest animals. Aerial parts of the plant die back.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “…dense patches [have lead] to the virtual exclusion of other vegetation and reducing the yield of cereal crops by as much as 75%.” Significant impact on yield in these situations.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Creeping knapweed seed is unlikely to occur in cereal grain because the heads are immature at the time of harvest, however, it commonly contaminates lucerne seed in parts of the United States.” Farmers may have difficulty selling contaminated seed. “The seeds are bitter and impart an unpleasant taste to flour made from contaminated grain.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: “It is one of the most competitive of all weeds and agricultural land in California has been abandoned because of it.” It is difficult to control and eradicate. “In 1982 the Victorian Government initiated a program of assistance to landholders by subsidising the purchase of herbicides.” Likely to have a major negative impact on the value of land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “It is one of the most competitive of all weeds and agricultural land in California has been abandoned because of it.” “The roots are long lived and one patch studied in Canada has survived for almost 80 years despite numerous attempts at eradication.” “…some growers not longer crop heavily infested paddocks.” Major detrimental change to land use resulting in significant loss.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to affect harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Requires natural seasonal disturbances, such as rainfall/temperature/day length for germination.
Preference for wet, sandy habitats. (Goldblatt, ’92).
Germinates in autumn. (Blood, ‘01).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Requires specific requirement (full sun / moisture) to establish.
Invades grass- and heathland, woodlands, and riparian habitats. (Weber, ’03).
Preference for wet, sandy habitats. (Goldblatt, ’92).
Full sun required. (Blood, ‘01).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.
Grows along roadsides, on vacant land and disturbed bushland (Botanic Gardens Trust, ’99-’07; Harden, ‘93).
Invades heathland and heathy woodland, lowland, grassland and grassy woodland and dry sclerophyll forest and woodland communities. (Carr et al. ‘92)

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Monocotyledon.
Family: Iridaceae.
Perrenial (Goldblatt, ’92).
Cormour geophyte. (Carr et al. ‘92).
[NB. It is noteworthy that Sparaxis spp. readily form intrageneric hybrids (e.g. Blood, ’01). Some authors do not distinguish between Sparaxis spp., putative hybrids, or varieties; but treat them as an aggregate (e.g. Hitchmough, ’89 and Hussey, et al. ‘97). Although this assessment only looks at S. bulbifera, it may be needful to consider other Sparaxis spp. known to be in Australia that may have differing weedy potentials that may hybridise with S. bulbifera.]

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Not described as having Allelopathic properties.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Consumed, but not preferred by herbivores AND growth encouraged by grazing.
Plants rarely eaten by animals, encouraged by light to moderate grazing. (Blood, ‘01).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Rapid growth rate that will exceed most other similar species.
Establish quickly (Richardson, et al. ’06).
Sparaxis sp. will crowd out small native plants. (http://www.treesforlife.org.au) (external link).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Resistant to drought, frost, and waterlogging. Not recorded as being susceptible to salinity.
Tolerates temperatures to -5�C, full sun, dry and wet conditions, various soils including sand and clay. Prefers moist conditions particularly drainage lines, roadside drains seasonal wetlands: (Blood, ‘01). Therefore assumed tolerant of some water logging. (Ibid. ‘01) Drought and frost resistant (Bodkin, ‘86)

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Both sexual AND vegetative reproduction.
Reproduce by seed, corms and leaf bulbs. (Muyt, ‘01).
May self-pollinate (Goldblatt et al. ’00).
Insect pollinated whilst being visited by hopliine beetles (Lepithrix ornatella), short-proboscid flies (Mesomyia sp.), and pollen-collecting bees (Ibid.) for nectar.
Reproduction vegetative (corms & bulbs), seeds in West Australia and New Zealand. (Blood, ‘01)

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
50 – 1,000 propagules per plant.
Goldblatt (’92) refers to a “remarkably constant” seed number, i.e. 8 – 10 seeds per locule, with 24 – 30 per floral capsule.
Six flowers per plant (Hitchmough ’89).
“Extremely prolific producer of corms and cormlets.” (Blood, ‘01).
- Assumed 50-1,000 propagules (or less), as plants only ~ 30 cm. (Van der Spuy, ‘71)

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Not recorded in literature reviewed.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
Mature plant produces viable propagules for three - ten years.
Corms assumed to produce bulbs and seeds for > three years. (PFF ‘02).
Forming large swards along roadsides and in other areas. In badly infested areas the task may well be daunting, as the infestations can be very dense. (http://www.treesforlife.org.au) (external link).
Perennial herb with above ground parts that die back each year to an underground corm. (Blood, ‘01)

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Produces propagules one – two years after germination.
Flowering plants within two years of seed germination (Hitchmough, ’89).
This species often flowers in its second year from seed. --- Corms assumed to produce bulbs and seeds for > three years. (PFF ‘02)

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Propagules spread by various means, including wind, water, soil movement; NOT by attachment or faunal food source.
Soil movement carries vegetative propagules (Esler, ’88).
Seed and bulbils dispersed by water, wind, slashing, in garden refuse, and soil movements (Muyt, ’01).
Corms dispersed in garden refuse, and soil movement. (Muyt, ’01).
Corms and cormlets…are easily transported and spread by slashing equipment and erosion. Cormlets easily transported in water (runoff) and soil. (Blood, ‘01).
Seeds are completely spherical and perfectly Smooth (Goldblatt, ’92) reducing the likelihood of seed attachment being a significant mode of transport.
Seeds without structures aiding ready dispersal include S. bulbifera according to Esler (’88).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Very likely that at least one propagule will disperse greater than one kilometre.
Small infestations can be spread for several kilometres by road making equipment. (Blood, ‘01).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
Minimal impact on human access.
Plants 15 – 45 cm high (Manning, et al. ’02)

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Weeds not obvious to the ‘average’ visitor; unless during flowering when ‘average’ visitor may think “pretty floral carpet”.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
No effects, no prickles, no injuries.
No recorded injuries to people (PFF ‘02).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
Little, or no, damage on aesthetics, or structure of site.
No recorded data re site damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species, therefore no affect on water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Terrestrial species, therefore no affect on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Terrestrial species, therefore no affect on soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: No evidence to suggest that carbon levels altered by the presence of S. bulbifera.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
Small, or negligible, effect on fire regime.
No evidence to suggest that fire regime altered by the presence of S. bulbifera.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC = Aquatic Herbland (BCS = E); CMA = Glenelg-Hopkins; Bioreg = Dundas Tablelands; Very High CLIMATE potential.
Where invasive, the plant forms extensive populations, especially after disturbance, and impedes the growth and regeneration of native plants. (Weber, ’03)

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC = Spray-zone Coastal Shrubland (BCS = R); CMA = Glenelg-Hopkins; Bioreg = Bridgewater; Very High CLIMATE potential.
Where invasive, the plant forms extensive populations, especially after disturbance, and impedes the growth and regeneration of native plants. (Weber, ’03)

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC = Heathy Dry Forest (BCS = LC); CMA = Glenelg-Hopkins; Bioreg = Dundas Tablelands; Very High CLIMATE potential. 
 Where invasive, the plant forms extensive populations, especially after disturbance, and impedes the growth and regeneration of native plants. (Weber, ’03)

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
Major effects on > 60% of the floral strata.
Where invasive, the plant forms extensive populations, especially after disturbance, and impedes the growth and regeneration of native plants. (Weber, ’03)

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments:
Reduction in habitat for local flora. Literature not found evidence to show that it has led to local extinctions.
Where invasive, the plant forms extensive populations, especially after disturbance, and impedes the growth and regeneration of native plants. (Weber, ’03)

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
Reduction in habitat / food for local fauna. Literature not found evidence to show that it has led to local extinctions.
Where invasive, the plant forms extensive populations, especially after disturbance, and impedes the growth and regeneration of native plants. (Weber, ’03)

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments:
Provides some assistance in food source (non-preferred) to fauna.
Visited by hopliine beetles (Lepithrix ornatella), short-proboscid flies (Mesomyia sp.), and pollen collecting bees (Goldblatt, et al. 2000) for nectar.
Plants rarely eaten by animals, encouraged by light to moderate grazing. (Blood, ‘01)

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No effect.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Provides minimal food for pest animals.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments:
No harbour for pest spp.
Life form not conducive to providing harbour to fauna.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Major impact on quantity of produce (~ 20% reduction).
Not recorded as a weed of agriculture, but as it has significant potential to invade grasslands (Blood, ’02; Goldblatt, ’92;  Manning, et al. ’02; Weber, ’03) it is likely to have some effect on quantity of produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments:
Major impact on quality of produce (~ 20% reduction).
Not recorded as a weed of agriculture, but as it has significant potential to invade grasslands (Blood, ’02; Goldblatt, ’92; Manning, et al. ’02; Weber, ’03) it is likely to have some effect on quality of produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments:
Major decrease in land value (>10% reduction), as increase in weed control costs, and/or change in land use.
Not recorded as a weed of agriculture, but as it has significant potential to invade grasslands (Blood, ’02; Goldblatt, ’92; Manning, et al. ’02; Weber, ’03) it is likely to have some effect on quality of produce.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments:
Downgrading of the priority land use, to one with less agricultural return, plus increase in weed control costs.
Not recorded as a weed of agriculture, but as it has significant potential to invade grasslands (Blood, ’02; Goldblatt, ’92; Manning, et al. ’02; Weber, ’03) it is likely to have some effect on quality of produce.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments:
Major increase in time, or labour, in harvesting to limit contamination.
Not recorded as a weed of agriculture, but as it has significant potential to invade grasslands (Blood, ’02; Goldblatt, ’92; Manning, et al. ’02; Weber, ’03) it is likely to have some effect on quality of produce.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Little, or no, host.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Seeds can germinate all year round but most successful germination occurs during spring and autumn.’  ‘Rarely germinate without exposure to light, and germination increases when seeds are heat treated’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2000) . Requires natural seasonal temperatures for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘It does not tolerate shade’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Requires access to light and open spaces to establish.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘Grows on poor undeveloped grassland .. prefers frost flats, scrub and higher tussock grasslands.’  Colonises up to altitudes of 1,500 m and is thus a serious threat to Australia’s alpine country’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Can establish in healthy and undisturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Evergreen perennial shrub (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Life form– other

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: ‘ releases allelopathic substances that may inhibit invasion and growth of some trees in heather-dominated heaths and moors’ (USDA Forest Service 2004).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘Intense sheep grazing pressure .. will suppress new growth and flowering and may eventually eliminate C. vulgaris after a number of years. .. Light grazing will not be helpful’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Heather beetle Lochmaea suturalis .. was released in New Zealand in 1996 but has had limited success so far.’ ‘Heather production greatly exceeds heather consumption by herbivores' (USDA Forest Service 2004).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Seedlings are easily out competed by grasses (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003 ). ‘ .. slow growing, early successional shrub’ (USDA Forest Service 2004). Slow-growth, will be exceeded by many other species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘Extremely frost hardy and tolerates water logging’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Fire helps spread the plant’ (Weber 2003). Grows on fixed sand dunes. ‘Very tolerant of salt spray’ (Underhill 1971). Highly resistant to at least 2 and not susceptible to more than one.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Mainly reproduces by seed although vegetative reproduction occurs through layering. (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Self-sterile but cross-pollinates (USDA Forest Service 2004).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Each plant can produce several thousand flowers and tens of thousands of seeds’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Above 2,000.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘.. seeds can remain viable for extended periods, up to 100 years’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments:
‘Plants live for about 30 years’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Produces viable
propagules for 10 years or more.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘In good conditions plants can produce seed within three years’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
‘ .. spread by wind, animals or walkers brushing against the plants’ (CRC for Australian Weed
Management 2003). Small wind-dispersed seeds.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘It spreads at rates of up to seven kilometres a year along roads, through seeds being spread by road machinery ..’ (Department of Conservation n.d.). Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grows up to 1.25 m, with woody pliable stems (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Varies from low and sparse to dense and bushy’ (USDA Forest Service 2004). Weed would have a minimal or negligible impact on human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: ‘The role of heather as a highly valued and major floristic component of British and European heathlands’ (Chapman & Bannister 1994). Visitors would be aware but not bothered by weed.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Not known to have any injurious effects.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: ‘.. alpine and subalpine areas of Victoria are threatened by C. vulgaris. Because of the cultural, environmental and recreational importance of these unique habitats..’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). If the weed did occur in cultural sites, likely to have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘.. deliberately planted in gardens and for erosion control’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Fibrous lateral root system. ‘A surface mat is formed by adventitious roots and fine branches of the main root system’ (USDA Forest Service 2004). Low probability of causing large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In a national park in New Zealand ‘C. vulgaris now dominates virtually all of the area previously covered in .. tussock grass-land’ (Rogers & Leathwick 1996). Has a ‘dense canopy during much of its life’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Likely that the biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: ‘Dense canopy during much of its life and forms persistent leaf litter’. ‘ .. large accumulation of wood and litter’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Temperatures and [fire] intensities increased with stand age until the mature phase,’ at which point they decline in degenerate stands (USDA Forest Service 2004). Likely that the weed would contribute to a minor change in intensity of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Clay heath (V); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Lowland; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘ .. ability to dominate leads to a severe loss of biodiversity by displacing native vegetation and reducing the range and habitat
available to native fauna’ (Rogers & Leathwick 1996). In a national park in New Zealand ‘C. vulgaris now dominates virtually all of the area previously covered in .. tussock grass-land’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within a strata

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Heathy woodland (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Lowland; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘ .. ability to dominate leads to a severe loss of biodiversity by displacing native vegetation and reducing the range and habitat available to native fauna’ (Rogers & Leathwick 1996). In a national park in New Zealand ‘C. vulgaris now dominates virtually all of the area previously covered in .. tussock grass-land’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within a strata.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Banksia woodland. (LC); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg=East Gippsland Lowland; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘.. ability to dominate leads to a severe loss of biodiversity by displacing native vegetation and reducing the range and habitat available to native fauna’ (Rogers & Leathwick 1996). In a national park in New Zealand ‘C. vulgaris now dominates virtually all of the area previously covered in .. tussock grass-land’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within a strata.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘ .. ability to dominate leads to a severe loss of biodiversity by displacing native vegetation and reducing the range and habitat available to native fauna’ (Rogers & Leathwick 1996). In a national park in New Zealand ‘C. vulgaris now dominates virtually all of the area previously covered in .. tussock grass-land’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Major effect on less than 60% of the floral strata

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: ‘.. ability to dominate .. displacing native vegetation and reducing the habitat available to native fauna (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Has the potential to have a minor effect on non-threatened fauna spp.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: ‘ the most important yearlong food of rock ptarmigan and grouse in Scotland and Denmark’. ‘Large portion of the diet of domestic sheep’ ‘ primary cover of the European red grouse .. probably also provides good cover for other upland game birds, small non-game birds, and small mammals’ (USDA Forest Service 2004). Possible that the weed could provide some assistance in either food or shelter to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be toxic to indigenous fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: ‘Red deer and mountain hare also browse heather’ (USDA Forest Service 2004). Possible that the weed would supply food for one or more minor pest spp.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Weed not known to affect value of land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed not known to cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not known as a host or vector for disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seed germinates at much the same time as mature plants begin their growing season in autumn after being dormant over summer (Boyce 1993).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Reported to be capable of invading dry coastal vegetation to riparian vegetation and pasture (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992; Roy et al 1998). Therefore capable of establishing under a variety of light and moisture conditions.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Can invade riparian vegetation (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Tuberous geophyte (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: There is no evidence of this.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: All parts of the plant are poisonous; the juice is an irritant to the skin and mouth which causes arum species in general to be avoided by grazing species. Stock death has occurred after consuming arum species (Connor 1977; McBarron 1977; Shepherd 2004). Arums are troubled by a few insect pests including aphids, red spider mite and slugs and snails, severe damage only occurs under high infestation rates, therefore the plant is relatively untroubled by herbivore pressure. (Boyce 1993).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Anecdotal reports of the plant crowding out garden beds, however this doesn’t compare with species of the same life form, presumed to be similar (Dave’s Garden 2007).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Drought tolerant, dies back during summer (Mendez & Obeso 1993) Frost tolerant; rated to zone 5a (-28.8�C) (Dave’s Garden 2007). Dieing back in summer would mean that it is unlikely to be effected by fire.  Reported growing in a coastal dune system (Mendez & Obeso 1993). Therefore may have some tolerance to salinity.
Unknown tolerance to waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually with seed and vegetatively with tubers (Mendez & Obeso 1993).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Found to have an average seed production per inflorescence of 82.8 � 62 with the maximum recorded as 335 (Albre, Quilichini & Gibernau 2003). Most plants produce 2-4 inflorescences which means the number of seeds produced is likely to be less than 1000 (Mendez & Diaz 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Not exactly known, there are anecdotal reports of people trying to control self persisting populations for 18-30 years (Dave’s Garden 2007).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
On average it takes between 4 and 5 years for arums grown from seed to flower (Boyce 1993).
Can produce independent daughter tubers in its second growing season (Mendez & Obeso 1993).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Has red to orange berries which are dispersed by birds (Mendez & Obeso 1993)

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: With the aid of bird dispersal seeds could travel more than 1 km, however dispersal distance for this species is not reported.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Only grows to 60 cm, however as contact with the sap can cause serve skin irritation this may impede individual access (Shepherd 2004).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: It is an ornamental species and as the flowers can smell like stale urine or decaying meat, this plant could alter aesthetics (Albre, Quilichini & Gibernau 2003; Spencer 2005).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: All parts of the plant are poisonous, contact can cause serve skin irritation and if eaten, it can cause death (Shepherd 2004).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: It is an ornamental species and as the flowers can smell like stale urine or decaying meat, this plant could alter aesthetics (Albre, Quilichini & Gibernau 2003; Spencer 2005).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species, not reported to impede water flow in any significant way even when occurring in riparian habitats.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Terrestrial species, not reported to impact on water quality in any significant way even when occurring in riparian habitats. Its tissues do contain toxic substances which may impact on an aquatic ecosystem if released into the water (Shepherd 2004).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Has a tuberous root system which would help to bind the soil, it does however die back over summer which could leave the soil surface exposed (Boyce 1993).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: A low growing herbaceous species, not reported to impact significantly on vegetation structure. It is likely that there would be direct replacement.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Dies back in summer (Boyce 1993). This could alter fuel loads and there is less biomass during the fire season and therefore alter fire intensities.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (V); CMA= Corangamite ; Bioreg= Otway Plain ; VH CLIMATE potential.
Anecdotally this species has been reported to crowd out garden beds and even displacing crabgrass (Dave’s Garden 2007). Therefore at least some minor displacement in a natural ecosystem is predicted.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Sedgy Riparian Woodland (D); CMA= Corangamite ; Bioreg= Otway Plain ; VH CLIMATE potential.
Anecdotally this species has been reported to crowd out garden beds and even displacing crabgrass (Dave’s Garden 2007). Therefore at least some minor displacement in a natural ecosystem is predicted.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Lowland Forest (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg= Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Anecdotally this species has been reported to crowd out garden beds and even displacing crabgrass (Dave’s Garden 2007). Therefore at least some minor displacement in a natural ecosystem is predicted.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Anecdotally this species has been reported to crowd out garden beds and even displacing crabgrass (Dave’s Garden 2007). Therefore at least some minor displacement in the lower strata of a natural ecosystem is predicted, this would still not realistically impact on more than 20% of the total vegetation community.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown, there is no evidence reported.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Not exactly known, unlikely however to significantly alter the habitat.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Provides fruit for bird species, but only invertebrates such as aphids and slugs and snails are reported to eat the leaves (Boyce 1993).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: May cause skin irritation, illness and death (Connor 1977; McBarron 1977; Shepherd 2004).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Eaten by slugs snails and aphids (Boyce 1993).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Only 60 cm high and contact can cause irritation, unlikely to provide significant harbour (Shepherd 2004).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Only a very minor weed of crops (Hidalgo, Saavedra & Garcia-Torres 1990).
Can cause poisoning and death in stock (Connor 1977; McBarron 1977). Significant stock losses have not been reported.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Unknown.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Anecdotally people have moved house, due to frustration of trying to control this species (Dave’s Garden 2007).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Unknown.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: May require stock to be restricted and moved more regularly to prevent poisoning and deaths.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Can be effected by aphids and slugs and snails (Boyce 1993).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in spring. New shoots emerge in… spring from buds on the extensive root system.” Requires natural seasonal disturbance (i.e. temperature).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: In Australia S. leprosa is found on channel banks and irrigated annual pastures in arid and semi-arid warm-temperate regions. Requires open space and access to water to establish.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: It occurs in established irrigated pastures where it, “…competes strongly with pasture species.” Little disturbance required.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial herb. “Aerial growth dies in autumn and new shoots emerge in the following spring from buds on the extensive root system.” Geophyte.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: It is not readily eaten by grazing animals. Heavy herbivory pressure will extend weed infestation.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: A deep-rooted perennial that competes strongly with pasture species. “…growth is rapid until plants flower in summer.” Growth equal to competitive species of similar life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Once established, this deeply rooted species may survive periods of drought and frost. Horizontal creeping roots grow at about 15 – 20 cm below the soil surface. In the U.S., it is known to occur in saline soils.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually and vegetatively.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Amount of seed produced is not documented. Parsons & Cuthbertson (2001) state that the plant produces abundant seeds. Assume > 1,000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: No data available.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: A perennial herb, the root system may persist for more than 2 years. In Australia, it is not known to occur in dense populations, although in California it occasionally forms large colonies in orchards, pastures and some agronomic crops.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Seedlings grow rapidly and flower in the first year.” Produce via propagules in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Root fragments produce new plants, so most spread is due to cultivation of infested land. Additionally, seed is spread by animals (in wool and hides) and agricultural produce. Water is also an effective means of seed dispersal.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: As most spread is due to cultivation, spread may be limited to less than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A semi-erect perennial herb to 30 cm high.” Does not inhibit human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Dense patches would be noticeable, but the low growth habit of the plant would not affect recreational activities. Minor effect to aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No spines or burrs. It is not known to be toxic.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Although it occurs on “channel banks and [in] irrigated annual pastures,” it is a terrestrial species. Not known to affect water flow.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A “deep-rooted perennial, [that] competes strongly with pastures species.” While aerial parts die off in autumn, the extensive root system likely to provide deeper soil binding. Moderate probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Competes strongly with pasture, particularly irrigated annual pasture. Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: A low-growing plant, it would not add greatly to the fuel load. Small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Creekline grassy woodland (E); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Area of potential distribution limited. “Whilst it is well established, the areas are not large. In Victoria, it is confined to the banks of some irrigation channels. A deep-rooted perennial, it competes strongly with pasture species.” Minor impact on lower stratum.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (E); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Area of potential distribution limited. Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Unlikely to occur in low value EVCs in Victoria. Potential distribution limited to small areas in North Central and Goulburn Broken CMAs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Competes strongly with pasture species. “Whilst it is well established, the areas are not large.” It would have a minor impact on the floral strata in grassland situations.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Competes strongly with pasture species, and animals do not readily eat the plant. Infested areas are not large. Reduce food source for some native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be toxic.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Competes strongly with pasture species…[and] it is not readily eaten by animals.” However, infested areas are not large. Likely to have minor impact on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known as a weed of cropping in Australia. Animals do not eat the plant.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Infested areas are not large. Not likely to seriously affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Infested areas are not large. Not likely to dictate a change in land use in pasture situations.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping in Australia.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “A closely related species is an important host for a virus disease of tobacco in parts of Africa.” Potential to host a serious disease of important agricultural produce.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: The species is not reported to have any additional requirements for propagation and other similar Ligustrum sp. have been found to germinate on a seasonal basis (Blood 2001; Burrows & Kohen 1983; PFAF 2007). The species is therefore considered to be capable of germinating on a seasonal basis.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: In cultivation the species is reported to be able to grow in full sun and full shade and is also reported to invade areas of moderate canopy cover i.e. forest and open areas i.e. roadsides and waste places (PFAF 2007; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). Therefore the species is presumed capable of establishing under moderate canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Reported to invade forest and riparian habitat (Henderson 1995). The species is therefore capable of establishing in minor disturbed environments.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; the species is a large shrub (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: A similar species, L. lucidum is suspected of having allelopathic properties (Blood 2001).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Used for ornamental hedging the species can tolerate heavy trimming (PFAF 2007).
The leaves of the species are reported to be toxic (Shepherd 2004). The species is therefore thought not to be a preferred browse species and if it is browsed capable of recovering quickly.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: The is conflicting data on the species growth rate, it is reported to be fairly slow growing and moderately fast growing (PFAF 2007).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
The species shows some salt tolerance, under extreme conditions however, plants can be killed (Wester & Cohen 1968).
Reported to be moderately frost hardy (Schulteis & Santarius 1989).
The species has some drought tolerance (PFAF 2007).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The species reproduces sexually producing seed (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Unknown; other Ligustrum sp. have been reported to produce more than 2000 propagules per season.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown; the seeds of other Ligustrum sp. have been reported to remain viable for less than five years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Unknown; other Ligustrum sp. have been reported have been reported to live for more than 100 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown; other Ligustrum sp. have been reported to take four years before flowering.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The species produces small purple black fruits (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). Like other Ligustrum sp. these fruits are thought to be dispersed by a range of birds (Blood 2001; Muyt 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Unknown; The seeds of other Ligustrum sp. however have been reported to be dispersed by currawongs which have a dispersal range in excess of 1 km (Bass 1996; Panetta 2000; Spennemann & Allen 2000).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: The species is used for hedging and can grow to 5 m (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). Therefore the species could form a barrier that would be of nuisance, it is unknown however if this occurs in the wild.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Unknown; the species is a large ornamental shrub, that has some toxic properties and may restrict access (Shepherd 2004; Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). The species has not however been reported to impact on recreation.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
Suspected to cause allergy (D’Amato & Liccardi 2002).
The fruit and leaves of Ligustrum species are reported to be potentially fatal (Shepherd 2004).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The species is a large ornamental shrub (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). The species may therefore have some impact upon aesthetics, this has not however been reported.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Unknown; a similar species can reportedly impact on the flow of water along drainage lines (Blood 2001, Muyt 2001).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Chemicals released from the leaves of the similar species L. sinense have been reported to impact on aquatic macro invertebrates (Llewellyn 2005). The species does occur in riparian areas, and could have some impact on water quality by changing light levels and nutrient imputes. There has been however no quantifiable reports of this species impacting upon water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: This is not specifically known, however as Webb et al (1988) describes the plant as a large shrub it is thought to pose some resistance to erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Unknown.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Damp Forest (E); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Strzelecki Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
The impact this species could potentially have on a specific strata is not known. The species has been reported to invade similar habitats to L. sinense, the impact of this has not been reported however (Roy et al 2004).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Wet Forest (D); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Strzelecki Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
The impact this species could potentially have on a specific strata is not known. The species has been reported to invade similar habitats to L. sinense, the impact of this has not been reported however (Roy et al 2004).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Forest (LC); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Wilsons Promontory; VH CLIMATE potential.
The impact this species could potentially have on a specific strata is not known. The species has been reported to invade similar habitats to L. sinense, the impact of this has not been reported however (Roy et al 2004).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: The impact this species could potentially have on a the vegetation structure is not known. The species has been reported to invade similar habitats to L. sinense, the impact of this has not been reported however (Roy et al 2004).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: The increased food privet species provide through the fruit load, supports increased populations of aggressive bird species such as currowongs (Blood 2001; Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999). This then has the potential to impact on other bird species populations, quantitative evidence of the impact on such species has not been reported however

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Being a large fruit producing shrub, the species is likely to provide some assistance in either food or shelter to desirable species (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The leaves and fruit of Ligustrum sp. are considered toxic (Shepherd 2004). There has been no evidence reported on if this species is toxic to native fauna and if so to what extent it impacts on them.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Blackbirds and starlings are also reported to eat fruit of other Ligustrum species (Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Unknown.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not reported as an agricultural weed. The species however is considered toxic and the similar species L. vulgare has been linked to cases of stock death (Everist 1974; Connor 1977; Shepherd 2004).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Honey collected from privet species is reported to smell like fish (Swarbrick, Timmins & Bullen 1999).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The species has been used as an ornamental (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). It is therefore unlikely to have any significant impact upon land values.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Unknown however as the species is considered to be largely an environmental weed this is unlikely.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Unknown however as the species is considered to be largely an environmental weed this is unlikely.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Unknown.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘…germination was greater after 4 weeks or more of stratification (Mackay et al 2002)’. Appears to require natural seasonal disturbances, e.g. cooler winter temperatures, for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Invades damp and wet sclerophyll forest (Carr et al 1992). ‘It tolerates full sun or shade equally well (TFS 2007)’. Known as an understorey species in Pinus radiata stands in NZ (Ogden et al 1997). Can establish under a moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘Able to invade relatively undisturbed sites (Blood 2001)’.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Large shrub or small tree to 6 m (Blood 2001).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No allelopathic properties described for C. robusta or similar species C. repens, of which the literature is more extensive.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘Plants are tolerant of heavy clipping or pruning (PFF 2002)’. Moderately tolerant of animal browsing (NZERN 2002). ‘Plants (C. repens) can re-shoot vigorously from the base if top growth is damaged or removed (Muyt 2001)’. Information suggests it would recover quickly from herbivory.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
‘Fast growing and inclined to become weedy (NZPCN 2005)’. Due to its rapid growth, in New Zealand it is often planted on bare infertile sites where it provides shelter for subsequent plantings (TFS 2007). Williams & Buxton (1989) found it to have one of the highest relative growth rates within a group of tree and shrub species studied. 
Rapid growth that will exceed most other species of the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Described as sensitive to drought (Bannister 1986) but also as having medium drought tolerance (NZERN 2002).
Occurs in rivers subject to tidal affects and ‘it has no trouble coping with inundation or brackish water (A. Crane pers. com)’. Often found where soil is poor or swampy, or where conditions are windy or cold, it is a tough plant that will grow in difficult conditions…wind hardy and frost tolerant when mature (TFS 2007)’. Similar species C. repens is tolerant to fire (Blood 2001). Displays tolerance to frost, water-logging, salinity and maybe fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: ‘Reproduces by seed (Blood 2001)’. ‘Plants are considered not self-fertile (PFF 2002)’, however, apomictic seed formation (without sexual reproduction) is observed in natural populations (Heenan et al 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Heavily fruiting females can be very spectacular (NZPCN 2005)’. Produces 4 seeds per fruit (Williams et al. 2000). Images indicate that an individual plant could produce many more than 500 fruits.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Burrows (1995) says that there is no indication that C. robusta forms ‘soil seed banks which would last for more than the period from seed-shed to the following spring’ and suggests that the dense stands ‘which spring up after forest disturbance do so from the seed crop of the previous fruiting season’. Seeds survive less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: As a large shrub / small tree (Blood 2001), likely to produce propagules for >10 yrs. Forms dense thickets / monocultures (R. Adair pers. com., J. Lynch pers. com).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Karamu does not produce fruit until about 3 years after planting (TFS 2007)’. Takes 2-5 years to reach sexual maturity.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Spread by birds and other animals and dumped garden waste (Blood 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Seedlings have been found germinating in gullies and bushland several kilometres from older infestations (Pers. com. J. Lynch). Birds and other animals (Blood 2001) could disperse seed greater than 1 km.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Will not flower and set seed if temperature is less than 15.5�C. ‘Most seed germinates in spring and early summer .. if conditions allow (late summer rains), seeds can also germinate from March to May’ (State Noxious Weed Control Board 1999). Does require seasonal disturbances for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
‘Thrives in warm, low rainfall environments’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). 

‘Competitiveness is limited under a closed canopy’ (Fisher et al 2000). Not documented as to whether or not the weed can establish under a canopy and prefers open, bare environments.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
‘In Colorado, was present in both logged forest and undisturbed, protected  ponderosa-pine/Douglas fir forest’ (Wali 1999, cited in CIPC 2003). ‘Invades disturbed sites 
such as roadsides, railways and eroded banks, and also grows in crops, pastures and rangelands’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).  Although thrives in highly disturbed natural ecosystems, can also establish in relatively intact or only minor disturbed natural ecosystem.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: ‘A bushy annual’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Life form– other

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: ‘Litter has allelopathic properties that affect crop plants and kochia seedlings. … Although it is allelopathic, the compounds appear to create autotoxicity that hastens its own demise’ (CIPC  2003).  ‘Some degree of allelopathy’ (University of Connecticut 2004).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: In Western Australia a control program where ‘high densities of sheep were used to provide extreme grazing pressure that caused defoliation of large plants and destruction of seedlings’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Under moderate herbivory pressure, assume plant would be capable of seed production.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Grows rapidly through spring and summer.’ ‘Seedlings grow vigorously, out competing perennial species with their rapid growth’ (State Noxious Weed Control Board 1999). ‘Rapid coloniser in high light situations’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Rapid growth that will equal competitive species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Very drought tolerant. Tolerant to saline soils. ‘Seeds germinate in early spring because of frost tolerance’ (State Noxious Weed Control Board 1999). Waterlogging tolerant. Highly resistant to at least 2 and not susceptible to more than one.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by seed only. Known to cross-pollinate but unknown whether it can self-pollinate (Csurhes & Edwards 1998).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘Typically produces around 14,600 seeds per plant’ (State Noxious Weed Control Board 1999).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘Laboratory studies report germination rates of 76 percent or better’. ‘Seeds buried in the soil have five percent viability after one year and zero percent after two years’ (State Noxious Weed Control Board 1999). ‘A small percentage of seeds may remain viable for two to four years’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual plant. ‘Normally the time between germination and death is six to seven months’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual plant (CIPC 2003).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Dispersed by wind and water (University of Connecticut 2004). Becomes a tumbleweed when mature (State Noxious Weed Control Board 1999).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: When winds reach 25 miles per hour, stem breaks and plants tumble (State Noxious Weed Control Board 1999). ‘Can spread up to several kilometres in a single year [by tumbling]’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Erect, much-branched stems from one to two metres long. Bush can grow up to 150 cm in height (Noxious Weed Control Board 1999). May have a low nuisance value which impedes individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Possible that the weed will have a minor effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Causes ‘ asthma, hayfever and allergic rhinitis.’ ‘Common cause of sensitisation ..’ (All Allergy 1998). Mildly toxic at certain times of year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Little or negligible effect on aesthetics or structure of cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘Has a main taproot [which can grow up to 5 metres] and network of finer roots.’ ‘Dead plants break off at the base and are blown by the wind as tumbleweeds (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Although, ‘can be used in revegetation programs for erosion control’ as it can out compete perennial species, chance of bare ground open to soil erosion is increased (Undersander et al 1990). Only low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Dense infestations could suppress recruitment of native ground cover plants and alter natural fire regime’ (Csurhes & Edwards 1998). As replacing grasses, biomass may slightly increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: ‘Dense infestations could suppress recruitment of native ground cover plants and alter natural fire regime’ (Csurhes & Edwards 1998). Plants die off during dry season. May have minor effect on intensity of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Parilla mallee (E); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘Dense infestations could suppress recruitment of native ground cover plants and alter natural fire regime’ (Csurhes & Edwards 1998).  Monoculture within the groundcover layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Parilla mallee (E); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘Dense infestations could suppress recruitment of native ground cover plants and alter natural fire regime’ (Csurhes & Edwards 1998).  Monoculture within the groundcover layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Grassy dry forest (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
‘Dense infestations could suppress recruitment of native ground cover plants and alter natural fire regime’ (Csurhes & Edwards 1998). Monoculture within the groundcover layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘Dense infestations could suppress recruitment of native ground cover plants and alter natural fire regime’ (Csurhes & Edwards 1998). Major effect on less than 60% of floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information available.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: No documented effect on non-threatened fauna spp.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Weed not known to provide benefits to indigenous fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: ‘Contains high levels of oxlates, alkaloids and nitrates that can be toxic to a variety of grazing animals if large amounts are consumed’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Toxic properties at certain times of the year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known to be a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbour to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Serious pest of late-maturing crops such as sorghum, soybeans and sugarbeets .. an effective competitor for light, nutrients and soil moisture, and can reduce crop yield’ (Noxious Weed Control Board 1999). ‘A weed that infests cereal crops in the Great Plains of the USA, often severely reducing yields’ (Fischer et al 2000). Assume greater than 20% reduction

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not documented to impact upon quality of yield.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not documented to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Unlikely that the weed would cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Possible that there will be a minor increase in time and labour required in harvesting.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: ‘Resistance to diseases’ (Undersander et al 1990). Not a known host or vector for diseases.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinate in autumn (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Requires seasonal temperatures.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Found principally in open areas (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Limited establishment in shade.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Primarily a plant of disturbed open areas… ‘occurs as weed of roadsides, railway reserves, sand dunes, cultivated fields, stubble paddocks , degraded pastures, and waste places ’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).  Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial herbaceous plants (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Life form – other.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: A. tenuifolia not documented to have Allelopathic properties (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not documented to be eaten by animals or insects (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Growth rate of A. tenuifolia is not documented. Others species have different growth rates. Therefore score as medium.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Susceptible to fire and waterlogging. Drought tolerant. Due to the locations it can be found, it appears to have saline tolerance. No documented evidence of ability to withstand frost (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually and vegetatively (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “All types (of ragweed) are prolific seeders … average about 3000 seeds per year’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Annual ragweed propagule longevity is up to 40 years (Schmoll, Reigner & Harrison 2004). In contrast, giant ragweed is only viable for 6 weeks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). No specific information on A. tenuifolia. Due to variation within genus, scored as medium.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Other ragweed species known to live up to 10 years. Lacy ragweed can form dense colonies (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: These three ragweed species reach maturity in approximately 9 months (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Known to be dispersed by clinging to sheep, furred animals, bags, clothing, water, contaminated gravel and soil (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Spreads ‘readily over long distances’. Hull provides buoyancy (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Assume likely that some of the propagules will disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grows between 30 to 60 cm high . Forms dense colonies but unlikely to have impact on human access (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Most species are ‘so ordinary in appearance that they are rarely noticed despite their abundance’. All species noted for allergens (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Some recreational uses affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: ‘Most important hay-fever producing plant in North America’. All species are noted for their allergens and are a major contributor to hay fever in US, with some places advertising as ‘ragweed free’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Also associated with asthma and dermatogenic properties. Major component in allergies.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Not known to cause structural damage. Little or negligible effect on aesthetics.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Plants have ‘creeping runner-like roots’ (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Aerial growth dies off but unlikely that the species would contribute to large-scale soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Occurs principally in open areas or waste lands (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Likely that biomass would slightly increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Herbaceous plant (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001) so assume that it would have small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains Grassy Woodland (E), CMA=Glenelg-Hopkins, Bioreg.=Dundas Tablelands, CLIMATE=VH. 
Weed
doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Very little displacement of any indigenous species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Coastal Alkaline Scrub (D), CMA=West Gippsland, Bioreg=Gippsland Plain, CLIMATE=H. 
Weed doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Very little displacement of any indigenous species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Coastal Tussock Grassland (LC), CMA=West Gippsland, Bioreg.=Gippsland Plain, CLIMATE=H. 
Weed doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata
are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Very little displacement of any indigenous species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Weed doesn’t occur in healthy, well-established ecosystems. Occurs mostly in open, disturbed areas where less than 3 strata are present (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Usually only affecting one of the strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information available.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
Tends to grow in rural sites so assume that there is no reduction in habitat/food/shelter for non threatened fauna species.
(Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Lacy ragweed not documented to provide benefit to non-threatened fauna species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not documented to be injurious to fauna species (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not documented to provide a food source to pest species.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not likely that it provides harbour for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Occurs in cultivated fields, stubble paddocks and degraded pastures but not documented to impact agricultural yield (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not documented to impact quality of yield (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No information on whether or not the weed affects land value. Weed can be controlled by herbicides (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed can be controlled by herbicide (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Often found on degraded lands. Assume no change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No documented evidence to suggest that harvest costs would increase due to the presence of lacy ragweed.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Germination usually takes place .. at 10�C’ (PFAF n.d.). Requires seasonal temperatures.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: ‘It can grow in full shade (deep woodland) semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade’ but flowers better in sun (PFAF n.d.). Can establish without additional factors.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Can be found in grassland, forest edges, disturbed sites (Weber 2003). Can establish in relatively intact natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Small shrub (Weber 2003). Life form – other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: In California, the chrysomelid beetle, Chrysolina quadrigemina, was found to attack H. calycinum (Van Klinken & Edwards 2002). In ‘H. calycinum, the same chemical not only attracts pollinating insects but also deters herbivores that pose a threat to its survival’ (Gronquist et al 2001). Score as medium high as is consumed in California but generally not eaten by animals or insects.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Grows ‘at a fast rate’ (PFAF n.d.). Assume that growth will equal competitive species of same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘A drought-resistant and fire-tolerant species’ (Weber 2003). Can grow in sandy soils (PFAF n.d.). ‘A very cold-hardy plant, tolerating temperatures down to about -25�C (PFAF n.d.). Not documented as to whether plant can withstand waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Has rhizomes (Weber 2003). Both cross and self-pollinated (PFAF n.d.). Both vegetative and sexual reproduction.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Propagules produced per flowering event not documented. Spreads more through rhizomes. Has ‘extensively creeping rhizomes’ (Weber 2003). Score as medium.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Mainly reproduces vegetatively. No documented information on seed viability. Score as low.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘.. forms dense colonies due to the extensively creeping rhizomes’ (Weber 2003). Capable of forming dense monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Time to reproductive maturity is not documented. Score as medium.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: No evidence of how propagules are spread. Mainly spread by gravity.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Unlikely that propagules will disperse greater than 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Shrub which can grow up to 60 cm tall (Weber 2003). Can grow up to one metre wide and dense (PFAF n.d.). Unlikely that the weed would restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Bright yellow flowers up to 8 cm in diameter (Weber 2003). ‘.its large golden flowers with pink anthers are very conspicuous’ (Webb et al 1988). Tourists may be aware of weed but not bothered or activity inhibited.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Plant not known to be injurious or toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: ‘.. its large golden flowers with pink anthers are very conspicuous’ (Webb et al 1988). Would have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Weber 2003).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Root system is fast spreading and stoloniferous. Unlikely that the plant would contribute to large scale soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘It impedes the growth and regeneration of native shrubs and trees by competing for nutrients and space’ (Weber 2003). Can be found in grassland, forest edges, disturbed sites (Weber 2003). In some situations, biomass may slightly decrease if plant out competes other trees and shrubs

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Evergreen plant. Weed would have a small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains Grassy Woodland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Volcanic Plains; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘It impedes the growth and regeneration of native shrubs and trees by competing for nutrients and space’ (Weber 2003). ‘.. forms dense colonies due to the extensively creeping rhizomes’ (Weber 2003). Displaces all species within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
Grassy Dry Forest (D); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Volcanic Plains; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘It impedes the growth and regeneration of native shrubs and trees by competing for nutrients and space’ (Weber 2003). ‘.. forms dense colonies due to the extensively creeping rhizomes’ (Weber 2003). Displaces all species within a layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
