EVC= Coastal Tussock Grassland (LC); CMA=Port Phillip; Bioreg=Gippsland Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
‘It impedes the growth and regeneration of native shrubs and trees by competing for nutrients and space’ (Weber 2003). ‘.. forms dense colonies due to the extensively creeping rhizomes’ (Weber 2003). Displaces all species within a layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘It impedes the growth and regeneration of native shrubs and trees by competing for nutrients and space’ (Weber 2003). ‘.. forms dense colonies due to the extensively creeping rhizomes’ (Weber 2003). Major effect on all layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Weed not documented to have an effect on non-threatened fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Weed not known to provide support to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Weed is not toxic and has no spines or burrs.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not listed as a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not listed as a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Weed not known to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed not known to cause a change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not listed as a weed of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not known as an alternative host or vector for diseases of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Each time [a stem] falls to the ground it takes root” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Protected, partly shaded position recommended for horticultural plantings (Bodkin, 1990).
However, pictures of the vine (Starr, 2002), and the types of vegetation that it invades (Starr, Starr & Loop, 2003) suggest that it needs access to light.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Mostly lowland moist disturbed areas; Sparingly adventive along hiking trails or margins of urban areas; spreading vegetatively from planting into nearby disturbed lowland scrub.

Remnant wet forests and coastal river habitat (Starr, Starr & Loop, 2003). Roadsides, pastures and headlands of canefields (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Climbing vine (PIER, 2005).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: None found in CRC Weed Management (2003).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Very tuberous root system which can resprout from many dormant buds when cut, but no record of herbivory in CRC Weed Management (2003).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Aggressive…attaining height up to at least 15 m (Starr, Starr & Loop, 2003). Large, aggressive
vine…capacity to smother coastal, lowland rainforest (Csurhes & Edwards, 1998).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Young plants die back when temperatures drop below freezing point. Commonly found in damp areas (CRC Weed Management, 2003), and Bodkin (1990) notes that it is drought and frost tender.  Tolerant of one and susceptible to at least two stressors.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Seeds, cuttings and fragments of stems and roots (PIER, 2005).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Most literature indicates that the vine is sterile, mostly reproducing by vegetative means. However, in Johnson Shire T. laurifolia has been observed growing from seed, which is quite unusual. Images in CRC publication suggest that if seeding were to occur, probably more than 1,000 seeds could be produced per flowering event (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Tubers numerous and large, often the size of a 4WD vehicle. Uncommonly produces viable seed and is assumed to reproduce vegetatively most of the time (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Individual patches completely cover several hectares, eventually leading to the destruction of most other vegetation (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Photographs show T. laurifolia forming dense monocultures (Starr, 2002).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: No data available. Mostly known to reproduce vegetatively

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds, cuttings and fragments of stems and roots (PIER, 2005). Contaminated fill. Careless disposal of garden waste. Infestations along riverbanks have been caused by root pieces… being transported by floodwaters (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Can spread from dumping of garden cuttings (PIER, 2005). Also floodwaters (see number of mechanisms) and stem/root fragments. Most propagation is vegetative and some vegetative  pieces could be transported km by people and water, but most would be unlikely to disperse more than 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A “vigorous, perennial climbing vine…forming impenetrable colonies” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).  See also the picture in this reference depicting a wall of vine that would be a major impediment to access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The extent of these infestations would be obvious to most visitors and it also has the ability to “pull down mature trees” with their weight and in lower layers of vegetation, “killing many plants” (NR & M, 2005).  This would render natural areas extremely unappealing to most potential visitors.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No spines, burrs or toxins noted in CRC Weed Management (2003).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: “Large tubers can cause damage to paths, fences and foundations” ” (NR & M, 2005) as well as the devastating effects on natural environments described in Q. 11. This plant could cause major structural damage to sites and obliteration of cultural features.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Infests areas along coastal streams ” (NR & M, 2005) and with its ability to pull down mature trees, could cause obstructions in waterways that might have a major effect on either subsurface or surface flow, depending on where the tree falls and how large it is.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Unlikely to have an impact on water quality as it is a terrestrial species not noted as growing in water (CRC Weed  Management, 2003).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Where this plant pulls down trees (see Q. 2) and exposes soil, erosion is likely to occur.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Biomass will be significantly reduced by this plant where it kills and replaces large woody vegetation (see Q. 2).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Where the less specialised Thunbergia replaces scleromorphic vegetation (see Q. 2) it is likely to greatly reduce the frequency and intensity of fire, an important mechanism even in rainforest (Groves, ed., 1994).

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Potential distribution analysis shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Potential distribution analysis shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Potential distribution analysis shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “The plant climbs and blankets native vegetation often pulling down mature trees with the weight of the vine. Smothered vegetation also has dramatically reduced light levels to lower layers of vegetation drastically limiting growth, and killing many plants” ” (NR & M, 2005). This plant could have a major effect on all layers in a community, killing trees as well as lower vegetation layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Potential distribution analysis shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: This vine’s ability to replace almost all the flora in a community (see Q. 11), dramatically changes habitat, leading to the possible extirpation of fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Provides very little support for desirable species as it “blankets native vegetation” (CRC Weed Management, 2003), reducing habitat value.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No spines, burrs, toxins etc. noted in CRC Weed Management (2003).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not noted as a food source for pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “In agricultural areas it infests roadsides, pastures and headlands of cane fields, forming impenetrable colonies” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Not recorded as palatable to herbivores, so there is the potential for it to reduce the carrying capacity of invaded pasture. The extent would depend on the infestation of which no data could be found, so a medium score was chosen.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No spines, burrs, toxicity noted in CRC Weed Management (2003).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: See Q. 19. This plant would be very obvious in a pasture, so if it colonises large areas, with an ability to significantly reduce yield it would reduce land value, but there is no evidence for this, so a medium value was chosen.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See Q. 20. Large enough infestations may force a change from pasture to cropping (where the plant is only recorded in headlands of cane fields (CRC Weed Management, 2003) and so is probably a viable alternative. No information about the extent of pasture infestations is available though.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not noted as a weed of cropping (just cane field headlands in CRC Weed Management, 2003), so should not increase harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: “Thunbergia species are susceptible to spider mites, white-flies and scale insects” (Starr, Starr & Loope, 2003). These pest species are a problem in agricultural crops, however they are not uncommon, so infestations on this plant probably won’t increase infection rates by much, if at all.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination will occur after the seeds have been exposed to a period of preconditioning; have been stimulated by root exudates of host or false host species and exposed to seasonal temperature and moisture levels (Koncaloc� & Krop�c 1997).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Needs to be in the vicinity of the roots of a host plant (Evans 1962).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in growing crops including clover, tobacco and broad bean (Foy et al 1989).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; an annual or perennial herbaceous obligate root parasite (Holm et al 1997).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Does reduce the host plants vigour, however there is allelopathy reported.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
In Europe it is considered unpalatable by stock as it smells and has a bitter taste, however it has been reported to be grazed in Australia (Evans 1962).
Grazing by sheep has reportedly resulted in death of those plants grazed, can be eliminated with heavy grazing (Southwood 1971).
Grazing may kill plants but seeds of other Orobanche sp. have been reported to remain viable after passing through a sheep (Foy et al 1989). Therefore under moderate grazing the species is considered to be still capable of sexual reproduction.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
As a parasite Orobanche clearly has a competitive advantage over any of its host species, it can effectively stop the host plant growing (Eizenberg, Colquhoun & Mallory-Smith 2005).
Once the plant emerges it will flower, set seed and die back in the space of a few months (Holm et al 1997).
Therefore the species is considered to be competitive with other fast growing annual and perennial herbs.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Unknown, probably dependent on host species.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Produces seed through self pollination (Elias et al 2006).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Jones (1991) report a maximum theoretical seed production of 111,780 seeds, if the plant produced 90 flowers which was the maximum number produced by a plant during their study and each capsule contained 1242 seeds which was also the maximum found during their study. The seed production is deemed high as to produce more than 200 seeds, either the plant with 90 flowers only need to produce 25 seeds per capsule or two capsules with the maximum number of seeds of 1242.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
There are reports that the species seeds can remain viable for more than 10 years, it is unknown however what proportion remain viable.
Seeds can remain viable in the soil for more than 10 years (Elias et al 2006).
Seed remains viable in the soil for 10-15 years (Edwards 1972).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Under favourable conditions can have two periods of reproduction, however most commonly acts as an annual (Evans 1962).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: The species is treated as an annual however the seedlings may live in the soil for a number of years before emerging (Mussleman 1994).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds are very small and can be dispersed by wind, water, grazing animals and accidental human dispersal though contamination (Elias et al 2006).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Not specifically known; however with the range and number of dispersal agents it is likely that some seeds will disperse more than 1km.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘In southern NSW lippias ability to grow and spread is mainly limited to the period October to April (Dellow et al 2001)’. The remarkable ability of Lippia to reinvade from seeds and cuttings means it can quickly regenerate, particularly following significant rain or flooding (Dellow et al 2001). Appears to require natural seasonal disturbances for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Being a C3 plant, it is able to tolerate shady conditions and has therefore been recommended
as a lawn and garden plant, particularly for shady conditions (Leigh & Walton 2004). Can establish under a moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘Lippia is considered a major threat to riparian and associated ecosystems because of its dominance over native plants. Forms monocultures on otherwise undisturbed land (Julien et al 2004)’. Establishes in relatively intact ecosystems, e.g. riparian communities, wetlands.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Creeper: Prostrate perennial herb with extensive fibrous roots and creeping stems (Julien et al 2004).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Studies show that plant extracts significantly reduce the germination of some species including lettuce, vetch and clover (Elakovich & Stevens 1985, Daley et al 2005). Allelopathic properties seriously affecting some plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Relatively unpalatable to cattle as they tend to only eat small amounts of the plant and only after other pasture species are exhausted (Lucy et al 1995). Consumed but not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Lippia is a fast growing plant and when in competition with other species, it can grow to a height of 20-30 cm, and dominate other plants (Leigh & Walton 2004). Rapid growth rate.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Drought resistant (Julien et al 2004) and able to tolerate long periods of water logging (Leigh & Walton 2004). It is documented as being salt tolerant and as growing at sites of heavy winter frost (Richardson 1994 in Leigh & Walton 2004) and is reported to be tolerant of fire (Earl 2003). Its deep taproot allows it to go into dormancy during periods of stress, and then quickly re-grow after rainfall or flooding (Lucy et al 1995).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually and vegetatively by producing roots at stem nodes (Mawhinney 2004).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Described as being a prolific seeder (Lucy et al 1995), but also, that seed set may be low in Australia due to the discovery of very small seed banks (Leigh & Walton 2004). However, no information on the number of propagules produced by an individual plant was found.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘There is no information in the literature on how long seed may remain viable in the soil (Lucy et al 1995)’.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: It forms monocultures (Julien et al 2004) and spreads rapidly by rooting at stem nodes (Mawhinney 2004) and is therefore likely to be self sustaining.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: It spreads rapidly by rooting at stem nodes (Mawhinney 2004), and vegetative fragments dispersed by floodwaters can quickly produce roots and become established as new plants within a matter of days (Lucy et al 1995). Vegetative propagules can become separate individuals in under a year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds and vegetative fragments are dispersed via flood.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Dispersal via attachment to birds or flood waters (Leigh & Walton 2004) could disperse seeds
greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: As a low growing prostrate herb (Leigh & Walton 2004) it is unlikely to restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments:
In a QLD survey some people indicated that ‘lippia detracts from the enjoyment gained from the land, partly in terms of impacts on recreation and partly through its mere presence (Elliot 2001 in Leigh & Walton 2004)’.
Lippia causes the surfaces of playing fields to become slippery and can be potentially dangerous for sporting activities (Leigh & Walton 2004). Some recreational uses affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Nothing was found documented to suggest this species possesses any properties injurious to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: ‘It contributes to deep soil drying leading to bank slumping and erosion especially in cracking clays, resulting in damage to diversion banks, dam walls and roads (Julien et al 2004)’. Structural damage is likely to be moderate.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Its low growth is linked to an associated increase in the speed of floodwaters (Lucy et al 1995). Likely to cause a minor increase to surface flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Increased soil erosion, caused by lippia, could result in increased nutrient loading and stream water turbidity, which may contribute to an increase in algal blooms and eutrophication (Lucy et al 1995).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Riverbanks overtaken by lippia often become extremely unstable with a greatly increased incidence of subsistence of sections of bank into the river (Lucy et al 1995), and ‘as well as being locally damaging, this has severe implications in terms of downstream water quality and movement of soil (Julien 2005)’. High probability of large scale soil movement with major off-site implications.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: As a very low growing prostrate herb its ability to completely displace ground layer vegetation (Leigh & Walton 2004), as well as affect the regeneration of woody species, such as the eucalypts, E. coolabah & E. carnaldulensis, and the large shrub Muehlenbeckia cunninghamii (Earl 2003), it could significantly decrease biomass of a community.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: ‘Reduced fire risk’ is described as one of the possible economic benefits of lippia, and, the NSW state forestry service does not consider it a problem plant because in forestry areas it reduces fire hazards due to the low fuel loads (Leigh & Walton 2004). Its ability to reduce fuel loads is likely to cause a decrease in the intensity of fire, and ‘reduced fire risk’ indicates that it may also reduce fire frequency.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Red Gum Wetland (E); CMA= Goulburn Broken; Bioreg= Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
There are many communities threatened by the presence of lippia (Earl 2003). It is able to completely dominate ground layer vegetation (Leigh & Walton 2004) forming monocultures, and is considered a major threat to riparian and associated ecosystems (Julien et al 2004).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Lakebed herbland (D); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; VH CLIMATE potential.
It is able to completely dominate ground layer vegetation (Leigh & Walton 2004) forming monocultures, and is considered a major threat to riparian and associated ecosystems (Julien et al 2004).

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Shrubby Riverine Woodland (V); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; VH CLIMATE potential.
It is able to completely dominate ground layer vegetation (Leigh & Walton 2004) forming monocultures, and is considered a major threat to riparian and associated ecosystems (Julien et al 2004).

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: It is able to completely dominate ground layer vegetation (Leigh & Walton 2004) forming monocultures, and is considered a major threat to riparian and associated ecosystems (Julien et al 2004). Major effect on <60% of floral strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Earl (2003) lists 14 threatened flora species listed under the EPBC Act, including Echinocloa inundata within the Macquarie Marshes, that are known to occur in the distribution of lippia, and that may be adversely impacted. She also states that ‘any species that occurs in wetlands, along riparian zones or on floodplains which are affected by lippia could be regarded as potentially threatened because of the extent of the modification of the habitat…’.  However, lippias direct impact on these species has not been officially assessed (Leigh & Walton 2004).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: ‘…the loss of wildlife habitat has been observed in the Macquarie marshes, including the reduced availability of waterbird nesting sites as a result of the conversion of water couch communities to lippa (Leigh & Walton 2004)’.  This reduced habitat suitability would likely lead to a population reduction of waterbirds in the area.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits to indigenous fauna were found documented, and as a prostrate herb described as having limited palatability (Julien 2005) t is likely to provide very little support to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No information was found documented to indicate that this species is injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Honey bees extract large quantities of nectar from the flowers (Leigh & Walton 2004). Supplies food for minor pest species

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: ‘Lippia replaces productive pasture species and reduces grazing productivity, in some cases necessitating total destocking (Julien et al 2004)’. In a Murray Darling Basin survey, average destocking rate was 55%, and up to 100% in severely infested paddocks (Julien et al 2004)’. Major reduction in available grazing land, serious impact on yield (>20% reduction).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Induced copper deficiency can develop in sheep that graze on lippia which may lead to the formation of ‘metallic wool’, which is described as a potential ‘economic cost of lippia (Leigh & Walton 2004)’. However, the degree to which wool quality may be affected is unclear.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: ‘The presence of lippia on a farm reduces the farm’s value because of the reduced productivity and cost of largely ineffectual controls (Julien et al 2004)’. ‘Lippia has been estimated to cost the Moree Shire $12A million in reduced land values (BRCMLC 2002 in Leigh & Walton 2004). Well documented, significant reductions (>10%) possible.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: ‘One such paddock, remembered as good pasture in the early 1970s, is now completely overgrown with lippia and has been abandoned as a grazing pasture (Leigh & Walton 2004)’. Total destocking from pasture is sometimes necessary as control is not achieved by conventional management practises. However, it is managed by cultivation, and inundated floodplains that should be maintained as permanent pastures are being cultivated (Julien et al 2004). Causes downgrading of the priority land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: ‘There are additional significant costs related to herbicidal control, clearing and infrastructure damage (Julien et al 2004)’. Major increase in production costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not found described as a host of pests or diseases of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Flowers in October to May (spring to autumn) (Webb et al, 1988, Blood, 2001). Prefers well composted, moist, well drained soils in a protected position (Shepherd, 2004). It is noted in horticulture information that the plant is susceptible to frost and requires moderately warm temperatures and sufficient moisture to germinate (The Garden Helper, 1997). Therefore the most suitable time for germination would be after winter frosts through to spring.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Naturalised in disturbed wet areas mostly coastal in Eastern Australia (Spencer, 2002) and is able to establish in shady places (Roy et al, 1998 ). In a study by Aliero et al (2006a) found that this species required little amount of nitrogen and that watering regimes significantly influenced growth performance. The species is intolerable to drought indicating that it is dependant on reliable and sufficient water input. It does not require specific nutrients
although it is responsive to some nutrient input and is able to establish under limited light.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Can invade damp sclerophyll forest, riparian vegetation and warm temperate rainforests (Carr et al, 1992), forests and forest edges (Weber, 2003). Establishes in hedges, plantations, remnant forest and shady places (Roy et al, 1998) In New Zealand the plant has been documented to be occasional to locally plentiful in damaged forests (Connor, 1977). A weed of disturbed areas, rough pasture and along bushland edges (Shepherd, 2004). The plant
is able to establish in a range of highly disturbed areas and in relatively intact areas also.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A herbaceous to somewhat woody perennial of 50 - 200 cm height with a spread of 1 m (Weber, 2003, Shepherd, 2004). Small to medium shrub (Carr et al, 1992). A shrub that may reach 1 m and can grow up to 2 m (Hussey et al 1997, Blood, 2001 ).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Fruit has been well studied for its compounds but no studies have been undertaken on its allelopathic qualities.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Plant is usually ignored by livestock (Roy et al, 1998). The poisons contained in berry are fatal to human and animal (Aliero et al, 2006b)

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: A herbaceous woody perennial, however no information was found on growth in relation to similar life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: The plant is intolerant to drought condition and requires small amounts of fertilizer for successful propagation (Aliero et al, 2006a). The species has been noted to occur in some frost free localities near Auckland (Roy et al, 1998) It is susceptible to drought and frost and may be somewhat tolerant to salinity by colonising in coastal areas in eastern Australia.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces by seed (Blood, 2001). No evidence of whether it’s self or cross fertilisation.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: The number of seeds per berry ranges from 50 to 100 while the berries could be as many as 100 per plant (Aliero et al, 2006a). Therefore the plant has the capacity to produce above 2,000 seeds per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: No information was found on propagule longevity.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: No information was found on the length of the reproductive periods of the plant.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: 2 to 5 years to reproductive maturity (Whyvale Garden Centres).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Birds, internal, water (Carr et al, 1992) and dumped garden waste (Blood, 2001). Berries are eaten by birds which are the main means of seed dispersal (Webb et al, 1988).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Very likely that at least one propagule will be dispersed greater than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A herbaceous to somewhat woody perennial of 50 - 200 cm height with a spread of 1 m (Weber, 2003; Shepherd, 2004). Can invade damp sclerophyll forest, riparian vegetation and warm temperate rainforests (Carr et al, 1992), forests and forest edges (Weber, 2003). Plant exudes an unpleasant odour (Weber, 2003). Stems are wiry and much branched (Roy et al, 1998). This plant is unlikely to restrict human access however can be a nuisance.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: The plant produces bright attractive red berries that might be perceived as being aesthetically pleasing conversely the odour produced from plant might have negative impact on visitors.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The majority of the compounds identified in the plant are known to be poisonous hence making both berries and leaves toxic to humans and animals (Aliero et al, 2006b). The berries if ingested have been reported to be fatal to humans and animals (Aliero et al, 2006b).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: The plant does not cause any structural damage however dense fruiting populations may have a moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Although the plant is known to invade riparian environments it is not known to invade the water body or streambeds.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: No noticeable effect on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant has the capacity to invade and transform areas by displacing existing natives and leaving area open to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: There is no evidence from the literature studied that the plant alters the biomass of the community.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: There is no direct information on fire response of this plant. Therefore on the basis that the plant does not significantly alter the biomass of a community it can be concluded that it has a small or negligible effect on fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Grassy Forest (E); CMA= Corangamite; Bioregion= Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
Prefers well composted, moist, well drained soils in a protected position (Shepherd, 2004). Can invade damp sclerophyll forest, riparian vegetation and warm temperate rainforests (Carr et al, 1992), forests and forest edges (Weber, 2003). A  herbaceous to somewhat woody perennial of 50 - 200 cm height with a spread of 1 m (Weber, 2003, Shepherd, 2004). Small to medium shrub (Carr et al, 1992). The DSE (2004) describes climbers and scramblers of damp heathland to comprise 5% of the lifeforms within this EVC. Furthermore infestations of this species can displace and shade out species of the lower stratum subsequently modifying ecosystem structure.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (D); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins; Bioregion= Greater Grampians; VH CLIMATE potential.
The DSE (2004) describes small shrubs to comprise 1% to the lifeforms within the Riparian Forest EVC. The species prefers well composted, moist, well drained soils in a protected position (Shepherd, 2004). The species is intolerable to drought indicating that it is dependant on reliable and sufficient water input. Riparian Forests are regularly inundated and permanently moist (DSE, 2004) making them suitable environmental for optimal growth of this species enabling it to establish and displace existing species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Damp Forests (LC); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioregion= Highlands Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. 
The species prefers well composted, moist, well drained soils in a protected position (Shepherd, 2004). The species is intolerable to drought indicating that it is dependant on reliable and sufficient water input. Riparian Forests are regularly inundated and permanently moist (DSE, 2004) making them suitable environmental for optimal growth of this species enabling it to establish and displace existing species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: The species grows to the height of 2 m hence affecting only up to the lower end of the mid stratum and the lower stratum. Images of infestations viewed online (North West Weeds, 2007) indicate that the species becomes abundant and forms dense patches that crowd out native plants and prevents shrub regeneration (Weber, 2003). Hence the species has the capacity to produce dense cover over other species in the lower stratum therefore it will still have some impact on structure on both under and mid story.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: The impact on threatened flora is indeterminable.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Plant is usually ignored by livestock (Roy et al, 1998). Therefore can assume that it is not an attractive food for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Seeds are dispersed by ingestion of birds. It has been recorded that currowongs eat the berries (Buchanan, 1989). In winter the leaves remain green and very attractive (Aliero et al, 2006) to animals making it a possible food source despite being poisonous however probably not a reliable one. Therefore it may be that the dense populations of this plant may provide an additional food source.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The plant has been recorded to contain poisonous solanocapsine and alkaloids that are reported to be fatal to man and animals (Aliero et al, 2006b). It is avoided by livestock and native animals might do the same. Birds must have a degree of tolerance because they are the main seed dispersal vector. The plant is toxic in the flowering and fruiting stages for guinea pigs and rabbits and toxic to horses as well (Eckell, 1946).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments:
A study conducted by Santos et al (2003) investigated the diet of the maned wolf (Chrysocyon brachyurus) in South America and found that S. pseudocapsicum made up a small percentage of this animals diet. This may suggest that foxes (Vulpes vulpes) may also eat fruit but again would comprise a minor component of diet
Furthermore it is noted in the literature (Buchanan, 1989) that the berries of this plant are readily ingested by Pied currowongs in suburban Sydney. Considering that this native species feeds on the berries it is highly likely that exotic species would do the same.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: This species has the capacity to produce dense crowded populations hence it has the potential to provide temporary harbour for foxes and rabbits however due to its wiry structure at medium height may not be suitable for permanent harbour for pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: This is a weed that can invade rough pastures additionally it is a plant that is ignored by livestock. It has a large seed set and can produce large dense populations. It might reduce the production or vigour of other crops or plants by competing with them for water and nutrients. Despite the preceding statement there is no evidence that this species is a serious weed of agriculture

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: There is no evidence that it is a weed of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The literature is noted that it is found in rough pastures this suggests poor quality land value to begin with so may not alter the land value significantly. There is insufficient information to suggest the plants impact on land value would be greater than 10%.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The plant is not considered a serious weed of agriculture therefore it would not cause serious alteration of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: The plant is not a weed of agriculture. It is not likely to increase agricultural costs by increasing harvesting time or is not a potential contaminant in agricultural produce.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: The plant is susceptible to a powdery mildew (Erysiphe sp) that occurred in greenhouse-grown tomato crops in southern England (Fletcher and Smewin, 1988). The plant has also been noted to harbour the new Psyllid-Yellows disease prevalent in potato and other solanaceous plants (Binkley, 1929). This disease can be transmitted from diseased tomato to healthy potato plants. The plant is also a possible host for the tomato moth Scrobipalpula absoluta (Galarza, 1984) and for the tomato leaf curl virus tested under glasshouse experiments (DPIF, 2006).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate from mid-spring to early autumn.” Requires natural seasonal disturbance (i.e. temperature & rainfall).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
A sun-loving plant, occurring on well drained fertile soils, commonly along streams, roadsides, fence lines and neglected fields. 

Requires open situation and fertile soils.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Occurs in disturbed situations such as stream banks, roadsides, fence lines and neglected pastures.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual herb. Others.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: No data available. The plant has poisoned horses and mules in Greece; cattle and sheep may avoid it.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
“Hemp grows rapidly and soon crowds out weeds. Hemp tends to exhaust the soil of nutrients.” 

“It is not usually competitive with crops but, in India, sometimes significantly reduces maize yields.” Possibly exceeds growth rate of species of similar life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “… plants are killed by frost. “ As the root system comprises a much-branched taproot with a mass of laterals in the upper 20 cm of soil, it would possibly survive dry periods during summer. “… once established, [it] survives on very little water.”

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces sexually. Dioecious plants; possibly out-cross.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Plants produce abundant seed! Assume plant produces less than 2,000 seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seed stored in cool dry place remain viable for up to two years.” Seeds survive less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: An annual. Mature plant produces propagules for only one year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Plants germinate from mid-spring to early summer and the plant requires about 110 days to mature. Flowering begins in January and continues until late autumn.” Reaches maturity in less than one year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The seed is not equipped with any mechanism to aid dispersal. Most seeds fall close to the plant. Seed can be spread by water, and some by birds. However, the majority of spread is by deliberate human action. Spread by highly mobile animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Some seed may be dispersed less than 1 km due to water or birds but, as most spread is due to human agency, propagules may spread more than one kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “A bushy, erect sometimes slightly woody herb 2 – 7 metres high. A sun loving plant, it becomes naturalised in open areas along streams, roadsides, fence lines and in neglected fields.” Dense stands of this plant may impede individual access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Infestation densities are not recorded and, “it is not usually competitive with crops.” Not likely to affect recreational activities greatly. Minor visual effect.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The fruit is toxic.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Branching taproot to 100 cm with dense laterals extending to about 3 meters. Root system not vigorous. Dense patches would create a moderate negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Branching taproot to 100 cm with dense laterals extending to about 3 meters. Competitiveness with other vegetation unknown. The plant itself would not contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “A bushy, erect sometimes slightly woody herb 2 – 7 meters high…it becomes naturalised in open areas along streams, roadsides, fence lines and in neglected fields.” Likely to slightly increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: In dense infestations, woody stems remaining after plant dies may increase the frequency of fire risk.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “It survives on very little water,” possibly because of the extensive root system. Survival may be to the detriment of understorey species. Infestation density not known; minor effect on the flora strata.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Dense patches may reduce food source of native species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No documented benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Mules and horses have been poisoned in Greece.” Potentially toxic to native fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No known as a food source to pests.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “It is not usually competitive with crops but, in India, sometimes significantly reduces maize yields.” May be toxic to stock.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No known to affect the quality of agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Control of this weed is not difficult, nor does it appear to affect agricultural yields. In arable areas, “the most effective and cheapest method of control is to establish strongly competitive pastures.” Not likely to affect land values.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Invasiveness and persistence of the plant is not documented. “Effective control can also be obtained with herbicides in both non-crop and cropping situations.” Not likely to result in change in land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination increases after a period of stratification (Mackay et al 2002). ‘Propagate from seed in spring and semi ripe cuttings in summer (Burnie et al 1998)’. Natural seasonal disturbances appear to be required for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Found in both shade and full sun (Muyt 2001). Seedling survival is best in protected areas under other shrubs and where leaf litter accumulations are deeper (Blood 2001). Able to establish under a moderate canopy/ litter cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Can establish in healthy natural ecosystems, such as heathland communities (Carr et al 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Prostrate shrub to small tree to 8 m high (Campbell & Atkinson 2002, Harden 1991).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Fast growing (Blood 2001).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘Tolerates sea and salt spray, strong wind, salt, exposed positions, drought, frost, fire and most soil types (Blood 2001)’. Tolerant of water logging, as occurs in permanent wetlands (Carr et al 1992).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: ‘In exposed areas can become prostrate. In these situations and coastal dunes plants develop the ability to layer themselves, the branches touching the ground and rooting to form new plants (Blood 2001)’. Can reproduce via seed and vegetatively by layering (Campbell & Atkinson 2002).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Fruiting is prolific on larger plants (Muyt 2001). ‘Many small seeds are produced in bright red berries (DPIWE 2001)’. As a shrub/ tree to 8 m (Blood 2001), it is assumed able to produce 2000+ seeds.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Not found described.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: As a long lived shrub/ tree (Blood 2001), with widespread medium to large populations (Carr et al 1992) capable of forming dense colonies (DPIWE 2001), it is likely to produce propagules for 10 + years or form self-sustaining  monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Not found described.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Seeds dispersed by birds (Fergusen and Drake 1999, Muyt 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Eaten and dispersed by starlings (Fergusen and Drake 1999) which are documented as dispersing seeds up to 40 km (Spennemann & Allen 2000).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Most musk thistle seedlings emerge in the fall, although seedlings can also emerge in large numbers in the spring.” Requires natural seasonal disturbance.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “… more seeds germinate and establish on bare soils in open pastures and other poorly vegetated sites. Exposure to darkness… inhibited germination.” Requires bare ground with direct access to sunlight.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “It is one of the weeds which establishes will on bare ground occurring in pastures at the end of summer or on sheep camps or bare patches caused by rabbits, pasture insects etc.” Establishes in highly disturbed systems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Annual or biennial herb. Other category.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: “there is overseas evidence that the plant produces allelopathic compounds which could contribute to its competitiveness.” Properties may seriously affect some plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “… it is not readily grazed because of its spiny foliage. Its presence also discourages animals from grazing neighbouring pasture plants.” In the U.S., “… cattle and domestic sheep and goats have been observed consuming flowers and seedheads.” Rarely eaten.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “It is one of the weeds which establishes well on bare ground occurring in pastures at the end of summer. In contrast, seedlings do not establish where reasonable pasture cover is maintained. [It] is a poor competitor with other thistle species.” However, once established as rosettes, shoots ‘bolt’ depending upon weather and altitude. In the U.S., it flowers and starts to produce seed 45 to 55 days after it bolts. Moderately rapid growth rate, similar to competitive species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Plants require a period of vernalisation for floral initiation to occur. In the U.S., this period is a minimum of at least 40 days below 10�C. “Musk thistle flowers and seeds are produced over a long period… continuing as later flowers mature until after fall frost.” Plant tolerates frost.
“… musk thistle occupies habitats ranging from saline soils in low altitude valleys.” Salt tolerant.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Reproduces sexually. 

“Each floret bears male and female organs and fertilization is primarily by outcrossing. Musk thistle can also produce a large number of seeds through self-pollination.”

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “Each plant produces about 7,000 viable seeds.”

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Seed longevity in the field depends on depth of burial; those on or near the surface lose viability in 2 to 4 years, whereas seeds buried 5 to 20 cm may survive for at least 10 years.” Some seeds survive for more than 10 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual or biennial herb. Mature plant produces seed for only one year.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual or biennial herb. Can produce propagules in under one year.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect annual herb commonly 80 cm to 120 cm high. “Nodding thistle grows in dense patches (up to 10 mature plants per square metre).” High nuisance value, but unlikely to restrict access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: An erect annual herb commonly 80 cm to 120 cm high. “Nodding thistle grows in dense patches (up to 10 mature plants per square metre).” Some recreational activities such as bushwalking may be affected.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Dried fragments and spines may cause injury.” An annual, spines are present for much of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual effect and seriously affect the aesthetics of an area.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: “It is one of the weeds which establishes well on bare ground occurring in pastures at the end of summer.” Dense growth habit provides soil cover when other species not present. Not likely to increase erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “It is one of the weeds which establishes well on bare ground occurring in pastures at the end of summer. Plants make strong autumn and winter growth, thereby competing at a time when pasture production is at its lowest.” Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “…research on fire and musk thistle was limited by difficulties in locating a thistle-infested research site where fuel was sufficient to support a fire.” Dead material does not alter fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassland (E); CMA=Corangamite; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; M CLIMATE potential.
Occurs in open situations, but establishes best on bare ground. “…grows in dense patches (up to 10 mature plants per metre).” Medium potential for infestation. Minor impact on ground-flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy woodland (E); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; M CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to infest low value EVCs in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Little other biomass production [occurred] within one-third of the area occupied by rosettes…[and] a thistle plant has a detrimental effect on pasture growth beyond the perimeter of its rosette.” Dense patches would have a major impact on ground-flora, but not known as a weed in natural ecosystems (not recorded in Carr et al 1992). Limited impact.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Nodding thistle grows in dense patches and is not readily grazed because of its spiny foliage. Its presence also discourages animals from grazing neighbouring pasture plants. Rosettes can occupy a considerable area of pasture.” The plant would reduce food source of native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Dried fragments and spines may cause physical injury.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest animals.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Seriously reduces carrying capacity. “Calculated stands of 1000 plants m-2 reduced pasture production by 13–14%.”

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “At maturity, the spiny heads contribute to vegetable fault in wool.”

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Control can be readily achieved by cultivation and establishing a “perennial pasture which provides ground cover in late summer to compete with thistle seedlings.” Cost of control may reduce the value of land slightly.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The plant can be controlled with suitable management techniques. Land use would not change.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
The above ground shoots act as annuals, emerging in autumn from rhizomes, to then senesce with increasing temperatures from November to January (Lawrie 2006a). 
Germination can occur during the cooler months from March to August (Dept. Water, Land & Biodiversity Conservation 2006). Therefore germination is restricted by seasonal conditions.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
In Australia, has been found in low open forest (Bass & Lawrie 2003).
Under experimental conditions it has been reported to grow well under 70-90% shade and open sun (Bass et al 2006). The species has not been reported to establish under such conditions and therefore its known establishment under moderate canopy conditions is all that can be gone by at this stage.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In South Africa, ‘found in fybros or coastal scrub, predominantly on rocky outcrops’ (Obermeyer 1984 cited in Bass & Lawrie 2003).‘Potential to inhabit a range of vegetation communities including closed forests and open woodlands’ (Lethbridge 2005). In Australia, has been found in low open forest (Bass & Lawrie 2003). Can establish in healthy natural ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Climbing perennial. Geophyte (Bass & Lawrie 2003).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Grazing by sheep and cattle has been tried as a control method, however it is not preferred by either species, sheep mainly eating the new shoots, at high stocking rates can reduce the plant and restrict flowering and therefore sexual reproduction (Lawrie 2006b). In summer the species is not preferred and high stocking rates are required to prevent sexual reproduction.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: There little is known about the growth rate of this species, however for management purposes it is presumed to be similar to A. asparagoides (Dept. Water, Land & Biodiversity Conservation 2006).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Drought tolerant, the species senesces during the summer months to regrow from rhizomes in autumn (Lawrie 2006a).
A. asparagoides ‘is frost tolerant and its root system allows it to survive summer droughts’ (Weeds CRC 2003).
Fire is still being experimented with as a control method, however at this stage it has been unsuccessful due to the difficulty of maintaining a high intensity fire so as to cook the tubers (Lawrie 2006b).
Susceptible to waterlogging.
Found along coast (Lawrie 2006a ). Therefore likely to be salt tolerant.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Capable of both sexual and vegetative reproduction, by flowering and producing fruit and having an extensive branching rhizomatous root system (Lawrie 2006a).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Normally have 5-8 seeds per fruit but can range from 2-14, fruit production can vary from 100-800 fruit m-2 therefore average seed production can be 4,800 seeds m-2 (Lawrie 2006a).
This species can form extensive root systems of branching rhizomes, with many of the rhizomes producing tubers and shoots (Lawrie 2006a).
Therefore multiple stems may be considered the same plant and therefore it is possible that the number of propagules produced by one plant exceeds 2,000.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: For A. asparagoides ‘buried seed .. rots within two years, while seed on the soil surface may be viable for at least three years’ (Weeds CRC 2003). Studies currently being done to determine propagule longevity for A. declinatus.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Insufficient information to determine reproductive period for A. declinatus.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown, A. asparagoides takes three years to flower, vegetative reproduction may occur faster.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
A. declinatus seeds may be dispersed by the grey currawong, Australian magpie, Australian raven, brush wattlebird and red wattlebird (Bass & Lawrie 2003; Lawrie 2006a). Mammal species are also reported as dispersal agents, including brush tailed and ring tailed possums, foxes and bush rats (Bass 2002; Lawrie 2006).
Bird dispersed and eaten by highly mobile animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Dispersal varies with the species between <100 m for the smaller bird species to 10 km for the currawong (Lawrie 2006a).
The dispersal range of various species has been reported as follows; the grey currawong , 20 km, the Australian magpie 1 km and fox, 5 km (Spennemann & Allen 2000).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Climbing perennial that grows up to 1 m with recurved and zig-zag branches. Can form dense mats. (Bass & Lawrie 2003). Unlikely to restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Introduced as an ornamental species (Lawrie 2004). Therefore may alter aesthetics; however at this stage there is no evidence to support this.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Weed not known to be injurious to people.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Introduced as an ornamental species (Lawrie 2004). Therefore may alter aesthetics; however at this stage there is no evidence to support this.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species (Marchant et al 1987).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
Tuberous roots (Marchant et al 1987). ‘Large plants may have 20-50 tubers and often become entangled with neighbouring plants to produce tuber masses of a square metre consisting of hundreds of tubers’ (Bass 2002). Invasion reduces the area of bare ground (Lawrie 2006a).
Plants die back during summer (Bass & Lawrie 2003). May have some soil erosion but low probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments:
Root systems form dense mats and can account for up to 85% of mass in mature plants. Where established, there is a decline in litter, bare ground and other ground cover’ (Bass & Lawrie 2003).
Long-term a woodland may be altered to an A.declinatus meadow (Leah 2001). However this would be due to prevention of regeneration and other processes would have to be involved to remove those other species (Lawrie 2006a).
Therefore an increase in biomass will largely be observed, largely due to the dense root system.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Plant dies back during summer. One study showed that litter in infested areas reduced from 67% to 7%. (Bass & Lawrie 2003). Plant can also establish on bare ground. May cause a minor change to intensity of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Parilla Mallee (BCS = E); CMA=Mallee; Bioreg=Lowan Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘A. declinatus reduces biodiversity between 8% and 71%, reduces the recruitment of woody species by 69% and may alter
successional pathways’ ‘Correlates with woody canopies > 2 m high’ Where established, there is a decline in litter, bare ground and other ground cover’. ..’approximately 69% less woody plant seedlings in 90 infested quadrats’ (Bass & Lawrie 2003). Potential to cause major displacement of dominant species within the lower and middle strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Grassy dry forest (BCS = D); CMA=Wimmera; Bioreg=Greater Grampians; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘A. declinatus reduces biodiversity between 8% and 71%, reduces the recruitment of woody species by 69% and may alter successional pathways’ ‘Correlates with woody canopies > 2 m high’ Where established, there is a decline in litter, bare ground and other ground cover’. ..’approximately 69% less woody plant seedlings in 90 infested quadrats’ (Bass & Lawrie 2003). Potential to cause major displacement of dominant species within the lower and middle strata.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Heathy woodland (BCS = LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; CLIMATE potential=VH.
‘A. declinatus reduces biodiversity between 8% and 71%, reduces the recruitment of woody species by 69% and may alter successional pathways’ ‘Correlates with woody canopies > 2 m high’ Where established, there is a decline in litter, bare ground and other ground cover’. ..’approximately 69% less woody plant seedlings in 90 infested quadrats’ (Bass & Lawrie 2003). Potential to cause major displacement of dominant species within the lower and middle strata.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘A. declinatus reduces biodiversity between 8% and 71%, reduces the recruitment of woody species by 69% and may alter successional pathways’ ‘Correlates with woody canopies > 2 m high’ Where established, there is a decline in litter, bare ground and other ground cover’. ..’approximately 69% less woody plant seedlings in 90 infested quadrats’ (Bass & Lawrie 2003). A. asparagoides ‘is a major threat to most low shrubs and groundcover plants in mallee, dry sclerophyll forest and heath vegetation’ (Weeds CRC 2003). Major effect on lower and middle strata.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: While no specific species are mentioned Winkler & Taylor (2006) report that the species has potential to impact on threatened flora species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Plant not documented as having an effect on non-threatened fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: ‘Preliminary seed dispersal observations of A. declinatus in South Australia indicate the main dispersers are medium to large gregarious birds such as Strepera versicolor (Grey Currowong), Gymnorhina tibicen (Australian Magpie) and Anthochaera carunculata (Red Wattlebird). Arboreal mammals, such as Trichosurus vulpecula (Brush-tailed Possum) and Pseudocheirus peregrinus (Common Ringtail Possum) and small rodents’ (Bass & Lawrie 2003). Plant may provide some assistance in food to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Plant not documented as being injurious to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Foxes have been reported to consume the species fruit (Lawrie 2006a).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
May impact upon forestry and some horticulture however, at this stage to what extent is unknown.
Has ‘similar morphology, ecology and impacts as A. asparagoides (Lawrie 2002). A. asparagoides ‘causes losses to primary industries by shading citrus and avocado trees and interfering with picking’ ‘Grows well in citrus orchards and pine plantations’(Weeds CRC 2003).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not documented to impact upon quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: ‘Appears to spread more rapidly and better withstand control activities than A. asparagoides’. Possible that land value may be affected if spreads to agricultural areas. Not documented at this stage.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: A. declinatus not documented to change priority of land use but if it spreads to agricultural areas has the potential to.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: A. declinatus not documented to increase harvest costs but if spreads to agricultural land may involve more time and labour.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not documented as a host or vector for disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination occurs in spring (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: In shaded areas seedling survival is reported to be low (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Therefore seedlings are capable of establishing in moderate shade if only to a minor extent.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Reported to be able to invade heathland (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: A grass species, forms large dense tussocks (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: There is evidence to suggest Cortaderia selloana contains phytotoxic substances which can inhibit germination; however of the species examined Cortaderia contained the least (Chou & Young 1975). Unknown to what extent these substances will impact on other species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Under intensive grazing, small plants are reported to be able to persist (Muyt 2001).
Historically used as a fodder source; tolerant of grazing (Blood 2001).
Unknown however if plants are able to flower under moderate grazing.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Able to exclude most other ground flora (Muyt 2001).
Reported to have more vigorous growth than C. jubata under both optimal and sub-optimal conditions (Stanton & DiTomaso 2004).
Faster growth is reported for a plant in its second season than its first (Parsons &  Cuthbertson 2001).
Bassett et al (1990) shows that early seedling growth of pampas can be suppressed by other grass species, however no mortality was observed, therefore the pampas seedling will persist and eventually out-compete the other grass species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerates frost (Blood 2001).
Tolerates drought (Blood 2001).
Tolerates fire, flowering may even be stimulated in older plants after being burnt (Blood 2001).
Tolerates salinity (Blood 2001).
Tolerates waterlogging; occurring in seasonal wetlands (Blood 2001).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces both sexually and asexually, producing seed, rhizomes and tillers (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Female plants are able to produce 1,000,000 seeds per panicle while hermaphrodites are able to produce 100,000 (Dom�nech et al 2005).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds remain viable for two years maximum (Blood 2001).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Plants are reported to be capable of surviving for 15 years (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Flowering is reported to be possible during the plants first season, but more likely to occur after two or three years (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seeds are dispersed by wind (Duckett 1989).
Seeds can be dispersed by wind and water and rhizomes can be dispersed accidentally by people (Muyt 2001).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Seeds have the potential to be dispersed distances of 25 km (Duckett 1989).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
Each tussock can grow to 6 m and several meters across, has serrated leaves and can invade riparian vegetation (Blood 2001).
Dense infestations can block access to forestry plantations (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
Growth of pampas grass along tracks can block access (Atkinson 1997).
Therefore growth of this species can result in tracks becoming impassable.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Reported to impact upon the aesthetics and recreational value of invaded conservation areas in California (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The leaves are serrated and can cut the skin or cause irritation (Blood 2001).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Reported to reduce the aesthetics in some areas of California (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Not reported to occur in flowing water.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Does occur in riparian vegetation and wetlands, no specific data reported on impact on water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Used historically to stabilise soil, its root system can extend radially 4 m and 3.5 m deep (Blood 2001). Therefore there is a low probability that large scale soil movement would occur in association with this species.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Pampas is a large tussock forming grass that can grow to 6 m, highly invasive after disturbance, dense infestations can seriously impede overstorey regeneration (Muyt 2001). Therefore while the pampas does contribute extra biomass, it can prevent regeneration after a disturbance event and cause an overall decrease in biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
Can increase fire potential, by accumulating dry matter (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
Able to regrow after fire (Blood 2001).
Invasion by the similar and closely related C. jubata has been shown to increase fire frequency (Lambrinos 2000).
Unknown to what extent invasion by pampas can increase fire frequency or if it alters fire intensity.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Creekline Grassy Woodland (E); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins ; Bioreg= Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Able to exclude most other ground flora species (Muyt 2001). Therefore major displacement within layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Plains Sedgy Woodland (D); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins ; Bioreg= Dundas Tablelands; VH CLIMATE potential.
Able to exclude most other ground flora species (Muyt 2001). Therefore major displacement within layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Heathland (LC); CMA= Glenelg Hopkins ; Bioreg= Glenelg Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
Able to exclude most other ground flora species (Muyt 2001). Therefore major displacement within layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
Reported to completely alter the structure of invaded communities (Blood 2001).
Can exclude most other ground flora, and seriously impede overstorey regeneration (Muyt 2001).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No specific evidence

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
Reported to completely alter the structure of invaded communities (Blood 2001).
Change in habitat structure and floristic composition, could impact upon food sources and available shelter and flowing on affect the composition of the fauna community. The level of impact has not however been quantified for pampas grass.
