fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Used as nesting sites by long-nosed bandicoot (Chambers & Dickman 2002).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: The leaves are serrated and can cut our skin and cause irritation (Blood 2001). Unknown how dangerous this would be to fauna species.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments:
Goats will graze the species but it is not preferred (Lambert et al 1989; Pande, Kemp & Hodgson 2002).
Therefore the species provides minimal food to pest species

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Competes with forestry species, slowing growth and reducing establishment (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
After three years of growth, fertilised trees competing with pampas were approximately 100 cm shorter than the control at 450 cm, were only just more than half the diameter of approximately 80 mm of the control and were less than a quarter of the volume. Competition with pampas also resulted in a 9% mortality after 3 years compared with 0 for the control (Richardson et al 1996).
Competition with pampas therefore causes a significant reduction in yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Unknown; it may have some impact in relation products of forestry.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Unknown; it may have some impact in relation products of forestry.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Unknown; it may have some impact in relation products of forestry.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments:
Invading areas of forestry pampas can prevent access and increases the fire hazard (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).
In New Zealand the need to manage this species has increased costs by 144% (Blood 2001).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: There is no evidence of this reported.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seeds germinated from 13oC to 28oC under light and dark conditions, suggesting that germination could occur at any time of the year as long as moisture is available (Smith et al. 1999).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Observed growing under a wide variety of light, temperature, moisture and substrate conditions including…forest edges, shrublands with some shade, and in the forest understorey (Frey 2005). Can establish without additional factors, under full canopy cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Commonly invades highly disturbed ecosystems, such as sand dunes, sparse pasture, roadsides and plantations (Frey 2005), and also capable of invading less disturbed ecosystems such as woodlands (Smith et al. 1999) and open mallee and forest, however this is probably only occurring in vegetation gaps (Virtue & Melland 2003).
Establishes in highly disturbed natural ecosystems and patchy pasture/crops.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Perennial grass (Smith et al. 1999).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: In D’Antonio & Vitousek (1992) the invasiveness of this species in several countries is described in some detail, but the section dealing with allelopathy does not mention E. calycina. No reference to allelopathic properties of this species was found.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Introduced as a forage crop, however, grazing can reduce populations and may eliminate them over 3 years of normal stocking rates (Frey 2005). Eliminated by moderate herbivory.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Rapid growth rate (Pickart 2007) that will exceed most other grass species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Established plants resprout vigorously from the base of the tussock after summer drought in WA, and may provide some tolerance to fire, but regular controlled burns would probably reduce its invasability (Smith et al. 1999). Does not tolerate waterlogging (Frey 2005).
Tolerates temperatures to at least -8oC, “low” salinity tolerance; tolerant to 2.1-4.0 dS/m (Pickart 2007). Highly tolerant of drought and frost. Some fire tolerance. Does not tolerate waterlogging or high salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: The Ehrharta perennials reproduce both by seed and vegetatively (expanding tussocks) (Frey 2005); rhizomatous (Virtue & Melland 2003).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Described as a prolific seeder, and soil seed bank densities were found to be at the upper end of figures for grasslands and arable fields (Smith et al. 1999). Seed yield was measured, and averaged 140 seeds per panicle, from the 31 panicles harvested (Rossiter 1947) = at least 4,340 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds of this species germinated from topsoil that had been stored for 3 years (Rokich et al 2000). No further information found.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Short lifespan (Pickart 2007), generally 3 to 7 years (Rossiter 1947), but with a “demonstrated capacity to form understorey monocultures in remnant native vegetation in SA” (Virtue & Melland 2003).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Produces seed in the first year of growth” (Virtue & Melland 2003).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Seeds are dispersed locally by wind and may occasionally be carried on animal fur” (Frey 2005).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
Seeds are dispersed by wind (Frey 2005), but long-distance spread by wind is unlikely (Virtue & Melland 2003).
Occasional dispersal on animal fur (Frey 2005) may spread few propagules to one kilometre, but most are likely to spread less than 20 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Can interfere with boats, effecting navigation and recreation, and can cause people to drown (Henderson & Cilliers 2002; Sheppard, Shaw & Sforza 2006). Therefore high nuisance factor.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Can limit recreational water activities even make areas unusable (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Can cause drowning (Henderson & Cilliers 2002). This would be largely restricted to warmer months.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Can interfere with infrastructure, including, irrigation works, hydro-electric outputs and water supplies (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The plant can form free floating mats, be attached and submerged or emergent and is reported to severely impede water flow (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Reduces light and water flow (Weber 2003). Therefore has the potential to alter temperature and dissolved oxygen. Unknown to what extent.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Can cause flooding (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Therefore creating the potential for erosion to occur in the floodplain.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Can block smaller streams with a tangled mass of vegetation (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Therefore can increase biomass, however, as the plant dies back during winter in colder climates, the biomass levels may fluctuate and not become a permanent carbon sink (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species; therefore would have not significant impact of fire.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Lignum Wetland (V); CMA= North Central; Bioreg= Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Can for dense stands to the exclusion of native aquatics and even shade out algae (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000; Weber 2003).

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Swampy Riparian Woodland (D); CMA= East Gippsland; Bioreg= Highlands-Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential.
Can move into marshy areas adjacent to aquatic populations (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Unknown to what extent the species impacts on vegetation in these areas, presumed some minor displacement.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Riverine Swamp Forest (LC); CMA= North Central; Bioreg= Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Can move into marshy areas adjacent to aquatic populations (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Unknown to what extent the species impacts on vegetation in these areas, presumed some minor displacement.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Can for dense stands to the exclusion of native aquatics and even shade out algae (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000; Weber 2003).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No specific evidence reported, presumed from major displacement of all native species reported in Weber (2003), there would be displacement of threatened species.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Through exclusion of other aquatic plants and algae, invasion by M. aquaticm can alter ecosystem dynamics by altering the base of the food web (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Can provide shelter for crayfish (Peterson, Fitzpatrick & VanderKooy 1996).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Can cause animals to drown (Henderson & Cilliers 2002).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: No species in Australia are reported to eat significant amounts of it.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Can invade rice fields and impact yield (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001). Unknown to what extent yield is affected.
Can result in the drowning of livestock (Hill 2003).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: No evidence of this

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No evidence of this

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: May result in some change in management practises.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Can foul pumps and irrigation equipment therefore increasing maintenance time (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Can be infected by powdery mildew (Micropshaera alphitoidies) (Boesewinkel 1986). It is unknown however to what impact this could have on any commercial crops.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
‘Although S. molle seed has no innate dormancy, cold temperatures in winter and drought in summer enforce dormancy for most of the year. (Howard & Minnich 1989)’. Seeds are described as taking 20-30 days to germinate under cooler temperatures and although less time, e.g. 10 days, in warmer temperatures, require sustained surface soil moisture to germinate without desiccation which is unusual. S. molle is described as having
a ‘low germinative capacity’ (Howard & Minnich 1989) and appears to require reasonably unseasonal events for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Described as growing in forests (Weber 2003, Carr et al 1992) and ‘…survives nearly everywhere it is planted (Howard & Minnich 1989)’. However, germination and seedling surviving are described as ‘the major bottleneck to establishment’. Appears to be some conflicting information regarding its establishment requirements.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Although often associated with disturbed and degraded environments (Muyt 2001), it appears also able to establish in minor disturbed natural ecosystems. For example, ‘S. molle becomes established on the periphery of densely vegetated riparian habitats (Howard & Minnich 1989)’ and Carr et al (1992) documents it occurring in lowland grassland, grassy woodland, dry sclerophyll forest/ woodland & rock outcrop vegetation.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Tree (Howard & Minnich 1989).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Leaves and fruit strongly inhibitory to seed germination and seedling growth of cucumber and wheat (Anaya & Gomez-Pompa 1971). Allelopathic properties seriously affecting some plants.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘Not normally grazed by animals (Blood 2001)’. Anacardaceae in general are known for their toxic compounds and S. molle in particular is infrequently eaten by goats or insects (Fuentes et al 1983). However it is described as being consumed by sheep (Salem et al 2005), the Emperor Gum moth (French 1945) and sometimes (seedlings) rabbits (Fuentes et al 1983). Likely to be consumed but not preferred.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Available information on growth rate is somewhat contradictory, with growth and spread appearing to vary in different locations. Seedling growth is described as both rapid (Howard & Minnich 1989) and as very slow, until the root system is firmly established. (Blood 2001). 
However it is also generally described as being ‘fast growing (Weber 2003, Blood 2001)’.
Overall it is likely to have a moderately rapid growth rate.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Mature trees very resistant to fire and drought (Blood 2001). Limited by extreme frost, but some tolerance likely as grows in the Andes to 3,300 m (Howard & Minnich 1989). Occurs on coastal dunes and beaches (Weber 2003).
Tolerant of poor soils and poor drainage (PIER 2001), occurring in seasonally wet areas. Once established seedling mortality is described as rare (Howard & Minnich 1989). Highly resistant to drought and fire, some tolerance to frost, waterlogging and salinity.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces both sexually and vegetatively via ‘Seed and suckers (Blood 2001)’.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Large tree with ‘huge quantities of seed set (Blood 2001)’ and fruits continuously throughout the year (Howard & Minnich 1989). Images indicate an individual would produce many more than 2,000 seeds (Blood 2001, Muyt 2001).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds remain viable for less than 3 years (Cal-IPC2003). ‘Seeds ripening during summer heat and drought can remain viable until the rainy season (Howard & Minnich 1989)’, also indicates short viability.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Howard & Minnich (1989) describes ‘large old trees’ as setting huge quantities of fruit. Presumed to produce propagules for > 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Takes more than 2 years to reach reproductive maturity (Cal-IPC 2003).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘Seed is dispersed by birds, mammals and water (Howard & Minnich 1989)’.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Seeds are widely dispersed by birds (Howard & Minnich 1989)’. Potential for seeds to disperse greater than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: It is described as freely coppicing and as forming extensive species poor stands (Weber 2003), and although not specifically documented, it has some potential to restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: No information was found to suggest it reduces tourism, but as a large tree to 10 m tall (Blood 2001) it is likely to be obvious to the ‘average’ visitor and may affect the aesthetics of an area.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Fruit are allergenic, especially toxic to children, causing vomiting, gastro-enteritis, irritation of mucous membranes, allergic dermatitis, hay fever, asthma and breathing difficulties (Shepherd 2004). Major component in allergies, hay fever and asthma.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Older trees grow top heavy, can blow down in storms and are consequently no longer planted on public streets in Riverside, California for fear of law suits (Howard & Minnich 1989). Has potential to cause damage to property, though this appears not directly as a result of its growth habit. Its gum is also documented as causing damage to car duco (Landcare 2007).

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species, not likely to impact water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Terrestrial species, not likely to impact water quality.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: ‘Since the soil under the canopy can remain bare and lacks an herbaceous ground flora, erosion can be accelerated in stands growing on slopes or near streams (Weber 2003)’. Moderate probability of large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Grows as a ‘tree in a shrubland’ (Howard & Minnich 1989). Could increase the biomass of a community.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: It is described growing as a ‘tree in a shrubland’ capable of shading out all native vegetation (Weber 2003) and there is suggestion that it could turn scrublands into savannahs (Howard & Minnich 1989). It is also described as fire retardant (Zanthorrea 2007) so there is potential for it to decrease fire intensity in some communities and also have a moderate affect on fire frequency.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Riparian scrub (BCS= E); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Wimmera; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘It is freely coppicing and forms extensive species poor stands that shade out all native vegetation (Weber 2003)’. Grows as a
‘tree in a shrubland’ (Howard & Minnich 1989). Major displacement of dominant species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Low Chenopod shrubland (BCS= D); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Scroll Belt; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘It is freely coppicing and forms extensive species poor stands that shade out all native vegetation (Weber 2003)’. Grows as a ‘tree in a shrubland’ (Howard & Minnich 1989). Major displacement of dominant species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Shrubby Riverine Woodland (BCS= LC); CMA= Mallee; Bioreg= Murray Mallee; CLIMATE potential=VH. 
‘It is freely coppicing and forms extensive species poor stands that shade out all native vegetation (Weber 2003)’. Grows as a ‘tree in a shrubland’ (Howard & Minnich 1989). Major displacement of dominant species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘S. molle potentially alters structure and composition in grasslands, woodlands and coastal scrub areas (Morisawa 2000)’. Forms extensive species poor stands that shade out all native vegetation (Weber 2003). Not described as forming monocultures.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Forms extensive species poor stands that shade out all native vegetation (Weber 2003). ‘S. molle potentially alters structure and composition in grasslands, woodlands and coastal scrub areas (Morisawa 2000)’. Likely to impact on threatened flora species but not specifically documented.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Forms extensive species poor stands that shade out all native vegetation (Weber 2003)’. Likely to alter habitat by eliminating native vegetation but its specific impact on fauna was not found documented.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: In degraded locations mature trees may provide food and shelter to native animals including birds, bats and possums (Muyt 2001). Leaves consumed by the native Emperor Gum moth (French 1945). Berries fed on by the threatened Spotted Bower bird (Walker & Christian 2003). Provides some assistance in food and shelter to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Fruit and leaves cause poisoning or death in poultry, pigs and possibly calves (Blood 2001). It could be toxic to some fauna but no information was found documented.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: ‘Seed is possibly dispersed by foxes (Muyt 2001)’. Fruits are eaten in large quantities by the ‘Patagonian Fox’ in South America (Silva et al 2005). Because it fruits year round it has the potential to provide food throughout the year to one serious pest.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: A pest in orange groves and other sites of irrigation (Howard & Minnich 1989) but not documented as impacting on yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: There is no information to suggest it impacts on agricultural quality.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: There is no information to suggest it impacts on agricultural quality.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: There is no information to suggest it would cause a change in land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Described as a pest in orange groves and sites of irrigation (Howard & Minnich 1989) but it is not clear from the information available whether it may increase harvest costs, for example due to increased irrigation requirements.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: ‘Host of fruit fly (Blood 2001)’. Host of a major agricultural pest.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Reproduces from seed and vegetatively. “Seeds germinate in autumn and plants develop rapidly over winter and spring. Plants… redevelop from adventitious root buds in autumn.”

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
In North America, A. psilostachya most commonly grows in grasslands, savannas and woodlands, while in Australia it occurs on semi-arid grasslands, and along roadsides, in uncultivated fields, vacant lots and waste places. 

“A buildup of 3 to 5 inches (8–13 cm) of grass mulch on a lightly grazed rangeland delayed western ragweed growth in the spring.” Requires access to direct light and rainfall in open situations.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: In Australia, it occurs on semi-arid grasslands, and along roadsides, in uncultivated fields, vacant lots and waste places. Occurs in disturbed ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Geophyte

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments:
“Extracts from aerial growth are allelopathic, inhibiting germination and early seedling growth of several plant species.”

“Western ragweed root exudate significantly inhibited the formation of nodules on legume roots, which decreases their ability to fix nitrogen.”

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
“It is not grazed by stock.”

“The foliage and stems contain cinnamic acid and sesquiterpene lactones that deter herbivores.”

But, in the U.S., it is a moderately important food source for ungulates. May be eaten by cattle and horses.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Perennial ragweed is a strongly competitive plant, often growing densely to the detriment of crop and pasture.” Rapid growth rate.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Aerial stems are killed by frost. Western ragweed is not drought tolerant.” Roots are not affected by frost, and the deeper set roots are not affected by fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproduces vegetatively and sexually.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: No data available on seed production. From available photographs it appears that each plant would produce < 1,000 seeds. Fruits are achenes (single seed).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “…seeds are able to survive many years in the soil, as is demonstrated by the reappearance of a patch of perennial ragweed ate Speed, Victoria, several years after all existing plants had been eliminated.” More than 25% of seeds survive 5–10 years in soil.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: “Differing sets of seral stages have been suggested for secondary succession in prairie ecosystems, and western ragweed has been reported to occur in all of them and in climax communities. In old field succession, western ragweed was present as a principal forb in stands aged 0–5 years and was present with 4 to 15 percent cover after 23 to 29 years.” It appears that A. psilostachya is long lived.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
“Once seeded into an area, western ragweed may not set fruit until the second year.”
Produces seed between 1 and 2 years after germination. However, new growth from roots will occur annually.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Perennial ragweed spreads widely because the fruit is well adapted to tangle in wool and stick to furred animals, clothing, bags and other fibrous materials. Spread also occurs when the seeds, n mud, stick to animals, farm machinery and vehicles of all kinds. It is also commonly spread when contaminated soil and gravel are moved during road grading and road-making, and when such soil is used as garden topdressing.” Cultivation can spread root fragments that grow to new plants.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Dispersal due to road grading and road-making, removal of soil could spread propagules more than 1 km, but most dispersal is likely to be less than this.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Erect robust perennial 30 cm to 150 cm high, forming dense colonies. With plants at full height, dense growth may be a nuisance to pedestrians.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: “…usually found as a weed along roadsides, in uncultivated fields, vacant lots and waste places.” Presence of the weed would be obvious but unlikely to restrict recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “Copious pollen from the small flower heads of perennial ragweed causes hay fever in many people.” Plants flower for about 3 months of the year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would seriously affect the aesthetics of an area. Moderate visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant develops, “…an extensive, interwoven mass of creeping perennial roots in the upper 30 cm of soil, with occasional branches extending downwards to 1 metre.” Not likely to affect soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “…usually found as a weed along roadsides, in uncultivated fields, vacant lots and waste places.” Biomass likely to increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Not data available on infestation density or

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Highest potential distribution is in Mallee & Wimmera CMAs. Murray Mallee bioregions not yet mapped for EVCs, thus no data available. It is a strongly competitive plant occurring on semi-arid grasslands. Displaces grass/forb species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Potential distribution limited to small areas in the Mallee and Wimmera CMAs. Occurs on semi-arid grasslands. Unlikely to affect medium value EVCs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: As in 10(b) above.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Perennial ragweed is a strongly competitive plant, often growing densely to the detriment of crop and pasture. Extracts from aerial growth are allelopathic, inhibiting germination and early seedling growth of several plant species.” Occurs on open situations; likely to have serious effect on the lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “It is not grazed by stock, dense infestations thus reducing pasture productivity considerably.” Would lead to a reduction in available fodder for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: In the United States, “Western ragweed is used for food and nesting material, and as a habitat component by small mammals and non-game birds…and is important food (seeds and foliage) on activity sites for upland gamebirds.” However, there are no known benefits to native fauna.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “The foliage and stems contain cinnamic acid and sesquiterpene lactones that deter herbivory. However, western ragweed is not considered a poisonous plant.”

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Potential food source for pest birds (see Q15 above).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Perennial ragweed is a strongly competitive plant, often growing densely to the detriment of crop and pasture. Extracts from aerial growth are allelopathic, inhibiting germination and early seedling growth of several plant species. It is not grazed by stock, dense infestations thus reducing pasture productivity considerably.” Likely to have a serious effect on agricultural yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known to affect the quality of agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Dense infestations may affect the value of grazing properties due to the considerable reduction in productivity and the cost of chemical control.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “At present, perennial ragweed occurs in rapidly spreading patches on the North Western Slopes and Plains and the North Coast [of NSW].” As stock do not graze the plant, if left untreated it would seriously impact the usefulness of grazing land.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No evidence of affect on harvesting.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Generally germination occurs in spring (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: In shaded areas, seedling survival is reported to be low (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). Therefore seedlings are capable of establishing in moderate shade if only to a minor extent.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Able to invade chaparrel (Heathland) in California (Lambrinos 2000). Therefore it is able to invade healthy undisturbed ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Large perennial tussock grass (Lambrinos 2000).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: There is evidence to suggest Cortaderia selloana contains phytotoxic substances which can inhibit germination (Chou & Young 1975). Unknown if C. jubata contains similar substances.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
Cattle do graze the plant and grazing has been recommended for use as a control method in commercial forests (Harradine 1991). However this requires an intense grazing pressure, under lower levels control is not effective (West & Dean 1989).
Grazing pressure from rabbits can reduce seedling establishment (Lambrinos 2006).
Smaller plants do not persist under intense grazing pressure (Muyt 2001).
Unknown however if plants are able to flower under moderate grazing.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Slow to start, fast once established, therefore competitive (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Resilient to fire, as the meristem is insulated from the fire within the tussock (Lambrinos 2000).
Once established can tolerate extended dry periods (Muyt 2001). This species has been reported to not tolerate drought (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000). This may be more due to establishment requirements of seedlings than stress tolerance of an established plant.
Can be damaged by frost, but the plant is not killed, therefore tolerant (Stanton & DiTomaso 2004).
Able to germinate in disturbed seasonal wetlands (Lambrinos 2002).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Produces seed through apomixis and reproduces vegetatively through fragmented tillers, as no pollen is produced seed production through apomixis is also viewed as vegetative (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001; Philipson 1978).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: On average annual viable seed production has been estimated to be almost 240,000 per plant (Drewitz & DiTomaso 2004).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: There is some doubt to how long seeds can remain viable, it is agreed not long and even suggested to be less than one year (Drewitz & DiTomaso 2004).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Plants are reported to be capable of surviving for 15 years (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky 2000).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Can flower in first year (Parsons & Cuthbertson 2001).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Seeds a very light, with most viable seeds being between 0.32 and 0.6 mg (Drewitz & DiTomaso 2004).
Fine hairs on the lemma assist in wind dispersal (Knowles & Ecroyd 1985).
Wind, water and human aided dispersal (Muyt 2001).
Therefore more than one method of dispersal, with the main mode being wind, which is aided by the seeds light weight and fine hairs.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Reported to have invaded an uninhabited island 16 km off New Zealand’s north coast (Coulston 2002). Therefore seed is able to disperse potentially more than 16 km and therefore quite capable of dispersing more than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Large clumps can block vehicle access especially in fire situations, and sharp leaf margins could restrict access by individuals (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky, 2000). A dense infestation would require significant works before reasonable access could be provided through.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Ornamental species can reduce the aesthetic and recreational values of areas (Duckett 1989; Harradine 1991).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The margins of the leaf blades are sharp and can cause injury (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky, 2000).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
Ornamental species reported to impact on the aesthetics of natural areas (Duckett 1989; Harradine 1991).
Therefore could impact on the aesthetics of cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Able to germinate in disturbed seasonal wetlands (Lambrinos 2002). The species is not however reported in flowing water.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Historically has been used for erosion control (West & Dean 1989). Therefore would have a low probability of large scale soil movement or reduce the probability.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments:
A large tussock grass reported to be able to alter a shrubland to perennial grasslands (Lambrinos 2000).
Can prevent re-establishment in forests, after fire or logging (Weber 2003). In which case biomass would decrease.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
Has been shown to increase fire frequency (Lambrinos 2000).
May have higher fuel loads than native grasslands.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Coastal Headland Scrub (V); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Wilsons Promontory; VH CLIMATE potential.
In California invasion by C. jubata has converted shrubland to grassland significantly altering floral composition (Lambinos 2000). If shrubland has been converted to grassland the shrub layer must have been displaced.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Sand Heathland (R); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Wilsons Promontory; VH CLIMATE potential.
In California invasion by C. jubata has converted shrubland to grassland significantly altering floral composition (Lambinos 2000). If shrubland has been converted to grassland the shrub layer must have been displaced.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Wet Heathland (LC); CMA= West Gippsland; Bioreg= Wilsons Promontory; VH CLIMATE potential.
In California invasion by C. jubata has converted shrubland to grassland significantly altering floral composition (Lambinos 2000). If shrubland has been converted to grassland the shrub layer must have been displaced.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: In California invasion by C. jubata has converted shrubland to grassland significantly altering floral composition (Lambinos 2000). Therefore having a major effect on all layers as the shrub layer would be removed and species composition of the grass/herb layer altered.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments:
Threatens an endangered community in California (Lambinos 2000).
However no data available on its impact on threatened species in Australia.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Simplified structure in heathland, resulted in a change in species composition and a decrease in diversity in Californian chaparral (Lambinos 2000).

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: May provide some food resources to grazing species and cover, however there is may be a decrease in available resources from the invaded vegetation (Lambinos 2000).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Leaves do have sharp margins (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky, 2000). However there are no reports of injuries to wildlife.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Eaten by rabbits (Lambinos 2000).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
Competition with pampas grass can have a negative effect on forestry tree growth (Gadgil et al 1990).
From the efforts taken to control pampas in forestry it is presumed to have a significant impact on yield (West & Dean 1989).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not reported.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: No evidence of this, potentially in areas of forestry.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Management may need to be altered.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Impedes access and can cause problems to management in terms of fire (Bossard, Randell & Hoshovsky, 2000).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: No evidence of this.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An erect shrub commonly 2 to 3 metres high. “Patches of Opuntia spp. grow densely forming an impenetrable barrier, hence their use as live fences in some areas.” However, O. vulgaris, while widespread, is not densely established in Australia. Most likely to be a high nuisance to people by restricting direct access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Although not occurring in dense populations, its presence would be obvious and, due to the spiny nature of the plant, it may affect some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Stems (cladodes) are regularly patterned with aureoles that bear very fine barbed bristles. Some aureoles also have 1 to 5 sharp spines about 5 cm long. The barbed bristles are obnoxious because they readily penetrate human skin causing sever irritation and are difficult to remove. Spines and bristles are present all year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Stands of O. vulgaris would create a negative visual impact on cultural sites and seriously affect the aesthetics of an area. The root system is fibrous and shallow and unlikely to cause structural damage.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The root system, while shallow, is fibrous. In dense patches, aerial growth provides good ground cover. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In Victoria, O. vulgaris occurs in small populations on lowland grassland and woody grassland and rock outcrop situations. The plant would likely increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: A succulent, it would have a small or negligible effect on fire risk. “Because of their high moisture content, plants are not easily burnt.”

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Plains grassy woodland (E); CMA=North Central; Bioreg=Victorian Riverina; VH CLIMATE potential.
Although not densely established in Australia, like other Opuntia spp., O. vulgaris grow densely forming impenetrable barriers. Stands can hinder growth of smaller shrubs and ground flora. Major impact on lower and mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Riverine grassy woodland (D); CMA=Goulburn Broken; Bioreg=Murray Fans; VH CLIMATE potential.
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Riparian forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands - Southern Fall; H CLIMATE potential.
Similar impact as in 10(a) above, however, effect lessened due to high CLIMATE potential only.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Large stands can hinder the growth and regeneration of indigenous plants, particularly smaller shrubs and ground-flora.” Minor effect on the lower and mid strata

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Opuntia spp. are not usually grazed by stock because of the stout spines.” In dense patches, the plant could hinder access to water and reduce available fodder for fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “seed…is spread in the droppings of birds, foxes and other animals.” May provide limited food to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Opuntia spp. are not usually grazed by stock because of the stout spines and bristles damage their tongues and lips.” Spines present all year.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: “seed…is spread in the droppings of birds, foxes and other animals. Opuntia spp. are hosts to fruit-fly.” Food source to at least one serious pest animal at a crucial time of year.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: O. vulgaris has not demonstrated the same level of invasiveness as O. stricta and, while it is widespread, it is not considered a serious weed. Animals do not graze the plant and dense patches may limit grazing capacity.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping. Animals avoid the plant because of the spines.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Population densities are small. Plant populations are generally controlled by the monocantha cochineal insect, Dactylopius ceylonicus. Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: The impact on agriculture is limited; change in land use not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No impact on harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Requires natural seasonal disturbances, such as seasonal rainfall, spring/summer temperatures for germination.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
This plant likes well-drained and fertile soils (coolexotics website) sun and semi shade and regular water (calfloranursery website).
Plant is able to establish under a moderate canopy.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Invades damp scherophyll forests and riparian vegetation (Carr et al, 1992). It can invade disturbed riparian environments and cool moist forests in Victoria and NSW (Muyt, 2001) and also invade undisturbed bush (Stewart-Howie, 2003).
The plant has the ability to colonise in both relatively intact and minimally disturbed ecosystems.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Family: Solanaceae
Perennial (Dave’s Garden website)
Shrubs to 2.4 – 3 m (Muyt, 2001, Dave’s Garden website) 5-8 ft (O’Hara.)
Night-flowering (sunnygardens website)
Life form is that of a shrub.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: None mentioned in literature reviewed.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Fast growth, tough and vigorous (Dave’s Garden website).
Form dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Muyt, 2001).
Rapid growth rate that will exceed most other species of the same life form.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Fairly drought tolerant, not over watering or waterlogging (Dave’s Garden website).
Plants damaged by heavy frosts usually ‘come back’ quickly (sunnygardens website).
Susceptible to at least two stresses.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
Vigorous suckering (Muyt, 2001).
Sexual.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
Not mentioned in literature reviewed, nor the number of flowers in inflorescences.
Number of propagules estimated at 500 – 1,500 per annum.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments:
Seeds can remain viable for at least eight years (Muyt, 2001).
Greater than 25% of seeds survive 5 - 10 years in the soil.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Not mentioned in literature reviewed however it has been noted that the plant out competes all native ground cover plants in this environment and threatens to form a total monoculture (Stewart-Howie, 2003). Mature plant produces viable propagules for 3 – 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments:
Flowered six weeks after planting (Dave’s Garden website).
Reaches maturity and produces viable propagules in under a year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Produces red berries (Richardson, et al. 2006) to attract mobile berry eaters.
Flowers attract hummingbirds (sunnygardens website; calfloranursery website).
Edible fruit that is readily eaten by highly mobile animals.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Not mentioned in literature reviewed.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Little, or no, effects expected in literature reviewed. However, as it forms dense thickets (Muyt, 2001), and shrub grows to over 2 m, it may be extrapolated that it may cause restrictions.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Little, or no, effects expected in literature reviewed. However, as it forms dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Muyt, 2001) it may be extrapolated that it may reduce tourism through reduced access to preferable sites/regions/flora.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: All parts of this plant are highly toxic (O’Hara, undated) if ingested (Dave’s garden website) Some people develop skin rashes from handling plant parts (Muyt, 2001)

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Little, or no, effects expected in literature reviewed. However, as it forms dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Muyt, 2001) and shrub grows to over 2 m, it may be extrapolated that it may cause adverse effects to cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species; therefore little or no effects expected.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Terrestrial species; therefore little or no effects expected.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Terrestrial species; therefore little or no effects expected.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Little, or no, effects discussed in literature reviewed. However, as it forms dense thickets (Muyt, 2001) it may be extrapolated that it may cause effects.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Fire combustibility was unmentioned in literature reviewed. Little, or no, effects discussed in literature reviewed. However, as it forms dense thickets (Muyt, 2001) it may be extrapolated that it may cause adverse effects by a build up of fuel load.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC = Sedgy Riparian Woodland (V); CMA = Corangamite; Bioreg = Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential. 
It grows best in riparian forests (Muyt, ’01). Fast growth that forms dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Ibid.). May form monoculture within a specific layer; displace all spp. within a strata/layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC = Lowland Forest (D); CMA = Corangamite; Bioreg = Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
It grows best in riparian forests (Muyt, ’01). Fairly drought tolerant (Dave’s Garden website). Fast growth that forms dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Ibid.).  May form monoculture within a specific layer; displace all spp. within a strata/layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC = Riparian Forest (LC); CMA = Corangamite; Bioreg = Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
It grows best in riparian forests (Muyt, ’01). Fairly drought tolerant (Dave’s Garden website). Fast growth that forms dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Ibid.). May form monoculture within a specific layer; displace all spp. within a strata/layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: May form monoculture/dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Muyt, 2001).

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Given suitable conditions, it may form dense thickets that exclude all other vegetation (Muyt, 2001).

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments:
All parts of this plant are highly toxic (Muyt, 2001, O’Hara, undated) if ingested (Dave’s garden website).
Attracts butterflies (Top Tropicals website).

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Little or no effects discussed in literature reviewed.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: All parts of this plant are highly toxic (Muyt, 2001, O’Hara, undated) if ingested (Dave’s garden website).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: All parts of this plant are highly toxic (O’Hara, undated) if ingested (Dave’s garden website); but berries produced to attract mobile eaters.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not a known weed of agriculture, therefore little or no effects expected in literature reviewed.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a known weed of agriculture, therefore little or no effects expected in literature reviewed.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not a known weed of agriculture, therefore little or no effects expected in literature reviewed.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not a known weed of agriculture, therefore little or no effects expected in literature reviewed.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a known weed of agriculture, therefore little or no effects expected in literature reviewed.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host/vector, therefore little or no effects expected in literature reviewed.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Unknown; Vegetative propagation may only be dependent on water.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments:
Overgrazing is seen as a form of passive dispersal as it creates gaps where seeds or vegetative propagules can establish.
In the United States overgrazing and suppression of fire has seen an increase in the species (Halstead 2002).
Therefore the species appears to have a requirement for bare ground to establish.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades grassland (Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; shrub or tree-like cactus (Kinraide 1978).

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: No allelopathic properties have been described for this species.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
The species can be affected by rabbits, rodents and cattle especially during drought or after being burnt (Bunting & Wright 1976).
In the United States overgrazing and suppression of fire has seen an increase in the species (Halstead 2002).
The species has been used as emergency fodder in times of drought but first needs the spines removed (Sawyer et al 2001).
The species is under some level of bio-control by the Cochineal insect (Dactylopious tomentosus) in Australia (North West Weeds 2007).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments:
Cacti in general a slow growing (Sawyer et al 2001).
Comparatively slow-growth rate (North West Weeds 2007).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
It’s range in the United States has been found to extend within areas that experience mean January temperatures of greater than -1�C (Kinraide 1978). Therefore the species can survive temperatures below freezing and therefore is viewed as tolerant of frost if not freezing.
Used as emergency feed during a drought can therefore tolerate of drought (Endecott et al 2005).
The impact of fire has been found to be related to size of the plant with almost three times greater mortality of those with a height below 60 cm than those above and fire can also leave the plant exposed to herbivory (Bunting & Wright 1976; Bunting, Wright & Neuenschwander 1980). Some plants can survive fire therefore the species displays some tolerance.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments:
The species can reproduce sexually, producing fruit, however it is reported to be self-incompatible (McFarland, Kevan & Lane 1989).
The species is capable of vegetative reproduction through pseudovivpary and cladodes (Palleiro, Mandujano & Golubov 2006).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Reported to produce numerous seeds, in a study by McFarland et al (1989) six plants had a total of 59 flowers which would mean on average approximately 10 flowers per plant and the control flowers became fruits which contained an average of 62 seeds with a maximum of 215 therefore an average seed production would be in the range of 600 but maximum could be more than 1,000 and possibly more than 2,000. In addition to sexual reproduction the species is also capable of producing vegetative propagules.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown; vegetative reproduction is reported to be the dominant method of spread by the species however (Allen et al 1991).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: No specific data for this species, however the majority of other Cactaceae sp. live longer than 10 years, and can reproduce vegetatively during this time (Bowers, Webb & Rondeau 1995).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown; It would likely depend if the plant established from a seed of vegetative propagule and would be capable of producing vegetative propagule before seeds.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments:
Potentially dispersed externally and internally by animals (Allen et al 1991).
Dispersed by floodwaters and strong winds (North West Weeds 2007).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Unknown.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
Is a many branched shrub like cactus with spines up to 30 mm long (Henderson 1995).

Can occasionally form “nearly impenetrable thickets” (Kinraide 1978).

Can interfere with moving livestock (Pierper 1971).

Therefore the species would be oh high nuisance value making access by people difficult.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Unknown; as the species does not resemble native flora invasion by this species may have some negative influence on the aesthetics of an area. While rare the species is reported to be able to form impenetrable thickets which may have some impact on recreation activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
The species has spines (Hubert 1980).

Its spines can be up to 30 mm long (Henderson 1995).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: There is no data reported on the species potential to incur structural damage, invasion by the species could result in an impact on the aesthetics of a site, this has not however been reported.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species is not reported to restrict flowing water and as a terrestrial species of semi-arid to arid environments it is unlikely to do so.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species is not reported to impact on water quality and as a terrestrial species of semi-arid to arid environments it is unlikely to do so.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Reduces grazing pressure on an area, by restricting the movement of grazing species, and protecting the grasses/herbs in the immediate vicinity of its spines (Pieper 1971), therefore increasing the groundcover and reducing soil exposed to erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invading grassland C. imbricata creates a shrub layer. It has also been reported to potentially improve the microclimate for grasses, while also restricting grazing, increasing net biomass (Pieper 1971).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments:
The species is reported to benefit from fire suppression (Halstead 2002). There is no evidence however of the species causing a reduction in fire frequency.

By restricting grazing, the species could potentially increase the biomass of grasses (Pieper 1971). This may have some impact on fire intensity.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Plains Savannah (E); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Lowan Mallee; VH CLIMATE potential.
Can occasionally form virtually impenetrable thickets (Kinraide 1978). Therefore the species can become a dominant species and potentially cause some level of displacement.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Semi-arid Woodland (D); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Lowan Mallee; VH CLIMATE potential.
Can occasionally form virtually impenetrable thickets (Kinraide 1978). Therefore the species can become a dominant species and potentially cause some level of displacement.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Lowan Sands Mallee (LC); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Lowan Mallee; VH CLIMATE potential.
Can occasionally form virtually impenetrable thickets (Kinraide 1978). Therefore the species can become a dominant species and potentially cause some level of displacement.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
In a grassland invasion by the species creates a shrub layer and reportedly may alter the microclimate for the grass and herb layer (Pieper 1971).
Can occasionally form virtually impenetrable thickets (Kinraide 1978). Therefore the species can become a dominant species and potentially cause some level of displacement.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No specific data; however the species is reported to restrict grazing (Pierper 1971). This may protect species sensitive to grazing.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Unknown; If the species invades grassland, it creates a vegetation layer that previously didn't exist.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments:
May be a food source during drought (Endecott et al 2005).

Eaten by rodents (Bunting. & Wright 1976).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments:
The species has spines (Hubert 1980).

Its spines can be up to 30 mm long (Henderson 1995).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: In the united states the cactus is eaten by rabbits and rodents especially during drought periods (Bunting. & Wright 1976).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments:
There is some conflicting evidence on the species impact on yield.

While it may have little impact on the herbage production it can restrict grazing (Pierper 1971).

It can however be used as an emergency fodder source in time of drought (Sawyer et al 2001).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Reported to potentially reduce the quality of wool, unknown to what extent. (Pierper 1971).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Unknown.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: There is no specific evidence reported. If invasion by this reduces the effective area of production it may result in range land becoming more marginal.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Reported to interfere with the movement of stock (Pierper 1971). This may result in an increase in labour time.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: The fruit of the species may be affected by fruit fly (Blood 2001).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Seed germinates April-Aug (from growth calendar). Germination is highest in winter, when ample water is available (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Propagation by scarified seed (Bodkin, 1990). Fresh scarified seed in Spring (Page & Olds, 1998). Despite inconsistencies in the data, all suggest that adequate, but seasonal, rainfall and temperature is required to break a dormancy imposed by the seed coating.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Pioneer species, dominating early forest successional stages (Grau et al., 1996). Open, sunny position (Bodkin, 1990). Requires access to direct light to establish.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Invades disturbed sites such as roadsides and creekbanks, and also grows in woodland and open grassland areas where grazing is absent. Able to spread rapidly into woodlands, firebreaks, tracks, roadsides and other open areas (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Able to establish in natural ecosystems that are relatively intact or have only minor disturbance.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Family Fabaceae (Cruz et. al., 2002)– leguminous plant.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: None recorded in CRC Weed Management (2003).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: In Bolivia…considered the most important fodder species…regrows well after grazing (Cruz et. al., 2002). Cattle will eat new growth and thus kill rosewood seedlings (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Mature trees will be able to continue reproducing under herbivory pressure, as tree can reach heights variously reported from 10 m to 30 m (beyond the reach of stock) and seed is wind-dispersed (CRC Weed Management, 2003), with the potential to germinate beyond the fenceline.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Fast growth rate (Cruz et. al., 2002). Up to 4 m in first two years of growth (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Drought resistant, tolerates temperatures below 0�C and survives very high levels of salinity (Cruz et. al., 2002). This contrasts with findings by Dunn et al. (1994) that T. tipu has poor survival in saline soils. This tree probably has some tolerance to salt, but could not be considered highly salt tolerant.  

Drought and frost tender when young (Bodkin, 1990). Will survive in temperatures down to minus 6.5�c (CRC Weed Management, 2003), which may refer to mature trees. The susceptibility of young trees to drought and frost puts this species in the lowest threat category.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Flowers bisexual. Pollinated by bees (Cruz et. al., 2002).  Sexual reproduction only. Will tend towards the medium value in the absence of more specific data.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Ability to produce many seeds and achieve high germination rates…up to 10 000 seeds per plant (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Orthodox seed. If stored at low moisture content at low temperatures, they can retain full viability for several years (Cruz et. al., 2002). Presume less than 5 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: A pioneer species, still present in secondary forests 20-50 years old (Grau et al., 1996). This indicates that the trees live for at least 20 years, producing seed from the age of 8-10 years  (see Q 13 below).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Trees normally start to set fruit when they are 8-10 years old (Cruz et. al., 2002).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Winged pod (samara) (Cruz et. al., 2002). Wind and water (when near waterways). Does not spread vegetatively (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Depending on wind velocity and distance above the ground, rosewood seeds can be carried considerable distances away from the parent plant (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Water dispersal (see Q. 14) may sometimes carry them further. Most propagules will disperse  0-200 m, very few will disperse to 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: As a tree to 23 m with a main trunk and elevated crown (Henderson, 2001), human access should not be impeded.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: As a deciduous tree, invading creek banks and woodlands (CRC Weed Management, 2003) this plant would be obviously out of place to the average visitor, however it should not affect recreational use.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No spines, burrs or toxicity noted in Henderson (2001).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: This large tree (Henderson, 2001) has the potential to have a visual effect on cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Invades riverbanks (Henderson, 2001), but not recorded in waterways and horticultural recommendations are for well-drained soil (Page & Olds, 1998 eds.) so unlikely to impact flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: This “large, massively branched deciduous tree” invades riverbanks (Henderson, 2001), and so has the potential to drop large amounts of leaf litter into waterways, which could lead to increased algal growth, with the potential to decrease light and oxygen levels in the water.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: See q. 5. As it is not recorded in waterways it is unlikely to increase soil erosion. “It is used for…erosion control” (Cruz et al, 2002).

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: In the roadsides and riverbanks, savannahs (Henderson, 2001), woodland and open grassland areas that it invades (CRC Weed Management, 2003), this large tree (Henderson, 2001) is likely to increase carbon sequestering biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “It’s ability to spread rapidly into woodlands, firebreaks, tracks, roadsides and other open areas has the potential to affect fire regimes” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). As a large plant it is likely to increase both the intensity and the frequency of fires in these landscapes, although the degree of change would depend on the infestation, so a medium value was chosen.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: Climate modelling shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Climate modelling shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Climate modelling shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: As a tree to 10 m with a main trunk and elevated crown (CRC Weed Management, 2003), the plant is likely to compete for sunlight with small trees, tall and medium shrubs, grasses and groundcovers. In most of communities that it invades this would comprise most strata, but the degree of impact would depend on the level of infestation.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Climate modelling shows that this species is not likely to occur as an invasive plant in Victoria.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Grows in woodland and open grassland areas” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). May reduce the available food for fauna that depend on ground-level vegetation. May be browsed by larger fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Since [native long-tailed pal-blue] butterflies are often seen round specimens of tipu tree…they probably breed on this too” (CaLM, 2005).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No spines, burrs or toxicity noted in Henderson (2001).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: As a tree (Henderson, 2001), provides little to no food for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Valued as a shade tree, a source of ‘rosewood’ timber and, in some circumstances, fodder for stock…It is popular in the Queensland pastoral industry for fattening stock during the winter period…cattle will eat new growth and thus kill rosewood seedlings.” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).   Soil improvement by rhizomatous roots and leaf litter improve the nutrient content and texture of soil “leading to increased pasture quality” (Cruz et al, 2002). Impact on yield likely to be positive rather than negative.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: See Q. 19, not likely to reduce the quality of stock nor to contaminate crop harvests.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: See Q.19, no reason to reduce land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: See Q. 19, no reason to change land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: See Q. 19 no increase in harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not recorded as a host of agricultural disease.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination occurs on mass in spring and summer (Blood 2001).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: While most common on fore dunes within the flotsam deposit, plants can establish in the swale behind the dunes, most commonly associated with an existing large plant (Heylinger 2002). They may remain small but do establish, therefore the species is able to establish under moderate shade.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
A pioneer species, most invasive on open sand which would have little to no competition with other species. It has been observed establishing however, behind the fore dunes within other existing vegetation (Heylinger 2002).
These coastal systems while it is natural disturbances are considered highly disturbed.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; perennial herb (Blood 2001)

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: The species is known to contain secondary compounds there is no evidence reported of allelopathy however (Abdelgaleil et al 2001; Jakupovic et al 1998; Sayed et al 1980).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments:
The sap of the plant contains irritating and cytotoxic compounds which have been shown to cause inflammation of a mouse’s ear (Sayed et al 1980). This is likely to deter grazing species.
Able to regrow if buried by sand and new stems grow to replace the old stems that die after flowering (Heylinger 2002). 
On the Canary Islands it is reported to be fed on by the larvae of Hyles tithymali  (Hundsdoerfer & Wink 2006).
Whilst grazing species may be deterred from this plant by irritants in the sap, the ability to regrow suggests that the species is able to recover from herbivore pressure.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Has rapid early growth (Blood 2001). While no specific measurements are reported, it is presumed with this description of early growth the species growth would be at least be equal to that of other competitive herb species.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of salt water (Blood 2001).
Drought tolerant (Blood 2001).
Reported tolerance to varying ground water levels (Blood 2001). Therefore shows some tolerance to waterlogging.
Able to regrow if buried by sand and as the above ground stems die after flowering to be replaced by new stems (Heylinger 2002). Therefore most damage to the above ground stems, from fire, frost or grazing could presumably be recovered from.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Able to reproduce sexually producing seed and vegetatively with root fragments (Blood 2001).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: There is some variation in the species reported seed production, Blood (2001) reports 5 000. Heylinger (2002) however, states that seed production is variable and dependent upon conditions, but plants are capable of producing 100 stems, 80 fruits per stem and three seeds per fruit and therefore 20 000 seeds per plant. While there is variation in the reported seed production capability there is agreement that the plant is capable of producing more than 2 000 seeds per season.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: After floating in salt water for 2 years 50% were found to be viable, with none found to be viable after 6 years, however stored seeds have been found to stay viable for at least 7 years (Heylinger 2002).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Unknown.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Unknown.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: The seeds are initially released explosively and then may be dispersed by wind, water and accidentally by people (Blood 2001; Carr, Yugovic & Robinson 1992; Heylinger 2002)
