EVC=Shallow Sands Woodland (E), CMA= Glenelg-Hopkins, Bioreg.=Gippsland Plain, CLIMATE=VH.
This 3 m tall x 6 m wide shrub “form[s] a scrub layer that can out compete and shade out native plants” and invades scrub and woodlands (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within different layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Woorinen Sands Mallee (D), CMA= Mallee, Bioreg.=Murray Mallee, CLIMATE=VH. 
This 3 m tall x 6 m wide shrub “form[s] a scrub layer that can out compete and shade out native plants” and invades scrub and woodlands (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within different layers.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC=Loamy Sands Mallee (Lc), CMA= Mallee, Bioreg.=Murray Mallee, CLIMATE=VH. 
This 3 m tall x 6 m wide shrub “form[s] a scrub layer that can out compete and shade out native plants” and invades scrub and woodlands (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Major displacement of some dominant species within different layers.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: This 3 m tall x 6 m wide shrub “form[s] a scrub layer that can out compete and shade out native plants” and invades scrub and woodlands (CRC Weed Management, 2003). It is likely to have a major impact on the ground and understorey and shrub layers, but less of an impact on the tree layer.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: As an unpalatable shrub (El-bana et al, 2003) that invades and out competes native understorey and shrub species, its presence may reduce the food available to fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: As a large shrub, with branches drooping to the ground (see photo in CRC Weed Management, 2003), it may provide some shelter.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Toxic and “not usually eaten...Palatable for the dromedary…Dromedaries and goats are the most often affected” (Bahri et al, 1999). It is possible that indigenous fauna, which may be poisoned by it, might eat this plant.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Toxic and “not usually eaten...Palatable for the dromedary…Dromedaries and goats are the most often affected” (Bahri et al, 1999). May be eaten by feral goats, but as it is toxic (Bahri et al, 1999) it would provide minimal food.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “It has the potential to become a significant threat to Australia’s pastoral industry.” As an “aggressive invader” that “may infest grazing land and prevent access to stock” (CRC Weed Management, 2003), and being an unpalatable shrub (El-bana et al, 2003), it could reduce the carrying capacity of the land by more than 5%. “All domestic species are susceptible” to intoxication which can kill (Bahri et al, 1999).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Its toxins can taint milk, giving it an acrid taste and nasty smell and may poison nursing animals” (El Bahri et al, 1999). This could cause milk products to be rejected for sale.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Land value is likely to be affected where severe infestations make grazing not viable (see Q. 19).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Control is expensive, since any treatments will need to continue for years until the seedbank is depleted (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Since the shrub is unpalatable (El-bana et al, 2003) and toxic (Bahri et al, 1999), land use may have to change from grazing to cropping.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: “May infest grazing land and prevent access to stock” and control is expensive, since any treatments will need to continue for years until the seedbank is depleted (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Managing stock on infested lands and the control of infestations could both cause a major increase in harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: No reference of this plant as a disease host/vector in CRC Weed Management (2003).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments:
Establish early in the season before canopy closure can occur (Osem, Perevolotsky & Kigel 2006).
Winter-spring annual, flowering in spring –summer (Cunningham et al 1981).
Germination appears to occur on a seasonal basis.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Not specifically known. Reported to invade mallee and belah-rosewood communities, therefore tolerant of dry conditions and some level of shade (Cunningham et al 1981).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Can invade mallee (Cunningham et al 1981).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Other; Annual forb (Cunningham et al 1981).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Not specifically known. Grazing has been observed to have some impact on the density of the species, as the species is more abundant in ungrazed plots and in areas not associated with rabbit warrens. At what intensity grazing can eliminate the species is unknown (Cunningham et al 1981; Eldridge 2002; Osem, Perevolotsky & Kigel 2006).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Not sufficiently known in comparison to similar life forms.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Occurs in semi arid environments, presumed drought tolerance (Osem, Perevolotsky & Kigel 2006).
Other tolerances not sufficiently described.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Flowers to produce seed (Cunningham et al 1981).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Has numerous small seeds (Osem, Perevolotsky & Kigel 2006). It is not known specific seed quantities per flowering event.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Unknown.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Annual species, with varying population dynamics year to year (Cunningham et al 1981).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Annual species (Cunningham et al 1981)

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Unknown.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Unknown.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Grows to less than 1 m tall (Cunningham et al 1981). Unlikely to inhibit access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Ornamental species could have some impact on aesthetics; however there is no evidence for this.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this, nor is it likely if no significant allergies have been reported at this stage.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: In the Wimmera the species has spread from plantings in cemeteries (Lardner pers comm. 2007). No significant physical damage has been reported however it has some impact on the aesthetics.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species with no particular association with water or attributes that would lead to impeding water flow.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Unknown, the species is an annual ground cover; it may prevent erosion by reducing bare ground, unknown when it dies back and if this would leave the soil vulnerable.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Low growing species, with no evidence of disrupting the establishment of canopy species, likely to only cause direct replacement.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Unknown.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Creekline Grassy Woodland (E); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential.
Reported to only occasionally be locally abundant and this varies from year to year (Cunningham et al 1981; Walsh and Entwistle 1996). Therefore it is considered capable of causing minor displacement of species.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Box Ironbark Forest (D); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential.
Reported to only occasionally be locally abundant and this varies from year to year (Cunningham et al 1981; Walsh and Entwistle 1996). Therefore it is considered capable of causing minor displacement of species.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Red Swale Mallee (LC); CMA= Wimmera; Bioreg= Wimmera; VH CLIMATE potential.
Reported to only occasionally be locally abundant and this varies from year to year (Cunningham et al 1981; Walsh and Entwistle 1996). Therefore it is considered capable of causing minor displacement of species.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: Reported to only occasionally be locally abundant and this varies from year to year (Cunningham et al 1981; Walsh and Entwistle 1996). Therefore it is considered capable of causing minor effect of a small proportion of the species.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Unknown.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Unknown; the species may be grazed or the flowers visited by insects.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Unknown.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: May be grazed by feral species including rabbits (Eldridge 2002).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Only occasionally reported growing on productive land, any drop in productivity is not believed to be significant (Lardner pers comm. 2007).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Only occasionally reported growing on productive land, any drop in productivity is not believed to be significant (Lardner pers comm. 2007).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Only occasionally reported growing on productive land

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Only occasionally reported growing on productive land

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Only occasionally reported growing on productive land

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Unknown.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: ‘Often germinate in response to fire’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Germinates during spring (CRC for Australian Weed management 2003). Requires natural seasonal conditions

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Plants take advantage of bare ground (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Can be in a sun or semi-shady position (Hitchmough 1992) but shows preference for full-sun.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: ‘It invades banksia/ tuart woodlands and limestone scrub and heath’ ‘The infestation in the Shenton bushland has shown that yellow soldier does not need disturbance to establish (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Stores food in bulbs (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Geophyte.

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: None described in CRC for Australian Weed management 2003.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: ‘Lachenalia are easy, trouble-free bulbs. The only pests .. likely to be encountered are aphids, which may cause puckering of the leaves’ (Hitchmough 1992). Consumed but recovers quickly.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Plant takes advantage of open spaces but no information to suggest that its growth rate would exceed other species of same life form. Score as medium.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: ‘In its native range .. it occurs in areas with winter rainfall, undergoing long dormant periods over the dry summers’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). ‘Fire does not appear to kill bulbs as plants flower prolifically the first season following fire (Brown et al 2002). Found on sandy calcareous soils – assume some level of tolerance to salinity. May be susceptible to frost.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: ‘Spreads mainly by seed’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003), but can also reproduce vegetatively through bulbs.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: ‘.. usually between one and ten flowers per plant and each flower produces a capsule that contains 40-60 seeds’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Plant would produce maximum of 600 propagules.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: ‘The seed does not appear to remain viable for more than two or three years’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: ‘.. flowering-sized bulbs can be produced by the second or third year’ (Hitchmough 1992). Not sufficient information to determine whether plant produces viable propagules for greater than 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: ‘Single annually renewed bulb’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Germinates in spring and flowers in following winter or early spring.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: ‘Water movement and human activity are the main causes of seed spread’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: ‘Experience in the Shenton bushland .. suggests that seed is not easily spread over long distances ’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Very unlikely to disperse greater than 200 m.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Low growing plant reaching up to 100 mm (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Weed would not restrict human access.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: ‘Can reduce the recreational enjoyment of bushland by people’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). May have a minor effect on aesthetics.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: Weed not documented as having any injurious or toxic effects.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Plant not recorded as having an effect on cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: Plant dies off during summer months (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003) so would leave some ground exposed although low probability of low scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: ‘Replaces native herbs and annuals in both disturbed and relatively intact bushland’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management 2003). Plants die off during summer months. May be periods where biomass is slightly decreased.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Although fire tolerant, no evidence to suggest that the weed would effect the frequency or intensity of fires.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Coastal Mallee Scrub (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; CLIMATE potential=M.
‘.. around Perth where it appears to be replacing the herbaceous and annual components of the native understorey’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management). Displaces all species within the groundcover layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Heathy herbrich woodland (D); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; CLIMATE potential=M.
. ‘.. around Perth where it appears to be replacing the herbaceous and annual components of the native understorey’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management). Displaces all species within the groundcover layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Heathy woodland (LC); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Glenelg Plain; CLIMATE potential=M.
‘.. around Perth where it appears to be replacing the herbaceous and annual components of the native understorey’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management). Displaces all species within the groundcover layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: ‘.. around Perth where it appears to be replacing the herbaceous and annual components of the native understorey’ (CRC for Australian Weed Management). Major effect on understorey.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Weed not documented to have an effect on non-threatened fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Weed not documented to provide support to desirable species.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Weed not documented to be toxic or have spines or burrs which may affect indigenous fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not documented as a food source for pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not a weed of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Weed not known to have an effect on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Weed not known to cause change in priority of land use.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not a weed of cropping.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not a known host or vector for disease of agriculture.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: Germination can occur throughout the year, though germination rates are highest after periods of rainfall (ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Seedlings require moist to wet, generally well lit conditions.” Low light levels restrict seedling growth as does waterlogging. Requires access to light and moisture, but does not tolerate inundation (ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Disturbance can play an important part in encouraging infestations of pond apple.” Canopy openings due to severe storms can stimulate germination and seedling growth. Unlikely to establish under deep rainforest canopy; favours estuaries and floodplains where plenty of light and moisture occur (ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: Small semi-deciduous tree to 6 metres (15 under optimal conditions) (ARMCANZ 2000). Other lifeform.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: The plant is not documented as eaten by fauna or domesticated stock. Animals such as pigs and birds eat the fruit (ARMCANZ 2000). No herbivory pressure

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: ‘Seedlings grow rapidly to form dense stands that shade out native grasses and sedges’( NRM 2001).  Moderately rapid growth equal to similar competitive spp.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Commonly found in estuarine situations - salt tolerant. Will withstand seasonal or tidal inundation, but not permanent waterlogging (e.g. wetlands, mangroves). Larger trees tolerate low intensity fires and, “[d]ense stands of pond apple lack sufficient fuel loads to sustain a fire.” (WTMT 2004). It has a high requirement for soil moisture, which limits its occurrence away from water sources. Unlikely to tolerate drought.  Tolerant to salt and temporary inundation; tolerates low intensity fire.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Sexual reproduction; cross-pollination only (possibly by beetles)(ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Each fruit contains ~ 140 seeds; number of fruit produced not documented. However, it is estimated that seed banks of, “several thousand seeds m-2/year,” are common (ARMCANZ 2000). Assume 1,000 – 2,000 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Not known.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Not documented. Plants reach reproductive maturity after two years and typically grow to 6 metres in height (WTMT 2004). Assume plants to live at least 3 to 10 years.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: Plants reach reproductive maturity after 2 years (WTMT 2004).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Propagules spread by water, humans and native and feral animals. “Water is the main dispersal agent for both pond apple fruit and seed. Spread of seed by animals vectors is very minor compared to its dispersal by water (WTMT 2004).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Under tidal influence, seed can be spread both up and downstream within a river. However, the major movement of seed is due to floodwater. It is also noted that ocean currents play a role in seed dispersal along the coast (WTMT 2004). Under these conditions seeds will be spread more than 1 kilometre.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: A semi-deciduous tree 12 – 15 metres tall, occurring on creek banks, wetlands, mangrove communities & high tide litter zones on beaches (NRM 2001). ‘Thickets of pond apple restrict access’ (ARMCANZ 2000).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: ‘Thickets of pond apple restrict access and impair outlooks and the general variety of the coastal recreational experience’ (ARMCANZ 2000).

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: “…pond apple was introduced to Australia as grafting stock for custard apple. In its native America pond apple fruit has some commercial use” (NRM 2001). No toxic principle or physical properties likely to cause injury.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Occurs mostly in riparian or wetland areas subjected to regular natural disturbance. Not documented to occur in areas of cultural significance (WTMT 2004). Where it may occur, dense infestations (approaching a monoculture) it would present a moderate negative visual impact.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species. “It grows in fresh, brackish and even saline waters. The plant will not survive, however, in areas that are permanently inundated” (ARMCANZ 2000). Due to its dependence on a high water supply, it is found in riparian areas, floodplains and the margins of wetland areas. In such areas a dense infestation may affect the watercourse by narrowing the channel or reducing the size of the waterbody (WTMT 2004).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Not documented to affect water quality. Does not withstand permanent inundation (ARMCANZ 2000).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A semi-deciduous tree that in open areas forms dense stands (NRM 2001). Unlikely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Pond apple can establish as a dense understorey that suppresses other growth and under favourable conditions can replace mature stands of paperbark with a monoculture forest of pond apple” (NRM 2001).  Suppression of other species may result in slight reduction of biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “Time between fires is lengthened due to the reduction in understorey in infested areas” (ARMCANZ 2000). Does not contribute to an increase in fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
Basin=South Gippsland (ISC=very poor-moderate); CMA=West Gippsland; CLIMATE potential=L.
Therefore no high value EVC exists.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: All Victorian waterbodies are presumed to be high value EVCs.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: All Victorian waterbodies are presumed to be high value EVCs.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Pond apple forms a dense understorey/sub-canopy, replacing ferns, grasses, shrubs and sedges and prevents tree regeneration” (ARMCANZ 2000). “Creeks may become muddy monocultures” (NRM 2001). Major effect on all strata in some situations.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: This species is not documented as posing an additional risk to threatened flora.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Dense infestations would alter the habitat for native fauna. The plant may provide suitable shelter/nesting sites, but food source is radically altered due to impacts on plant diversity (NRM 2001). Possible serious reduction in local faunal populations.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: The fruit is a food source to some fruit-eating animals such as the cassowary and flying foxes (ARMCANZ 2000).

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not known to be harmful.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The fruit is known as a food source to native fauna. In Queensland feral pigs spread the seed (ARMCANZ 2000).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: May provide harbour to minor pest species such as birds (NRM 2001).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture (ARMCANZ 2000).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture (ARMCANZ 2000).

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture (ARMCANZ 2000).

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture (ARMCANZ 2000).

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known as a weed of agriculture (ARMCANZ 2000).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not known to be a host or vector of disease for agriculture (ARMCANZ 2000).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds have no inherent dormancy and germinate at any time of the year, but mostly in autumn shortly after seed fall”.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “While scattered populations occur in shade it is mostly found in open, sunny locations”.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments:
Invades undisturbed vegetation e.g. heathland and heathy woodland.

“Invasive on the margins of sub alpine lakes in Central Tasmania”.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
Erect biennial or perennial (rarely annual) herb.

Other.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Cutting, grazing or ineffective chemical control stimulates regeneration from the crow, thereby converting biennial plants to perennials”.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “When firmly established, ragwort dominates an area almost to the exclusion of all other plants…maintaining a vigorous pasture helps reduce, but not prevent, ragwort invasion”.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments:
Tolerant of frost (occurs in sub alpine areas of Tasmania).

Assumed tolerant of some drought (occurs in central Victoria, WA and California).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing from crowns, roots and by seed”.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: “It has been estimated that a well developed multi-stemmed ragwort plant produces about 250,000 seeds per year of which about 80% may be viable”.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “Can remain viable for at least 8 years and germinates when brought to the surface”.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Biennial or perennial (if aerial growth stimulated by cutting, grazing etc).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Only very rarely do plants flower in their first summer…some plants flower in the second summer but many more may be as much as 5 years old before developing flowering stems”.  (P & C 1992 p. 299).

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: Water, animals, vehicles, clothing, hay and chaff, wind.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments:
See ‘dispersal’ in P & C (1992 page 300 & 301).

Very descriptive.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Erect biennial or perennial herb commonly 45 to 60 cm high. Primarily associated with disturbed habitats in which it can form dense infestations. In such situations it may be a nuisance to people.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: During flowering, the plant’s presence would be obvious, as would dense patches. It may have a serious impact on the aesthetic of an area.  Minor impact – photos taken – soft leaf – no threat

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
“Ragwort pollen is believed to produce an allergic reaction in some people but this is not well documented.” 
“Probably poisonous to humans.” Toxic properties throughout the year. Impact may only occur sometimes of year

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a moderate visual impact.  Negligible

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: The plant has perennial roots, slightly fleshy to 15 cm long and many fibrous roots extending deeper into the soil. Not likely to contribute to soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Invader replaces biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “In autumn, the flower stems die back.” Little dry matter remains to establish or support fire. Negligible change to fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments: EVC=Valley grassy forest (V); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. “Dense infestations develop over disturbed ground, smother other ground-flora and impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major displacement of ground-flora.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: EVC=Grassy woodland (D); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. “Dense infestations develop over disturbed ground, smother other ground-flora and impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major displacement of ground-flora.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: EVC=Damp forest (LC); CMA=West Gippsland; Bioreg=Highlands – Southern Fall; VH CLIMATE potential. “Dense infestations develop over disturbed ground, smother other ground-flora and impeding overstorey regeneration.” “Scattered populations occur in shade.” Minor displacement of ground-flora or mid stratum spp.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Dense infestations develop over disturbed ground, smother other ground-flora and impeding overstorey regeneration.” Major effect on lower and mid strata.  1st year affects ground covers, grass  not much impact on overstorey impacts.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “When firmly established, ragwort dominates an area almost to the exclusion of all other plants.” “It is mostly found in open, sunny locations.” Reduction in habitat for fauna species. Minor primarily weed of agric land not of native habitat reduction

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “Ragwort is poisonous to grazing animals.” No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments:
“Ragwort is poisonous to grazing animals. The plant is more palatable but equally toxic when dry.”
Unknown

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pest species.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “When firmly established, ragwort dominates an area almost to the exclusion of all other plants and, because it has low grazing value, the production from such areas is considerably reduced.” Serious impact on yield. Not viable to have stock – 50% reduction but not reduce yield – Ragwort strategy

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Whilst ragwort does not generally occur as a crop weed in Australia, it is occasionally found in lucerne in Tasmania. It is also troublesome in lucerne in New Zealand and North America.” Potential contaminant. Produce may not be fit for animal consumption; unable to sell crop. “It is reported from New Zealand and North America that ragwort imparts a taint to honey making it unfit for sale.”  Too many assumptions

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The plant’s potential impact on yield may reduce the value of grazing land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: “Some of the land on which it occurs is marginal for agriculture – it is steep, has a short growing period and is prone to competition from pests such as rabbits, blackberry and bracken.” One recommended method of control is afforestation with Pinus radiata. This would lead to a significant change in land use with potential agricultural loss.  As dairy area – much more effective to clean ragwort and run dairy cattle

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Not known to increase harvest costs.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seedlings emerge after autumn rains or at other times following soil disturbance if moisture is adequate.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: Can establish under moderate canopy as occurs in ‘woods’.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: Establishes in minor disturbed natural ecosystems, e.g. riparian vegetation wetlands.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments:
An erect biennial herb.

“Other”.

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Spines on leaves and stems discourage grazing by livestock.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Competes with pasture plants.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: Tolerant of water logging, salinity (occurs in saline and subsaline wetlands), frost (occurs in UK), drought (occurs in Africa, California).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Reproducing by seed.

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments:
About 800 seeds are produced in each head.

At least 4 heads per plant therefore 800 x 4 = 3,200 seeds per plant.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Seeds remain viable for at least 6 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Form monocultures see picture P & C (1992) p. 414

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Flowering stems are not produced until the 2nd or even later years.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Contaminants on agricultural produce machinery, vehicles, animals, etc.”.  also water, wind and in hay silage, wool and industrial refuse.

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: Most seeds fall in the vicinity of the parent plant.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments:
“An erect biennial herb to 2 m high.” 

It is widespread in medium to large populations in riparian vegetation and saline and subsaline wetland. 

Dense patches may make access to waterways difficult.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments:
“An erect biennial herb to 2 m high.” 

It is widespread in medium to large populations in riparian vegetation and saline and subsaline wetland.

Its presence in dense patches may affect some recreational activities.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments:
The stems are armed with slightly downward curved prickles, and stem leaves are toothed with prickles on lower side of midvein.

In dense patches, the prickles may cause some discomfort to humans. Prickles present all year.

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: Dense patches would create a negative visual effect.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: A terrestrial species, it does occur on streambanks. However, it is not known to affect water flow.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: A biennial with a fleshy taproot to 75 cm; large rosettes that remain until the following year. Dense patches not likely to affect soil erosion.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: It is widespread in medium to large populations in riparian vegetation and saline and subsaline wetland. Biomass may increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: “…dead stems remain standing for many months, even years.” Dense patches may increase the frequency of fire risk.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC=Creekline grassy woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Victorian Volcanic Plain; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Is widespread, occurring in medium to large populations. A biennial to 2 metres, the deep roots and large rosettes allow the weed to compete with other plants. Infestations may affect species in both lower and mid strata.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC=Sedgy riparian woodland (E); CMA=Glenelg Hopkins; Bioreg=Central Victorian Uplands; VH CLIMATE potential. 
Impact as in 10(a) above.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Does not appear likely to occur in any low value EVC in Victoria.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “The deep roots and large rosettes compete with pasture plants for moisture and nutrients as well as for light.” In Victoria, it is widespread in medium to large populations. Dense patches are likely to have a major effect on lower stratum.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “The deep roots and large rosettes compete with pasture plants for moisture and nutrients as well as for light, while the spines on leaves and stems discourage grazing by livestock.” Competition with other plants and prickly property of plant may reduce available fodder for fauna species.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: No known benefits.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: Not documented to cause injury. The prickly nature of the plant may cause some discomfort.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Not known as a food source to pests.

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Not known to provide harbor.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “The deep roots and large rosettes compete with pasture plants for moisture and nutrients as well as for light, while the spines on leaves and stems discourage grazing by livestock.” Effect on yield not documented, however, “It sometimes invades pastures, particularly on fertile damp soils, and this is the reason for its proclamation in Victoria.” Consider possibly minor impact (< 5%).

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Not known as a weed of cropping or to affect the quality of agricultural produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Limited infestations in Victorian agricultural situations. Ploughing is an effective method of controlling the plant. Not likely to affect land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: With minimal impact on agricultural activity, change in land use not required.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: No data available.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: None evident.

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Seeds germinate in Spring” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 2001)

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: 6 hours of light or less cause seeds to germinate (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). “A large amount of stubble can…[shade] arrowhead seeds, slowing germination” (RIRDC, 2000). Require light to germinate (Flower et al, 1999). Less than 10% of seed germinated without light, compared to up to 50-65% with light (Flower et al, 1998). Can establish under moderate cover.

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Usually found in warm-temperate shallowly flooded or marshy areas associated with rivers and streams…drainage ditches, rice fields and permanent swamps associated with irrigation drainage systems.” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). All evidence points towards highly disturbed aquatic environments, such as irrigation channels and rice fields.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: “Emergent, broad-leafed aquatic plant” (Flower et al, 1999)

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: Spoonbills and carp have been observed feeding on the plant. Either or both of these animals may have been the cause of the plants disappearance on river flats along the River Murray but this is not certain (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). The weed may still persist.

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: Rice has been observed outgrowing S. montevidensis in California (Gibson et al, 2001) however Australian rice yields can be reduced by up to 75% (Flower et al, 1999). The ability of rice to out compete arrowhead depends on when it is sown after flooding (Flower et al, 2002). Equal competitiveness of same life forms.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: One study showed that draining rice bays for up to two weeks killed very young arrowhead seedlings, but didn’t kill more mature seed-grown plants (Flower et al, 1999). Survive in temporary dry ditches (Sagliocco & Bruzzese, 2005). Killed by frost and most plants killed by drought (Kaul, 1985 Angelo & Boufford (2005) record it growing in tidal mud flats of estuaries and salt marshes.  The rosette form may be able to tolerate submersion for years (MGW, nd). As a low growing aquatic species (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) will not be affected by fire. Tolerance of fire, waterlogging and salinity, but not frost or drought (severe enough to dry out damp areas).

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: “Reproducing by seed and rhizomes” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992)

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: Can produce many thousands of seeds per plant (MGW, nd). 414,000 achenes per plant per year (Kaul, 1985).

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: “The viability of …seeds does not reduce significantly after three years in the soil, suggesting that they remain viable for many years after being deposited” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). Kaul (1985) found that scarified seed viability reduced to 50% after 7 years.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Species forms dense monocultures, as seen in photograph (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Seeds germinate in spring and plants mature during summer, producing flowers from January to March. Seeds mature in autumn” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). Kaul (1985) describes S. calycina (syn. for subspecies ) as a fruit-bearing annual. “Two subspecies recorded in Australia, one perennial (ssp. Montevidensis and one annual ssp. calycina)” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft).  Produces propagules in under a year.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “Under Australian field conditions, spread of arrowhead is by seed. They move in water along channels and ditches and also in mud sticking to hooves and fur of animals…Some seeds are eaten by ducks and believed to be viable when excreted” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Under Australian field conditions, spread of arrowhead is by seed. They move in water along channels and ditches and also in mud sticking to hooves and fur of animals” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) “due to a slightly sticky surface” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft).  “The achenes produced by Altismataceous species have a pericarp that provides buoyancy…those of S. montevidensis float for a little under two weeks.” (Murray-Goulburn Water, draft). Very likely that some propagules will disperse greater than 1 km by sticking to animal fur, or transport by water.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: An emergent aquatic perennial herb. Inhabits shallowly flooded (to 45 cm) or marshy areas associated with rivers and streams. In south eastern Australia it is commonly found in drainage ditches and permanent swamps associated with irrigation and drainage systems (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Would not impede human access to waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Although most commonly found in drainage ditches and irrigation canals, it has also been found in a number of creeks in Victoria including Nine Mile Creek, Wunghnu and Bullock Creek near the junction of the Oven and Murray Rivers. In drain and irrigation channels it can form dense infestations that block the flow of water (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Its presence may affect water-based activities such as fishing or swimming.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: No prickles, spines or burrs described (Aston, 1973). Sagittaria species are eaten by ducks and sometimes humans, suggesting that they are not toxic either (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: An aquatic species (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Not likely to impact on sites of cultural significance.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: "Sagittaria forms extensive infestations in shallow waterways, seriously restricting water flow and increasing sedimentation, thus aggravating flooding." (BPRC, 2004). An emergent aquatic, firmly rooted. “Dense infestations block channels and drainage ditches” (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992). “Arrowhead can severely retard and completely choke water flow in irrigation channels” (Gunasekera & Krake, 2001).  Serious impacts to both surface and subsurface water flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: “Decaying plant material contributes to water pollution and sedimentation and may also increase the risk of algal bloom and microbial activity” (Sagliocco & Bruzesse, 2005). Likely to cause noticeable but minor effects on dissolved O2.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: In New Zealand it, "forms extensive infestations in shallow waterways, seriously restricting water flow and increasing sedimentation, thus aggravating flooding" (BPRC, 2004). Increased chance of flooding would create the potential for large-scale soil movement with minor off-site implications.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Where it occurs in drainage channels and irrigation canals (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992) little other vegetation would normally exist. Infestations of arrowhead would increase biomass.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Aquatic species (Flower et al, 1999). Fire not applicable in this ecosystem.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
Basin=East Gippsland- Cann River (ISC=Excellent); CMA=East Gippsland; CLIMATE=VH. 
“S. calycina [syn. S. montevidensis ssp. calycina] is very abundant in suitable years, sometimes forming vast beds” (Kaul, 1985). Can displace native water plants which occupy the same habitat (ESC, 2005). Able to form monocultures displacing all species within a layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)i.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments: Aquatic species. All Victorian water bodies considered to comprise high value EVCs only (Weiss pers. coms.)ii.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments:
“S. calycina [syn. S. montevidensis ssp. calycina] is very abundant in suitable years, sometimes forming vast beds” (Kaul, 1985). Can displace native water plants which occupy the same habitat (ESC, 2005).
Able to form monocultures.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: “Has a negative impact on native species and on the integrity of natural waterways, such as the waterways of the Barmah-Millewa forest, where it has been recorded” (GMW). Large populations obstruct the movement of wildlife and fish (Sagliocco & Bruzzese, 2005). May reduce habitat and have a minor effect on native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Spoonbills have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). The plant may provide an alternate source of food.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: No prickles, spines or burrs described (Aston, 1973). Spoonbills and carp have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992). Not harmful to fauna.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: Carp (considered a serious aquatic pest) have been observed feeding on the plant (Parson & Cuthberston, 1992).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: Carp (considered a serious aquatic pest) have been observed feeding on the plant Parson & Cuthberston (1992) and dense infestations (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992) may also provide harbor for them.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Grain yields were not affected by Californian arrowhead densities up to 200 plants/m2 (Gibson et al, 2001). “Arrowhead reduced the yield of rice by up to 75% if completely unchecked” (Flower, Pratley & Slater, 1999). The ability of rice to out compete arrowhead depends on when it is sown after flooding (Flower et al, 2002). This species has the capacity to have a serious impact on rice yield.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: “Weed senesced well before rice maturity” (Gibson et al, 2001). Unlikely to impact on the quality of the produce.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Whilst this species can “severely retard and completely choke water flow in irrigation channels” (Gunasekera & Krake, 2001), it is the responsibility of the water service provider to control the weed (GMW) so is unlikely to have an impact on land value.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Land use may need to change from rice growing to another crop (see Q. 19), however, this is unlikely to cause a reduction in income.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: One study showed that draining rice bays for up to two weeks killed very young arrowhead seedlings, but didn’t kill more mature seed-grown plants (Flower et al, 1999). Controlling arrowhead this way may cause a minor increase to the costs of harvest.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Harbours several important plant viruses (Parsons & Cuthbertson, 1992).

inv_germination.question: Germination requirements?
inv_germination.comments: “Germination generally occurs in the wetter winter and spring periods, providing there is not too much rain” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Requires natural seasonal rainfall.

inv_establishment.question: Establishment requirements?
inv_establishment.comments: “Seedlings germinate readily in sunshine or in shade” (de Beer, 1988).

inv_disturbance.question: How much disturbance is required?
inv_disturbance.comments: “Forestry and conservation areas…amongst riparian vegetation along the banks of rivers…grows well in the subtropical eucalypt communities of southeastern Queensland” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Invades forest margins and gaps, plantations (Henderson, 2001). Tends to establish in natural ecosystems that experience some disturbance.

inv_life_form.question: Life form?
inv_life_form.comments: “Shrubby to clambering vine” Henderson, 2001

inv_allelopathic.question: Allelopathic properties?
inv_allelopathic.comments: Not noted in CRC Weed Management (2003), de Beer (1988) or Moran & Zimmerman (1991).

inv_herb_pressure.question: Tolerates herb pressure?
inv_herb_pressure.comments: “Heavily spined” (Moran & Zimmerman, 1991) in “closely spaced groups…make the infested area inaccessible” (de Beer, 1988) so this would prevent herbivory. Is subject to insect herbivory in South Africa through the introduction of biocontrol agents but these are South American species (Moran & Zimmerman, 1991).

inv_growth_rate.question: Normal growth rate?
inv_growth_rate.comments: “Grows quite vigorously in tropical and subtropical environments” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).  “Reasonably vigorous…It overshadows all other vegetation and even big trees could collapse under the mass of the tangled branches” (de Beer, 1988). Growth rate has been observed to exceed most other species in the communities that it invades.

inv_stress_tolerance.question: Stress tolerance to frost, drought, w/logg, sal. etc?
inv_stress_tolerance.comments: “Drought tolerant…dislikes too much water.” Burning has been used to control this weed, but presumably it is not flammable because fresh material was burnt in oil drums (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Frost tolerant to –3�C (Faucon, 2005). Found in “dunes near the sea” (Leuenberger, 1986). Tolerant of at least 2 (drought, frost, salinity & fire) and susceptible to waterlogging.

inv_repro_system.question: Reproductive system
inv_repro_system.comments: Seeds and stem pieces (de Beer, 1988).

inv_propagules_count.question: Number of propagules produced?
inv_propagules_count.comments: A picture of approximately 1 m2 of this plant shows about 400 flowers (Faucon, 2005). This plant can reach 12 m and each fruit has a single seed (CRC Weed Management, 2003), so 12 x 400 = 4,800.

inv_propagule_longevity.question: Propagule longevity?
inv_propagule_longevity.comments: Reference to seed longevity was not found.

inv_repro_period.question: Reproductive period?
inv_repro_period.comments: Photographs of Pereskia from the Agricultural Research Council in South Africa (pers. comm.) show this plant forming dense monocultures.

inv_maturity_time.question: Time to reproductive maturity?
inv_maturity_time.comments: “Local experience is that is needs to grow to 6 metres long before it will flower” (Perrin, 2003). Being “reasonably vigorous” (de Beer, 1988), you would expect the plant to reach this height in 2-5 years.

inv_mechanisms_count.question: Number of mechanisms?
inv_mechanisms_count.comments: “The fruit are eaten by birds…that spread the seeds to other areas” de Beer (1988). Pieces of the plant may be washed downstream a considerable distance” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

inv_dispersal_distance.question: How far do they disperse?
inv_dispersal_distance.comments: “Pieces of the plant may be washed downstream a considerable distance…Birds can move propagules…a long way from gardens” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). It is very likely that some propagules will disperse more than 1 km.

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: “The plant has a tendency to form large impenetrable clumps and its extreme thorniness makes control of large infestations difficult…Growing amongst riparian vegetation along the banks of rivers in Queensland and New South Wales” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). “Runners…also spread along the ground to make the whole area inaccessible” (de Beer, 1988).

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments: Large, thorny, impenetrable thickets that are difficult to control and situated along riverbanks (see Q. 1) are likely to have a major impact on recreation in and around those rivers.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: The main shoots vigorously bear curved spines 4-8 mm long and 2-5 mm thick and straight spines 10-35 mm long and 0.5-1.5 mm thick and trichomes 1-2 mm long (Leuenberger, 1982).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments: As a large, thorny climbing shrub that clambers over trees (Moran & Zimmermann, 1991) this plant has the capacity to detract visually from cultural sites.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: Terrestrial species that “dislikes too much water” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: Terrestrial species that “dislikes too much water” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments: This plant can smother vegetation (de beer, 1988) that might otherwise bind soil. In cool or drought conditions this plant loses its leaves (Leuenberger, 1986) and where it has killed the vegetation it has smothered, it will leave the soil bare and prone to erosion. It can form major infestations along riverbanks (pers. comm. photo from the Agricultural Research Council (ARC) in South Africa) making the likelihood of flooding, and large scale soil movement with major offsite effects highly likely.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: “Clambers over…trees…and may eventually kill them (Moran & Zimmermann, 1991).

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Burning is used to control this weed in South Africa (CRC Weed Management, 2003) however this appears to have been by dropping plant pieces into oil drums. This indicates that it is not very flammable.  In subtropical eucalypt communities it has the potential to reduce the incidence and intensity of fires.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Foothill Box Ironbark Forest (V); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg= East Gippsland Upland; CLIMATE potential=H.
 “Listed as a noxious weed in conservation areas in South Africa due to its formation of dense infestations” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). “It overshadows all other vegetation and even big trees could collapse under the mass of the tangled branches” (de Beer, 1988). Monoculture within the canopy layer.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (D); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg= East Gippsland Lowland; CLIMATE potential=H.
“Listed as a noxious weed in conservation areas in South Africa due to its formation of dense infestations” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). “It overshadows all other vegetation and even big trees could collapse under the mass of the tangled branches” (de Beer, 1988). Monoculture within the canopy layer.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Lowland Forest (Lc); CMA=East Gippsland; Bioreg= East Gippsland Lowland; CLIMATE potential=H 
“Listed as a noxious weed in conservation areas in South Africa due to its formation of dense infestations” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). “It overshadows all other vegetation and even big trees could collapse under the mass of the tangled branches” (de Beer, 1988). Monoculture within the canopy layer.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: “Listed as a noxious weed in conservation areas in South Africa due to its formation of dense infestations” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). “It overshadows all other vegetation and even big trees could collapse under the mass of the tangled branches” (de Beer, 1988). This vine has the capacity to form monocultures affecting all layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: No information found.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Dense infestations that smother native trees (CRC Weed Management, 2003) could reduce habitat and food for native fauna.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: “It bears …edible fruits 25-45 mm in diameter, which are popular with birds” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). Its thorny branches may also protect small birds from predation.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: “Heavily spined” (Moran & Zimmermann, 1991).

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: May provide habitat and a food source for pest bird species (see Q. 15).

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: “Listed as a noxious weed in forestry in South Africa due to its formation of dense infestations” (CRC Weed Management, 2003). It “clambers over…commercially planted forest trees…and may eventually kill them” (Moran & Zimmermann, 1991). Given how difficult this plant is to control (CRC Weed Management, 2003), this could have a major impact on quantity of produce.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: This plant is not noted as a weed of other agricultural systems in CRC Weed Management, (2003) and is not likely to impact on the quality of forestry products.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: The labour-intensive nature of controlling this species, due to dense infestations that are thorny and that can regrow from stumps, leaf and stem fragments (CRC Weed Management, 2003), would probably reduce the value of badly infested land. Photographs from ARC in South Africa (pers. comm.) show extensive infestations that have entirely smothered acres of land.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Commercial forests may no longer be viable in the presence of this weed (see Q. 19).

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: The South African experience has shown that infestations are difficult to remove, involve meticulous human labour, and require “a great deal of follow-up treatment” (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: Not noted as a host for agricultural diseases (CRC Weed Management, 2003).

social_access.question: 1. Restrict human access?
social_access.comments: Sycamore maple is a tree species reported to occur in riparian habitats, which can form dense infestations (Weber 2003). Therefore it could form a major impediment in accessing waterways.

social_tourism.question: 2. Reduce tourism?
social_tourism.comments:
Unknown; the species is cultivated as an ornamental tree and can form dense infestations (Weber 2003).
Therefore having the potential to affect aesthetics or restrict some activities; however there is no evidence of the species impacting upon recreation and tourism.

social_injurious.question: 3. Injurious to people?
social_injurious.comments: People have been reported to have allergic reactions to the species’ pollen (Shah & Lin 2004).

social_cultural.question: 4. Damage to cultural sites?
social_cultural.comments:
Unknown; the species is cultivated as an ornamental tree and has an extensive root system (Muyt 2001).
Therefore having the potential to affect aesthetics or damage infrastructure with its roots; there is no evidence however of this occurring.

env_flow.question: 5. Impact flow?
env_flow.comments: The species is reported to invade riparian habitats (Muyt 2001). There is no evidence however of the species restricting flow.

env_water.question: 6. Impact water quality?
env_water.comments: The species is a deciduous tree that is reported to occur in riparian habitats (Muyt 2001). As a deciduous species alteration of seasonal light levels and changes to nutrient cycling could impact water quality, the impact this species has on water quality has not been reported however.

env_erosion.question: 7. Increase soil erosion?
env_erosion.comments:
A large tree reported to have an extensive root system (Muyt 2001).
Therefore there would be a low probability of the species being associated with large scale soil movement.

env_biomass.question: 8. Reduce biomass?
env_biomass.comments: Sycamore maple can be a large tree, growing to 35 m and forming dense infestations. It may displace certain species from the undergrowth by decreasing light levels and litter accumulation reducing diversity (Blood 2001; Weber 2003). It is not reported however to eliminate the undergrowth and therefore invasion by sycamore maple is likely to result in a direct replacement of biomass or possibly a net increase.

env_fire.question: 9. Change fire regime?
env_fire.comments: Reported to be extremely flammable during summer in Spain, but has a low Calorific power (N��ez-Regueira, A��n & Casti�eiras 1997). Unknown however how this will impact on the fire regime of Australian vegetation.

hab_high.question:
10. Impact on composition 
(a) high value EVC
hab_high.comments:
EVC= Swampy Riparian Woodland (E); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
A tree species which is reported to form dense infestations, altering light levels displacing the majority of species and impeding regeneration (Weber 2003). Being a deciduous species, its litter is reported to cause displacement of ground flora as it accumulates (Blood 2001). Therefore Sycamore maple is able to cause displacement within various layers.

hab_med.question: (b) medium value EVC
hab_med.comments:
EVC= Sedgy Riparian Woodland (D); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Plain; VH CLIMATE potential.
A tree species which is reported to form dense infestations, altering light levels displacing the majority of species and impeding regeneration (Weber 2003). Being a deciduous species, its litter is reported to cause displacement of ground flora as it accumulates (Blood 2001). Therefore Sycamore maple is able to cause displacement within various layers.

hab_low.question: (c) low value EVC
hab_low.comments:
EVC= Riparian Forest (LC); CMA= Corangamite; Bioreg= Otway Ranges; VH CLIMATE potential.
A tree species which is reported to form dense infestations, altering light levels displacing the majority of species and impeding regeneration (Weber 2003). Being a deciduous species, its litter is reported to cause displacement of ground flora as it accumulates (Blood 2001). Therefore Sycamore maple is able to cause displacement within various layers.

hab_structure.question: 11. Impact on structure?
hab_structure.comments: A tree species which is reported to form dense infestations, altering light levels displacing the majority of species and impeding regeneration (Weber 2003). Being a deciduous species, its litter is reported to cause displacement of ground flora as it accumulates (Blood 2001). Therefore Sycamore maple is able to cause displacement within all layers.

hab_flora.question: 12. Effect on threatened flora?
hab_flora.comments: Unknown; there is no evidence of this reported.

fauna_threatened.question: 14. Effect on non-threatened fauna?
fauna_threatened.comments: Significant alteration of habitat in terms of flora composition could have a significant impact on food supply for fauna species. The degree to which this species would impact on Australian fauna has not been quantified however.

fauna_no_benefit.question: 15. Benefits fauna?
fauna_no_benefit.comments: Has nectar bearing flowers (Blood 2001). The species could therefore provide some assistance in terms of food for insects or birds.

fauna_injurious.question: 16. Injurious to fauna?
fauna_injurious.comments: There is no evidence of this reported.

pest_food.question: 17. Food source to pests?
pest_food.comments: The flowers are reported to be attractive to bees (Blood 2001).

pest_harbor.question: 18. Provides harbor?
pest_harbor.comments: A tree species of up to 35 m which is reported to form dense infestations (Blood 2001; Weber 2003). It could therefore be capable of providing shelter to pest fauna; no specific species have been reported however.

ag_yield.question: 19. Impact yield?
ag_yield.comments: Reported to naturalise in regenerating forest (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). It is not reported however to impact on forestry operations and in Europe is itself a plantation timber (Brunet 2007). Therefore it is not reported as a pest of agriculture.

ag_quality.question: 20. Impact quality?
ag_quality.comments: Reported to naturalise in regenerating forest (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). It is not reported however to impact on forestry operations and in Europe is itself a plantation timber (Brunet 2007). Therefore it is not reported as a pest of agriculture.

ag_land_value.question: 21. Affect land value?
ag_land_value.comments: Reported to naturalise in regenerating forest (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). It is not reported however to impact on forestry operations and in Europe is itself a plantation timber (Brunet 2007). Therefore it is not reported as a pest of agriculture.

ag_land_use.question: 22. Change land use?
ag_land_use.comments: Reported to naturalise in regenerating forest (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). It is not reported however to impact on forestry operations and in Europe is itself a plantation timber (Brunet 2007). Therefore it is not reported as a pest of agriculture.

ag_harvest_costs.question: 23. Increase harvest costs?
ag_harvest_costs.comments: Reported to naturalise in regenerating forest (Webb, Sykes & Garnock-Jones 1988). It is not re ported however to impact on forestry operations and in Europe is itself a plantation timber (Brunet 2007). Therefore it is not reported as a pest of agriculture.

ag_disease.question: 24. Disease host/vector?
ag_disease.comments: There is no evidence of this.
